entry.def: Either one of two handles on the back of a piece of ordnance.
See Manioc.

entry.ety: OD. manneken, dim. of man man. See Man, and -kin

sn.def: A little man; a dwarf; a pygmy; a manakin.
A model of the human body, made of papier-mache or other material, commonly in detachable pieces, for exhibiting the different parts and organs, their relative position, etc.
A mannequin.

cs.cd: a cheroot or cigar made of tobacco grown in the Philippine Islands.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Manila or Manilla, the capital of the Philippine Islands; made in, or exported from, that city.
Manila paper or the color of manila papaer.

entry.def: The name of a naval battle in the Spanish-American War (1898), in which the American fleet under Admiral Dewey defeated the Spanish fleet off the shore of Manila in the Phillipines.
A tuberous-rooted twining annual vine (Psophocarpus tetragonolobus) bearing clusters of purplish flowers and pods with four jagged wings; Old World tropics.
entry.syn: winged bean, winged pea, goa bean, goa bean vine, Psophocarpus tetragonolobus.

entry.def: A lawn grass (Zoysia matrella) common in the Philippines; grown also in US.

sn.def: A fibrous material obtained from the abaca plant (Musa textilis), a plant allied to the banana, growing in the Philippine and other East India islands; -- called also by the native name abaca. From it matting, canvas, ropes, and cables are made.
A Philippine plant (Musa textilis) having leafstalks that yield Manila hemp used for rope and paper etc.; called also the abaca.

entry.def: A hard fiber used in making coarse twine; from Philippine agave plants.

A durable brown or buff paper or thin cardboard with a smooth light brown finish, made of Manila hemp, and used as a wrapping paper, or as a cheap printing and writing paper. The name is also given to inferior papers, made of other fiber.
entry.syn: manila, manila paper, manilla, manilla paper.

entry.def: A common thorny tropical American tree (Pithecellobium dulce) having terminal racemes of yellow flowers followed by sickle-shaped or circinate edible pods and yielding good timber and a yellow dye and mucilaginous gum.
entry.syn: camachile, huamachil, wild tamarind, Pithecellobium dulce.

entry.def: See Manilla, 1.
See manila manila hemp manila paper.
A genus of large evergreen trees with milky latex; pantropical.

entry.ety: Sp. manilla; cf. It. maniglio maniglia; F. manille; Pg. manilha; all fr. L. manus hand, and formed after the analogy of L. monile, pl. monilia, necklace: cf. F. manille

sn.def: A ring worn upon the arm or leg as an ornament, especially among the tribes of Africa.
A piece of copper of the shape of a horseshoe, used as money by certain tribes of the west coast of Africa.

entry.def: Same as Manila.
See 1st Manilla, 1.
An average person; as, the views of the man in the street .
The tropical plants (Manihot utilissima, and Manihot Aipi), from which cassava and tapioca are prepared; also, cassava.

entry.ety: L. manipulus maniplus, a handful, a certain number of soldiers; manus hand + root of plere to fill, plenus full: cf. F. maniple. See Manual, and Full a.

sn.def: A handful.
A division of the Roman army numbering sixty men exclusive of officers; any small body of soldiers; a company.

Originally, a napkin; later, an ornamental band or scarf worn upon the left arm as a part of the vestments of a priest in the Roman Catholic Church. It is sometimes worn in the English Church service.
Of or pertaining to the maniple, or company.
Manipulatory; as, manipular operations.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Manipulated; p. pr. & vb. n. Manipulating
entry.ety: LL. manipulatus, p. p. of manipulare to lead by the hand, fr. L. manipulus. See Maniple

sn.def: To treat, work, or operate with the hands, especially when knowledge and dexterity are required; to manage in hand work; to handle; as, to manipulate scientific apparatus.

To control the action of, by management; as, to manipulate a convention of delegates; also, to manage artfully or fraudulently; as, to manipulate accounts, or election returns; to manipulate the stock market.

entry.def: To use the hands in dexterous operations; to do hand work;
to manage the apparatus or instruments used in scientific work, or in artistic or mechanical processes; also, specifically, to use the hand in mesmeric operations.

sn.def: The act or process of manipulating, or the state of being manipulated; the act of handling work by hand; use of the hands, in an artistic or skillful manner, in science or art.
sn.q: Manipulation is to the chemist like the external senses to the mind.

sn.def: The use of the hands in mesmeric operations.
Artful management; as, the manipulation of political bodies; sometimes, a management or treatment for purposes of deception or fraud.
Of or pertaining to manipulation; performed by manipulation.
Prone to attempt to influence others by devious or subtle psychological means, in order to induce them to do what one wants.

entry.def: Any object given to children to encourage them to learn by manipulating physical objects; applied especially to solid objects of varying geometrical shape that can be fit together to form larger aggregates.
One who manipulates, sometimes in an underhanded or fraudulent manner; as, a stock market manipulator .
Of or pertaining to manipulation.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. manes the ghosts or shades of the dead. So called from its dismal appearance, and because it seeks for its food by night
entry.def: A genus of edentates, covered with large, hard, triangular scales, with sharp edges that overlap each other like tiles on a roof. They inhabit the warmest parts of Asia and Africa, and feed on ants. Called also Scaly anteater. See Pangolin.
A name given by tribes of American Indians to a great spirit, whether good or evil, or to any object of worship.
entry.q: Gitche Manito the mighty, The Great Spirit, the creator, Smiled upon his helpless children!
Mitche Manito the mighty, He the dreadful Spirit of Evil, As a serpent was depicted.

entry.def: The anterior segment of the thorax in insects. See Insect.
A single individual person; as, every man jack of them.

entry.ety: AS. mancynn. See Kin kindred, Kind n.

sn.def: The human race; man, taken collectively.
sn.q: The proper study of mankind is man.

sn.def: Men, as distinguished from women; the male portion of human race.
Human feelings; humanity.

entry.def: Manlike; not womanly; masculine; bold; cruel.
entry.q: Are women grown so mankind? Must they be wooing?
Be not too mankind against your wife.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the language or people of the Isle of Man.

def2.def: The language spoken in the Isle of Man. See Manx.

sn.def: Destitute of men.
Unmanly; inhuman.

entry.def: Inhumanly.
Like man, or like a man, in form or nature; having the qualities of a man, esp. the nobler qualities; manly.
entry.q: Gentle,manlikespeech.
A rightmanlikeman.
In glaring Chloe's manlike taste and mien.

entry.def: The quality or state of being manly.
A little man.
Having qualities becoming to a man; not childish or womanish; manlike, esp. brave, courageous, resolute, noble.
entry.q: Let's briefly put on manly readiness.
Serene and manly, hardened to sustain The load of life.
entry.syn: Bold; daring; brave; courageous; firm; undaunted; hardy; dignified; stately.

entry.def: In a manly manner; with the courage and fortitude of a manly man; as, to act manly .

Not of natural origin; prepared or made by humans; artificial; of substances, made by chemical reaction rather than extracted from a natural source; as, man-made fibers; man-made gems. Opposed to natural.
A fiber created from natural materials or by chemical processes.

entry.note: ☞ Persian manna is the secretion of the camel's thorn (see Camel's thorn, under Camel); Tamarisk manna, that of the Tamarisk mannifera, a shrub of Western Asia; Australian, manna, that of certain species of eucalyptus; Briançon manna, that of the European larch.

cs.cd: a scale insect (Gossyparia mannipara), which causes the exudation of manna from the Tamarix tree in Arabia.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. ma`nna, Heb. mān; cf. Ar. mann, properly, gift (of heaven)

sn.def: The food supplied to the Israelites in their journey through the wilderness of Arabia; hence, divinely supplied food.
A name given to lichens of the genus Lecanora, sometimes blown into heaps in the deserts of Arabia and Africa, and gathered and used as food; called also manna lichen.

A sweetish exudation in the form of pale yellow friable flakes, coming from several trees and shrubs and used in medicine as a gentle laxative, as the secretion of Fraxinus Ornus, and Fraxinus rotundifolia, the manna ashes of Southern Europe.

entry.def: A South Mediterranean ash (Fraxinus ornus) having fragrant white flowers in dense panicles and yielding manna.

entries.entry:
Man"na croup` măn"nȧ kr�p`. Manna + Russ. & Pol. krupa groats, grits
The portions of hard wheat kernels not ground into flour by the millstones: a kind of semolina prepared in Russia and used for puddings, soups, etc. -- called also manna groats.
The husked grains of manna grass.

entry.def: Any of several tall slender grasses of the genus Glyceria. They have long loose panicles, have a sweet flavor or odor, and grow in moist places. Nerved manna grass is Glyceria nervata, and Floating manna grass is Glyceria fluitans.
A tall tree (Eucalyptus viminalis) yielding a false manna.
Any of several Old World semicrustaceous or shrubby lecanoras that roll up and are blown about over African and Arabian deserts and used as food by people and animals; same as manna2}.

sn.def: Having a crew; -- of vehicles; as, a manned earth satellite was considered a necessary research step; to minimize casualties, the military used cruise missiles rather than manned aircraft for the bombardment. Opposite of unmanned.
a woman who wears clothes to display fashions; a fashion model.
A three-dimensional model of a person, used to display clothes, especially in retail stores and in window displays; a dummy.
A model of a human form used by tailors to help make clothing of the proper shape.

entry.note: ☞ In old usage, of was often omitted after manner, when employed in this sense. “A manner Latin corrupt was her speech.”
entry.cs:
By any manner of means in any way possible; by any sort of means.
To be taken in the mannerorTo be taken with the manner . A corruption of to be taken in the mainor. See Mainor
To be taken in the very act. Obs See Mainor. To make one's manners to make a bow or courtesy; to offer salutation. Manners bit a portion left in a dish for the sake of good manners. Hallwell.
entry.ety: OE. manere, F. manière, from OF. manier, adj., manual, skillful, handy, fr. (assumed) LL. manarius, for L. manuarius belonging to the hand, fr. manus the hand. See Manual

sn.def: Mode of action; way of performing or effecting anything; method; style; form; fashion.
sn.q: The nations which thou hast removed, and placed in the cities of Samaria, know not the manner of the God of the land.
The temptations of prosperity insinuate themselves after a gentle, but very powerful, manner.

sn.def: Characteristic mode of acting, conducting, carrying one's self, or the like; bearing; habitual style.

sd.def: Customary method of acting; habit.
sd.q: Paul, as his manner was, went in unto them.
Air and manner are more expressive than words.

sd.def: Carriage; behavior; deportment; also, becoming behavior; well-bred carriage and address; as, mind your manners!.
sd.q: Good manners are made up of petty sacrifices.

sd.def: The style of writing or thought of an author; characteristic peculiarity of an artist.

sn.def: Certain degree or measure; as, it is in a manner done already.
sn.q: The bread is in a manner common.

sn.def: Sort; kind; style; -- in this application sometimes having the sense of a plural, sorts or kinds; as, all manners of people came to the rally.
sn.q: And they being afraid wondered, saying to one another, What manner of man is this! for he commandeth even the winds and the water, and they obey him.
Ye tithe mint, and rue, and all manner of herbs.
I bid thee say, What manner of man art thou?
sn.syn: Method; mode; custom; habit; fashion; air; look; mien; aspect; appearance. See Method.

entries.entry: ‖Män"ner*chor` n.; G. pl.-chöre # . G.; männer, pl. of mann man + chor chorus A German men's chorus or singing club.

sn.def: Having a certain way, esp. a polite way, of carrying and conducting one's self; as, a well-mannered child.
sn.q: Give her princely training, that she may beMannered as she is born.

sn.def: Affected with mannerism; marked by excess of some characteristic peculiarity.
sn.q: His style is in some degree mannered and confined.

sn.def: Adherence to a peculiar style or manner; a characteristic mode of action, bearing, behavior, or treatment of others.
Adherence to a peculiar style or manner carried to excess, especially in literature or art.
sn.q: Mannerism is pardonable,and is sometimes even agreeable, when the manner, though vicious, is natural . . . . But a mannerism which does not sit easy on the mannerist, which has been adopted on principle, and which can be sustained only by constant effort, is always offensive.

entry.def: One addicted to mannerism; a person who, in action, bearing, or treatment, carries characteristic peculiarities to excess. See citation under Mannerism.
The quality or state of being mannerly; civility; complaisance.
Showing good manners; civil; respectful; complaisant.
entry.q: What thou thinkest meet, and is most mannerly.

entry.def: With good manners.
A word that denotes a manner of doing something; a troponym; as, "march" is a manner name for "walk".
The characteristic style or manner that a person uses to express himself orally.

entries.entry: Mann"heim gold". From Mannheim in Germany, where much of it was made A kind of brass made in imitation of gold. It contains eighty per cent of copper and twenty of zinc.

entry.def: A white amorphous or crystalline substance, obtained by dehydration of mannite, and distinct from, but convertible into, mannitan.

sn.def: Resembling a human being in form or nature; human.
sn.q: But yet it was a figure Most like to mannish creature.

sn.def: Resembling, suitable to, or characteristic of, a man, manlike, masculine.
sn.q: A woman impudent and mannish grown.

sn.def: Fond of men; -- said of a woman.

entry.def: A white amorphous or crystalline substance obtained by the partial dehydration of mannite.
A salt of mannitic acid.

sn.def: Same as mannitol.
A sweet white efflorescence from dried fronds of kelp, especially from those of the Laminaria saccharina, or devil's apron.

cs.cd: a white amorphous substance, intermediate between saccharic acid and mannitol, and obtained by the partial oxidation of the latter.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, resembling, or derived from, mannitol.

sn.syn: D-mannitol; manna sugar; cordycepic acid; Diosmol; Mannicol; Mannidex; Osmiktrol; Osmosal.

entry.def: A variety of sugar obtained by the partial oxidation of mannite, and closely resembling levulose.
The muller, or crushing and grinding stone, used in grinding corn on a metate.
See Maneuver.
A person who prefers to act rather than contemplate and gets things accomplished quickly an efficiently.
A person engaged in commercial or industrial business (especially an owner or executive).
Same as man of action.

sn.def: A writer, especially one who writes for a living.
A learned person; a scholar.

entry.def: A wealthy person.
A scientist.

sn.def: A long-rooted morning glory (Ipomoea leptophylla) of Western U. S.
sn.syn: man of the earth, Ipomoea leptophylla.

sn.def: A tropical American prostrate or climbing herbaceous perennial (Ipomoea panurata or Ipomoea fastigiata) having an enormous starchy root; sometimes held to be source of the sweet potato.
sn.syn: wild potato vine, wild sweet potato vine, man of the earth, manroot, scammonyroot, Ipomoea panurata Ipomoea fastigiata.

entry.def: A worldly-wise person; a sophisticate.

entries.entry:
Man`-of-war"
Man-of-war hawk Zoöl the frigate bird. Man-of-war's man a sailor serving in a ship of war. Portuguese man-of-war Zoöl any species of the genus Physalia; it is a hydrozoan having both medusa and polyp stages present in a single colony. It floats on the surface of the sea by a buoyant bladderlike structure, from which dangle multiple long tentacles with stinging cells. Its can cause severe rashes when it comes in contact with humans swimming in the area. See Physalia.
n; pl.Men-of-war.
A government vessel employed for the purposes of war, esp. one of large size; a ship of war. wns=1 ship of the line.
The Portuguese man-of-war. , jellyfish.

entry.def: The frigate bird, a long-billed warm-water seabird with wide wingspan and forked tail; also applied to the skua gulls, and to the wandering albatross.

entry.ety: Gr. � thin, rare + -graph: cf. F. manographe
entry.def: An optical device for making an indicator diagram for high-speed engines. It consists of a light-tight box or camera having at one end a small convex mirror which reflects a beam of light on to the ground glass or photographic plate at the other end. The mirror is pivoted so that it can be moved in one direction by a small plunger operated by an elastic metal diaphragm which closes a tube connected with the engine cylinder. It is also moved at right angles to this direction by a reducing motion, called a reproducer, so as to copy accurately on a smaller scale the motion of the engine piston. The resultant of these two movements imparts to the reflected beam of light a motion similar to that of the pencil of the ordinary indicator, and this can be traced on the sheet of ground glass, or photographed.

entry.ety: Gr. � thin, rare + -meter: cf. F. manomètre
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the tension or elastic force of gases, steam, etc., constructed usually on the principle of allowing the gas to exert its elastic force in raising a column of mercury in an open tube, or in compressing a portion of air or other gas in a closed tube with mercury or other liquid intervening, or in bending a metallic or other spring so as to set in motion an index; a pressure gauge. See Pressure, and Illust. of Air pump.
Of or pertaining to the manometer; made by the manometer.

entry.note: ☞ In these days, a manor rather signifies the jurisdiction and royalty incorporeal, than the land or site, for a man may have a manor in gross, as the law terms it, that is, the right and interest of a court-baron, with the perquisites thereto belonging.

cs.cd: the house belonging to a manor; the house of the lord of the manor; a manse.

entry.ety: OE. maner, OF. maneir habitation, village, F. manoir manor, prop. the OF. inf. maneir to stay, remain, dwell, L. manere, and so called because it was the permanent residence of the lord and of his tenants. See Mansion, and cf. Remain

sn.def: The land belonging to a lord or nobleman, or so much land as a lord or great personage kept in his own hands, for the use and subsistence of his family.
sn.q: My manors, rents, revenues, l forego.

sn.def: A tract of land occupied by tenants who pay a free-farm rent to the proprietor, sometimes in kind, and sometimes by performing certain stipulated services.

entry.def: The large room of a manor or castle.
Of or pertaining to a manor.
entry.q: Manorialclaims.

entry.def: Same as Manometer.
The science of the determination of the density of vapors and gases.
A contrivance or maneuvering to catch game illegally.
A killer of men; a manslayer.
Homage or service rendered to a superior, as to a lord; vassalage.
One of the side ropes to the gangway of a ship.

entries.entry: Man"sard roof". So called from its inventor, François Mansard , or Mansart, a distinguished French architect, who died in 1666 Arch A hipped curb roof; that is, a roof having on all sides two slopes, the lower one being steeper than the upper one.

cs.cd: the manor house, or lord's court.

entry.ety: LL. mansa mansus mansum, a farm, fr. L. manere mansum, to stay, dwell. See Mansion Manor

sn.def: A dwelling house, generally with land attached.
The parsonage; a clergyman's house.

entry.def: A male servant.

cs.cd: the house in which one resides; specifically, in London and some other cities, the official residence of the Lord Mayor.

entry.ety: OF. mansion, F. maison, fr. L. mansio a staying, remaining, a dwelling, habitation, fr. manere mansum, to stay, dwell; akin to Gr. �. Cf. Manse Manor Menagerie Menial Permanent

sn.def: A dwelling place, -- whether a part or whole of a house or other shelter.
sn.q: In my Father's house are many mansions.
These poets near our princes sleep, And in one grave their mansions keep.

sn.def: The house of the lord of a manor; a manor house; hence: Any house of considerable size or pretension.
A twelfth part of the heavens; a house. See 1st House, 8.
The place in the heavens occupied each day by the moon in its monthly revolution.
sn.q: The eight and twenty mansions That longen to the moon.

entry.def: To dwell; to reside.
Resident; residentiary; as, mansionary canons.
A large and imposing house.
The state of dwelling or residing; occupancy as a dwelling place.

sn.def: Calling for manly attributes; as, a man-sized job.
Large enough to satisfy a man; as, a man-sized piece of cake.
The slaying of a human being; destruction of men.
The unlawful killing of a man, either in negligence or incidentally to the commission of some unlawful act, but without specific malice, or upon a sudden excitement of anger.

entry.def: One who kills a human being; one who commits manslaughter.
A person who steals or kidnaps a human being or beings.
The act or business of stealing or kidnaping human beings, especially with a view to e�slave them.

entry.ety: L. mansuetus, p. p. of mansuescere to tame; manus hand + suescere to accustom: cf. F. mansuet
entry.def: Tame; gentle; kind.
Tameness; gentleness; mildness.
To swear falsely. Same as Mainswear.
The manta ray. See also Cephaloptera and Sea devil.

An extremely large pelagic tropical ray of the family Mobulidae, that feeds on plankton and small fishes. It is usually harmless but its size (up to 20 feet across and up to a ton in weight) make it dangerous if harpooned. Called also manta sea devil and devilfish. See also Cephaloptera and Sea devil.
Same as Manchu.

entries.entry:
‖Man`teau" n.; pl. F. Manteaux #, E. Manteaus #. F. See Mantle n.
A woman's cloak or mantle.
A gown worn by women. Obs

entry.def: A natural family of insects including the mantises. Also spelled Mantidae .

entry.ety: The same word as mantle a garment; cf. F. manteau de cheminée. See Mantle
entry.def: The finish around a fireplace, covering the chimney-breast in front and sometimes on both sides; especially, a shelf above the fireplace, and its supports. The shelf is called also a mantelpiece or mantlepiece.

entry.ety: F., dim. of manteau, OF. mantel. See Mantle

sd.def: A short cloak formerly worn by knights.
A short cloak or mantle worn by women.
sd.q: A mantelet upon his shoulders hanging.

sn.def: A musket-proof shield of rope, wood, or metal, which is sometimes used for the protection of sappers or riflemen while attacking a fortress, or of gunners at embrasures; -- now commonly written mantlet.

entry.def: A silk or woolen vestment without sleeves worn by cardinals, bishops, abbots, and the prelates of the Roman court. It has a low collar, is fastened in front, and reaches almost to the knees.
Same as Mantel.
The shelf of a mantel.
The lintel of a fireplace when of wood, as frequently in early houses.
Of or pertaining to divination, or to the condition of one inspired, or supposed to be inspired, by a deity; prophetic.
entry.q: Manticfury.

entry.def: A mythical monster having the head of man (with horns) and the body of a lion and the tail of a scorpion.
A mantis.
The natural family conmprising the mantises. Same as Manteidae.
The manticore.

sn.def: A lady's light cloak of cape of silk, velvet, lace, or the like.
A kind of veil, covering the head and falling down upon the shoulders; -- worn in Spain, Mexico, etc.

entry.def: The site of three famous battles among Greek city-states: in 418 BC and 362 BC and 207 BC.

entry.cs: Mantis shrimp. Zoöl The Squilla, a tropical marine burrowing crustacean with large grasping appendages. Also called mantis crab and mantis prawn.
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of voracious orthopterous insects of the genus Mantis, and allied genera. They are predacious long-bodied large-eyed insects of warm regions, are remarkable for their slender grotesque forms, and for holding their stout anterior legs in a manner suggesting hands folded in prayer. The common American species is Mantis Carolina.
Same as Squilla.
Same as Squilla.
Any neuropterous insect of the genus Mantispa, and allied genera. The larvæ feed on plant lice. Also used adjectively. See Illust. under Neuroptera.
The natural family comprising the mantispids.

entry.ety: L., an addition, makeweight; of Tuscan origin
entry.def: The decimal part of a logarithm, as distinguished from the integral part, or characteristic.

entry.ety: OE. mantel, OF. mantel, F. manteau, fr. L. mantellum mantelum, a cloth, napkin, cloak, mantle (cf. mantele mantile, towel, napkin); prob. from manus hand + the root of tela cloth. See Manual Textile, and cf. Mandil Mantel Mantilla
entry.sn: A loose garment to be worn over other garments; an enveloping robe; a cloak. Hence, figuratively, a covering or concealing envelope. The] children are clothed with mantles of satin. The green mantle of the standing pool. Now Nature hangs her mantle green On every blooming tree.

sn.def: Same as Mantling.

sd.def: The external fold, or folds, of the soft, exterior membrane of the body of a mollusk. It usually forms a cavity inclosing the gills. See Illusts. of Buccinum, and Byssus.
Any free, outer membrane.
The back of a bird together with the folded wings.

sn.def: A mantel. See Mantel.
The outer wall and casing of a blast furnace, above the hearth.
A penstock for a water wheel.
The highly viscous shell of hot semisolid rock, about 1800 miles thick, lying under the crust of the Earth and above the core. Also, by analogy, a similar shell on any other planet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mantled; p. pr. & vb. n. Mantling
entry.def: To cover or envelop, as with a mantle; to cloak; to hide; to disguise.

sn.def: To unfold and spread out the wings, like a mantle; -- said of hawks. Also used figuratively.
sn.q: Ne is there hawk which mantleth on her perch.
Or tend his sparhawk mantling in her mew.
My frail fancy fed with full delight. Doth bathe in bliss, and mantleth most at ease.

sn.def: To spread out; -- said of wings.
sn.q: The swan, with arched neck Between her white wings mantling proudly, rows.

sn.def: To spread over the surface as a covering; to overspread; as, the scum mantled on the pool.
sn.q: Though mantled in her cheek the blood.

sn.def: To gather, assume, or take on, a covering, as froth, scum, etc.
sn.q: There is a sort of men whose visages Do cream and mantle like a standing pond.
Nor bowl of wassail mantle warm.

entry.def: Covered with or as if with clothes or a wrap or cloak.
A common black-striped reddish-brown ground squirrel (Citellus lateralis) of western North America, resembling a large chipmunk.
A shelf that projects from the wall above a fireplace; a mantel; as, in England they call a mantelpiece a chimneypiece.
See Mantelet.
The representation of a mantle, or the drapery behind and around a coat of arms: -- called also lambrequin.

entry.ety: It. or Sp. manto, abbrev., from L. mantelum. See Mantle
entry.def: See Manteau.
One who is skilled in mantology; a diviner.
The act or art of divination.
A skin test for hypersensitivity to tuberculin. It determines whether there is or has been any infection with tubercle bacilli.

entry.note: ☞ Among the Hindoos each caste and tribe has a mantra peculiar to itself; as, the mantra of the Brahmans.
entry.def: A prayer; an invocation; a religious formula; a charm.

sn.def: A trap for catching trespassers.
A dangerous place, as an open hatch, into which one may fall.
A superior kind of rich silk formerly exported from Mantua in Italy.
A woman's cloak or mantle; also, a woman's gown.

entry.def: One who makes dresses, cloaks, etc., for women; a dressmaker.
Of or pertaining to Mantua.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Mantua.

entry.def: One of a series of progenitors of human beings, and authors of human wisdom.

entry.cs: Manual exercise Mil the exercise by which soldiers are taught the use of their muskets and other arms. Seal manual the impression of a seal worn on the hand as a ring. Sign manual. See under Sign.
entry.ety: OE. manuel, F. manuel, L. manualis, fr. manus hand; prob. akin to AS. mund hand, protection, OHG. munt, G. mündel a ward, vormund guardian, Icel. mund hand. Cf. Emancipate Legerdemain Maintain Manage Manner Manure Mound a hill

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the hand.
Performed by a person using physical as contrasted with mental effort; as, manual labor.
Done or made by the hand. In some contexts, contrasted with automatic or mechanical.
sn.q: Manualand ocular examination.

entry.ety: Cf. F. manuel, LL. manuale. See Manual a.

sn.def: A small book, such as may be carried in the hand, or conveniently handled; a handbook; specifically, the service book of the Roman Catholic Church.
sn.q: This manual of laws, styled the Confessor's Laws.

sn.def: A keyboard of an organ or harmonium for the fingers, as distinguished from the pedals; a clavier, or set of keys.
A prescribed exercise in the systematic handing of a weapon; as, the manual of arms; the manual of the sword; the manual of the piece (cannon, mortar, etc.).

entry.def: An alphabet of signs made by movement of the hands, used by the deaf; in it letters are represented by finger positions. See Dactylology.
Adroitness in using the hands.
One who works with the hands; an artificer.
Labor done with the hands.
A person who works with the hands, rather than with the mind.
By hand. In some contexts, contrasted with automatically.
Manual.

entry.ety: L. manubialis, fr. manubiae money obtained from the sale of booty, booty
entry.def: Belonging to spoils; taken in war.
Of or pertaining to a manubrium; shaped like a manubrium; handlelike.

entries.entry:
‖Ma*nu"bri*um n.; pl. L. Manubria #, E. Manubriums #. L., handle, fr. manus hand
Anat A handlelike process or part; esp., the anterior segment of the sternum, or presternum, and the handlelike process of the malleus.
Zoöl The proboscis of a jellyfish; -- called also hypostoma. See Illust. of Hydromedusa.

entry.ety: Javanese manukdewata the bird of the gods: cf. F. manucode
entry.def: Any bird of the genus Manucodia, of Australia and New Guinea. They are related to the bird of paradise.
One who leads by the hand; a manuductor.

entry.ety: L. manus hand + ductio a leading, ducere to lead: cf. F. manuduction
entry.def: Guidance by the hand.

entry.ety: L. manus the hand + ductor a leader, ducere to lead: cf. F. manuducteur
entry.def: A conductor; an officer in the ancient church who gave the signal for the choir to sing, and who beat time with the hand, and regulated the music.

entries.entry:
Man`u*fac"to*ry n.; pl.-ries #. Cf. L. factorium an oil press, properly, place where something is made. See Manufacture
Manufacture. Obs
A building or place where anything is manufactured; a factory.

entry.def: Pertaining to manufacturing.
Of or pertaining to manufactures.

entry.ety: L. manus the hand + factura a making, fr. facere to make: cf. F. manufacture. See Manual, and Fact

sn.def: The operation of making wares or any products by hand, by machinery, or by other agency.
Anything made from raw materials by the hand, by machinery, or by art, as cloths, iron utensils, shoes, machinery, saddlery, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Manufactured; p. pr. & vb. n. Manufacturing

sn.def: To make (wares or other products) by hand, by machinery, or by other agency; as, to manufacture cloth, nails, glass, etc.
To work, as raw or partly wrought materials, into suitable forms for use; as, to manufacture wool, cotton, silk, or iron.

entry.def: To be employed in manufacturing something.
Produced in a large-scale industrial operation. Contrasted with hand-made.
One who manufactures.

sn.def: Employed, or chiefly employed, in manufacture; as, a manufacturing community; a manufacturing town.
Pertaining to manufacture; as, manufacturing projects.

entry.def: A business engaged in manufacturing some product.
A factory.
A wild cat (Felis manul), having long, soft, light-colored fur. It is found in the mountains of Central Asia, and dwells among rocks.
To manumit.

entry.ety: L. manumissio: cf. F. manumission. See Manumit
entry.def: The act of manumitting, or of liberating a slave from bondage.
entry.q: Given to slaves at theirmanumission.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Manumitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Manumitting
entry.ety: L. manumittere manumissum; manus the hand + mittere to send, to send off. See Manual, and Missile
entry.def: To release from slavery; to liberate from personal bondage or servitude; to free, as a slave.
entry.q: Manumittedslaves.

entry.ety: L. manus the hand + E. motive
entry.def: Movable by hand.

entry.ety: L. manus the hand + E. motor
entry.def: A small wheel carriage, so constructed that a person sitting in it may move it.

sn.def: Capable of cultivation.
Capable of receiving a fertilizing substance.

entry.def: Cultivation.
Cultivation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Manured mȧ*nūrd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Manuring
entry.ety: Contr, from OF. manuvrer manovrer, to work with the hand, to cultivate by manual labor, F. manœuvrer. See Manual Ure Opera, and cf. Inure

sn.def: To cultivate by manual labor; to till; hence, to develop by culture.
sn.q: To whom we gave the strand for to manure.
Manure thyself then; to thyself be improved; And with vain, outward things be no more moved.

sn.def: To apply manure to; to enrich, as land, by the application of a fertilizing substance.
sn.q: The blood of English shall manure the ground.

entry.def: Any matter which makes land productive; a fertilizing substance.
dung, the contents of stables and barnyards, decaying animal or vegetable substances, etc.
Cultivation.
One who manures land.
Relating to manures.
The act of process of applying manure; also, the manure applied.

entries.entry: ‖Ma"nus n.; pl.Manus. L., the hand Anat The distal segment of the fore limb, including the carpus and fore foot or hand.

entry.ety: L. manu scriptus. See Manual, and Scribe
entry.def: Written with or by the hand; not printed; as, a manuscript volume.

entry.note: ☞ The word is often abbreviated to MS., plural MSS.
entry.ety: LL. manuscriptum, lit., something written with the hand. See Manuscript a.

sn.def: An original literary or musical composition written by the author, formerly with the hand, now usually by typewriter or word processor. It is contrasted with a printed copy.
Writing, as opposed to print; as, the book exists only in manuscript .

entry.def: Manuscript.

entry.ety: L. manus hand + tenere to hold
entry.def: Maintenance.
A small passageway, as in a mine, that a man may pass through.
Of or pertaining to the Isle of Man, or its inhabitants; as, the Manx language.
A breed of domestic cats having a rudimentary tail, containing only about three vertebrae. It is believed to have originated on the Isle of Man.

A small black-and-white oceanic bird (Puffinus puffinus, or Puffinus anglorum), common in the Eastern North Atlantic. Called also Manx petrel Manx puffin. It is avariety of shearwater. It was formerly abundant in the Isle of Man.
The language of the inhabitants of the Isle of Man, a dialect of the Celtic.
A retinue of servants; a household.

entry.note: It has no variation to express degrees of comparison; more and most, which are used for the comparative and superlative degrees, are from a different root

☞ Many is freely prefixed to participles, forming compounds which need no special explanation; as, many-angled, many-celled, many-eyed, many-footed, many-handed, many-leaved, many-lettered, many-named, many-peopled, many-petaled, many-seeded, many-syllabled (polysyllabic), many-tongued, many-voiced, many-wived, and the like. In such usage it is equivalent to multi. Comparison is often expressed by many with as or so. “As many as were willing hearted . . . brought bracelets.” Exod. xxxv. 22. “So many laws argue so many sins.” Milton. Many stands with a singular substantive with a or an.
entry.cs:
Many a a large number taken distributively; each one of many. “For thy sake have I shed many a tear.” Shak. “Full many a gem of purest ray serene.” Gray. Many one many a one; many persons. Bk. of Com. Prayer. The many the majority; -- opposed to the few. See Many n.
Too many too numerous; hence, too powerful; as, they are too many for us. L'Estrange.
entry.ety: OE. mani moni, AS. manig mænig monig; akin to D. menig, OS. & OHG. manag, G. manch, Dan. mange, Sw. månge, Goth. manags, OSlav. mnog', Russ. mnogii; cf. Icel. margr, Prov. E. mort. √103
entry.def: Consisting of a great number; numerous; not few.
entry.q: Thou shalt be a father of many nations.
Not many wise men after the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble, are called.
entry.syn: Numerous; multiplied; frequent; manifold; various; divers; sundry.

entry.note: ☞ In this sense, many is connected immediately with another substantive (without of) to show of what the many consists; as, a good manyof] people think so.
entry.ety: AS. menigeo menigo menio, multitude; akin to G. menge, OHG. managī menigī, Goth. managei. See Many a.

sn.def: The populace; the common people; the majority of people, or of a community.
sn.q: After him the rascal many ran.

sn.def: A large or considerable number.
sn.q: A many of our bodies shall no doubt Find native graves.
Seeing a great many in rich gowns.
It will be concluded by many that he lived like an honest man.
He is liable to a great many inconveniences.

entry.def: Having many faculties; versatile; many-sided.

entry.ety: Many, adj. + plies, pl. of ply a fold
entry.def: The third division, or that between the reticulum, or honeycomb stomach, and the abomasum, or rennet stomach, in the stomach of ruminants; the omasum; the psalterium. So called from the numerous folds in its mucous membrane. See Illust of Ruminant.

sn.def: Having many sides; -- said of figures. Hence, presenting many questions or subjects for consideration; as, a many-sided topic.
Interested in, and having an aptitude for, many unlike pursuits or objects of attention; versatile.

entry.def: In many different ways; variously.

sn.def: A kind of small roundish olive with a small freestone pit, a fine skin, and a peculiar bitterish flavor. Manzanillas are commonly pitted and stuffed with Spanish pimientos.
A very dry pale sherry from Spain.

entry.ety: Sp., dim. of manzana an apple
entry.def: A name given to several species of Arctostaphylos, but mostly to Arctostaphylos glauca and Arctostaphylos pungens, shrubs of California, Oregon, etc., with reddish smooth bark, ovate or oval coriaceous evergreen leaves, and bearing clusters of red berries, which are said to be a favorite food of the grizzly bear.
See Mao Tsetung.
A form of communism developed in China by Mao Zedong.
An advocate of Maoism.

entries.entry:
Ma"o*ri prop. n.; pl.Maoris. Ethnol One of the aboriginal inhabitants of New Zealand; also, the original language of New Zealand.
a. Of or pertaining to the Maoris or to their language.

entry.def: A flightless New Zealand rail of thievish disposition having short wings each with a spur used in fighting.
The leader of the Chinese communist party and later of teh People's Repbulic of China; b. 1893, d. 1976. Also referred to a simply Mao.

entry.note: ☞ There are five principal kinds of projection used in making maps: the orthographic, the stereographic, the globuar, the conical, and the cylindrical, or Mercator's projection. See Projection.

cs.cd: a lichen (Lecidea geographica.) growing on stones in curious maplike figures.

entry.ety: From F. mappe, in mappemonde map of the world, fr. L. mappa napkin, signal cloth; -- a Punic word. Cf. Apron Napkin Nappe

sn.def: A representation of the surface of the earth, or of some portion of it, showing the relative position of the parts represented; -- usually on a flat surface. Also, such a representation of the celestial sphere, or of some part of it.
Anything which represents graphically a succession of events, states, or acts; as, an historical map .
sn.q: Thus is his cheek the map of days outworn.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mapped; p. pr. & vb. n. Mapping
entry.def: To represent by a map; -- often with out; as, to survey and map, or map out, a county . Hence, figuratively: To represent or indicate systematically and clearly; to sketch; to plan; as, to map, or map out, a journey; to map out business.
entry.q: I am near to the place where they should meet, if Pisanio have mapped it truly.

entry.def: The raccoon.
A supposed human-sized slothlike creature reported sighted by Indians in the Amazon rain forest.

entry.note: ☞ Maple is much used adjectively, or as the first part of a compound; as, maple tree, maple leaf, etc.

cs.cd: varieties of the wood of the rock maple, in which a beautiful lustrous grain is produced by the sinuous course of the fibers.
cs.mcol: Maple honey Maple molasses Maple syruporMaple sirup
cs.cd: maple sap boiled to the consistency of molasses.
sugar obtained from the sap of the sugar maple by evaporation.

entry.ety: AS. mapolder mapulder mapol; akin to Icel. möpurr; cf. OHG. mazzaltra mazzoltra, G. massholder
entry.def: A tree of the genus Acer, including about fifty species. Acer saccharinum is the rock maple, or sugar maple, from the sap of which sugar is made, in the United States, in great quantities, by evaporation; the red maple or swamp maple is Acer rubrum; the silver maple Acer dasycarpum, having fruit wooly when young; the striped maple Acer Pennsylvanium, called also moosewood. The common maple of Europe is Acer campestre, the sycamore maple is Acer Pseudo-platanus, and the Norway maple is Acer platanoides.
A tuberous or semi-tuberous South African begonia (Begonia dregei) having shallowly lobed ovate leaves and small white flowers.
An Indian tree (Pterospermum acerifolium) having fragrant nocturnal white flowers and yielding a reddish wood used for planking; often grown as an ornamental or shade tree. Called also mayeng.
The natural family of trees Aceraceae, including the maples.
Having or consisting of lines resembling a map; as, the maplike figures in which certain lichens grow.
A person who makes maps; a cartographer.
the making of maps and charts; cartography.
The making, or study, of maps.
A function such that for every element of one set there is a unique element of another set.
A Chilian shrub (Aristotelia Maqui). Its bark furnishes strings for musical instruments, and a medicinal wine is made from its berries.

sn.def: A guerrilla fighter in the French underground in World War II.
The French underground that fought against the German occupation in World War II.

entry.def: A small lake. See Mere.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Marred märd; p. pr. & vb. n. Marring
entry.ety: OE. marren merren, AS. merran myrranin comp.), to obstruct, impede, dissipate; akin to OS. merrian, OHG. marrjan merran; cf. D. marren meeren, to moor a ship, Icel. merja to bruise, crush, and Goth. marzjan to offend. Cf. Moor v.

sn.def: To make defective; to do injury to, esp. by cutting off or defacing a part; to impair; to disfigure; to deface.
sn.q: I pray you mar no more trees with wiring love songs in their barks.
But mirth is marred, and the good cheer is lost.
Ire, envy, and despair Which marred all his borrowed visage.

sn.def: To spoil; to ruin.
sn.q: It makes us, or itmarsus.
Striving to mend, tomarthe subject.

entry.def: A mark or blemish made by bruising, scratching, or the like; a disfigurement.
The principal or ruling evil spirit.

entry.ety: Icel. mara nightmare, an ogress. See Nightmare
entry.def: A female demon who torments people in sleep by crouching on their chests or stomachs, or by causing terrifying visions.
The Patagonian cavy, a hare-like rodent (Dolichotis patagonum or Dolichotis Patagonicus) of the pampas of Argentina.

sn.def: A large black-and-white carrion-eating stork of the genus Leptoptilosformerly Ciconia), esp. the African species (Leptoptilus crumeniferus syn. Leptoptilos crumenifer), whose downy under-wing feathers are used to trim garments; called also marabout. The Asiatic species (Leptoptilos dubius, or Leptoptilos argala) is the adjutant. See Adjutant.
One having five eighths negro blood; the offspring of a mulatto and a griffe.

A kind of thrown raw silk, nearly white naturally, but capable of being dyed without scouring; also, a thin fabric made from it, as for scarfs, which resembles the feathers of the marabou in delicacy, -- whence the name.

entry.ety: F., from Pg. marabuto, Ar. morābit. Cf. Maravedi

sn.def: A Mohammedan saint; especially, one who claims to work cures supernaturally.
The marabou1}.

entry.def: A macaw.
A sacred inclosure or temple; -- so called by the islanders of the Pacific Ocean.

“Our Lord cometh;” -- an expression used by St. Paul at the conclusion of his first Epistle to the Corinthians (xvi. 22). This word has been used in anathematizing persons for great crimes; as much as to say, “May the Lord come quickly to take vengeance of thy crimes.” See Anathema maranatha, under Anathema.
A Philippine tree (Artocarpus odoratissima) similar to the breadfruit tree bearing edible fruit. Called also marang.

A genus of endogenous plants found in tropical America, and some species also in India. They have tuberous roots containing a large amount of starch, and from one species (Maranta arundinacea, the American arrowroot or obedience plant arrowroot arrowroot starch) is obtained. Many kinds are cultivated for ornament.
A natural family of tropical perennial herbs with usually starchy rhizomes, including the arrowroot; the arrowroot family.
The small bitter fruit of the marasca cherry tree from whose juice maraschino liqueur is made.

sn.def: The marasca cherry.
sn.syn: marasca cherry, maraschino cherry, Prunus cerasus marasca.

entry.def: A Dalmation bitter wild cherry tree (Prunus cerasus marasca) bearing fruit whose juice is made into maraschino liqueur.

entry.ety: It., fr. marasca amarasca, a sour cherry, L. amarus bitter
entry.def: A liqueur distilled from fermented cherry juice, and flavored with the pit of a variety of cherry which grows in Dalmatia.

sn.def: A cherry which is colored a deep red and sweetened by cooking in colored syrup, and flavored with maraschino. It is used as a garnish in deserts and cocktails.
The marasca cherry tree.

entry.def: A genus of chiefly small white-spored mushrooms, including the Marasmius oreades , the mushroon that grow in a fairy ring.

cs.cd: progressive atrophy of the aged.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � , fr. �, to quench, as fire; pass., to die away
entry.def: A wasting of flesh without fever or apparent disease; a kind of consumption; atrophy; phthisis.
entry.q: Pining atrophy,Marasmus, and wide-wasting pestilence.

entry.def: A Sanskritic language of western India, prob. descended from the Maharastri Prakrit, spoken by the Marathas and neighboring peoples. It has an abundant literature dating from the 13th century. It has a book alphabet nearly the same as Devanagari and a cursive script translation between the Devanagari and the Gujarati.

sn.def: A footrace of 26 miles 385 yards.
Any long and arduous undertaking, straining the endurance of the participants.
a battle in 490 BC in which the Athenians and their allies defeated the Persians.

entry.def: The type genus of the Marattiaceae, consisting of ferns having the sporangia fused together in two rows.
The natural family of ferns coextensive with the order Marattiales, consisting of chiefly tropical eusporantiate ferns with gigantic fronds.
An order of lower ferns coextensive with the family Marattiaceae.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Marauded; p. pr. & vb. n. Marauding
entry.ety: F. marauder, fr. maraud vagabond, OF. marault; of uncertain origin, perh. for malault, fr. (assumed) LL. malaldus; fr. L. malus bad, ill + a suffix of German origin (cf. Herald). Cf. Malice
entry.def: To rove in quest of plunder; to make an excursion for booty; to plunder.
entry.q: Maraudinghosts.

entry.def: An excursion for plundering.

entry.ety: From Maraud v.: cf. F. maraudeur
entry.def: A rover in quest of booty or plunder; a plunderer; one who pillages.

entry.ety: Sp. maravedí; -- so called from the Morābitīnlit., the steadfast), an Arabian dynasty which reigned in Africa and Spain. Cf. Marabout
entry.def: A small copper coin of Spain, equal to three mils American money, less than a farthing sterling. Also, an ancient Spanish gold coin.

sn.def: A wildflower (Mirabilis multiflora) having vibrant deep pink tubular evening-blooming flowers; found in sandy and desert areas from Southern California to Southern Colorado and into Mexico.
sn.syn: desert four o'clock, Colorado four o'clock, Mirabilis multiflora.

sn.def: A leafy wildflower (Mirabilis longiflora) having fragrant slender white or pale pink trumpet-shaped flowers; found in the Southwestern US and Northern Mexico.

entry.note: ☞ Breccia marble consists of limestone fragments cemented together.Ruin marble, when polished, shows forms resembling ruins, due to disseminated iron oxide.Shell marble contains fossil shells.Statuary marble is a pure, white, fine-grained kind, including Parianfrom Paros) and Carrara marble. If coarsely granular it is called saccharoidal.

☞ Marble is also much used in self-explaining compounds; when used figuratively in compounds it commonly means, hard, cold, destitute of compassion or feeling; as, marble-breasted, marble-faced, marble-hearted.
entry.ety: OE. marbel marbre, F. marbre, L. marmor, fr. Gr. ma`rmaros, fr. marmai`rein to sparkle, flash. Cf. Marmoreal

sn.def: A massive, compact limestone; a variety of calcite, capable of being polished and used for architectural and ornamental purposes. The color varies from white to black, being sometimes yellow, red, and green, and frequently beautifully veined or clouded. The name is also given to other rocks of like use and appearance, as serpentine or verd antique marble, and less properly to polished porphyry, granite, etc.
A thing made of, or resembling, marble, as a work of art, or record, in marble; or, in the plural, a collection of such works; as, the Arundel or Arundelian marbles; the Elgin marbles.
A little ball of glass, marble, porcelain, or of some other hard substance, used as a plaything by children; or, in the plural, a child's game played with marbles.
Made of, or resembling, marble; as, a marble mantel; marble paper.
Cold; hard; unfeeling; as, a marble breast or heart.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Marbled; p. pr. & vb. n. Marbling
entry.ety: Cf. F. marbrer. See Marble n.
entry.def: To stain or vein like marble; to variegate in color; as, to marble the edges of a book, or the surface of paper.

sn.def: Made of, or faced with, marble.
sn.q: Themarbledmansion.

sn.def: Made to resemble marble; veined or spotted like marble.
sn.q: Marbledpaper.

sn.def: Varied with irregular markings, or witch a confused blending of irregular spots and streaks.
Having small flecks of fat interspered with the muscle; -- of cuts of meat, especially beef; as, a well-marbled steak. Such marbling improves the flavor of beef for most people.

entry.def: A made of light and dark batter very lightly blended, so as to produce a variegated appearance resembling that of marble.
Having the edge veined or spotted with different colors like marble, as a book.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Marbleized; p. pr. & vb. n. Marbleizing
entry.def: To stain or grain in imitation of marble; to cover with a surface resembling marble; as, to marbleize slate, wood, or iron.
A texture like that of marble.

sn.def: One who works upon marble or other stone.
One who colors or stains in imitation of marble.

entry.def: A children's game played with marbles{3}, little balls made of a hard substance (as glass).

sn.def: A hard marbled wood.
A large Asiatic tree (Diospyros kurzii) having hard marbled zebrawood.
sn.syn: Andaman marble, Andaman marble, Diospyros kurzii.

sn.def: The art or practice of variegating in color, in imitation of marble.
An intermixture of fat and lean in meat, giving it a marbled appearance.
Distinct markings resembling the variegations of marble, as on birds and insects.

entry.def: Containing, or resembling, marble.

entry.ety: LL., fr. OF. & F. marble marble. See Marble
entry.def: A cloth woven so as to imitate the appearance of marble; -- much used in the 15th and 16th centuries.
The refuse matter which remains after the pressure of fruit, particularly of grapes.

entry.ety: AS. marc; akin to G. mark, Icel. mörk, perh. akin to E. mark a sign. √106, 273

sn.def: A weight of various commodities, esp. of gold and silver, used in different European countries. In France and Holland it was equal to eight ounces.
A coin formerly current in England and Scotland, equal to thirteen shillings and four pence.
A German coin and money of account. See Mark.

entry.def: A merchant.

cs.cd: tin.

entry.ety: F. marcassite; cf. It. marcassita, Sp. marquesita, Pg. marquezita; all fr. Ar. marqashītha
entry.def: A sulphide of iron resembling pyrite or common iron pyrites in composition, but differing in form; white iron pyrites.
Containing, or having the nature of, marcasite.
A young wild boar.
In a marked emphatic manner; -- used adverbially as a direction.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. marcidus withered, fr. marcere to wither, shrivel
entry.def: A thin silk fabric used for linings, etc., in ladies' dresses.
A French novelist (1871-1922).

entry.ety: L. marcescens, p. pr. of marcescere to wither, decay, fr. marcere to wither, droop: cf. F. marcescent
entry.def: Withering without falling off; fading; decaying.
Liable to wither or decay.

cs.col: As mad as a March Hare
cs.cd: an old English Saying derived from the fact that March is the rutting time of hares, when they are excitable and violent.

entry.ety: L. Martius mensis Mars'month fr. Martius belonging to Mars, the god of war: cf. F. mars. Cf. Martial
entry.def: The third month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
entry.q: The stormy March is come at last, With wind, and cloud, and changing skies.

entry.ety: OE. marche, F. marche; of German origin; cf. OHG. marcha, G. mark, akin to OS. marka, AS. mearc, Goth. marka, L. margo edge, border, margin, and possibly to E. mark a sign. √106. Cf. Margin Margrave Marque Marquis
entry.def: A territorial border or frontier; a region adjacent to a boundary line; a confine; -- used chiefly in the plural, and in English history applied especially to the border land on the frontiers between England and Scotland, and England and Wales.
entry.q: Geneva is situated in the marches of several dominions -- France, Savoy, and Switzerland.
Lords of waste marches, kings of desolate isles.

cs.cd: to have the same boundary for a greater or less distance; -- said of an estate.

entry.def: To border; to be contiguous; to lie side by side.
entry.q: That was in a strange land Which marcheth upon Chimerie.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Marched; p. pr. & vb. n. Marching
entry.ety: F. marcher, in OF. also, to tread, prob. fr. L. marcus hammer. Cf. Mortar

sn.def: To move with regular steps, as a soldier; to walk in a grave, deliberate, or stately manner; to advance steadily.
To proceed by walking in a body or in military order; as, the German army marched into France.

entry.def: To cause to move with regular steps in the manner of a soldier; to cause to move in military array, or in a body, as troops; to cause to advance in a steady, regular, or stately manner; to cause to go by peremptory command, or by force.
entry.q: March them again in fair array.

cs.cd: to take all the tricks of a hand, in the game of euchre.

sn.def: The act of marching; a movement of soldiers from one stopping place to another; military progress; advance of troops.
sn.q: These troops came to the army harassed with a long and wearisome march.

sn.def: Hence: Measured and regular advance or movement, like that of soldiers moving in order; stately or deliberate walk; steady onward movement; as, the march of time.
sn.q: With solemn march Goes slow and stately by them.
This happens merely because men will not bide their time, but will insist on precipitating the march of affairs.

sn.def: The distance passed over in marching; as, an hour's march; a march of twenty miles.
A piece of music designed or fitted to accompany and guide the movement of troops; a piece of music in the march form.
sn.q: The drums presently striking up a march.

entry.def: A sauce consisting of brown sauce with mushrooms and red wine or madeira.
The type genus of Marchantiaceae; liverworts that reproduce asexually by gemmae and have stalked antheridiophores.
A natural family of liverworts with prostrate and usually dichotomously branched thalli.
An oder of liverworts with gametophyte differentiated internally.
The vernal equinox.
One who marches.
The lord or officer who defended the marches or borders of a territory.
In old English and in Scots law, a fine paid to the lord of the soil by a tenant upon the marriage of one the tenant's daughters.

entry.cs: Marching money Mil the additional pay of officer or soldier when his regiment is marching. In marching order Mil equipped for a march. Marching regiment. Mil A regiment in active service. In England, a regiment liable to be ordered into other quarters, at home or abroad; a regiment of the line.
entry.def: a. & n., fr. March v.

entry.ety: LL. marchionissa, fr. marchio a marquis. See Marquis
entry.def: The wife or the widow of a marquis; a woman who has the rank and dignity of a marquis.
Extremely rash; foolhardy. See under March, the month.
A person living in the marches between England and Scotland or Wales.

entry.ety: Cf. It. marzapane,Sp. pan,. massepain, prob. fr. L. maza frumenty (Gr. ma^za) + L. panis bread; but perh. the first part of the word is from the name of the inventor
entry.def: A kind of sweet bread or biscuit; a cake of pounded almonds and sugar. Called also marzipan.
A warden of the marches; a marcher.
Under the influence of Mars; courageous; bold.

entry.ety: L. marcidus, fr. marcere to wither, pine

sn.def: Pining; lean; withered.
Characterized by emaciation, as a fever.

entry.def: The state or quality of being withered or lean.

A follower of Marcion, a Gnostic of the second century, who adopted the Oriental notion of the two conflicting principles, and imagined that between them there existed a third power, neither wholly good nor evil, the Creator of the world and of man, and the God of the Jewish dispensation.
A celebrated Rhine wine.

entry.ety: After Guglielmo Marconi b. 1874), Italian inventor
entry.def: Designating, or pert. to, Marconi's system of wireless telegraphy; as, Marconi aërial, coherer, station, system, etc. archaic
same as radiogram; a wireless message.
The apparatus used in Marconi wireless telegraphy.
A rig of triangular sails for a yacht.
entry.syn: Bermuda rig, Bermudan rig, Bermudian rig.

entry.def: The law that the maximum good signaling distance varies directly as the square of the height of the transmitting antenna.
The theory or practice of Marconi's wireless telegraph system.

entries.entry: Mar*co"ni system. Elec A system or wireless telegraphy developed by G. Marconi , an Italian physicist, in which Hertzian waves are used in transmission and a coherer is used as the receiving instrument.

entry.def: An Asiatic wild sheep (Ovis poli) with exceptionally large horns; sometimes considered a variety of the argali: Ovis ammon poli.
A wasting away of flesh; decay.
One of a Gnostic sect of the second century, so called from Marcus, an Egyptian, who was reputed to be a margician.

sn.def: The last day of Carnival; the Tuesday before Ash Wednesday (the beginning of Lent and fasting); Shrove Tuesday; -- in some cities a great day of carnival and merrymaking; in the United States it is especially associated with New Orleans.
The series of festival events celebrated on Mardi Gras1}.

entry.ety: OE. mere, AS. mere myre, fem of AS. mearh horse, akin to D. merrie mare, G. mähre, OHG. marah horse, meriha mare, Icel. marr horse, OCelt. markaPausan. 19, 19,4), Ir. marc, W. march. Cf. Marshal
entry.def: The female of the horse and other equine quadrupeds.

entry.ety: AS. mara incubus; akin to OHG. & Icel. mara; cf. Pol. mora, Bohem. můra
entry.def: Sighing, suffocative panting, intercepted utterance, with a sense of pressure across the chest, occurring during sleep; the incubus; -- obsolete, except in the compound nightmare.
entry.q: I will ride thee o' nights like the mare.

entries.entry:
Mare"chal Niel". F A kind of large yellow rose.
Marshal Niel

‖Ma"re clau"sum. L Internat. Law Lit., closed sea; hence, a body of water within the separate jurisdiction of the nation; -- opposed to open sea mare liberum), the water open to all nations and over which no single nation has special control.

entry.def: A Marsh.
A navigable body of water to which all nations have equal access; the opposite of mare clausum.

entry.ety: NL. Salmo maraena, G. maräne moräne; -- so called from Lake Morin, in the March of Brandenburg, in Prussia
entry.def: A European whitefish of the genus Coregonus.
The term used by the ancient Romans to refer to the Mediterranean Sea.

entry.ety: OF. mareschal, F. maréchal. See Marshal
entry.def: A military officer of high rank; a marshal.
A supposed discovery which turns out to be a hoax; something grossly absurd.

sn.def: A confused multitude of things.
A long streaky cloud, spreading out like a horse's tail, and believed to indicate rain; a cirrus cloud. See Cloud.
sn.q: Mackerel sky and mare's-tails Make tall ships carry low sails.

sn.def: An aquatic plant of the genus Hippuris Hippuris vulgaris), having narrow leaves in whorls.

entry.def: A compound of the so-called margaric acid with a base.

entry.cs: Margaric acid. Physiol. Chem A fatty body, crystallizing in pearly scales, and obtained by digesting saponified fats (soaps) with an acid. It was formerly supposed to be an individual fatty acid, but is now known to be simply an intimate mixture of stearic and palmitic acids. Chem A white, crystalline substance, C17H34O2 of the fatty acid series, intermediate between palmitic and stearic acids, and obtained from the wax of certain lichens, from cetyl cyanide, and other sources. Called also heptadecanoic acid.
entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, pearl; pearly.

A fatty substance, extracted from animal fats and certain vegetable oils, formerly supposed to be a definite compound of glycerin and margaric acid, but now known to be simply a mixture or combination of tristearin and tripalmitin.

sn.def: A processed food product used as an inexpensive substitute for butter, made primarily from refined vegetable oils, sometimes including animal fats, and churned with skim milk to form a semisolid emulsion; also called oleomargarine; artificial butter.
sn.q: The word margarine shall mean all substances, whether compounds or otherwise, prepared in imitation of butter, and whether mixed with butter or not.

sn.def: Margarin.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, pearl; pearly.

entry.ety: L. margarita, Gr. � a pearl; cf. F. marguerite

sn.def: A pearl.
A mineral related to the micas, but low in silica and yielding brittle folia with pearly luster.

entry.def: Margaric.

entry.ety: L. margaritifer; margarita pearl + ferre to bear: cf. F. margaritifère
entry.def: Producing pearls.
A hidrous potash mica related to muscovite.
The ketone of margaric acid.
Margaric; -- formerly designating a supposed acid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. -ized; p. pr. & vb. n. -izing
entry.ety: (J. J. LloydMargary, inventor of the process + -ize
entry.def: To impregnate (wood) with a preservative solution of copper sulphate (often called Mar"ga*ry's flu"id -rĭz).

entries.entry: Mar"gate fish". Zoöl A sparoid fish (Diabasis aurolineatus) of the Gulf of Mexico, esteemed as a food fish; -- called also red-mouth grunt.

entry.def: A small American wild cat (Felis wiedi syn. Felis tigrina), ranging from Mexico to Brazil. It is spotted with black. Called also long-tailed cat.
Border; margin; edge; verge.
entry.q: Along the river's stony marge.

entry.def: A margin; border; brink; edge.
entry.q: The beached margent of the sea.

entry.def: To enter or note down upon the margin of a page; to margin.

cs.cd: a smooth cut margin on the face of hammer-dressed ashlar, adjacent to the joints.
that part of a course, as of slates or shingles, which is not covered by the course immediately above it. See 2d Gauge.

entry.ety: OE. margine margent, L. margo ginis. Cf. March a border, Marge

sn.def: A border; edge; brink; verge; as, the margin of a river or lake.
Specifically: The part of a page at the edge left uncovered in writing or printing.
The difference between the cost and the selling price of an article.
Something allowed, or reserved, for that which can not be foreseen or known with certainty.

Collateral security deposited with a broker to secure him from loss on contracts entered into by him on behalf of his principial, as in the speculative buying and selling of stocks, wheat, etc. It is usually less than the full value of the security purchased, in which case it may be qualified by the portion of the full value required to be deposited; as, to buy stocks on 50% margin .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Margined; p. pr. & vb. n. Marginging

sn.def: To furnish with a margin.
To enter in the margin of a page.

entry.def: An account with a securities brokerage in which the broker extends credit.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a margin.
Written or printed in the margin; as, a marginal note or gloss.
At the lower limit; barely sufficient; as, of marginal utility.

entry.def: The increase in total cost of production as a result of producing one more unit of output; since certain ovrhead costs are fixed, the marginal cost is almost aways less than the total per-unit cost of production averaged over all units produced.
Marginal notes.
the property of being marginal or on the fringes.

sn.def: In the margin of a book.
In a marginal3} manner; barely sufficiently; almost not; as, marginally useful.

entry.ety: L. marginatus, p. p. of marginare to margin. See Margin n.
entry.def: Having a margin distinct in appearance or structure.
To furnish with a distinct margin; to margin.
Same as Marginate a.

sn.def: Having a margin.
Bordered with a distinct line of color.

entry.def: A demand by a broker that a customer deposit enough to bring his margin up to the minimum requirement; -- caused by the decline in market prices of a security or commodity purchased on margin{5}.

entry.ety: NL., dim. of L. margo marginis, a margin
entry.def: A genus of small, polished, marine univalve shells, native of all warm seas.

entry.ety: L. margo -ginis, margin + caedere to cut
entry.def: Dehiscent by the separation of united carpels; -- said of fruits.

A large tree of the genus Melia Melia Azadirachta) found in India. Its bark is bitter, and used as a tonic. A valuable oil is expressed from its seeds, and a tenacious gum exudes from its trunk. The Melia Azedarach is a much more showy tree, and is cultivated in the Southern United States, where it is known as Pride of India Pride of China, or bead tree. Various parts of the tree are considered anthelmintic.
entry.q: The margosa oil . . . is a most valuable balsam for wounds, having a peculiar smell which prevents the attacks of flies.

entry.def: The territory or jurisdiction of a margrave.

entry.ety: G. markgraf, prop., lord chief justice of the march; mark bound, border, march + graf earl, count, lord chief justice; cf. Goth. gagrëfts decree: cf. D. markgraaf, F. margrave. See March border, and cf. Landgrave Graff

sn.def: Originally, a lord or keeper of the borders or marches in Germany.
The English equivalent of the German title of nobility, markgraf; a marquis.

entry.def: The wife of a margrave.

entry.ety: F., a pearl, a daisy. See Margarite
entry.def: The daisy (Bellis perennis). The name is often applied also to the ox-eye daisy and to the China aster.

sn.def: Plural form of mare, a dark region of considerable extent on the surface of the moon.
A valuable timber tree of Panama.

entry.cs: Maid Marian. See Maidmarian in the Vocabulary. A prominent character in the legend of Robin Hood.
entry.def: Pertaining to the Virgin Mary, or sometimes to Mary, Queen of England, daughter of Henry VIII.
entry.q: Of all the Marian martyrs, Mr. Philpot was the best-born gentleman.

entry.def: Marry.

entry.ety: F. mariette, prop. dim. of Marie Mary
entry.def: A kind of bellflower, Companula Trachelium, once called Viola Mariana; but it is not a violet.
Produced in or by the sea.

entry.note: ☞ There are several yellow-flowered plants of different genera bearing this name; as, the African marigoldorFrench marigold of the genus Tagetes, of which several species and many varieties are found in gardens. They are mostly strong-smelling herbs from South America and Mexico: bur marigold, of the genus Bidens; corn marigold, of the genus Chrysanthemum Chrysanthemum segetum, a pest in the cornfields of Italy); fig marigold, of the genus Mesembryanthemum; marsh marigold, of the genus Caltha Caltha palustris), commonly known in America as the cowslip. See Marsh Marigold.
entry.cs: Marigold window. Arch See Rose window, under Rose.
entry.def: A name for several plants with golden yellow blossoms, especially the Calendula officinalissee Calendula), and the cultivated species of Tagetes.

sn.def: A strong-smelling Asian plant (Cannabis sativa), also called hemp, from which a number of euphorogenic and halucinogenic drugs are prepared. The euphoric effect is predominently due to tetrahydrocannabinol THC).
sn.syn: cannabis, ganja, pot, grass, marihuana, Cannabis sativa.

sn.def: The dried leaves or the female flowers of the hemp plant, which is smoked or chewed to obtain a euphoric effect. The flowers usually have a higher concentration of the active ingredient, tetrahydrocannabinol.
sn.syn: cannabis, ganja, pot, grass, marihuana, dope, weed, gage, sess, sens, smoke, skunk, Mary Jane.

entry.ety: From the native name: cf. Pg. mariquinha
entry.def: A small marmoset (Midas rosalia); the silky tamarin.
A musical istrument of percussion, consisting of bars yielding musical tones when struck.
A spider monkey (Ateles belzebuth) of Central and South America.

entry.ety: F.: cf. It. marinato marinade, F. mariner to preserve food for use at sea. See Marinate
entry.def: A brine or pickle containing wine or vinegar, with opil, herbs, and spices, for enriching the flavor of meat and fish, which are steeped in it prior to cooking.
An Italian sauce containing tomatoes, garlic, herbs, and spices.
Served in marinara sauce; -- used postpositionally, as veal marinara.
To salt or pickle, as fish, and then preserve in oil or vinegar; to prepare (food) by the use of marinade.

entry.cs:
Marine acid Chem hydrochloric acid. Obs Marine barometer. See under Barometer. Marine corps a corps formed of the officers, noncommissioned officers, privates, and musicants of marines.
Marine engine Mech a steam engine for propelling a vessel. Marine glue. See under Glue. Marine insurance insurance against the perils of the sea, including also risks of fire, piracy, and barratry. Marine interest interest at any rate agreed on for money lent upon respondentia and bottomry bonds. Marine law. See under Law. Marine league three geographical miles. Marine metal an alloy of lead, antimony, and mercury, made for sheathing ships. Mc Elrath. Marine soap cocoanut oil soap; -- so called because, being quite soluble in salt water, it is much used on shipboard. Marine store a store where old canvas, ropes, etc., are bought and sold; a junk shop. Eng
entry.ety: L. marinus, fr. mare the sea: cf. F. marin. See Mere a pool

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the sea; having to do with the ocean, or with navigation or naval affairs; nautical; as, marine productions or bodies; marine shells; a marine engine.
Formed by the action of the currents or waves of the sea; as, marine deposits.

cs.cd: an expression of disbelief, the marines being regarded by sailors as credulous.

entry.ety: F. marin a sea solider, marine naval economy, a marine picture, fr. L. marinus. See Marine a.

sn.def: A solider serving on shipboard; a sea soldier; one of a body of troops trained to do duty in the navy.
A member of the United States Marine Corps, or a similar foreign military force.
The sum of naval affairs; naval economy; the department of navigation and sea forces; the collective shipping of a country; as, the mercantile marine .
A picture representing some marine subject.

entry.def: Having the lower part of the body like a fish.

A military explosive device designed to be placed on or under the surface of a body of water, and to explode when ships pass nearby or come in contact with it. Its function is to destroy enemy ships or deny hostile naval forces access to certain areas of the sea, usually near the shoreline. Also called underwater mine and floating mine, and previously referred to as a torpedoSee torpedo2).

entry.cs: Mariner's compass. See under Compass.
entry.ety: F. marinier, LL. marinarius. See Marine
entry.def: One whose occupation is to assist in navigating ships; a seaman or sailor.
Seamanship.
A bombastic literary style marked by the use of metaphors and antitheses characteristic of the Italian poet Giambattista Marini1569-1625).

entry.ety: NL., from L. marinus marine + Gr. � view
entry.def: A representation of a sea view.
One who worships the Virgin Mary.
The worship of the Virgin Mary.

entry.ety: F. marionette, prop. a dim. of Marie Mary

sn.def: A puppet moved by strings, as in a puppet show.
The buffel duck.

entries.entry: Ma`ri*otte's law`. Physics See Boyle's law, under Law.

Ma`ri*po"sa lil`y. Sp. mariposa a butterfly + E. lily. So called from the gay appearance of the blossoms Bot One of a genus (Calochortus) of tuliplike bulbous herbs with large, and often gaycolored, blossoms. Called also butterfly lily. Most of them are natives of California.

entry.def: A species of civet; the zoril.

entry.ety: Cf. F. marais, LL. marascus. See Marsh
entry.def: Low, wet ground; a marsh; a fen; a bog; a moor.

sn.def: Moory; fenny; boggy.
Growing in marshes.
sn.q: Marishflowers.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. maritalis, fr. maritus belonging to marriage, n., a husband. See Marry v.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a husband; as, marital rights, duties, authority.
sn.q: Maritalaffection.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to marriage; matrimonial.

entry.def: Having a husband; married.
See Maritime.

entry.cs: Maritime law. See Law. Maritime loan a loan secured by bottomry or respodentia bonds. Martime nations nations having seaports, and using the sea more or less for war or commerce.
entry.ety: L. maritimus, fr. mare the sea: cf. F. maritime. See Mere a pool

sn.def: Bordering on, or situated near, the ocean; connected with the sea by site, interest, or power; having shipping and commerce or a navy; as, maritime states.
sn.q: Amaritimetown.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the ocean; marine; pertaining to navigation and naval affairs, or to shipping and commerce by sea.
sn.q: Maritimeservice.

entry.def: The Canadian provinces of New Brunswick and Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island.

entry.ety: OE. majoran, F. marjolaine, LL. marjoraca, fr. L. amaracus amaracum, Gr. 'ama`rakos 'ama`rakon
entry.def: A genus of mintlike plants (Origanum) comprising about twenty-five species. The sweet marjoram (Origanum Majorana) is pecularly aromatic and fragrant, and much used in cookery. The wild marjoram of Europe and America is Origanum vulgare, far less fragrant than the other.
A license of reprisals. See Marque.

sn.def: An old weight and coin. See Marc.
sn.q: Lend me amark.

sn.def: The unit of monetary account of the German Empire, equal to 23.8 cents of United States money (1913); the equivalent of one hundred pfennigs. Also, a silver coin of this value. The unit was retained by subsequent German states up to the time of the Federal Republic of Germany. In 1995, the value was approximately 65 cents American. In 1999 it began to be superseded by the Euro as a unit of currency in Germany and throughout much of the European union.

entry.cs: A man of mark a conspicuous or eminent man. To make one's mark. a To sign, as a letter or other writing, by making a cross or other mark. To make a distinct or lasting impression on the public mind, or on affairs; to gain distinction.
entry.ety: OE. marke merke, AS. mearc; akin to D. merk, MHG. marc, G. marke, Icel. mark, Dan. mærke; cf. Lith. margas party-colored. √106, 273. Cf. Remark

sn.def: A visible sign or impression made or left upon anything; esp., a line, point, stamp, figure, or the like, drawn or impressed, so as to attract the attention and convey some information or intimation; a token; a trace.
sn.q: The Lord set a mark upon Cain, lest any finding him should kill him.

entry.sn:
Specifically: A character or device put on an article of merchandise by the maker to show by whom it was made; a trade-mark.
A character (usually a cross) made as a substitute for a signature by one who can not write. The mark of the artisan is found upon the most ancient fabrics that have come to light.

sn.def: A fixed object serving for guidance, as of a ship, a traveler, a surveyor, etc.; as, a seamark, a landmark .
A trace, dot, line, imprint, or discoloration, although not regarded as a token or sign; a scratch, scar, stain, etc.; as, this pencil makes a fine mark .
sn.q: I have some marks of yours upon my pate.

sn.def: An evidence of presence, agency, or influence; a significative token; a symptom; a trace; specifically, a permanent impression of one's activity or character.
sn.q: The confusion of tongues was a mark of separation.

sn.def: That toward which a missile is directed; a thing aimed at; what one seeks to hit or reach.
sn.q: France was a fairer mark to shoot at than Ireland.
Whate'er the motive, pleasure is the mark.

sn.def: Attention, regard, or respect.
sn.q: As much in mock as mark.

sn.def: Limit or standard of action or fact; as, to be within the mark; to come up to the mark.
Badge or sign of honor, rank, or official station.
sn.q: In the official marks invested, you Anon do meet the Senate.

sn.def: Preëminence; high position; as, patricians of mark; a fellow of no mark.
A characteristic or essential attribute; a differential.
A number or other character used in registering; as, examination marks; a mark for tardiness.
Image; likeness; hence, those formed in one's image; children; descendants.
sn.q: All themarkof Adam.

sn.def: One of the bits of leather or colored bunting which are placed upon a sounding line at intervals of from two to five fathoms. The unmarked fathoms are called “deeps.”
sn.syn: Impress; impression; stamp; print; trace; vestige; track; characteristic; evidence; proof; token; badge; indication; symptom.

entry.cs: To mark out. To designate, as by a mark; to select; as, the ringleaders were marked out for punishment. To obliterate or cancel with a mark; as, to mark out an item in an account. To mark time Mil to keep the time of a marching step by moving the legs alternately without advancing.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Marked märkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Marking
