sn.q: And o'er his eyebrows hung his matted hair.

entry.def: To grow thick together; to become interwoven or felted together like a mat, as hair when wetted with a sticky substance; as, a long-haired cat whose fur is matted .
A warlike South African Kaffir tribe.
An old dance with swords and bucklers; a sword dance.
The three-banded armadillo (Tolypeutis tricinctus). See Illust. under Loricata.

entry.ety: Sp. matador, prop., a killer, fr. matar to kill, L. mactare to sacrifice, kill

sn.def: The killer; the man appointed to kill the bull in bullfights; a bullfighter; a toreador.

In the game of quadrille or omber, the three principal trumps, the ace of spades being the first, the ace of clubs the third, and the second being the deuce of a black trump or the seven of a red one.
sn.q: When Lady Tricksey played a four, You took it with a matadore.

sn.def: The jack of clubs, or any other trump held in sequence with it, whether by the player or by his adversaries.
A certain game of dominoes in which four dominoes (the 4-3, 5-2, 6-1, and double blank), called matadors, may be played at any time in any way.

entry.def: A shrike or butcher bird; -- called also mattages.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. matajudío a kind of fish
entry.def: A large squirrel fish (Holocentrus ascensionis) of Florida and the West Indies.

entries.entry: Ma`ta*jue"lo blan"co mä`tȧ*hwā"lō bläṉ"kō. Sp. blanco white A West Indian food fish (Malacanthus plumieri) related to the tilefish.

entry.def: The bearded tortoise (Chelys fimbriata) of South American rivers.

entry.ety: Sp., slaughter, fr. matar to kill
entry.def: A place where animals are slaughtered for their hides and tallow.

cs.cd: a tub with a perforated cover for holding slow matches for firing cannon, esp. on board ship. The tub contains a little water in the bottom, for extinguishing sparks from the lighted matches.

threads of cotton or cotton wick soaked in a solution of gunpowder mixed with gum arabic and boiling water and afterwards strewed over with mealed powder. It burns at the rate of one yard in thirteen seconds, and is used as priming for heavy mortars, fireworks, etc.

slightly twisted hempen rope soaked in a solution of limewater and saltpeter or washed in a lye of water and wood ashes. It burns at the rate of four or five inches an hour, and is used for firing cannon, fireworks, etc.

entry.ety: OE. macche, F. mèche, F. mèche, fr. L. myxa a lamp nozzle, Gr. my`xa mucus, nostril, a lamp nozzle. Cf. Mucus
entry.def: Anything used for catching and retaining or communicating fire, made of some substance which takes fire readily, or remains burning some time; esp., a small strip or splint of wood or cardboard dipped at one end in a substance which can be easily ignited by friction, as a preparation of phosphorus or chlorate of potassium.

cs.cd: boards fitted together with tongue and groove, or prepared to be so fitted; a surface composed of match boarding. See matchboard.
a game arranged as a test of superiority.
either of the two planes used to shape the edges of boards which are joined by grooving and tonguing.
a board or plate on the opposite sides of which the halves of a pattern are fastened, to facilitate molding.
a cogwheel of suitable pitch to work with another wheel; specifically, one of a pair of cogwheels of equal size.

entry.ety: OE. macche, AS. gemæcca; akin to gemaca, and to OS. gimako, OHG. gimah fitting, suitable, convenient, Icel. mark suitable, maki mate, Sw. make, Dan. mage; all from the root of E. make, v. See Make mate, and Make v., and cf. Mate an associate

sn.def: A person or thing equal or similar to another; one able to mate or cope with another; an equal; a mate.
sn.q: Government . . . makes an innocent man, though of the lowest rank, a match for the mightiest of his fellow subjects.

entry.sn:
A bringing together of two parties suited to one another, as for a union, a trial of skill or force, a contest, or the like; specifically:
A contest to try strength or skill, or to determine superiority; a sporting contest; an emulous struggle. Many a warlikematch. Drayton. A solemn match was made; he lost the prize.
A matrimonial union; a marriage.

sn.def: An agreement, compact, etc.
sn.q: Thy hand upon thatmatch.
Love doth seldom suffer itself to be confined by other matches than those of its own making.

sn.def: A candidate for matrimony; one to be gained in marriage.
sn.q: She . . . was looked upon as the richestmatchof the West.

sn.def: Equality of conditions in contest or competition, or one who provides equal competition to another in a contest; as, he had no match as a swordsman within the city.
sn.q: It were no match, your nail against his horn.

sn.def: Suitable combination or bringing together; that which corresponds or harmonizes with something else; as, the carpet and curtains are a match .
A perforated board, block of plaster, hardened sand, etc., in which a pattern is partly imbedded when a mold is made, for giving shape to the surfaces of separation between the parts of the mold.

cs.cd: a planing machine for forming a tongue or a groove on the edge of a board.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Matched; p. pr. & vb. n. Matching

sn.def: To be a mate or match for; to be able to complete with; to rival successfully; to equal.
sn.q: No settled senses of the world can match The pleasure of that madness.

sn.def: To furnish with its match; to bring a match, or equal, against; to show an equal competitor to; to set something in competition with, or in opposition to, as equal.
sn.q: No history or antiquity can matchis policies and his conduct.

sn.def: To oppose as equal; to contend successfully against.
sn.q: Eternal might To match with their inventions they presumed So easy, and of his thunder made a scorn.

sn.def: To make or procure the equal of, or that which is exactly similar to, or corresponds with; as, to match a vase or a horse; to match cloth.
sn.q: Matchingof patterns and colors.

sn.def: To make equal, proportionate, or suitable; to adapt, fit, or suit (one thing to another).
sn.q: Let poets match their subject to their strength.

sn.def: To marry; to give in marriage.
sn.q: A senator of Rome survived, Would not have matched his daughter with a king.

sn.def: To fit together, or make suitable for fitting together; specifically, to furnish with a tongue and a groove, at the edges; as, to match boards.
To be united in marriage; to mate.
sn.q: I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.
Let tigers match with hinds, and wolves with sheep.

sn.def: To be of equal, or similar, size, figure, color, or quality; to tally; to suit; to correspond; as, these vases match .

entry.def: Capable of being matched; comparable on equal conditions; adapted to being joined together; correspondent.
entry.q: Sir Walter Raleigh . . . is matchable with the best of the ancients.

entry.def: A board that has a groove cut into one edge and a tongue cut into the other so they fit tightly together (as in a floor); see match boarding.
A small folder of paper safety matches.
a box for holding matches. See first match n.
any of several plants of the genus Gutierrezia having tiny matchlike flowerheads.
A coarse cloth.
A coat made of match-cloth.
One who, or that which, matches; a matching machine. See under 3d Match.

entries.entry: Match game. A game arranged as a test of superiority; also, one of a series of such games.

entry.def: a large heavy knife used in Central and South America as a weapon or for cutting vegetation; usually called machete.

sn.def: having identical or closely similar appearance or properties; as, a pair of matching candlesticks.
Harmonious and pleasing in appearance when used together; as, a matching skirt and blouse.
Having no equal; unequaled.
sn.q: Amatchlessqueen.

sn.def: Unlike each other; unequal; unsuited.
sn.q: Matchlessears.

entry.def: An old form of gunlock containing a match for firing the priming; hence, a musket fired by means of a match.

sn.def: One who makes matches for burning or kinding.
One who tries to bring about marriages.
The act or process of making matches for kindling or burning.
The act or process of trying to bring about a marriage for others.

entry.def: Busy in making or contriving marriages; as, a matchmaking woman.

entries.entry: Match play. Golf Play in which the score is reckoned by counting the holes won or lost by each side; -- distinguished from medal play.

sn.def: wood in small pieces or splinters; as, the vessel was beaten to matchwood on the rocks.
Wood suitable for making matchsticks.

entry.def: The Paraguay tea, being the dried leaf of the Brazilian holly (Ilex Paraguensis). The infusion has a pleasant odor, with an agreeable bitter taste, and is much used for tea in South America.

entry.ety: F. mat, abbrev. fr. échec et mat. See Checkmate
entry.def: Same as Checkmate.
See 2d Mat.

entry.ety: F. mater to fatigue, enfeeble, humiliate, checkmate. See Mate checkmate

sn.def: To confuse; to confound.
To checkmate.

entry.ety: Perhaps for older make a companion; cf. also OD. maet companion, mate, D. maat. Cf. Make a companion, Match a mate

sn.def: One who customarily associates with another; a companion; an associate; any object which is associated or combined with a similar object.
Hence, specifically, a husband or wife; and among the lower animals, one of a pair associated for propagation and the care of their young.
A suitable companion; a match; an equal.
sn.q: Ye knew me once no mate For you; there sitting where you durst not soar.

sn.def: An officer in a merchant vessel ranking next below the captain. If there are more than one bearing the title, they are called, respectively, first mate second mate third mate, etc. In the navy, a subordinate officer or assistant; as, master's mate; surgeon's mate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mated; p. pr. & vb. n. Mating

sn.def: To match; to marry.
sn.q: If she be mated with an equal husband.

sn.def: To match one's self against; to oppose as equal; to compete with.
sn.q: There is no passion in the mind of man so weak but it mates and masters the fear of death.
I, . . . in the way of loyalty and truth, . . . Dare mate a sounder man than Surrey can be.

sn.def: To breed; to bring (animals) together for the purpose of breeding; as, she mated a doberman with a German shepherd.
To join together; to fit together; to connect; to link; as, he mated a saw blade to a broom handle to cut inaccessible branches.

entry.def: To be or become a mate or mates, especially in sexual companionship; as, some birds mate for life; this bird will not mate with that one.

sn.def: Brought together for sexual activity; bred; -- of animals.
Sorted into pairs of identical size, color, or other properties; -- used of gloves, socks, etc.
Same as married. Opposite of unmarried; as, they were a devoted couple, mated for life.

entry.ety: F., p.p. of matelasser to cushion, to cover as with a mattress, fr. matelas mattress. See Mattress
entry.def: Ornamented by means of an imitation or suggestion of quilting, the surface being marked by depressed lines which form squares or lozenges in relief; as, matelassé silks.
A quilted ornamented dress fabric of silk or silk and wool.
Having no mate.

entry.ety: F. matelote, fr. matelot a sailor; properly, a dish such as a sailors prepare

sn.def: A stew, commonly of fish, flavored with wine, and served with a wine sauce containing onions, mushrooms, etc.
An old dance of sailors, in double time, and somewhat like a hornpipe.

entry.ety: Gr. mataiologi`a; ma`taios useless, vain + lo`gos discourse: cf. F. matéologie
entry.def: A vain, unprofitable discourse or inquiry.

entry.ety: Gr. mataiotechni`a; ma`taios vain + te`chnh art, science
entry.def: Any unprofitable science.
See Alma mater Dura mater, and Pia mater.

entry.cs: Material cause. See under Cause. Material evidence Law evidence which conduces to the proof or disproof of a relevant hypothesis. Wharton.
entry.ety: L. materialis, fr. materia stuff, matter: cf. F. matériel. See Matter, and cf. MatÉriel

sn.def: Consisting of matter; not spiritual; corporeal; physical; as, material substance or bodies.
sn.q: The material elements of the universe.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or affecting, the physical nature of man, as distinguished from the mental or moral nature; relating to the bodily wants, interests, and comforts; as, material well-being; material comforts.
Of solid or weighty character; not insubstantial; of consequence; not be dispensed with; important; significant.
sn.q: Discourse, which was always material, never trifling.
I shall, in the account of simple ideas, set down only such as are most material to our present purpose.

sn.def: Pertaining to the matter, as opposed to the form, of a thing. See Matter.
sn.syn: Corporeal; bodily; important; weighty; momentous; essential.

cs.cd: any crude, unfinished, or elementary materials that are adapted to use only by processes of skilled labor. Cotton, wool, ore, logs, etc., are raw material .

entry.def: The substance or matter of which anything is made or may be made.
To form from matter; to materialize.

cs.cd: The theory that matter and energy are the only objects existing within the universe, and that mental and spiritual phenomena are explainable as functions of the nervous system of people. Same as materialism1}.

sn.def: The doctrine of materialists; materialistic views and tenets; called also philosophical materialism.
sn.q: The irregular fears of a future state had been supplanted by the materialism of Epicurus.

sn.def: The tendency to give undue importance to material interests as contrasted with spiritual concerns; devotion to the material nature and its wants.
Material substances in the aggregate; matter.

One who denies the existence of spiritual substances or agents, and maintains that spiritual phenomena, so called, are the result of some peculiar organization of matter. A believer in philosophical materialism.
One who holds to the existence of matter, as distinguished from the idealist, who denies it.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to materialism or materialists; of the nature of materialism.
entry.q: But to me his very spiritualism seemed more materialistic than his physics.

sn.def: Primarily concerned with material objects and worldly activities, as contrasted with spiritual, moral or philosophical concerns; especially, concerned primarily with gaining money and the things that money can buy.
The quality or state of being material; material existence; corporeity.
Importance; as, the materiality of facts.

entry.def: The act of materializing, or the state of being materialized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Materialized; p. pr. & vb. n. Materializing

sn.def: To invest with material characteristics; to make perceptible to the senses; hence, to present to the mind through the medium of material objects.
sn.q: Having with wonderful art and beauty materialized, if I may so call it, a scheme of abstracted notions, and clothed the most nice, refined conceptions of philosophy in sensible images.

sn.def: To regard as matter; to consider or explain by the laws or principles which are appropriate to matter.
To cause to assume a character appropriate to material things; to occupy with material interests; as, to materialize thought.
To make visable in, or as in, a material form; -- said of spirits.
sn.q: A female spirit form temporarily materialized, and not distinguishable from a human being.

sn.def: To appear as a material form; to take substantial shape.
To come into existence; as, the promised donations never materialized .
In the state of matter.
sn.q: I do not mean that anything is separable from a body by fire that was not materially preëxistent in it.

sn.def: In its essence; substantially.
sn.q: An ill intention is certainly sufficient to spoil . . . an act in itself materially good.

sn.def: In an important manner or degree; essentially; as, it materially concerns us to know the real motives of our actions.

entry.def: The state of being material.

entries.entry:
‖Ma*te"ri*a med"i*ca. L. See Matter, and Medical
Material or substance used in the composition of remedies; -- a general term for all substances used as curative agents in medicine.
That branch of medical science which treats of the sources, nature and properties of all the substances that are employed for the cure of diseases, primarily with natural preparations, rather than pure or synthetic medicines; pharmacognosy.

entry.def: See Materialist.

entry.ety: L. materiatus, p. p. of materiare to build of wood
entry.def: Consisting of matter.
Act of forming matter.

That in a complex system which constitutes the materials, or instruments employed, in distinction from the personnel, or men; as, the baggage, munitions, provisions, etc., of an army; or the buildings, libraries, and apparatus of a college, in distinction from its officers.
See Material.

entry.ety: F. maternel, L. maternus, fr. mater mother. See Mother
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a mother; becoming to a mother; motherly; as, maternal love; maternal tenderness.
showing maternal instincts; behaving as a mother should; motherly.
In a motherly manner.

sn.def: The state of being a mother; motherhood.
The character of a mother; maternal quality; motherliness.
The maternity ward; the maternity department of a hospital.
Of or pertaining to childbirth or the period during which a woman is pregnant; as, maternity care; a maternity hospital.
For use during pregnancy; as, a maternity outfit.

entry.def: The section of a hospital devoted to assisting women during childbirth and caring for them and their newborn infants until they are released to go home.
having the relationship of friends or pals.
The knapweed (Centaurea nigra).

entry.ety: AS. mǣð; akin to māwan to mow, G. mahd math. See Mow to cut (grass)
entry.def: A mowing, or that which is gathered by mowing; -- chiefly used in composition; as, an aftermath .
entry.q: The first mowing thereof, for the king's use, is wont to be sooner than the common math.

entry.ety: F. mathématique, L. mathematicus, Gr. � disposed to learn, belonging to learning or the sciences, especially to mathematics, fr. � that which is learned, learning, pl. � things learned, learning, science, especially mathematical science, fr. �, �, to learn; akin to E. mind. See Mind
entry.def: See Mathematical.
Of or pertaining to mathematics; according to mathematics; hence, theoretically precise; accurate; as, mathematical geography; mathematical instruments; mathematical exactness.
One versed in mathematics.

entry.note: ☞ Mathematics embraces three departments, namely: 1.Arithmetic. 2.Geometry, including Trigonometry and Conic Sections. 3.Analysis, in which letters are used, including Algebra Analytical Geometry, and Calculus. Each of these divisions is divided into pure or abstract, which considers magnitude or quantity abstractly, without relation to matter; and mixed or applied, which treats of magnitude as subsisting in material bodies, and is consequently interwoven with physical considerations.
entry.ety: F. mathématiques, pl., L. mathematica, sing., Gr. � (sc. �) science. See Mathematic, and -ics
entry.def: That science, or class of sciences, which treats of the exact relations existing between quantities or magnitudes, and of the methods by which, in accordance with these relations, quantities sought are deducible from other quantities known or supposed; the science of spatial and quantitative relations.
See Madder.

entry.ety: Perh. corrupted fr. L. anthemis camomile, Gr. �
entry.def: The mayweed. Cf. Maghet.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, from �, �, to learn
entry.def: Learning; especially, mathematics.
See Trinitarian.
A Peruvian plant (Piperelongatum or Artanthe elongatum), allied to the pepper, the leaves of which are used as a styptic and astringent.
A fat herring with undeveloped roe.
A French mastiff.

entry.ety: F. fr. L. matutinum the morning, matutinus of the morning, Matuta the goddess of the morning. See Matutinal

sn.def: Morning.
Morning worship or service; morning prayers or songs.
sn.q: The winged choristers began To chirp their matins.

sn.def: Time of morning service; the first canonical hour in the Roman Catholic Church.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the morning, or to matins; used in the morning; matutinal.
Relating to the morning, or to matins; matutinal.
A reception, or a musical or dramatic entertainment, held in the daytime. See SoirÉe.

entry.ety: F. matras; perh. so called from its long narrow neck; cf. OF. matras large arrow, L. materis mataris matara, a Celtic javelin, pike; of Celtic origin
entry.def: A round-bottomed glass flask having a long neck; a bolthead.
See Matress.

sn.def: The mother and ruler of a family or of her descendants; a ruler by maternal right.
A woman who dominates or is the most important member of a group or organization; in businesses, often the founder or owner of the largest interest.
A venerated old woman.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a matriarch; governed by a matriarch or matriarchs; as, a matriarchal society.
The office or jurisdiction of a matriarch; a matriarchal form of government.
admission to a group (especially a college or university).
A genus of chiefly Old World strong-smelling weedy herbs; it comprises plants sometimes included in other genera, such as Tanacetum and Tripleurospermum.
See Matrix.

entries.entry: matricentric adj. centered upon the mother.Narrower terms: matriarchal (vs. patriarchal

entry.def: Of or pertaining to matricide.

entry.ety: L. matricidium; mater mother + coedere to kill, slay: cf. F. matricide. See Mother, and cf. Homicide

sn.def: The murder of a mother by her son or daughter.
One who murders one's own mother.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Matriculated; p. pr. & vb. n. Matriculating
entry.ety: L. matricula a public roll or register, dim. of matrix a mother, in respect to propagation, also, a public register. See Matrix
entry.def: To enroll; to enter in a register;
to enter or admit to membership in a body or society, particularly in a college or university, by enrolling the name in a register.
entry.q: In discovering and matriculating the arms of commissaries from North America.

entry.def: To go though the process of admission to membership, as by examination and enrollment, in a society or college.
Matriculated.
The act or process of matriculating; the state of being matriculated.
The line of descent traced through the maternal side of the family; the mother's line of descent.
tracing descent through the female line.
Matrimony.

entry.ety: L. matrimonialis: cf. F. matrimonial. See Matrimony
entry.def: Of or pertaining to marriage; derived from marriage; connubial; nuptial; hymeneal; as, matrimonial rights or duties.
entry.q: If he relied upon that title, he could be but a king at courtesy, and have rather a matrimonial than a regal power.
entry.syn: Connubial; conjugal; sponsal; spousal; nuptial; hymeneal.

entry.def: In a matrimonial manner.
Matrimonial.

cs.cd: a climbing thorny vine (Lycium barbarum) of the Potato family.

entry.ety: OE. matrimoine, through Old French, fr. L. matrimonium, fr. mater mother. See Mother

sn.def: The union of man and woman as husband and wife; the nuptial state; marriage; wedlock.
sn.q: If either of you know any impediment, why ye may not be lawfully joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it.

sn.def: A kind of game at cards played by several persons.

entry.def: One related on the mother's side.
entry.syn: enate, matrikin, matrilineal kin, matrilineal sib.

entries.entry:
ma"trix mā"trĭks n.; pl.Matrices măt"rĭ*sēz. L., fr. mater mother. See Mother, and cf. Matrice
Anat The womb. All that openeth the matrix is mine.
Hence: That which gives form or origin to anything; as: Mech The cavity in which anything is formed, and which gives it shape; a die; a mold, as for the face of a type.
Min The earthy or stony substance in which metallic ores or crystallized minerals are found; the gangue.
pl. Dyeing The five simple colors, black, white, blue, red, and yellow, of which all the rest are composed.
Biol The lifeless portion of tissue, either animal or vegetable, situated between the cells; the intercellular substance.
Math A rectangular arrangement of symbols in rows and columns. The symbols may express quantities or operations.

cs.cd: a jury of experienced women called to determine the question of pregnancy when set up in bar of execution, and for other cognate purposes.

entry.ety: F. matrone, L. matrona, fr. mater mother. See Mother

sn.def: A wife or a widow, especially, one who has borne children; a woman of staid or motherly manners.
sn.q: Your wives, your daughters, Your matrons, and your maids.
Grave from her cradle, insomuch that she was a matron before she was a mother.

sn.def: A housekeeper; esp., a woman who manages the domestic economy of a public instution; a head nurse in a hospital; as, the matron of a school or hospital.
The state of a matron.
The collective body of matrons.
sn.q: Can a politician slight the feelings and convictions of the whole matronage of his country?

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a matron; suitable to an elderly lady or to a married woman; grave; motherly.
The state of being a matron.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Matronized; p. pr. & vb. n. Matronizing

sn.def: To make a matron of; to make matronlike.
sn.q: Childbed matronizes the giddiest spirits.

sn.def: To act the part of a matron toward; to superintend; to chaperone; as, to matronize an assembly.

entry.def: Like a matron; sedate; grave; matronly.

sn.def: Advanced in years; elderly.
Like, or befitting, a matron; grave; sedate.

entry.ety: L. mater mother + -nymic, as in patronimic
entry.def: See Metronymic.
Formerly, in the British service, a gunner or a gunner's mate; one of the soldiers in a train of artillery, who assisted the gunners in loading, firing, and sponging the guns.
See Matte.
A shrike or butcher bird; -- written also matagasse.
A subterranean repository for wheat.

entry.ety: F. matte; cf. F. mat, masc., matte, fem., faint, dull, dim; -- said of metals. See Mate checkmate

sn.def: A partly reduced copper sulphide, obtained by alternately roasting and melting copper ore in separating the metal from associated iron ores, and called coarse metal fine metal, etc., according to the grade of fineness. On the exterior it is dark brown or black, but on a fresh surface is yellow or bronzy in color.
A dead or dull finish, as in gilding where the gold leaf is not burnished, or in painting where the surface is purposely deprived of gloss.

entry.def: Having a dull, lusterless surface finish; opposed to glossy or polished; as, a matte photograph; a proof coin with matte figures on a polished field.

cs.cd: glass ornamented with figures on a dull ground.

entry.def: Having a dull surface; lusterless; unburnished; same as matte; as, matted gold leaf or gilding.

sn.def: Covered with a mat or mats; as, a matted floor.
Tangled closely together; having its parts adhering closely together; as, matted hair.

entry.note: ☞ Matter is usually divided by philosophical writers into three kinds or classes: solid liquid, and gaseous. Solid substances are those whose parts firmly cohere and resist impression, as wood or stone. Liquids have free motion among their parts, and easily yield to impression, as water and wine. Gaseous substances are elastic fluids, called vapors and gases, as air and oxygen gas.
entry.cs:
Dead matter Print type which has been used, or which is not to be used, in printing, and is ready for distribution. Live matter Print type set up, but not yet printed from.
Matter in bar Matter of fact . See under Bar, and Fact. Matter of record anything recorded.
Upon the matterorUpon the whole matter
considering the whole; taking all things into view; all things considered.
entry.ety: OE. matere, F. matière, fr. L. materia; perh. akin to L. mater mother. Cf. Mother Madeira Material

sn.def: That of which anything is composed; constituent substance; material; the material or substantial part of anything; the constituent elements of conception; that into which a notion may be analyzed; the essence; the pith; the embodiment.
sn.q: He is the matter of virtue.

sn.def: That of which the sensible universe and all existent bodies are composed; anything which has extension, occupies space, or is perceptible by the senses; body; substance.

That with regard to, or about which, anything takes place or is done; the thing aimed at, treated of, or treated; subject of action, discussion, consideration, feeling, complaint, legal action, or the like; theme.
sn.q: If themattershould be tried by duel.
Son of God, Savior of men! Thy name Shall be the copious matter of my song.
Every great matter they shall bring unto thee, but every small matter they shall judge.

sn.def: That which one has to treat, or with which one has to do; concern; affair; business.
sn.q: To help the matter, the alchemists call in many vanities out of astrology.
Some young female seems to have carried matters so far, that she is ripe for asking advice.

sn.def: Affair worthy of account; thing of consequence; importance; significance; moment; -- chiefly in the phrases what matter? no matter, and the like.
sn.q: A prophet some, and some a poet, cry; No matter which, so neither of them lie.

sn.def: Inducing cause or occasion, especially of anything disagreeable or distressing; difficulty; trouble.
sn.q: And this is the matter why interpreters upon that passage in Hosea will not consent it to be a true story, that the prophet took a harlot to wife.

sn.def: Amount; quantity; portion; space; -- often indefinite.
sn.q: Away he goes, . . . a matter of seven miles.
I have thoughts to tarry a small matter.
No small matter of British forces were commanded over sea the year before.

sn.def: Substance excreted from living animal bodies; that which is thrown out or discharged in a tumor, boil, or abscess; pus; purulent substance.
That which is permanent, or is supposed to be given, and in or upon which changes are effected by psychological or physical processes and relations; -- opposed to form.
Written manuscript, or anything to be set in type; copy; also, type set up and ready to be used, or which has been used, in printing.
sn.q: Waller, with Sir William Balfour, exceeded in horse, but were, upon the whole matter, equal in foot.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mattered; p. pr. & vb. n. Mattering

sn.def: To be of importance; to import; to signify.
sn.q: It matters not how they were called.

sn.def: To form pus or matter, as an abscess; to maturate.
sn.q: Each slight soremattereth.

entry.def: To regard as important; to take account of; to care for.
entry.q: He did not matter cold nor hunger.

entry.note: According to WordNet, 14,780 feet high
entry.def: A mountain in Italy and Switzerland, 14,690 feet high.

sn.def: Not being, or having, matter; as, matterless spirits.
Unimportant; immaterial.

entry.def: Adhering to facts; not turning aside from absolute realities; not fanciful or imaginative; commonplace; dry.

sn.def: Generating or containing pus; purulent.
Full of substance or matter; important.

entry.def: A small genus sometimes included in genus Onoclea; in some classifications both genera are placed in Polypodiaceae.
Saint Matthew, a disciple of Jesus; author of the first Gospel.
entry.syn: Saint Matthew, St. Matthew, Saint Matthew the Apostle, Levi.

entry.def: A genus of Old World plants grown as ornamentals.

sn.def: The act of interweaving or tangling together so as to make a mat; the process of becoming matted.

An American clupeoid fish (Clupea mediocris), similar to the shad in habits and appearance, but smaller and less esteemed for food; -- called also hickory shad tailor shad fall herring, and shad herring.

cs.cd: A variety of mattress{1} having springs inside to provide a flexible support; it is considered more comfortable than a stuffed mattress.

entry.ety: OF. materas, F. matelas, LL. matratium; cf. Sp. & Pg. almadraque, Pr. almatrac; all from Ar. maṭrah a place where anything is thrown, what is thrown under something, fr. ṭaraha to throw

sn.def: A large pad stuffed with hair, moss, or other suitable soft material, and quilted or otherwise fastened, used as or in a bed, to support the human body while lying down.

entry.ety: L. maturans, p. pr. See Maturate

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Maturated; p. pr. & vb. n. Maturating
entry.ety: L. maturatus, p. p. of maturare to make ripe, fr. maturus ripe, mature. See Mature v. & a.

sn.def: To bring to ripeness or maturity; to ripen.
sn.q: A tree may be maturated artificially.

sn.def: To promote the perfect suppuration of (an abscess).

entry.def: To ripen; to become mature; specifically, to suppurate.

entry.ety: L. maturatio a hastening: cf. F. maturation
entry.def: The process of bringing, or of coming, to maturity; hence, specifically, the process of suppurating perfectly; the formation of pus or matter.
Conducing to ripeness or maturity; hence, conducing to suppuration.
A remedy promoting maturation; a maturant.

entry.usage: Mature Ripe. Both words describe fullness of growth. Mature brings to view the progressiveness of the process; ripe indicates the result. We speak of a thing as mature when thinking of the successive stayes through which it has passed; as ripe, when our attention is directed merely to its state. A mature judgment; mature consideration; ripe fruit; a ripe scholar.
entry.ety: L. maturus; prob. akin to E. matin

sn.def: Brought by natural process to completeness of growth and development; fitted by growth and development for any function, action, or state, appropriate to its kind; full-grown; ripe.
sn.q: Now is love mature in ear.
How shall I meet, or how accost, the sage, Unskilled in speech, nor yet mature of age?

sn.def: Completely worked out; fully digested or prepared; ready for action; made ready for destined application or use; perfected; as, a mature plan.
sn.q: This lies glowing, . . . and is almost mature for the violent breaking out.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a condition of full development; as, a man of mature years.
Come to, or in a state of, completed suppuration.
sn.syn: Ripe; perfect; completed; prepared; digested; ready.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Matured; p. pr. & vb. n. Maturing
entry.def: To bring or hasten to maturity; to promote ripeness in; to ripen; to complete; as, to mature one's plans.

sn.def: To advance toward maturity; to become ripe; as, wine matures by age; the judgment matures by age and experience.
Hence, to become due, as a note.

cs.cd: a dyestuff produced artificially by the oxidation of commercial aniline, and the first discovered of the so-called coal-tar, or aniline dyes. It consists of the sulphate of mauveïne, and is a dark brown or bronze amorphous powder, which dissolves to a beatiful purple color. Called also aniline purple violine Perkin's mauve, etc.

entries.entry:
‖Max*il"la ☞ There are usually two pairs in Crustacea and one pair in insects. In certain insects they are not used as jaws, but may form suctorial organs. See Illust. under Lepidoptera, and Diptera. n.; pl.Maxillæ #. L., dim. of mala jaw, jawbone
Anat
The bone of either the upper or the under jaw.
The bone, or principal bone, of the upper jaw, the bone of the lower jaw being the mandible. Now commonly used in this restricted sense
Zoöl One of the lower or outer jaws of arthropods.

entry.ety: L. maxillaris, fr. maxilla jawbone, jaw: cf. F. maxillaire

sn.def: Pertaining to either the upper or the lower jaw, but now usually applied to the upper jaw only.

def2.def: The principal maxillary bone; the maxilla.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a maxilla.

entry.def: Having the form, or structure, of a maxilla.
One of the mouth appendages of Crustacea, situated next behind the maxillæ. Crabs have three pairs, but many of the lower Crustacea have but one pair of them. Called also jawfoot, and foot jaw.
Pertaining to the maxilla and mandible; as, the maxillo-mandibular nerve.
Pertaining to the maxillary and palatine regions of the skull; as, the maxillo-palatine process of the maxilla. Also used as n.
Pertaining to the maxillary and turbinal regions of the skull.

def2.def: The maxillo-turbinal, or inferior turbinate, bone.

entry.ety: F. maxime, L. maximasc. sententia), the greatest sentence, proposition, or axiom, i. e., of the greatest weight or authority, fem. fr. maximus greatest, superl. of magnus great. See Magnitude, and cf. Maximum

entries.entry:
Max"i*mum
Maximum thermometer a thermometer that registers the highest degree of temperature attained in a given time, or since its last adjustment.
n.; pl.Maxima #. L., neut. from maximus the greatest. See Maxim
The greatest quantity or value attainable in a given case; or, the greatest value attained by a quantity which first increases and then begins to decrease; the highest point or degree; -- opposed to minimum. Good legislation is the art of conducting a nation to the maximum of happiness, and the minimum of misery.

entry.def: Greatest in quantity or highest in degree attainable or attained; as, a maximum consumption of fuel; maximum pressure; maximum heat.
A cgs unit of magnetic flux, abbreviated Mx; it is equal to the magnetic flux passing through one sqaure centimeter which is normal to a magnetic field of one gauss.

cs.cd: are used as equivalent to possibly perhaps maybe by chance peradventure. See 1st Maybe.

entry.ety: AS. pres. mæg I am able, pret. meahte mihte; akin to D. mogen, G. mögen, OHG. mugan magan, Icel. mega, Goth. magan, Russ. moche. √103. Cf. Dismay Main strength, Might. The old imp. mought is obsolete, except as a provincial word
entry.def: An auxiliary verb qualifying the meaning of another verb,
Ability, competency, or possibility; -- now oftener expressed by can.

For what he [the kingmay do is of two kinds; what he may do as just, and what he may do as possible.
For of all sad words of tongue or pen The saddest are these: “It might have been.”

entry.cs:
Italian may Bot a shrubby species of Spiræa Spiræa hypericifolia) with many clusters of small white flowers along the slender branches. May apple Bot the fruit of an American plant (Podophyllum peltatum). Also, the plant itself (popularly called mandrake), which has two lobed leaves, and bears a single egg-shaped fruit at the forking. The root and leaves, used in medicine, are powerfully drastic.
May beetle May bug
Zoöl any one of numerous species of large lamellicorn beetles that appear in the winged state in May. They belong to Melolontha, and allied genera. Called also June beetle. May Day the first day of May; -- celebrated in the rustic parts of England by the crowning of a May queen with a garland, and by dancing about a May pole. May dew the morning dew of the first day of May, to which magical properties were attributed. May flower Bot a plant that flowers in May; also, its blossom. See Mayflower, in the vocabulary. May fly Zoöl any species of Ephemera, and allied genera; -- so called because the mature flies of many species appear in May. See Ephemeral fly, under Ephemeral. May game any May-day sport. May lady the queen or lady of May, in old May games. May lily Bot the lily of the valley (Convallaria majalis). May pole. See Maypole in the Vocabulary. May queen a girl or young woman crowned queen in the sports of May Day. May thorn the hawthorn.

The name (in Vedantic philosphy) for the doctrine of the unreality of matter, called, in English, idealism; hence, nothingness; vanity; illusion.

entries.entry:
Ma"ya mä"yȧ prop. n.; pl.Maya or Mayas.
the Indian people occupying the area of Veracruz, Chiapas, Tabasco, Campeche, and Yucatan, together with a part of Guatemala and a part of Salvador. The Maya peoples are dark, short, and brachycephalic, and at the time of the discovery had attained a higher grade of culture than any other American people. They cultivated a variety of crops, were expert in the manufacture and dyeing of cotton fabrics, used cacao as a medium of exchange, and were workers of gold, silver, and copper. Their architecture comprised elaborately carved temples and palaces, and they possessed a superior calendar, and a developed system of hieroglyphic writing, with records said to go back to about 700 a. d.
the language of the Mayas.

entry.def: A small genus of delicate mossy bog plants having white or violet flowers.

sn.def: Designating, or pertaining to, an American Indian linguistic stock occupying the Mexican States of Veracruz, Chiapas, Tabasco, Campeche, and Yucatan, together with a part of Guatemala and a part of El Salvador. See 2nd Maya.

entry.ety: OE. maire, F. maire, fr. L. major greater, higher, nobler, compar. of magnus great; cf. Sp. mayor. See Major, and cf. Merino
entry.def: The chief magistrate of a city or borough; the chief administrative officer of a municipal corporation. In some American cities there is a city court of which the major is chief judge. The post is usually elective, its holder chosen by the electorate of the entire city.

entry.def: The conductor of a mule team; also, a head shepherd.

entry.note: ☞ In methinks me is properly in the dative case, and the verb is impersonal, the construction being, it appears to me. In early use me was often placed before forms of the verb to be with an adjective; as, me were lief.
entry.ety: AS. mē, dat. & acc., mec, acc. only ; akin to D. mij, G. mich, Icel. & Goth. mik, L. me, Gr. me` 'eme`, Skr. mā mām. √187. Cf. 2d Mine
entry.def: The person speaking, regarded as an object; myself; a pronoun of the first person used as the objective and dative case of the pronoum I; as, he struck me; he gave me the money, or he gave the money to me; he got me a hat, or he got a hat for me.
entry.q: Me rather had my heart might frrl your love Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy.

entry.def: To skulk; to cower. See Mich.
An uxorious, effeminate, or spiritless man.

entry.ety: OE. mede, AS. meodo; akin to D. mede, G. met meth, OHG. metu mitu, Icel. mjöðr, Dan. miöd, Sw. mjöd, Russ. med', Lith. midus, W. medd, Gr. me`qy wine, Skr. madhu honey, a sweet drink, as adj., sweet. √270. Cf. Metheglin

sn.def: A fermented drink made of water and honey with malt, yeast, etc.; metheglin; hydromel.
A drink composed of sirup of sarsaparilla or other flavoring extract, and water. It is sometimes charged with carbonic acid gas.

entry.def: A meadow.
entry.q: A mede All full of freshe flowers, white and reede.
To fertile vales and dewy meads My weary, wandering steps he leads.

entry.ety: AS. meady; akin to mǣd, and to G. matte; prob. also to E. mow. See Mow to cut (grass), and cf. 2d Mead

sn.def: A tract of low or level land producing grass which is mown for hay; any field on which grass is grown for hay.
Low land covered with coarse grass or rank herbage near rives and in marshy places by the sea; as, the salt meadows near Newark Bay.

entry.note: ☞ For many names of plants compounded with meadow, see the particular word in the Vocabulary.
entry.cs: Meadow beauty. Bot Same as Deergrass. Meadow foxtail Bot a valuable pasture grass (Alopecurus pratensis) resembling timothy, but with softer spikes. Meadow hay a coarse grass, or true sedge, growing in uncultivated swamp or river meadow; -- used as fodder or bedding for cattle, packing for ice, etc. Local, U. S Meadow hen. Zoöl The American bittern. See Stake-driver. The American coot (Fulica). The clapper rail. Meadow mouse Zoöl any mouse of the genus Arvicola, as the common American species Arvicola riparia; -- called also field mouse, and field vole. Meadow mussel Zoöl an American ribbed mussel (Modiola plicatula), very abundant in salt marshes. Meadow ore Min bog-iron ore , a kind of limonite. Meadow parsnip. Bot See under Parsnip. Meadow pink. Bot See under Pink. Meadow pipit Zoöl a small singing bird of the genus Anthus, as Anthus pratensis, of Europe. Meadow rue Bot a delicate early plant, of the genus Thalictrum, having compound leaves and numerous white flowers. There are many species. Meadow saffron. Bot See under Saffron. Meadow sage. Bot See under Sage. Meadow saxifrage Bot an umbelliferous plant of Europe (Silaus pratensis), somewhat resembling fennel. Meadow snipe Zoöl the common or jack snipe.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a meadow; of the nature of a meadow; produced, growing, or living in, a meadow.
entry.q: Fatmeadowground.

entry.def: Any of various grasses that thrive in the presence of abundant moisture, especially those of the genus Poa, common in meadows, and of great value for hay and for pasture. See Grass.
Any species of Sturnella, a genus of North American songbirds allied to the starlings. The common species (Sturnella magna) has a yellow breast with a black crescent.

The name of several plants of the genus Spiræa, especially the white- or pink-flowered Spiræa salicifolia, a low European and American shrub, and the herbaceous Spiræa Ulmaria, which has fragrant white flowers in compound cymes.
Of or pertaining to meadows; resembling, or consisting of, meadow.

entry.ety: OE. merge, F. maigre, L. macer; akin to D. & G. mager, Icel. magr, and prob. to Gr. makro`s long. Cf. Emaciate Maigre

sn.def: Destitue of, or having little, flesh; lean.
sn.q: Meager were his looks; Sharp misery had worn him to the bones.

entry.sn:
Destitute of richness, fertility, strength, or the like; defective in quantity, or poor in quality; poor; barren; scanty in ideas; wanting strength of diction or affluence of imagery; as, meager resources; meager fare. Opposite of ample. wns=1Narrower terms: exiguous] [Narrower terms: hardscrabble, marginal] [Narrower terms: measly, miserable, paltry
Meagersoil. meagre, meagerly, scanty. Of secular habits and meager religious belief. His education had been but meager.

sn.def: Dry and harsh to the touch, as chalk.
less than a desirable amount; -- of items distributed from a larger supply.
sn.syn: Thin; lean; lank; gaunt; starved; hungry; poor; emaciated; scanty; barren.

entry.def: To make lean.
same as meager, 2. Opposite of ample.
Poorly; thinly.
The state or quality of being meager; leanness; scantiness; barrenness.
A large European sciænoid fish (Sciæna umbra or Sciæna aquila), having white bloodless flesh. It is valued as a food fish.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. mēce sword, OS. māki, Icel. mækir
entry.def: A hook with a long handle.

cs.cd: the tool with which old oakum is picked out of a vessel's seams.

entry.def: The process of picking out the oakum from the seams of a vessel which is to be recalked.

entry.ety: OE. mele, AS. mǣl part, portion, portion of time; akin to E. meal a repast. Cf. Piecemeal
entry.def: A part; a fragment; a portion.

entry.ety: OE. mel; akin to E. meal a part, and to D. maal time, meal, G. mal time, mahl meal, Icel. māl measure, time, meal, Goth. mēl time, and to E. measure. See Measure
entry.def: The portion of food taken at a particular time for the satisfaction of appetite; the quantity usually taken at one time with the purpose of satisfying hunger; a repast; the act or time of eating a meal; as, the traveler has not eaten a good meal for a week; there was silence during the meal.
entry.q: What strange fish Hath made his meal on thee?

cs.cd: the adult of the meal worm. See Meal worm, below.
a lepidopterous insect (Asopia farinalis), the larvæ of which feed upon meal, flour, etc.
the larva of a beetle (Tenebrio molitor) which infests granaries, bakehouses, etc., and is very injurious to flour and meal.

entry.ety: OE. mele, AS. melu melo; akin to D. meel, G. mehl, OHG. melo, Icel. mjöl, SW. mjöl, Dan. meel, also to D. malen to grind, G. mahlen, OHG., OS., & Goth. malan, Icel. mala, W. malu, L. molere, Gr. my`lh mill, and E. mill. √108. Cf. Mill Mold soil, Mole an animal, Immolate Molar

sn.def: Grain (esp. maize, rye, or oats) that is coarsely ground and unbolted; also, a kind of flour made from beans, pease, etc.; sometimes, any flour, esp. if coarse.
Any substance that is coarsely pulverized like meal, but not granulated.
To sprinkle with, or as with, meal.
To pulverize; as, mealed powder.

entry.def: Maize or Indian corn; -- the common name in South Africa.
The quality or state of being mealy.
See Mealy-mouthed.

A program that delivers hot meals to persons, such as the elderly or disabled, who are confined to their homes and unable to cook for themselves; also, the meals thus delivered. Such programs are usually conducted by governmental or charitable organizations.
The usual time of eating a meal.

sn.def: Having the qualities of meal; resembling meal; soft, dry, and friable; easily reduced to a condition resembling meal; as, a mealy potato.
Overspread with something that resembles meal; as, the mealy wings of an insect.

entry.def: Any of several homopteran scale insects (as, Coccus adonidum, and related species of the families Pseudococcidae and Eriococcidae), that cover themselves with a white powderlike or cottony wax secretion. They are common plant-eating pests in hothouses and are also destructive of fruit trees.
Using soft words; not straightforward; plausible; affectedly or timidly delicate of speech; speaking deviously; unwilling to tell the truth in plain language. Opposite of frank or blunt.
entry.q: Mealy-mouthedphilanthropies.
She was a fool to be mealy-mouthed where nature speaks so plain.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Meant mĕnt; p. pr. & vb. n. Meaning
entry.ety: OE. menen, AS. mǣnan to recite, tell, intend, wish; akin to OS. mēnian to have in mind, mean, D. meenen, G. meinen, OHG. meinan, Icel. meina, Sw. mena, Dan. mene, and to E. mind. √104. See Mind, and cf. Moan

sn.def: To have in the mind, as a purpose, intention, etc.; to intend; to purpose; to design; as, what do you mean to do?
sn.q: What mean ye by this service ?
Ye thought evil against me; but God meant it unto good.
I am not a Spaniard To say that it is yours and not to mean it.

sn.def: To signify; to indicate; to import; to denote.
sn.q: What mean these seven ewe lambs ?
Go ye, and learn what that meaneth.

entry.def: To have a purpose or intention.
entry.mark: Rare, except in the phrase to mean well, or ill

entry.note: ☞ Mean is sometimes used in the formation of compounds, the sense of which is obvious without explanation; as, meanborn, mean-looking, etc.
entry.ety: OE. mene, AS. mǣne wicked; akin to mān, a., wicked, n., wickedness, OS. mēn wickedness, OHG. mein, G. meineid perjury, Icel. mein harm, hurt, and perh. to AS. gemǣne common, general, D. gemeen, G. gemein, Goth. gamáins, and L. communis. The AS. gemǣne prob. influenced the meaning

sn.def: Destitute of distinction or eminence; common; low; vulgar; humble.
sn.q: Ofmeanparentage.
The mean man boweth down, and the great man humbleth himself.

sn.def: Wanting dignity of mind; low-minded; base; destitute of honor; spiritless; as, a mean motive.
sn.q: Can you imagine I so mean could prove, To save my life by changing of my love ?

sn.def: Of little value or account; worthy of little or no regard; contemptible; despicable.
sn.q: The Roman legions and great Cæsar found Our fathers no mean foes.

sn.def: Of poor quality; as, mean fare.
Penurious; stingy; close-fisted; illiberal; as, mean hospitality.
sn.syn: Base; ignoble; abject; beggarly; wretched; degraded; degenerate; vulgar; vile; servile; menial; spiritless; groveling; slavish; dishonorable; disgraceful; shameful; despicable; contemptible; paltry; sordid. See Base.

entry.cs:
Mean distanceof a planet from the sunAstron the average of the distances throughout one revolution of the planet, equivalent to the semi-major axis of the orbit. Mean error Math. Phys the average error of a number of observations found by taking the mean value of the positive and negative errors without regard to sign.
Mean-square errororError of the mean square
Math. Phys the error the square of which is the mean of the squares of all the errors; -- called also, mean square deviation mean error. Mean line. Crystallog Same as Bisectrix. Mean noon noon as determined by mean time. Mean proportionalbetween two numbersMath the square root of their product. Mean sun a fictitious sun supposed to move uniformly in the equator so as to be on the meridian each day at mean noon. Mean time time as measured by an equable motion, as of a perfect clock, or as reckoned on the supposition that all the days of the year are of a mean or uniform length, in contradistinction from apparent time, or that actually indicated by the sun, and from sidereal time, or that measured by the stars.
entry.ety: OE. mene, OF. meiien, F. moyen, fr. L. medianus that is in the middle, fr. medius; akin to E. mid. See Mid

sn.def: Occupying a middle position; middle; being about midway between extremes.
sn.q: Being of middle age and a mean stature.

sn.def: Intermediate in excellence of any kind.
sn.q: According to the fittest style of lofty, mean, or lowly.

sn.def: Average; having an intermediate value between two extremes, or between the several successive values of a variable quantity during one cycle of variation; as, mean distance; mean motion; mean solar day.

entry.note: ☞ In this sense the word is usually employed in the plural form means, and often with a singular attribute or predicate, as if a singular noun.

cs.cd: certainly; without fail; as, go, by all means .
in any way; possibly; at all.
cs.q: If by any means I might attain to the resurrection of the dead.
cs.mcol: By no meansorBy no manner of means
cs.cd: not at all; certainly not; not in any degree.
cs.q: The wine on this side of the lake is by no means so good as that on the other.

sn.def: That which is mean, or intermediate, between two extremes of place, time, or number; the middle point or place; middle rate or degree; mediocrity; medium; absence of extremes or excess; moderation; measure.
sn.q: But to speak in a mean, the virtue of prosperity is temperance; the virtue of adversity is fortitude.
There is a mean in all things.
The extremes we have mentioned, between which the wellinstracted Christian holds the mean, are correlatives.

sn.def: A quantity having an intermediate value between several others, from which it is derived, and of which it expresses the resultant value; usually, unless otherwise specified, it is the simple average, formed by adding the quantities together and dividing by their number, which is called an arithmetical mean. A geometrical mean is the nth root of the product of the n quantities being averaged.
That through which, or by the help of which, an end is attained; something tending to an object desired; intermediate agency or measure; necessary condition or coagent; instrument.
sn.q: Their virtuous conversation was a mean to work the conversion of the heathen to Christ.
You may be able, by this mean, to review your own scientific acquirements.
Philosophical doubt is not an end, but a mean.
By this means he had them more at vantage.
What other means is left unto us.

sn.def: Resources; property, revenue, or the like, considered as the condition of easy livelihood, or an instrumentality at command for effecting any purpose; disposable force or substance.
sn.q: Your means are very slender, and your waste is great.

sn.def: A part, whether alto or tenor, intermediate between the soprano and base; a middle part.
sn.q: The mean is drowned with your unruly base.

sn.def: Meantime; meanwhile.
A mediator; a go-between.
sn.q: He wooeth her by means and by brokage.

entry.ety: L. Maeander, orig., a river in Phrygia, proverbial for its many windings, Gr. �: cf. F. méandre

sn.def: A winding, crooked, or involved course; as, the meanders of the veins and arteries.
sn.q: While lingering rivers in meanders glide.

sn.def: A tortuous or intricate movement.
Fretwork. See Fret.

entry.def: To wind, turn, or twist; to make flexuous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Meandered; p. pr. & vb. n. Meandering
entry.def: To wind or turn in a course or passage; to be intricate.
entry.q: Five miles meandering with a mazy motion Through wood and dale the sacred river ran.

entry.def: Winding; having many turns.
A genus of corals with meandering grooves and ridges, including the brain corals.
Winding; flexuous.

sn.def: That which is meant or intended; intent; purpose; aim; object; as, a mischievous meaning was apparent.
sn.q: If there be any good meaning towards you.

sn.def: That which is signified, whether by act lanquage; signification; sense; import; as, the meaning of a hint.
Sense; power of thinking.

entries.entry: meaningful adj. Having a meaning or purpose; having significance; as, a meaningful explanation; a meaningful discussion; a meaningful pause; to live a meaningful life. Opposite of meaningless.Narrower terms: comprehensible, understandable; indicative, significative, suggestive ; meaty, substantive ; purposeful Also See: purposeful significant important.

entry.def: the quality of having great meaning or value.

entries.entry: meaningless adj. having no meaning; of no value; as, a meaningless endeavor; a meaningless life; a meaningless explanation. Opposite of meaningful.Narrower terms: insignificant ; mindless, unmeaning ; nonsense(prenominal), nonsensical ; pointless, purposeless Also See: insignificant unimportant purposeless unimportant.

entry.def: Moderately.
entry.q: A man meanly learned himself, but not meanly affectioned to set forward learning in others.

entry.def: In a mean manner; unworthily; basely; poorly; ungenerously.
entry.q: While the heaven-born child All meanly wrapt in the rude manger lies.
Would you meanly thus rely On power you know I must obey ?
We can not bear to have others think meanly of them [our kindred].

sn.def: The condition, or quality, of being mean; want of excellence; poorness; lowness; baseness; sordidness; stinginess.
sn.q: This figure is of a later date, by the meanness of the workmanship.

sn.def: A mean act; as, to be guilty of meanness .
Of a mean spirit; petty; small-minded; base; groveling; -- of people.
Done for malevolent reasons; -- of deeds and actions.
sn.syn: base, contemptible, currish, mean, meanspirited, scurvy.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Mean.
The intervening time; as, in the meantimeor mean time .
In the intervening time; during the interval.
A boundary. See Mere.
Five hundred; as, a mease of herrings.

entry.ety: OE. meselrie, OF. mesellerie. See 1st Measle
entry.def: Leprosy.

entry.ety: OE. mesel, OF. mesel, LL. misellus, L. misellus unfortunate, dim. of miser. See Miser
entry.def: A leper.
A tapeworm larva. See 2d Measles, 4.
Infected or spotted with measles, as pork.
Leprosy; also, a leper.

entries.entry:
Mea"sles
German measles A mild contagious viral disease, which may cause birth defects if contracted by a pregnant woman during early pregnancy; also called rubella.
n.; pl. in form, but used as singular in senses 1, 2, & 3. D. mazelen; akin to G. masern, pl., and E. mazer, and orig. meaning, little spots. See Mazer
Med A contagious viral febrile disorder commencing with catarrhal symptoms, and marked by the appearance on the third day of an eruption of distinct red circular spots, which coalesce in a crescentic form, are slightly raised above the surface, and after the fourth day of the eruption gradually decline; rubeola. It is a common childhood disease.
Measles commences with the ordinary symptoms of fever.
Veter. Med A disease of cattle and swine in which the flesh is filled with the embryos of different varieties of the tapeworm.
A disease of trees. Obs
pl. Zoöl The larvæ of any tapeworm (Tænia) in the cysticerus stage, when contained in meat. Called also bladder worms.

sn.def: Infected with measles.
Containing larval tapeworms; -- said of pork and beef.
Contemptibly small in quantity; meager; absurdly insufficient or bad; as, a measly few dollars for all that work.

entry.def: the quality of being measurable.

entry.ety: F. mesurable, L. mensurabilis. See Measure, and cf. Mensurable

sn.def: Capable of being measured; susceptible of mensuration or computation.
Moderate; temperate; not excessive.
sn.q: Of his diet measurable was he.
Yet do it measurably, as it becometh Christians.

cs.cd: measure of length; the measure of lines or distances.
the measure of liquids.
the measure of superficial area of surfaces in square units, as inches, feet, miles, etc.
to have harsh treatment meted out to one; to be harshly or oppressively dealt with.
to make preparations; to provide means.
to measure one, as for a garment; hence, to form an opinion of one's disposition, character, ability, etc.
to dance in the style so called. See 9 .

entry.ety: OE. mesure, F. mesure, L. mensura, fr. metiri mensus, to measure; akin to metrum poetical measure, Gr. me`tron, E. meter. Cf. Immense Mensuration Mete to measure

sn.def: A standard of dimension; a fixed unit of quantity or extent; an extent or quantity in the fractions or multiples of which anything is estimated and stated; hence, a rule by which anything is adjusted or judged.
An instrument by means of which size or quantity is measured, as a graduated line, rod, vessel, or the like.
sn.q: False ells and measures be brought all clean adown.

sn.def: The dimensions or capacity of anything, reckoned according to some standard; size or extent, determined and stated; estimated extent; as, to take one's measure for a coat.
sn.q: The measure thereof is longer than the earth, and broader than the sea.

sn.def: The contents of a vessel by which quantity is measured; a quantity determined by a standard; a stated or limited quantity or amount.
sn.q: It is like leaven which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal.

sn.def: Extent or degree not excessive or beyong bounds; moderation; due restraint; esp. in the phrases, in measure; with measure; without or beyond measure.
sn.q: Hell hath enlarged herself, and opened her mouth without measure.

sn.def: Determined extent, not to be exceeded; limit; allotted share, as of action, influence, ability, or the like; due proportion.
sn.q: Lord, make me to know mine end, and the measure of my days.

sn.def: The quantity determined by measuring, especially in buying and selling; as, to give good or full measure .
Undefined quantity; extent; degree.
sn.q: There is a great measure of discretion to be used in the performance of confession.

entry.sn:
Regulated division of movement: Dancing A regulated movement corresponding to the time in which the accompanying music is performed; but, especially, a slow and stately dance, like the minuet.
Mus1The group or grouping of beats, caused by the regular recurrence of accented beats.2The space between two bars. See Beat Triple Quadruple Sextuple Compound time, under Compound a., and Figure.
Poetry The manner of ordering and combining the quantities, or long and short syllables; meter; rhythm; hence, a foot; as, a poem in iambic measure .

sn.def: A number which is contained in a given number a number of times without a remainder; as in the phrases, the common measure, the greatest common measure, etc., of two or more numbers; a denominator. See common denominator under denominator.
A step or definite part of a progressive course or policy; a means to an end; an act designed for the accomplishment of an object; as, political measures; prudent measures; an inefficient measure.
sn.q: His majesty found what wrong measures he had taken in the conferring that trust, and lamented his error.

sn.def: The act of measuring; measurement.
Beds or strata; as, coal measures; lead measures.
sn.q: Say to her, we have measured many milesTo tread a measure with her on this grass.

cs.cd: to try another's skill in the use of the sword; hence, figuratively, to match one's abilities against an antagonist's.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Measured; p. pr. & vb. n. Measuring
entry.ety: F. mesurer, L. mensurare. See Measure n.

sn.def: To ascertain by use of a measuring instrument; to compute or ascertain the extent, quantity, dimensions, or capacity of, by a certain rule or standard; to take the dimensions of; hence, to estimate; to judge of; to value; to appraise.
sn.q: Great are thy works, Jehovah, infinite Thy power! what thought can measure thee?

sn.def: To serve as the measure of; as, the thermometer measures changes of temperature.
To pass throught or over in journeying, as if laying off and determining the distance.
sn.q: A true devoted pilgrim is not weary To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps.

sn.def: To adjust by a rule or standard.
sn.q: To secure a contented spirit, measure your desires by your fortunes, not your fortunes by your desires.

sn.def: To allot or distribute by measure; to set off or apart by measure; -- often with out or off.
sn.q: With what measure ye mete, it shall be measured to you again.
That portion of eternity which is called time, measured out by the sun.

sn.def: To make a measurement or measurements.
To result, or turn out, on measuring; as, the grain measures well; the pieces measure unequally.

To be of a certain size or quantity, or to have a certain length, breadth, or thickness, or a certain capacity according to a standard measure; as, cloth measures three fourths of a yard; a tree measures three feet in diameter.

entry.def: Regulated or determined by a standard; hence, equal; uniform; graduated; limited; moderated; as, he walked with measured steps; he expressed himself in no measured terms.
Without measure; unlimited; immeasurable.
entry.q: Where Alf, the sacred river ran, Through canyons measureless to man, Down to a hidden sea.
entry.syn: Boundless; limitless; endless; unbounded; unlimited; vast; immense; infinite; immeasurable.

sn.def: The act or result of measuring; mensuration; as, measurement is required.
The extent, size, capacity, amount. or quantity ascertained by measuring; as, its measurement is five acres.

entry.def: One who measures; one whose occupation or duty is to measure commondities in market.

cs.cd: a faucet which permits only a given quantity of liquid to pass each time it is opened, or one by means of which the liquid which passes can be measured.

the larva of any geometrid moth. They are so called because they move by a process in which they first pull the rear legs forward toward their front legs, forming a loop which resembles the process of measuring with a tape measure. The motion is completed by subsequently moving the front legs forward to an advanced position. See Geometrid.

entry.def: Used in, or adapted for, ascertaining measurements, or dividing by measure.

entry.cs: Meat biscuit. See under Biscuit. Meat earth Mining vegetable mold. Raymond. Meat fly. Zoöl See Flesh fly, under Flesh. Meat offering Script an offering of food, esp. of a cake made of flour with salt and oil. To go to meat to go to a meal. Obs To sit at meat to sit at the table in taking food.
entry.ety: OE. mete, AS. mete; akin to OS. mat meti, D. met hashed meat, G. mettwurst sausage, OHG. maz food, Icel. matr, Sw. mat, Dan. mad, Goth. mats. Cf. Mast fruit, Mush

sn.def: Food, in general; anything eaten for nourishment, either by man or beast. Hence, the edible part of anything; as, the meat of a lobster, a nut, or an egg.
sn.q: And God said, Behold, I have given you every herb bearing seed, . . . to you it shall be for meat.
Every moving thing that liveth shall be meat for you.

sn.def: The flesh of animals used as food; esp., animal muscle; as, a breakfast of bread and fruit without meat .
Dinner; the chief meal.

entry.def: To supply with food.
entry.q: His shield well lined, his horses meated well.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a meatus; resembling a meatus.

sn.def: Fed; fattened.
Having (such) meat; -- used chiefly in composition; as, thick-meated .

entry.def: A sweet liquor; mead.
Quality of being meaty.
Having no meat; without food.
entry.q: “Leave these beggars meatless.”

entry.def: A speculum for examining a natural passage, as the urethra.
An instrument for cutting into the urethra so as to enlarge its orifice.

entries.entry: ‖Me*a"tus n. sing. & pl.; E. pl.Meatuses. L., a going, passage, fr. meare to go Anat A natural passage or canal; as, the external auditory meatus . See Illust. of Ear.

entry.def: Abounding in meat.
The sea mew.
See Mew, to cry as a cat.
See Mewl, and Miaul.
See 1st Measle.
Falling in small drops; mistling; mizzing.
See Moebles.
A rope of hair or of maguey fiber, for tying horses, etc.
Of or pertaining to Mecca, in Arabia.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Mecca.

entry.ety: F. mécanique mechanics. See Mechanic a.

sn.def: The art of the application of the laws of motion or force to construction.

A mechanician; an artisan; an artificer; one who practices any mechanic art; one skilled or employed in shaping and uniting materials, as wood, metal, etc., into any kind of structure, machine, or other object, requiring the use of tools, or instruments. Also, a technician who maintains or repairs machinery; as, an auto mechanic .
sn.q: An art quite lost with our mechanics.

entry.ety: F. mécanique, L. mechanicus, Gr. mhchaniko`s, fr. mhchanh` a machine. See Machine

sn.def: Having to do with the application of the laws of motion in the art of constructing or making things; of or pertaining to mechanics; mechanical; as, the mechanic arts.
sn.q: Thesemechanicphilosophers.
Mechanic slaves, With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a mechanic or artificer, or to the class of artisans; hence, rude; common; vulgar.
sn.q: To make a god, a hero, or a king Descend to a mechanic dialect.
Sometimes he ply'd the strong, mechanic tool.

sn.def: Base.

entry.cs: Mechanical effect effective power; useful work exerted, as by a machine, in a definite time. Mechanical engineering. See the Note under Engineering. Mechanical maneuvers Mil the application of mechanical appliances to the mounting, dismounting, and moving of artillery. Farrow. Mechanical philosophy the principles of mechanics applied to the investigation of physical phenomena. Mechanical powers certain simple instruments, such as the lever and its modifications (the wheel and axle and the pulley), the inclined plane with its modifications (the screw and the wedge), which convert a small force acting through a great space into a great force acting through a small space, or vice versa, and are used separately or in combination. Mechanical solution Math a solution of a problem by any art or contrivance not strictly geometrical, as by means of the ruler and compasses, or other instruments.

sn.def: Pertaining to, governed by, or in accordance with, mechanics, or the laws of motion; pertaining to the quantitative relations of force and matter on a macroscopic scale, as distinguished from mental vital chemical electrical electronic atomic etc.; as, mechanical principles; a mechanical theory;
using only the interactions of solid parts against each other; as mechanical brakes, in contrast to hydraulic brakes.
Of or pertaining to a machine or to machinery or tools; made or formed by a machine or with tools; as, mechanical precision; mechanical products.
sn.q: We have also divers mechanical arts.

sn.def: Done as if by a machine; uninfluenced by will or emotion; proceeding automatically, or by habit, without special intention or reflection; as, mechanical singing; mechanical verses; mechanical service.
Made and operated by interaction of forces without a directing intelligence; as, a mechanical universe.
Obtained by trial, by measurements, etc.; approximate; empirical. See the 2d Note under Geometric.

entry.def: A mechanic.
To cause to become mechanical.
In a mechanical manner.
The state or quality of being mechanical.
One skilled in the theory or construction of machines; a machinist.

Pertaining to, connected with, or dependent upon, both mechanics and chemistry; -- said especially of those sciences which treat of such phenomena as seem to depend on the laws both of mechanics and chemistry, as electricity and magnetism.

entry.note: ☞ That part of mechanics which considers the action of forces in producing rest or equilibrium is called statics; that which relates to such action in producing motion is called dynamics. The term mechanics includes the action of forces on all bodies, whether solid, liquid, or gaseous. It is sometimes, however, and formerly was often, used distinctively of solid bodies only: The mechanics of liquid bodies is called also hydrostatics, or hydrodynamics, according as the laws of rest or of motion are considered. The mechanics of gaseous bodies is called also pneumatics. The mechanics of fluids in motion, with special reference to the methods of obtaining from them useful results, constitutes hydraulics.

cs.cd: that portion of physiology which has for its object the investigation of the laws of equilibrium and motion in the animal body. The most important mechanical principle is that of the lever, the bones forming the arms of the levers, the contractile muscles the power, the joints the fulcra or points of support, while the weight of the body or of the individual limbs constitutes the weight or resistance.
the principles of abstract mechanics applied to human art; also, the practical application of the laws of matter and motion to the construction of machines and structures of all kinds.
the principles governing the motion of bodies in orbit around other bodies under gravitational influence, such as artificial Earth satellites.

entry.def: That science, or branch of applied mathematics, which treats of the action of forces on bodies.
Mechanization.

entry.ety: Cf. F. mécanisme, L. mechanisma. See Mechanic

sn.def: The arrangement or relation of the parts of a machine; the parts of a machine, taken collectively; the arrangement or relation of the parts of anything as adapted to produce an effect; as, the mechanism of a watch; the mechanism of a sewing machine; the mechanism of a seed pod.
The series of causal relations that operate to produce an effect in any system; as, the mechanism of a chemical reaction.
Mechanical operation or action.
sn.q: He acknowledges nothing besides matter and motion; so that all must be performed either by mechanism or accident.

sn.def: An ideal machine; a combination of movable bodies constituting a machine, but considered only with regard to relative movements.

entry.def: The mechanism{2} by which a pharmacologically active substance produces an effect on a living organism or in a biochemical system; as, the mechanism of action of actinomycin involves its binding to DNA. The mechanism of action is usually considered to include an identification of the specific molecular targets to which a pharmacologically active substance binds or whose biochemical action it influences; a general recognition of the broad biochemical pathways (such as DNA synthesis, protein synthesis, cholesterol synthesis) which are inhibited or affected by a substance is termed its mode of action.

sn.def: A maker of machines; one skilled in mechanics.
One who regards the phenomena of nature as the effects of forces merely mechanical.
The act or process of mechanizing.
Causing to be performed by machines, especially by a highly technical implementation, usually involving electronic hardware; as, the mechanization of a manufacturing process.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mechanized; p. pr. & vb. n. Mechanizing

sn.def: To cause to be mechanical.
To introduce machinery into (a process) in order to reduce human effort or improve uniformity or quality of the result;
To cause to be accomplished by a mechanical means which requires little or no human supervision; to automate.
To equip (an armed force) with tanks or other vehicles.

entry.def: One of a number of copies of anything multiplied mechanically.

sn.def: Treating of mechanics.
Written, copied, or recorded by machinery; produced by mechanography; as, a mechanographic record of changes of temperature; mechanographic prints.

entry.def: An artist who, by mechanical means, multiplies copies of works of art.
The art of mechanically multiplying copies of a writing, or any work of art.

entry.ety: Gr. mhchanh` machine + the root of � work
entry.def: That branch of science which treats of moving machines.

entry.ety: From Mechitar, an Armenian., who founded the congregation in the early part of the eighteenth century
entry.def: One of a religious congregation of the Roman Catholic Church devoted to the improvement of Armenians.
A kind of lace made at, or originating in, Mechlin, in Belgium.
A species of jalap, of very feeble properties, said to be obtained from the root of a species of Convolvulus Convolvulus Mechoacan); -- so called from Michoacan, in Mexico, whence it is obtained.

cs.cd: the cartilaginous rod which forms the axis of the mandible; -- called also Meckel's cartilage.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or discovered by, J. F. Meckel, a German anatomist.
A salt of meconic acid.

entry.ety: Gr. � belonging to the poppy, fr. � the poppy: cf. F. méconique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the poppy or opium; specif. Chem, designating an acid related to aconitic acid, found in opium and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a yellow amorphous substance which is easily decomposed.

entry.ety: NL., dim. of Gr. � a poppy. So called in allusion to the shape of the seed capsules of the poppy
entry.def: A kind of gonophore produced by hydroids of the genus Gonothyræa. It has tentacles, and otherwise resembles a free medusa, but remains attached by a pedicel.

A substance regarded as an anhydride of meconinic acid, existing in opium and extracted as a white crystalline substance. Also erroneously called meconina meconia, etc., as though it were an alkaloid.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid which occurs in opium, and which may be obtained by oxidizing narcotine.
Opium.
The contents of the fetal intestine; hence, first excrement.

entry.ety: F. médaille, It. medaglia, fr. L. metallum metal, through (assumed) LL. metalleus made of metal. See Metal, and cf. Mail a piece of money
entry.def: A piece of metal in the form of a coin, struck with a device, and intended to preserve the remembrance of a notable event or an illustrious person, or to serve as a reward.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Medaled, or Medalled; p. pr. & vb. n. Medaling or Medalling
entry.def: To honor or reward with a medal.
entry.q: Medaledby the king.

entry.def: A small medal.

sn.def: A person that is skilled or curious in medals; a collector of medals.
A designer of medals.
One who has gained a medal as the reward of merit; as, the gold medalist in downhill skiing.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a medal, or to medals.
entry.q: Ourmedallichistory.

entry.ety: F. médaillion, It. medaglione, augm. of medaglia. See Medal

sn.def: A large medal or memorial coin.
A circular or oval (or, sometimes, square) tablet bearing a figure or figures represented in relief.

entries.entry: Med"al play`. Golf Play in which the score is reckoned by counting the number of strokes.

entry.ety: Medal + the root of Gr. � work
entry.def: The art of making and striking medals and coins.

cs.cd: to intrude one's self into another person's concerns.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Meddled; p. pr. & vb. n. Meddling
entry.ety: OE. medlen to mix, OF. medler mesler, F. mêler, LL. misculare, a dim. fr. L. miscere to mix. √271. See Mix, and cf. Medley Mellay

sn.def: To mix; to mingle.
sn.q: More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.

sn.def: To interest or engage one's self; to have to do; -- in a good sense.
sn.q: Study to be quiet, and to meddle with your own business.

sn.def: To interest or engage one's self unnecessarily or impertinently, to interfere or busy one's self improperly with another's affairs; specifically, to handle or distrub another's property without permission; -- often followed by with or in.
sn.q: Why shouldst thou meddle to thy hurt?
The civil lawyers . . . have meddled in a matter that belongs not to them.

entry.def: To mix; to mingle.
