imp. of May.

entry.cs: With might and main. See under 2d Main.
entry.ety: AS. meaht miht, from the root of magan to be able, E. may; akin to D. magt, OS. maht, G. macht, Icel. māttr, Goth. mahts. √103. See May v.
entry.def: Force or power of any kind, whether of body or mind; energy or intensity of purpose, feeling, or action; means or resources to effect an object; strength; force; power; ability; capacity.
entry.q: What so strong, But wanting rest, will also want of might?
Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thine heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy might.

entry.def: Mighty.

sn.def: In a mighty manner; with might; with great earnestness; vigorously; powerfully.
sn.q: Whereunto I also labor, striving according to his working, which worketh in me mightily.

sn.def: To a great degree; very much.
sn.q: Practical jokes amused us mightily.

sn.def: The quality of being mighty; possession of might; power; greatness; high dignity.
sn.q: How soon this mightiness meets misery.

sn.def: Highness; excellency; -- with a possessive pronoun, a title of dignity; as, their high mightinesses .

entry.def: Without; weak.

entry.ety: AS. meahtig mihtig; akin to G. mächtig, Goth. mahteigs. See Might n.

sn.def: Possessing might; having great power or authority.
sn.q: Wise in heart, and mighty in strength.

sn.def: Accomplished by might; hence, extraordinary; wonderful.
sn.q: Hismightyworks.

sn.def: Denoting an extraordinary degree or quality in respect of size, character, importance, consequences, etc.
sn.q: Amightyfamine.
Giants ofmightybone.
Mighty was their fuss about little matters.

entries.entry: Might"y n.; pl.Mighties #. A warrior of great force and courage. R. & Obs

entry.def: In a great degree; very.
entry.q: He wasmightymethodical.
We have a mighty pleasant garden.

entry.ety: F. mignard, akin to mignon. See Minion
entry.def: Soft; dainty.
Delicate fondling.
See 3d Minion.
To flatter.

cs.cd: coarse pepper.

entry.ety: F. mignonnette, dim. of mignon darling. See 2d Minion
entry.def: A plant (Reseda odorata) having greenish flowers with orange-colored stamens, and exhaling a delicious fragrance. In Africa it is a low shrub, but further north it is usually an annual herb.

entry.ety: F. migraine, LL. hemigrania, L. hemicrania hemicranium, Gr. "hmikrani`a; "hmi- half + krani`on skull. See Hemi- and Cranium, and cf. Hemicrania Migraine

sn.def: A kind of intense sick or nervous headache, usually periodical and confined to one side of the head; called also migraine headache. Same as megrim.

entry.ety: L. migrans, p. pr. of migrare. See Migrate
entry.def: Migratory.

sn.def: A migratory bird, person, or other animal.

A person who changes residence frequently in search of employment, especially farm labor, such as harvesting crops seasonally; also called migrant laborer or migrant worker. Sometimes the migrant worker is not a resident of the country in which the work is performed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Migrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Migrating
entry.ety: L. migratus, p. p. of migrare to migrate, transfer

sn.def: To remove from one country or region to another, with a view to residence; to change one's place of residence; to remove; as, the Moors who migrated from Africa into Spain; to migrate to the West.
To pass periodically from one region or climate to another for feeding or breeding; -- said of certain birds, fishes, and quadrupeds.

entry.def: The act of migrating.

cs.cd: See Locust.
the American robin. See Robin.

sn.def: Removing regularly or occasionally from one region or climate to another; as, migratory birds.
Hence, roving; wandering; nomad; as, migratory habits; a migratory life.

entry.def: The popular designation of the hereditary sovereign of Japan; the emperor of Japan.
A microphone, the device for converting sound waves into electrical energy.
Same as Micmacs.

sn.def: an obsolete monetary unit of Cyprus equal in value to 1/1000 of a pound.
a unit of length equal to 1/1000 inch, used especially in measuring the thickness of sheets of materials.
one milliliter; -- used mostly in informal speech.
sn.syn: milliliter, millilitre, ml, cubic centimeter, cubic centimetre, cc.

sn.def: a unit of angular size equal to 1/6400 of 360 degrees; -- it is used especially in artillery ranging.

entry.def: One million dollars; as, his new house cost over a mil .
Lit., my lady; hence (as used on the Continent), an English noblewoman or gentlewoman.
Same as Mileage.
Of or pertaining to Milan in Italy, or to its inhabitants.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Milan; people of Milan.

entry.ety: OE. milche; akin to G. melk, Icel. milkr mjōlkr, and to E. milk. See Milk

sn.def: Giving milk; -- now applied only to beasts.
sn.q: Milchcamels.
Milchkine.

sn.def: Tender; pitiful; weeping.

cs.cd: steel that has but little carbon in it and is not readily hardened.

entry.ety: AS. milde; akin to OS. mildi, D. & G. mild, OHG. milti, Icel. mildr, Sw. & Dan. mild, Goth. milds; cf. Lith. melas dear, Gr. � gladdening gifts
entry.def: Gentle; pleasant; kind; soft; bland; clement; hence, moderate in degree or quality; -- the opposite of harsh severe irritating violent disagreeable, etc.; -- applied to persons and things; as, a mild disposition; a mild eye; a mild air; a mild medicine; a mild insanity.
entry.q: The rosy morn resigns her light And milder glory to the noon.
Adore him as a mild and merciful Being.
entry.syn: Soft; gentle; bland; calm; tranquil; soothing; pleasant; placid; meek; kind; tender; indulgent; clement; mollifying; lenitive; assuasive. See Gentle.

entry.def: To make mild, or milder.

cs.cd: a fungal disease of plants caused by an ascomycete of the order Erysiphales, characterized by a powdery white film on the surface of the affected plants. It is damaging to, e.g., roses and lilacs. Also, a fungus that causes such a disease.

entry.ety: AS. meledeáw; akin to OHG. militou, G. mehlthau mehltau; prob. orig. meaning, honeydew; cf. Goth. milip honey. See Mellifluous, and Dew
entry.def: A growth of minute powdery or webby fungi, whitish or of different colors, found on various diseased or decaying substances.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mildewed; p. pr. & vb. n. Mildewing
entry.def: To taint with mildew; as, mildewed clothing.
entry.q: He . . . mildews the white wheat.

entry.def: To become tainted with mildew.
In a mild manner.
The quality or state of being mild; as, mildness of temper; the mildness of the winter.

entry.note: ☞ The distance called a mile varies greatly in different countries. Its length in yards is, in Norway, 12,182; in Brunswick, 11,816; in Sweden, 11,660; in Hungary, 9,139; in Switzerland, 8,548; in Austria, 8,297; in Prussia, 8,238; in Poland, 8,100; in Italy, 2,025; in England and the United States, 1,760; in Spain, 1,552; in the Netherlands, 1,094.
entry.cs:
Geographical mileorNautical mile
one sixtieth of a degree of a great circle of the earth, or 6080.27 feet. Mile run. Same as Train mile. See under Train. Roman mile a thousand paces, equal to 1,614 yards English measure. Statute mile a mile conforming to statute, that is, in England and the United States, a mile of 5,280 feet, as distinguished from any other mile.
entry.ety: AS. mīl, fr. L. millia milia; pl. of mille a thousand, i. e., milia passuum a thousand paces. Cf. Mill the tenth of a cent, Million
entry.def: A certain measure of distance, being equivalent in England and the United States to 320 poles or rods, or 5,280 feet.

cs.cd: a mileage allowed for journeys supposed to be made, but not actually made.

sn.def: An allowance for traveling expenses at a certain rate per mile.
Aggregate length or distance in miles; esp., the sum of lengths of tracks or wires of a railroad company, telegraph company, etc.

The number of miles that a vehicle can travel after consuming a certain quantity of fuel; in the United States, usually expressed in units of miles per gallon; as, smaller cars tend to get better mileage . It is sometimes used as a nmeasure of the energy efficiency of a vehicle.
Use, profit or advantage; as, he got a lot of mileage out of one hit record.

entry.def: a meter that shows mileage traversed.

sn.def: A post, or one of a series of posts, set up to indicate spaces of a mile each or the distance in miles from a given place.
An event or accomplishment marking a significant advance in an endeavor; a notable achievment; as, putting a man in orbit was a big milepost on the way to the moon.
Of or pertaining to Miletus, a city of Asia Minor, or to its inhabitants.
Descended from King Milesius of Spain, whose two sons are said to have conquered Ireland about 1300 b. c.; or pertaining to the descendants of King Milesius; hence, Irish.
A native or inhabitant of Miletus.
A native or inhabitant of Ireland.
A stone serving the same purpose as a milepost.
An event or accomplishment marking a significant advance in an endeavor; a notable achievment; as, putting a man in orbit was a major milestone on the way to the moon.

cs.cd: an aquatic herb with dissected leaves (Myriophyllum).

entry.ety: F. mille-feuille, L. millefolium; mille thousand + folium leaf. See Foil a leaf
entry.def: A common composite herb (Achillea Millefolium) with white flowers and finely dissected leaves; yarrow.
A fever accompanied by an eruption of small, isolated, red pimples, resembling a millet seed in form or size; miliary fever.

entry.ety: L. miliarius, fr. milium millet: cf. F. miliaire

sn.def: Like millet seeds; as, a miliary eruption.
Accompanied with an eruption like millet seeds; as, a miliary fever.
Small and numerous; as, the miliary tubercles of Echini.

entry.def: One of the small tubercles of Echini.
Militia.

entry.ety: F., fr. mi middle (L. medius) + lieu place. See Demi- Lieu
entry.def: Environment.
entry.q: The intellectual and moral milieu created by multitudes of self-centered, cultivated personalities.
It is one of the great outstanding facts of his progressive relation to the elements of his social milieu.

entry.ety: NL., dim. of L. milium millet. So named from its resemblance to millet seed
entry.def: A genus of Foraminifera, having a porcelanous shell with several longitudinal chambers.
A fossil shell of, or similar to, the genus Miliola.

cs.cd: a building stone, one of the group of the Paris basin, almost entirely made up of many-chambered microscopic shells.

entry.def: The same Miliolitic.
Of or pertaining to the genus Miliola; containing miliolites.

sn.def: The state of being militant; warfare.
A military spirit or system; militarism.

cs.cd: the Christian church on earth, which is supposed to be engaged in a constant warfare against its enemies, and is thus distinguished from the church triumphant, in heaven.

entry.ety: L. militans -antis, p. pr. of militare to be soldier: cf. F. militant. See Militate
entry.def: Engaged in warfare; fighting; combating; serving as a soldier.
entry.q: At which command the powers militant . . . Moved on in silence.

entry.def: Military.
In a military manner.
militarization.

sn.def: A military state or condition; a military system; reliance on military force in administering government.
The spirit and traditions of military life.
The view that military strength, efficiency and values should dominate the country's public policy choices and take precedence over other interests.

The policy of maintaining a large military force, even in peacetime; -- a term usually used by opponents of such a policy on the assumption that such a large force is unnecessary for national defense.
A military man.
A person having a strong spirit of militarism, in senses 3 or 4.

entry.def: imbued with militarism, in senses 3 or 4.
act of assembling and putting into readiness the military forces for war or other emergency.
to lend a military character to (a country), as by building up a military force.

sn.def: Equipped with eapons; armed; -- used of persons, regions, or the military. Contrasted to unarmed and demilitarized.

entry.cs: Military law. See Martial law, under Martial. Military order. a A command proceeding from a military superior. An association of military persons under a bond of certain peculiar rules; especially, such an association of knights in the Middle Ages, or a body in modern times taking a similar form, membership of which confers some distinction. Military tenure tenure of land, on condition of performing military service.
entry.ety: L. militaris militarius, from miles militis, soldier: cf. F. militaire

sn.def: Of or pertaining to soldiers, to arms, or to war; belonging to, engaged in, or appropriate to, the affairs of war; as, a military parade; military discipline; military bravery; military conduct; military renown.
sn.q: Nor do I, as an enemy to peace, Troop in the throngs of military men.

sn.def: Performed or made by soldiers; as, a military election; a military expedition.

entry.def: The whole body of soldiers; soldiery; militia; troops; the army.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Militated; p. pr. & vb. n. Militating
entry.ety: L. militare militatum, to be a soldier, fr. miles militis, soldier
entry.def: To make war; to fight; to contend; -- usually followed by against and with.
entry.q: These are great questions, where great names militate against each other.
The invisible powers of heaven seemed to militate on the side of the pious emperor.

entry.def: To argue against; to cast doubt on; -- used in reference to facts which tend to disprove a hypothesis; as, the absence of a correlation of budget deficits with inflation militates against any causal relation between the two. Opposite of support.

entry.ety: L., military service, soldiery, fr. miles militis, soldier: cf. F. milice

sn.def: In the widest sense, the whole military force of a nation, including both those engaged in military service as a business, and those competent and available for such service; specifically, the body of citizens enrolled for military instruction and discipline, but not subject to be called into actual service except in emergencies.
sn.q: The king's captains and soldiers fight his battles, and yet . . . the power of the militia is he.

sn.def: Military service; warfare.

entries.entry: Mi*li"tia*man n.; pl.Militiamen. One who belongs to the militia.

entry.def: To carry on, or prepare for, war.

entry.cs:
Condensed milk. See under Condense v. t.
Milk crust Med vesicular eczema occurring on the face and scalp of nursing infants. See Eczema. Milk fever. Med A fever which accompanies or precedes the first lactation. It is usually transitory. Vet. Surg A form puerperal peritonitis in cattle; also, a variety of meningitis occurring in cows after calving. Milk glass glass having a milky appearance. Milk knot Med a hard lump forming in the breast of a nursing woman, due to obstruction to the flow of milk and congestion of the mammary glands. Milk leg Med a swollen condition of the leg, usually in puerperal women, caused by an inflammation of veins, and characterized by a white appearance occasioned by an accumulation of serum and sometimes of pus in the cellular tissue. Milk meats food made from milk, as butter and cheese. Obs Bailey. Milk mirror. Same as Escutcheon, 2. Milk molar Anat one of the deciduous molar teeth which are shed and replaced by the premolars. Milk of lime Chem a watery emulsion of calcium hydrate, produced by macerating quicklime in water. Milk parsley Bot an umbelliferous plant (Peucedanum palustre) of Europe and Asia, having a milky juice. Milk pea Bot a genus (Galactia) of leguminous and, usually, twining plants. Milk sickness Med See milk sickness in the vocabulary. Milk snake Zoöl a harmless American snake (Ophibolus triangulus, or Ophibolus eximius). It is variously marked with white, gray, and red. Called also milk adder chicken snake house snake, etc. Milk sugar. Physiol. Chem See Lactose, and Sugar of milkbelow). Milk thistle Bot an esculent European thistle (Silybum marianum), having the veins of its leaves of a milky whiteness. Milk thrush. Med See Thrush. Milk tooth Anat one of the temporary first set of teeth in young mammals; in man there are twenty. Milk tree Bot a tree yielding a milky juice, as the cow tree of South America (Brosimum Galactodendron), and the Euphorbia balsamifera of the Canaries, the milk of both of which is wholesome food. Milk vessel Bot a special cell in the inner bark of a plant, or a series of cells, in which the milky juice is contained. See Latex. Rock milk. See Agaric mineral, under Agaric. Sugar of milk. The sugar characteristic of milk; a hard white crystalline slightly sweet substance obtained by evaporation of the whey of milk. It is used in pellets and powder as a vehicle for homeopathic medicines, and as an article of diet. See Lactose.
entry.ety: AS. meoluc meoloc meolc milc; akin to OFries. meloc, D. melk, G. milch, OHG. miluh, Icel. mjōlk, Sw. mjölk, Dan. melk, Goth. miluks, G. melken to milk, OHG. melchan, Lith. milszti, L. mulgere, Gr. 'ame`lgein. √107. Cf. Milch Emulsion Milt soft roe of fishes

sn.def: A white fluid secreted by the mammary glands of female mammals for the nourishment of their young, consisting of minute globules of fat suspended in a solution of casein, albumin, milk sugar, and inorganic salts.
sn.q: White as mornemilk.

sn.def: A kind of juice or sap, usually white in color, found in certain plants; latex. See Latex.
An emulsion made by bruising seeds; as, the milk of almonds, produced by pounding almonds with sugar and water.
The ripe, undischarged spat of an oyster.

cs.cd: to squeeze the smaller operators in stocks and extract a profit from them, by alternately raising and depressing prices within a short range; -- said of the large dealers.
to use for one's own advantage the contents of a telegram belonging to another person.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Milked mĭlkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Milking

sn.def: To draw or press milk from the breasts or udder of, by the hand or mouth; to withdraw the milk of.
sn.q: Milkingthe kine.
I have given suck, and know How tender 't is to love the babe that milks me.

sn.def: To draw from the breasts or udder; to extract, as milk; as, to milk wholesome milk from healthy cows.
To draw anything from, as if by milking; to compel to yield profit or advantage; to plunder.
sn.q: They [the lawyersmilk an unfortunate estate as regularly as a dairyman does his stock.

sn.def: To draw or to yield milk.
To give off small gas bubbles during the final part of the charging operation; -- said of a storage battery.

entry.def: A type of edible mushroom (Lactarius delicioso).
Consisting of milk.

sn.def: One who milks; also, a mechanical apparatus for milking cows.
A cow or other animal that gives milk.

entry.def: Full of milk; abounding with food.
entry.q: Milkfulvales.

entry.def: In a milky manner.
State or quality of being milky.
White-livered; cowardly; timorous.
A woman who milks cows or is employed in the dairy.

entries.entry: Milk"man n.; pl.Milkmen. A man who sells milk or delivers it to customers.

entry.def: A frothy drink of milk and flavoring and sometimes fruit or ice cream, shaken together or blended in a blender.

entries.entry: Milk sickness. Veter., Med A peculiar malignant disease, occurring in parts of the western United States, and affecting certain kinds of farm stock (esp. cows), and persons using the meat or dairy products of infected cattle. Its chief symptoms in man are uncontrollable vomiting, obstinate constipation, pain, and muscular tremors. Its origin in cattle has been variously ascribed to the presence of certain plants in their food, and to polluted water.

entry.def: A piece of bread sopped in milk; figuratively, an effeminate or weak-minded person.
entry.q: To wed a milksop or a coward ape.

entries.entry: Milk" vetch` ☞ The name is sometimes taken for the whole genus Astragalus, of which there are about two hundred species in North America, and even more elsewhere.. Bot A leguminous herb (Astragalus glycyphyllos) of Europe and Asia, supposed to increase the secretion of milk in goats.

entry.def: a wagon for delivering milk.

Any plant of the genera Asclepias and Acerates, abounding in a milky juice, and having its seed attached to a long silky down; silkweed. The name is also applied to several other plants with a milky juice, as to several kinds of spurge. Its leaves are a favorite food source for the larvae of the monarch butterfly.

entry.note: ☞ The species of Campanula, or bellflower, are sometimes called milkwort, from their juice.
entry.def: A genus of plants (Polygala) of many species. The common European Polygala vulgaris was supposed to have the power of producing a flow of milk in nurses.

entry.cs: Milky Way. Astron See Galaxy, 1.

sn.def: Consisting of, or containing, milk.
sn.q: Pails high foaming with a milky flood.

sn.def: Like, or somewhat like, milk; whitish and turbid; as, the water is milky. “Milky juice.”
Yielding milk.
sn.q: Milkymothers.

sn.def: Mild; tame; spiritless.
sn.q: Has friendship such a faint and milky heart?

entry.ety: L. mille a thousand. Cf. Mile
entry.def: A money of account of the United States, having the value of the tenth of a cent, or the thousandth of a dollar.

cs.cd: etc. See under Edge Flint, etc.
a rough bar rolled or drawn directly from a bloom or puddle bar for conversion into merchant iron in the mill.
slag from a puddling furnace.
the head of water employed to turn the wheel of a mill.
a pick for dressing millstones.
a pond that supplies the water for a mill.
the canal in which water is conveyed to a mill wheel, or the current of water which drives the wheel.
the water which flows from a mill wheel after turning it, or the channel in which the water flows.
a grinder or molar tooth.
the water wheel that drives the machinery of a mill.
a tavern; a bar; a saloon; especially, a cheap or seedy establishment that serves liquor by the drink.
a mill in which flour or meal is made by crushing grain between rollers.
a mill in which ore is crushed by stamps.
to experience the suffering or discipline necessary to bring one to a certain degree of knowledge or skill, or to a certain mental state.

entry.ety: OE. mille melle mulle milne, AS. myln mylen; akin to D. molen, G. mühle, OHG. mulī mulīn, Icel. mylna; all prob. from L. molina, fr. mola millstone; prop., that which grinds, akin to molere to grind, Goth. malan, G. mahlen, and to E. meal. √108. See Meal flour, and cf. Moline

sn.def: A machine for grinding or comminuting any substance, as grain, by rubbing and crushing it between two hard, rough, or indented surfaces; as, a gristmill, a coffee mill; a bone mill.
A machine used for expelling the juice, sap, etc., from vegetable tissues by pressure, or by pressure in combination with a grinding, or cutting process; as, a cider mill; a cane mill.
A machine for grinding and polishing; as, a lapidary mill .
A common name for various machines which produce a manufactured product, or change the form of a raw material by the continuous repetition of some simple action; as, a sawmill; a stamping mill, etc.
A building or collection of buildings with machinery by which the processes of manufacturing are carried on; as, a cotton mill; a powder mill; a rolling mill.
A hardened steel roller having a design in relief, used for imprinting a reversed copy of the design in a softer metal, as copper.

sd.def: An excavation in rock, transverse to the workings, from which material for filling is obtained.
A passage underground through which ore is shot.

sn.def: A milling cutter. See Illust. under Milling.
A pugilistic encounter.
Short for Treadmill.
The raised or ridged edge or surface made in milling anything, as a coin or screw.
A building or complex of buildings containing a mill{1} or other machinery to grind grains into flour.

cs.cd: to make it frothy, as by churning.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Milled mĭld; p. pr. & vb. n. Milling
entry.ety: See Mill n., and cf. Muller

sn.def: To reduce to fine particles, or to small pieces, in a mill; to grind; to comminute.
To shape, finish, or transform by passing through a machine; specifically, to shape or dress, as metal, by means of a rotary cutter.
To make a raised border around the edges of, or to cut fine grooves or indentations across the edges of, as of a coin, or a screw head; also, to stamp in a coining press; to coin.
To pass through a fulling mill; to full, as cloth.
To beat with the fists.
To roll into bars, as steel.

entry.def: To swim under water; -- said of air-breathing creatures.

sn.def: To undergo hulling, as maize.
To move in a circle, as cattle upon a plain; to move around aimlessly; -- usually used with around.
sn.q: The deer and the pig and the nilghar were milling round and round in a circle of eight or ten miles radius.

sn.def: To swim suddenly in a new direction; -- said of whales.
To take part in a mill; to box.
To fill (a winze or interior incline) with broken ore, to be drawn out at the bottom.
To cause to mill, or circle round, as cattle.

entry.def: A kind of stout pasteboard.
The incorporated materials for gunpowder, in the form of a dense mass or cake, ready to be subjected to the process of granulation.
A dam or mound to obstruct a water course, and raise the water to a height sufficient to turn a mill wheel.

cs.cd: cloth that has been beaten in a fulling mill.
lead rolled into sheets.

sn.def: Having been subjected to some process of milling.

Having multiple fine grooves on the rim, in the direction from obverse to reverse; -- of coins. Coins of silver and gold were milled to make it impossible for uncrupulous persons to shave small pieces from the edge without detection.

entries.entry: Mil`le*fi*o"re glass`. It. mille thousand + fiore flower Slender rods or tubes of colored glass fused together and embedded in clear glass; -- used for paperweights and other small articles.

entry.def: Consisting of a thousand years; of or pertaining to the millennium, or to the Millenarians.
One who believes that Christ will personally reign on earth a thousand years; a Chiliast.
The doctrine of Millenarians.

entry.ety: L. millenarius, fr. milleni a thousand each, fr. mille a thousand: cf. F. millénaire. See Mile
entry.def: Consisting of a thousand; millennial.
The space of a thousand years; a millennium; also, a Millenarian.
entry.q: During thatmillenary.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the millennium, or to a thousand years; as, a millennial period; millennial happiness.
One who believes that Christ will reign personally on earth a thousand years; a Chiliast; also, a believer in the universal prevalence of Christianity for a long period.
Belief in, or expectation of, the millennium{2}; millenarianism.
One who believes in the millennium{2}.

entry.note: Technically, if the calendar of the Common Era (Anno Domini) is considered as beginning on January 1, 1 a. d., then the millenium will fall in each year ending in 001, as in 1001 a. d. or January 1, 2001 a. d.. However in the common culture, the change of the first digit of the year from 1 to 2, as from 1999 to 2000 is considered as the more symbolic event, especially since the dating of the beginning of the Christian era is somewhat arbitrary, having been an attempt to fix the date of the birth of Christ, and being considered by scholars as being in error by as much as five years.
entry.ety: LL., fr. L. mille a thousand + annus a year. See Mile, and Annual

sn.def: A period of one thousand years.

The period of a thousand years mentioned in the twentieth chapter of Revelation, during which holiness is to be triumphant throughout the world. Some believe that, during this period, Christ will reign on earth in person with his saints.
A long period of happiness, righteousness, and prosperity, usually considered as being in the indefinite future.
A thousandth anniversary;

Each first day of January falling in a year which is a multiple of one thousand, such as in 1000 a. d. or 2000 a. d.; as, the second millenium will be celebrated on January 1, 2000; also used attributively, as a millenium celebration.

entry.note: In the several years leading up to the year 2000, large corporations and other users of computers in total spent many billions of dollars correcting this error in the programs they use.
entry.def: An error in the coding of certain computer programs which store the year component of the date as two digits, assuming that the first two digits are 19, rather than as a complete number of four digits; when such programs are used after January 1, 2000, the date may be misinterpreted, causing serious errors or total failure of the program; -- called also year 2000 bug year 2000 problem and Y2K bug.

entry.ety: L. millepeda; mille a thousand + pes pedis, foot: cf. F. mille-pieds
entry.def: A myriapod with many legs, esp. a chilognath, as the galleyworm.
A genus of Hydrocorallia, which includes the millipores.

entry.ety: L. mille thousand + porus pore: cf. F. millépore
entry.def: Any coral of the genus Millepora, having the surface nearly smooth, and perforated with very minute unequal pores, or cells. The animals are hydroids, not Anthozoa. See Hydrocorallia.
A fossil millepore.

entry.cs: Miller's thumb. Zoöl A small fresh-water fish of the genus Uranideaformerly Cottus), as the European species (Uranidea gobio), and the American (Uranidea gracilis); -- called also bullhead. A small bird, as the gold-crest, chiff-chaff, and long-tailed tit. Prov. Eng

sn.def: One who keeps or attends a flour mill or gristmill.
A milling machine.

sd.def: A moth or lepidopterous insect; -- so called because the wings appear as if covered with white dust or powder, like a miller's clothes. Called also moth miller.
The eagle ray.
The hen harrier.

entry.def: A believer in the doctrine of William Miller d. 1849), who taught that the end of the world and the second coming of Christ were at hand.

entry.ety: From W. H. Miller , of Cambridge, Eng
entry.def: A sulphide of nickel, commonly occurring in delicate capillary crystals, also in incrustations of a bronze yellow; -- sometimes called hair pyrites.

entry.ety: L. millesimus, fr. mille a thousand
entry.def: Thousandth; consisting of thousandth parts; as, millesimal fractions.

entry.note: ☞ Arabian millet is Sorghum Halepense.Egyptian milletorEast Indian millet is Penicillaria spicata.Indian millet is Sorghum vulgare. (See under Indian.)Italian millet is Setaria Italica, a coarse, rank-growing annual grass, valuable for fodder when cut young, and bearing nutritive seeds; -- called also Hungarian grass.Texas millet is Panicum Texanum.Wild millet or Millet grass, is Milium effusum, a tall grass growing in woods.

☞ Arabian millet is Sorghum Halepense.Egyptian milletorEast Indian millet is Penicillaria spicata.Indian millet is Sorghum vulgare. (See under Indian.)Italian millet is Setaria Italica, a coarse, rank-growing annual grass, valuable for fodder when cut young, and bearing nutritive seeds; -- called also Hungarian grass.Texas millet is Panicum Texanum.Wild millet or Millet grass, is Milium effusum, a tall grass growing in woods.
entry.ety: F., dim. of mil, L. milium; akin to Gr. meli`nh, AS. mil
entry.def: The name of several cereal and forage grasses which bear an abundance of small roundish grains. The common millets of Germany and Southern Europe are Panicum miliaceum, and Setaria Italica.
a girl who works in a mill.

entries.entry: Mil"li- mĭl"lĭ-. From L. mille a thousand Metric System, Elec., Mech., etc A prefix denoting a thousandth part of; as, millimeter, milligram, milliampère.

entry.def: a sensitive ammeter for detecting small currents, graduated in milliamperes.
The thousandth part of one ampère.

entry.ety: F., from mille mil, thousand, L. mille
entry.def: A thousand millions; -- usually called billion in the United States. See Billion.

entry.ety: L. milliarius containing a thousand, fr. mille thousand: cf. F. milliaire milliary. See Mile
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a mile, or to distance by miles; denoting a mile or miles.
entry.q: A milliary column, from which they used to compute the distance of all the cities and places of note.

entries.entry:
Mil"li*a*ry n.; pl.Milliaries #. L. milliarium. See Milliary a.
A milestone.

entry.def: A weight of the metric system, being one million grams; a metric ton.

entry.ety: L. mille thousand + E. fold times
entry.def: Thousandfold.

entry.ety: F. milligramme; milli- milli- + gramme. See 3d Gram
entry.def: A measure of weight, in the metric system, being the thousandth part of a gram, equal to the weight of a cubic millimeter of water, or .01543 of a grain avoirdupois.

entry.ety: F. millilitre; milli- milli- + litre. See Liter
entry.def: A measure of capacity in the metric system, containing the thousandth part of a liter. It is a cubic centimeter, and is equal to .061 of an English cubic inch, or to .0338 of an American fluid ounce.

entry.ety: F. millimètre; milli- milli- + mètre. See 3d Meter
entry.def: A lineal measure in the metric system, containing the thousandth part of a meter; equal to .03937 of an inch. See 3d Meter.
The thousandth part of a micron or the millionth part of a millimeter; -- a unit of length used in measuring light waves, etc.
an advertising measure; one agate line appearing in one million copies of a publication.

cs.cd: a man who makes or deals in millinery, that occupation having been at one time predominantly performed by women; hence, contemptuously, a man who is busied with trifling occupations or embellishments.

entry.ety: From Milaner an inhabitant of Milan, in Italy; hence, a man from Milan who imported women's finery

sn.def: Formerly, a man who imported and dealt in small articles of a miscellaneous kind, especially such as please the fancy of women.
sn.q: No milliner can so fit his customers with gloves.

sn.def: A person who designs, makes, trims, or deals in hats, bonnets, headdresses, etc., for women.
The articles made or sold by milliners, as headdresses, hats or bonnets, laces, ribbons, and the like.
The business of work of a milliner.

entry.def: A stiff cotton fabric used by milliners for lining bonnets.

cs.cd: milling in which grain is reduced to flour by a succession of crackings, or of slight and partial crushings, alternately with sifting and sorting the product.
milling in which the reduction is effected in a single crushing or grinding.
a fluted, sharp-edged rotary cutter for dressing surfaces, as of metal, of various shapes.
a machine tool for dressing surfaces by rotary cutters.
a roller with indented edge or surface, for producing like indentations in metal by rolling pressure, as in turning; a knurling tool; a milling cutter.

entry.def: The act or employment of grinding or passing through a mill; the process of fulling; the process of making a raised or intented edge upon coin, etc.; the process of dressing surfaces of various shapes with rotary cutters. See Mill.

entry.ety: F., from LL. millio, fr. L. mille a thousand. See Mile

sn.def: The number of ten hundred thousand, or a thousand thousand, -- written 1,000,000. See the Note under Hundred.
A very great number; an indefinitely large number.
sn.q: Millions of truths that a man is not concerned to know.

sn.def: The mass of common people; -- with the article the.
sn.q: For the play, I remember, pleased not the million.

entry.def: One whose wealth is counted by millions of francs, dollars, or pounds; a very rich person; a person worth a million or more.
A woman who is a millionaire, or the wife of a millionaire.
Of or pertaining to millions; consisting of millions; as, the millionary chronology of the pundits.
Multiplied by millions; innumerable.
Millionaire.
Being the last one of a million of units or objects counted in regular order from the first of a series or succession; being one of a million.
The quotient of a unit divided by one million; one of a million equal parts.
The same Milleped.

entry.ety: F. millistère, from milli- milli- + stère
entry.def: A liter, or cubic decimeter.
The thousandth part of one weber.
a pond formed by damming a stream to provide a head of water to turn a mill wheel.
a channel from a millpond to a millwheel, to provide the water current that turns the millwheel.
See Milreis.
A figure supposed to represent the iron which holds a millstone by being set into its center.
a millrace.
A milled sixpence; -- the sixpence being one of the first English coins milled (1561).

entry.note: ☞ The cellular siliceous rock called buhrstone is usually employed for millstones; also, some kinds of lava, as that Niedermendig, or other firm rock with rough texture. The surface of a millstone has usually a series of radial grooves in which the powdered material collects.

cs.cd: a hard and coarse, gritty sandstone, dividing the Carboniferous from the Subcarboniferous strata. See Farewell rock, under Farewell a., and Chart of Geology.
cs.mcol: To see into a millstoneorTo see through a millstone
cs.cd: to see into or through a difficult matter.

entry.def: One of two circular stones used for grinding grain or other substance in a mill{1}.
entry.q: No man shall take the nether or the upper millstone to pledge.

entry.def: a waterwheel that is used to drive machinery in a mill.

sn.def: The shafting, gearing, and other driving machinery of mills.
The business of setting up or of operating mill machinery.

entry.def: A mechanic whose occupation is to build mills, or to set up their machinery.
a meter that shows mileage traversed.

entry.ety: F. (also It., Sp., Russ.), fr. E. my lord
entry.def: Lit., my lord; hence (as used on the Continent), an English nobleman or gentleman.

entry.ety: From Caspar Milquetoast, a character in a cartoon strip by H. T. Webster, The Timid Soul1935)
entry.def: a timid, unassertive man or boy fearful of confrontation and easily manipulated and dominated.

entry.ety: Pg. mil reis, i. e., one thousand reis; mil a thousand + reis, pl. of real a rei
entry.def: A Portuguese money of account rated in the treasury department of the United States at one dollar and eight cents; also, a Brazilian money of account rated at fifty-four cents and six mills (1913).

entry.ety: AS. milte; akin to D. milt, G. milz, OHG. milzi, Icel. milti, Dan. milt, Sw. mjälte, and prob. to E. malt melt. √108. See Malt the grain
entry.def: The spleen.

entry.ety: Akin to Dan. melk, Sw. mjölke, G. milch, and E. milk. See Milk
entry.def: The spermatic fluid of fishes.
The testes, or spermaries, of fishes when filled with spermatozoa.
To impregnate (the roe of a fish) with milt.

entry.ety: Cf. D. milter, G. milcher milchner. See 2d Milt
entry.def: A male fish.
Miltonic.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, Milton, or his writings; as, Miltonic prose.
A small European fern (Asplenium Ceterach) formerly used in medicine.
Of or resembling birds of the kite kind.
A bird related to the kite.
A genus of raptorial birds, including the European kite.

entry.ety: L. mimus, Gr. �, akin to � to imitate, to mimic: cf. F. mime. Cf. Mimosa

sn.def: A kind of drama in which real persons and events were generally represented in a ridiculous manner; an ancient Greek or Roman form of farce.
An actor in such representations.
The art of representing actions, events, situations, or stories solely by gestures and body movements, without speaking; pantomime{3}.
An actor who performs or specializes in mime{3}; an actor who communicates entirely by gesture and facial expression; a pantomime{2}; a pantomimist; a mimer.
A mimic.

entry.def: To mimic.
A mimeograph.
to make copies of using a mimeograph.
A copying device that uses a stencil through which ink is pressed; it was invented by Edison.
to make copies of using a mimeograph; as, She mimeographed the syllabus.

sn.def: A person who performs in a mime.
A mimic.

entry.def: Imitation; mimicry.
See Mimetite.

sn.def: Apt to imitate; given to mimicry; imitative.
Characterized by mimicry; -- applied to animals and plants; as, mimetic species; mimetic organisms. See Mimicry.

entry.def: Same as Mimicry.

entry.ety: Gr. � an imitator. So called because it resembles pyromorphite
entry.def: A mineral occurring in pale yellow or brownish hexagonal crystals. It is an arseniate of lead.

entry.note: ☞ Mimic often implies something droll or ludicrous, and is less dignified than imitative.

cs.cd: a beetle that feigns death when disturbed, esp. the species of Hister and allied genera.

entry.ety: L. mimicus, Gr. �, fr. � mime: cf. F. mimique. See Mime

sn.def: Imitative; mimetic.
sn.q: Oft, in her absence, mimic fancy wakes To imitate her.
Man is, of all creatures, the most mimical.

sn.def: Consisting of, or formed by, imitation; imitated; as, mimic gestures.
sn.q: Mimichootings.

sn.def: Imitative; characterized by resemblance to other forms; -- applied to crystals which by twinning resemble simple forms of a higher grade of symmetry.

entry.def: One who imitates or mimics, especially one who does so for sport; a copyist; a buffoon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mimicked; p. pr. & vb. n. Mimicking

sn.def: To imitate or ape for sport; to ridicule by imitation.
sn.q: The walk, the words, the gesture, could supply, The habit mimic, and the mien belie.

sn.def: To assume a resemblance to (some other organism of a totally different nature, or some surrounding object), as a means of protection or advantage.

entry.def: In an imitative manner.

sn.def: One who mimics; a mimic.
An animal which imitates something else, in form or habits.
The act or practice of one who mimics; ludicrous imitation for sport or ridicule.

Protective resemblance; the resemblance which certain animals and plants exhibit to other animals and plants or to the natural objects among which they live, -- a characteristic which serves as their chief means of protection against enemies; imitation; mimesis; mimetism.

entry.def: A giant who guarded the well of wisdom.

entry.ety: L. mimographus, Gr. �; � a mime + � to write: cf. F. mimographe
entry.def: A writer of mimes.

entry.note: ☞ The term mimosa is also applied in commerce to several kinds bark imported from Australia, and used in tanning; -- called also wattle bark.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � imitator. Cf. Mime
entry.def: A genus of leguminous plants, containing many species, and including the sensitive plants (Mimosa sensitiva, and Mimosa pudica).
A natural family of spiny woody plants (usually shrubs or small trees) whose leaves mimic animals in sensitivity to touch; commonly included in the family Leguminosae.
An alternative name used in some classification systems for the family Mimosaceae.
Pertaining to, or designating, a variety of tannin or tannic acid found in Acacia, Mimosa, etc.
The type genus of the family Mimidae, comprising certain of the mockingbirds.
An abbreviation for minute, a unit of time equal to 60 seconds or 1/60th of an hour.

sn.def: a dialect of Chinese.
sn.syn: Min dialect, Fukkianese, Hokkianese, Amoy, Taiwanese.

sn.def: an Egyptian god of procreation.

entries.entry: ‖mi"na n.; pl. L. Minæ #, E. Minas #. L., fr. Gr. � An ancient weight or denomination of money, of varying value. The Attic mina was valued at a hundred drachmas.

entry.def: See Myna.
Such as can be mined; as, minable earth.
Threatening; menacing.
Disposition to threaten.

entry.ety: Sp. minarete, Ar. manārat lamp, lantern, lighthouse, turret, fr. nār to shine
entry.def: A slender, lofty tower attached to a mosque and surrounded by one or more projecting balconies, from which the summon to prayer is cried by the muezzin.

entry.ety: Prob. contr. from aluminium + L. argentum silver
entry.def: An alloy consisting of copper, nickel, tungsten, and aluminium; -- used by jewelers.
In a minatory manner; with threats.

entry.ety: L. minatorius, fr. minari to threaten. See Menace
entry.def: Threatening; menacing.
Same as Manul.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Minced mĭnst; p. pr. & vb. n. Minging mĭn"sĭng
entry.ety: AS. minsian to grow less, dwindle, fr. min small; akin to G. minder less, Goth. minniza less, mins less, adv., L. minor, adj. (cf. Minor); or more likely fr. F. mincer to mince, prob. from (assumed) LL. minutiare. √101. See Minish

sn.def: To cut into very small pieces; to chop fine; to hash; as, to mince meat.

To suppress or weaken the force of; to extenuate; to palliate; to tell by degrees, instead of directly and frankly; to clip, as words or expressions; to utter half and keep back half of; as, he doesn't mince words.
sn.q: I know no ways to mince it in love, but directly to say -- “I love you.”
Siren, now mince the sin, And mollify damnation with a phrase.
If, to mince his meaning, I had either omitted some part of what he said, or taken from the strength of his expression, I certainly had wronged him.

sn.def: To affect; to make a parade of.
To walk with short steps; to walk in a prim, affected manner.
sn.q: The daughters of Zion are haughty, and walk with stretched forth necks and wanton eyes, . . . mincing as they go.
I 'll . . . turn two mincing steps Into a manly stride.

sn.def: To act or talk with affected nicety; to affect delicacy in manner.

entry.def: A short, precise step; an affected manner.
Minced meat; meat chopped very fine; a mixture of boiled meat, suet, apples, etc., chopped very fine, to which spices and raisins are added; -- used in making mince pie.

entries.entry: Mince" pie`. A pie made of mince-meat.

entry.def: One who minces.
That minces; characterized by primness or affected nicety.
In a mincing manner; not fully; with affected nicety.

entry.cs:
To have a mindorTo have a great mind
to be inclined or strongly inclined in purpose; -- used with an infinitive. “Sir Roger de Coverly . . . told me that he had a great mind to see the new tragedy with me.” Addison. To lose one's mind to become insane, or imbecile. To make up one's mind to come to an opinion or decision; to determine. To put in mind to remind. “Regard us simply as putting you in mind of what you already know to be good policy.” Jowett (Thucyd. ).
entry.ety: AS. mynd gemynd; akin to OHG. minna memory, love, G. minne love, Dan. minde mind, memory, remembrance, consent, vote, Sw. minne memory, Icel. minni, Goth. gamunds, L. mens mentis, mind, Gr. me`nos, Skr. manas mind, man to think. √104, 278. Cf. Comment Man Mean v., 3d Mental Mignonette Minion Mnemonic Money

sn.def: The intellectual or rational faculty in man; the understanding; the intellect; the power that conceives, judges, or reasons; also, the entire spiritual nature; the soul; -- often in distinction from the body.
sn.q: By the mind of man we understand that in him which thinks, remembers, reasons, wills.
What we mean by mind is simply that which perceives, thinks, feels, wills, and desires.
Let every man be fully persuaded in his own mind.
The mind shall banquet, though the body pine.

sn.def: The state, at any given time, of the faculties of thinking, willing, choosing, and the like; psychical activity or state;

sd.def: Opinion; judgment; belief.
sd.q: A fool uttereth all his mind.
Being so hard to me that brought your mind, I fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling her mind.

sd.def: Choice; inclination; liking; intent; will.
sd.q: If it be your minds, then let none go forth.

sd.def: Courage; spirit.

sn.def: Memory; remembrance; recollection; as, to have or keep in mind, to call to mind, to put in mind, etc.

cs.cd: do not regard it; it is of no consequence; no matter.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Minded; p. pr. & vb. n. Minding
entry.ety: AS. myndian gemyndīan to remember. See Mind n.

sn.def: To fix the mind or thoughts on; to regard with attention; to treat as of consequence; to consider; to heed; to mark; to note.
sn.q: Mindnot high things, but condescend to men of low estate.
My lord, you nod: you do not mind the play.

sn.def: To occupy one's self with; to employ one's self about; to attend to; as, to mind one's business.
sn.q: Bidding him be a good child, and mind his book.

sn.def: To obey; as, to mind parents; the dog minds his master.
To have in mind; to purpose.
sn.q: I mind to tell him plainly what I think.

sn.def: To put in mind; to remind.
sn.q: He minded them of the mutability of all earthly things.
I do thee wrong to mind thee of it.
sn.syn: To notice; mark; regard; obey. See Attend.

entry.def: To give attention or heed; to obey; as, the dog minds well.
producing mood changes or distorted perception; -- used mostly of psychoactive substances; as, hallucinogenic drugs are mind-altering substances.
intensely affecting the mind, especially in producing hallucinations; -- usually of chemical substances.

sn.def: mind-bending.
intensely affecting the mind or emotions; astonishing; -- usually referring to extraordinary experiences; as, spending a week in the jungle was a mind-blowing experience; a mind-blowing horror story.

entry.def: intellectually or emotionally overwhelming; straining one's capacity to comprehend or cope; as, a mind-boggling display; a mind-boggling puzzle.

entry.note: ☞ Minded is much used in composition; as, high-minded, feeble-minded, bloody-minded, sober-minded, double-minded.
entry.def: Disposed; inclined; having a mind.
entry.q: Joseph . . . was minded to put her away privily.
If men were minded to live virtuously.

entry.def: A battle in the Seven Years' War (1759) in which the Anglo-Allied forces under duke Ferdinand of Brunswick defeated the French under Marshal Contades.

sn.def: One who minds, tends, or watches something, as a child, a machine, or cattle; as, a minder of a loom.
One to be attended; specif., a pauper child intrusted to the care of a private person.

entry.def: Bearing in mind; regardful; attentive; heedful; observant.
entry.q: What is man, that thou art mindful of him?
I promise you to be mindful of your admonitions.

entry.def: Regard; mindfulness.

sn.def: Not indued with mind or intellectual powers; stupid; unthinking.
Unmindful; inattentive; heedless; careless.
sn.q: Cursed Athens, mindless of thy worth.

entry.def: See Mien.

entry.note: ☞ Mine is often used absolutely, the thing possessed being understood; as, his son is in the army, mine in the navy.
entry.ety: OE. min, fr. AS. mīn; akin to D. mijn, OS., OFries., & OHG. mīn, G. mein, Sw. & Dan. min, Icel. minn, Goth. meins my, mine, meina of me, and E. me. √187. See Me, and cf. My
entry.def: Belonging to me; my. Used as a pronominal to me; my. Used as a pronominal adjective in the predicate; as, “Vengeance is mine; I will repay.” Rom. xii. 19 . Also, in the old style, used attributively, instead of my, before a noun beginning with a vowel.
entry.q: I kept myself from mine iniquity.
When a man deceives me once, says the Italian proverb, it is his fault; when twice, it is mine.
This title honors me and mine.
She shall have me and mine.

entry.ety: F. miner, L. minare to drive animals, in LL. also, to lead, conduct, dig a mine (cf. E. lode, and lead to conduct), akin to L. minari to threaten; cf. Sp. mina mine, conduit, subterraneous canal, a spring or source of water, It. mina. See Menace, and cf. Mien

sn.def: To dig a mine or pit in the earth; to get ore, metals, coal, or precious stones, out of the earth; to dig in the earth for minerals; to dig a passage or cavity under anything in order to overthrow it by explosives or otherwise.
To form subterraneous tunnel or hole; to form a burrow or lodge in the earth; as, the mining cony.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mined; p. pr. & vb. n. Mining

sn.def: To dig away, or otherwise remove, the substratum or foundation of; to lay a mine under; to sap; to undermine; hence, to ruin or destroy by slow degrees or secret means.
sn.q: They mined the walls.
Too lazy to cut down these immense trees, the spoilers . . . had mined them, and placed a quantity of gunpowder in the cavity.

sn.def: To dig into, for ore or metal.
sn.q: Lead veins have been traced . . . but they have not been mined.

sn.def: To get, as metals, out of the earth by digging.
sn.q: The principal ore mined there is the bituminous cinnabar.

cs.cd: a form of magnetic compass used by miners.
pig iron made wholly from ore; in distinction from cinder pig, which is made from ore mixed with forge or mill cinder.
a mine where gold is obtained.
a rich source of wealth or other good; same as Mine 3.

entry.ety: F., fr. LL. mina. See Mine v. i.
entry.sn:
A subterranean cavity or passage; especially:
A pit or excavation in the earth, from which metallic ores, precious stones, coal, or other mineral substances are taken by digging; -- distinguished from the pits from which stones for architectural purposes are taken, and which are called quarries.
Mil A cavity or tunnel made under a fortification or other work, for the purpose of blowing up the superstructure with some explosive agent.

sn.def: Any place where ore, metals, or precious stones are got by digging or washing the soil; as, a placer mine .

entry.sn: Fig: A rich source of wealth or other good.

sn.def: An explosive device placed concealed in a location, on land or at sea, where an enemy vehicle or enemy personnel may pass through, having a triggering mechanism which detects people or vehicles, and which will explode and kill or maim personnel or destroy or damage vehicles. A mine placed at sea (formerly called a torpedo, see torpedo2) is also called an marine mine and underwater mine and sometimes called a floating mine , even though it may be anchored to the floor of the sea and not actually float freely. A mine placed on land (formerly called a torpedo, see torpedo3}), usually buried, is called a land mine.

entries.entry: mined adj. extracted from a source of supply as of minerals from the earth.Narrower terms: deep-mined; exploited; strip-mined

sn.def: a region in which explosive mines{4} have been placed, especially a region on land.

A situation in which a simple mistake can have disastrous consequences; a touchy or dangerous situation requiring great caution; as, the candidate threaded his way skillfully through a minefield of loaded questions from the audience.

entry.def: a ship equipped for laying underwater mines.
The act or process of laying explosive mines in concealed places to destroy enemy personnel and equipment.

cs.cd: a swelling on the black of the elbow due to inflammation of the bursa over the olecranon; -- so called because of frequent occurrence in miners.
in hydraulic mining, the amount of water flowing under a given pressure in a given time through a hole one inch in diameter. It is a unit for measuring the quantity of water supplied.

sn.def: One who mines; a digger for metals, etc.; one engaged in the business of getting ore, coal, or precious stones, out of the earth; one who digs military mines; as, armies have sappers and miners .

sd.def: Any of numerous insects which, in the larval state, excavate galleries in the parenchyma of leaves. They are mostly minute moths and dipterous flies.
The chattering, or garrulous, honey eater of Australia (Myzantha garrula).

entry.ety: F. minéral, LL. minerale, fr. minera mine. See Mine v. i.

sn.def: An inorganic species or substance occurring in nature, having a definite chemical composition and usually a distinct crystalline form. Rocks, except certain glassy igneous forms, are either simple minerals or aggregates of minerals.
A mine.
Anything which is neither animal nor vegetable, as in the most general classification of things into three kingdoms (animal, vegetable, and mineral).

entry.cs: Mineral acids Chem inorganic acids, as sulphuric, nitric, phosphoric, hydrochloric, acids, etc., as distinguished from the organic acids. Mineral blue the name usually given to azurite, when reduced to an impalpable powder for coloring purposes. Mineral candle a candle made of paraffin. Mineral caoutchouc an elastic mineral pitch, a variety of bitumen, resembling caoutchouc in elasticity and softness. See Caoutchouc, and Elaterite. Mineral chameleon Chem See Chameleon mineral, under Chameleon. Mineral charcoal. See under Charcoal. Mineral cotton. See Mineral woolbelow). Mineral green a green carbonate of copper; malachite. Mineral kingdom Nat. Sci that one of the three grand divisions of nature which embraces all inorganic objects, as distinguished from plants or animals. Mineral oil. See Naphtha, and Petroleum. Mineral paint a pigment made chiefly of some natural mineral substance, as red or yellow iron ocher. Mineral patch. See Bitumen, and Asphalt. Mineral right the right of taking minerals from land. Mineral salt Chem a salt of a mineral acid. Mineral tallow a familiar name for hatchettite, from its fatty or spermaceti-like appearance. Mineral water. See under Water. Mineral wax. See Ozocerite. Mineral wool a fibrous wool-like material, made by blowing a powerful jet of air or steam through melted slag. It is a poor conductor of heat.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to minerals; consisting of a mineral or of minerals; as, a mineral substance.
Impregnated with minerals; as, mineral waters.

entry.def: One versed in minerals; mineralogist.

sn.def: The process of mineralizing, or forming a mineral by combination of a metal with another element; also, the process of converting into a mineral, as a bone or a plant.
The act of impregnating with a mineral, as water.
The conversion of a cell wall into a material of a stony nature.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mineralized; p. pr. & vb. n. Mineralizing

sn.def: To transform into a mineral.
sn.q: In these caverns the bones are not mineralized.

sn.def: To impregnate with a mineral; as, mineralized water.
To charge or impregnate with ore.

entry.def: To go on an excursion for observing and collecting minerals; to mineralogize.

sn.def: containing or impregnated with minerals; as, mineralized water; red stains that signify mineralized land.
converted into a mineral.

entry.def: An element which is combined with a metal, thus forming an ore. Thus, in galena, or lead ore, sulphur is a mineralizer; in hematite, oxygen is a mineralizer .
Of or pertaining to mineralogy; as, a mineralogical table.
According to the principles of, or with reference to, mineralogy.

sn.def: One versed in mineralogy; one devoted to the study of minerals.
A carrier shell (Phorus).

entry.def: To study mineralogy by collecting and examining minerals.

entries.entry:
Min`er*al"o*gy n.; pl.Mineralogies #.
Mineral + -logy: cf. F. minéralogie
The science which treats of minerals, and teaches how to describe, distinguish, and classify them.
A treatise or book on this science.

entry.def: The goddess of wisdom, of war, of the arts and sciences, of poetry, and of spinning and weaving; -- identified with the Grecian Pallas Athene.
A boat designed for the purpose of detecting and disposing of marine mines.

sn.def: the activity of detecting and disposing of marine mines.

entry.def: The smallest of regular sizes of portrait photographs.
Same as Miniver.

entry.ety: AS. myngian; akin to E. mind
entry.def: To mingle; to mix.
A small biting fly; a midge.
an extreme stinginess.
entry.syn: meanness, niggardliness, niggardness, parsimony, parsimoniousness, tightfistedness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mingled; p. pr. & vb. n. Mingling
entry.ety: From OE. mengen, AS. mengan; akin to D. & G. mengen, Icel. menga, also to E. among, and possibly to mix. Cf. Among Mongrel

sn.def: To mix; intermix; to combine or join, as an individual or part, with other parts, but commonly so as to be distinguishable in the product; to confuse; to confound.
sn.q: There was . . . fire mingled with the hail.

sn.def: To associate or unite in society or by ties of relationship; to cause or allow to intermarry; to intermarry.
sn.q: The holy seed have mingled themselves with the people of those lands.

sn.def: To deprive of purity by mixture; to contaminate.
sn.q: A mingled, imperfect virtue.

sn.def: To put together; to join.
To make or prepare by mixing the ingredients of.
sn.q: He] proceeded to mingle another draught.

sn.def: To become mixed or blended.
To associate (with certain people); as, he's too highfalutin to mingle with working stiffs.
To move (among other people); -- of people; as, the president left his car to mingle with the crowd; a host at a a party should mingle with his guests.

entry.def: A mixture.
That can be mingled.
Confusedly.
To mix in a disorderly way; to make a mess of.
A hotchpotch.
The act of mingling, or the state of being mixed.
One who mingles.
In a mingling manner.
Of the color of minium or red lead; miniate.
Migniard.
To render delicate or dainty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Miniated; p. pr. & vb. n. Miniating
entry.ety: L. miniatus, p. p. of miniare. See Minium
entry.def: To paint or tinge with red lead or vermilion; also, to decorate with letters, or the like, painted red, as the page of a manuscript.
Of or pertaining to the color of red lead or vermilion; painted with vermilion.

entry.ety: It. miniatura, fr. L. miniare. See Miniate v.,Minium

sn.def: Originally, a painting in colors such as those in mediæval manuscripts; in modern times, any very small painting, especially a portrait.
Greatly diminished size or form; reduced scale.
Lettering in red; rubric distinction.
A particular feature or trait.

entry.def: Being on a small scale; much reduced from the reality; as, a miniature copy.
To represent or depict in a small compass, or on a small scale.
miniaturization.
miniaturize.
A painter of miniatures.
The act or process of making on a greatly reduced scale.
To design or construct on a smaller scale.

entry.ety: L. minor less + -bus, as in omnibus

sn.def: A kind of light passenger vehicle, carrying four persons.

A type of bus (omnibus) similar in general appearnace to a standard-sized bus, but smaller and having a smaller passenger capacity, typically about 15 persons. It is usually used for transportation over relatively short distances.

entry.def: a mid-sized digital computer; at any given point in the development of computer technology, a minicomputer will be faster and have greater capacity than a microcomputer, but will be slower and have less capacity than a mainframe computer.

entries.entry: Min"ie ball`. From the inventor, Captain Minié, of France A conical rifle bullet, with a cavity in its base plugged with a piece of iron, which, by the explosion of the charge, is driven farther in, expanding the sides to fit closely the grooves of the barrel.
Min"ie ri"fle. A rifle adapted to minie balls.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Minified; p. pr. & vb. n. Minifying

sn.def: To make small, or smaller; to diminish the apparent dimensions of; to lessen.
To degrade by speech or action.

entry.ety: OD. minneken a darling, dim. of minne love; akin to G. minne, and to E. mind

sn.def: A little darling; a favorite; a minion.
A little pin.

entry.def: Small; diminutive.

entry.ety: F. minime, L. minimus the least, smallest, a superl. of minor: cf. It. minima a note in music. See Minor, and cf. Minimum

sn.def: Anything very minute; as, the minims of existence; -- applied to animalcula; and the like.

The smallest liquid measure, equal to about one drop; the sixtieth part of a fluid drachm, equal to one four-hundred-eightieth of a fluid ounce, or 0.06161 milliliter (U. S. measure) or 0.05919 milliliters (British measure).
A small fish; a minnow.
A little man or being; a dwarf.
One of an austere order of mendicant hermits or friars founded in the 15th century by St. Francis of Paola.
A time note, formerly the shortest in use; a half note, equal to half a semibreve, or two quarter notes or crotchets.
A short poetical encomium.

entry.def: Minute.
entry.q: Minimforms.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or having a character of, a minim or minimum; least; smallest; as, a minimal amount or value.
A trifle; a trinket; a token.
minimization.
The act or process of minimizing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. minimized mĭn"ĭ*mīzd; p. pr. & vb. n. minimizing mĭn"ĭ*mī*zĭng

sn.def: To reduce to the smallest part or proportion possible; to reduce to a minimum.
To represent, to oneself or others, as of no importance or minimal importance or effect; to belittle or disarage.

entry.def: Reduced to the smallest possible size or amount or degree.

entries.entry:
Min"i*mum
Minimum thermometer a thermometer for recording the lowest temperature since its last adjustment.
n.; pl.Minima #. L., fr. minimus. See Minim
The least quantity assignable, admissible, or possible, in a given case; hence, a thing of small consequence; -- opposed to maximum.

‖Min"i*mus
de minimisorde minimus
a. of trifling consequence or importance; too insignificant to be worthy of concern; -- a reference to the phrase de minimis non curat lex. de minimis non curat lex Latin The law does not concern itself with trifles; -- a principle of law, that even if a technical violation of a law appears to exist according to the letter of the law, if the effect is too small to be of consequence, the violation of the law will not be considered as a sufficient cause of action, whether in civil or criminal proceedings.
n.; pl.Minimi #. L. See Minim
A being of the smallest size. Obs
Anat The little finger; the fifth digit, or that corresponding to it, in either the manus or pes.

entry.def: The act or business of making mines or of working them.

entry.cs: Mining engineering. See the Note under Engineering.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to mines; as, mining engineer; mining machinery; a mining region.
Minimum.

entry.ety: F. mignon, fr. OHG. minni love, G. minne; akin to E. mind. See Mind, and cf. Mignonette

sn.def: A loved one; one highly esteemed and favored; -- in a good sense.
sn.q: God's disciple and his dearest minion.
Is this the Athenian minion whom the world Voiced so regardfully?

sn.def: An obsequious or servile dependent or agent of another; a fawning favorite.
sn.q: Go, rate thy minions, proud, insulting boy!

entry.sn: Print A small kind of type, in size between brevier and nonpareil.This line is printed in minion type.This line is printed in minion type.

sn.def: An ancient form of ordnance, the caliber of which was about three inches.

entry.def: Fine; trim; dainty.
entry.q: Their . . .miniondancing.

entry.def: Small; delicate.
entry.q: Hisminionetteface.

entry.def: A size of type between nonpareil and minion; -- used in ornamental borders, etc.
Kind treatment.
To flavor.
Like a minion; daintily.
State of being a minion.
Of the color of red or vermilion.

entry.ety: OE. menusen, F. menuiser to make small, cut small, fr. (assumed) LL. minutiare, for minutare, fr. L. minutus small. See Minute a., and cf. Diminish Minge
entry.def: To diminish; to lessen.
entry.q: The living of poor men thereby minished.

entry.def: The act of diminishing, or the state of being diminished; diminution.

entry.note: ☞ Ambassadors are classed (in the diplomatic sense) in the first rank of public ministers, ministers plenipotentiary in the second. “The United States diplomatic service employs two classes of ministers, -- ministers plenipotentiary and ministers resident.”
entry.ety: OE. ministre, F. ministre, fr. L. minister, orig. a double comparative from the root of minor less, and hence meaning, an inferior, a servant. See 1st Minor, and cf. Master Minstrel

sn.def: A servant; a subordinate; an officer or assistant of inferior rank; hence, an agent, an instrument.
sn.q: Moses rose up, and his minister Joshua.
I chose Camillo for the minister, to poison My friend Polixenes.

sn.def: An officer of justice.
sn.q: I cry out the on the ministres, quod he, That shoulde keep and rule this cité.

sn.def: One to whom the sovereign or executive head of a government intrusts the management of affairs of state, or some department of such affairs.
sn.q: Ministers to kings, whose eyes, ears, and hands they are, must be answerable to God and man.

sn.def: A representative of a government, sent to the court, or seat of government, of a foreign nation to transact diplomatic business.
One who serves at the altar; one who performs sacerdotal duties; the pastor of a church duly authorized or licensed to preach the gospel and administer the sacraments.
sn.syn: Delegate; official; ambassador; clergyman; parson; priest.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ministered; p. pr. & vb. n. Ministering
entry.ety: OE. ministren, OF. ministrer, fr. L. ministrare. See Minister n.
entry.def: To furnish or apply; to afford; to supply; to administer.
entry.q: He that ministereth seed to the sower.
We minister to God reason to suspect us.

sn.def: To act as a servant, attendant, or agent; to attend and serve; to perform service in any office, sacred or secular.
sn.q: The Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister.

sn.def: To supply or to things needful; esp., to supply consolation or remedies; as, to minister to the sick.
sn.q: Canst thou not minister to a mind diseased?

entry.cs: The ministerial benches the benches in the House of Commons occupied by members of the cabinet and their supporters; -- also, the persons occupying them. “Very solid and very brilliant talents distinguish the ministerial benches.” Burke.
entry.ety: L. ministerialis: cf. F. ministériel. See Minister, and cf. Minstrel

sn.def: Of or pertaining to ministry or service; serving; attendant.
sn.q: Enlightening spirits and ministerial flames.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the office of a minister or to the ministry as a body, whether civil or sacerdotal.
sn.q: Ministerialoffices.
Aministerialmeasure.
Ministerialgarments.

sn.def: Tending to advance or promote; contributive.
sn.q: Ministerialto intellectual culture.

entry.def: A supporter of the ministers, or the party in power.
In a ministerial manner; in the character or capacity of a minister.
See Ministry.
Ministration.
Ministerial.

entry.ety: L. ministrans -antis, of ministrare to minister
entry.def: Performing service as a minister; attendant on service; acting under command; subordinate.
entry.q: Princedoms and dominationsministrant.

entry.def: The act of ministering; service; ministry.
entry.q: The days of hisministration.

entry.def: Serving to aid; ministering.
A woman who ministers.

entries.entry:
Min"is*try n.; pl. Ministries #. L. ministerium. See Minister n., and cf. Mystery a trade
The act of ministering; ministration; service. With tenderministry.
Hence: Agency; instrumentality. The ordinary ministry of second causes. The wicked ministry of arms.
The office, duties, or functions of a minister, servant, or agent; ecclesiastical, executive, or ambassadorial function or profession.
The body of ministers of state; also, the clergy, as a body.
Administration; rule; term in power; as, the ministry of Pitt.

entry.def: The office of a minister.

entry.ety: L. minium, an Iberian word, the Romans getting all their cinnabar from Spain; cf. Basque armineá
entry.def: A heavy, brilliant red pigment, consisting of an oxide of lead, Pb3O4, obtained by exposing lead or massicot to a gentle and continued heat in the air. It is used as a cement, as a paint, and in the manufacture of flint glass. Called also red lead lead tetroxide lead orthoplumbate mineral orange mineral red Paris red Saturn red, and less definitively, lead oxide.
A fur esteemed in the Middle Ages as a part of costume. It is uncertain whether it was the fur of one animal only or of different animals.
A singing bird of India of the family Campephagidæ.

sn.def: A carnivorous mammal of the genus Mustelaforemrly Putorius), allied to the weasel. The European mink is Mustela lutreola. The common American mink (Mustela vison) varies from yellowish brown to black. Its fur is highly valued. Called also minx nurik, and vison.
The fur of the mink{1}. Together with sable, it is one of the most expensive furs not taken from endangerd species. When the fur is taken from animals grown on a farm, it called ranch mink.

entry.ety: G., fr. minne love + singen to sing
entry.def: A love-singer; specifically, one of a class of German poets and musicians who flourished from about the middle of the twelfth to the middle of the fourteenth century. They were chiefly of noble birth, and made love and beauty the subjects of their verses.
A resident of Minnesota.
A low shrub (Menziesia pilosa) of the eastern U. S. with downy twigs.

entry.ety: OE. menow, cf. AS. myne; also OE. menuse, OF. menuise small fish; akin to E. minish minute

sn.def: A small European fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Phoxinus lævis, formerly Leuciscus phoxinus); sometimes applied also to the young of larger kinds; -- called also minim and minny. The name is also applied to several allied American species, of the genera Phoxinus Notropis, or Minnilus, and Rhinichthys.
Any of numerous small American cyprinodont fishes of the genus Fundulus, and related genera. They live both in fresh and in salt water. Called also killifish minny, and mummichog.

entry.def: A minnow.

entries.entry:
Mi"no bird" mī"n� bẽrd. Hind. mainā
Zoöl An Asiatic bird (Gracula musica), allied to the starlings. It is black, with a white spot on the wings, and a pair of flat yellow wattles on the head. It is often tamed and taught to pronounce words. It is one of the birds called mynah bird.

cs.cd: the Lesser Asia; that part of Asia which lies between the Euxine, or Black Sea, on the north, and the Mediterranean on the south.
that mode, or scale, in which the third and sixth are minor, -- much used for mournful and solemn subjects.
the rank of persons employed in ecclesiastical offices who are not in holy orders, as doorkeepers, acolytes, etc.

The form of the minor scale is various. The strictly correct form has the third and sixth minor, with a semitone between the seventh and eighth, which involves an augmented second interval, or three semitones, between the sixth and seventh, as, 6/F 7/G♯ 8/A. But, for melodic purposes, both the sixth and the seventh are sometimes made major in the ascending, and minor in the descending, scale, thus:
See Major.
the subject of the conclusion.

entry.ety: L., a comparative with no positive; akin to AS. min small, G. minder less, OHG. minniro, a., min, adv., Icel. minni, a., minnr, adv., Goth. minniza, a., mins, adv., Ir. & Gael. min small, tender, L. minuere to lessen, Gr. miny`qein, Skr. mi to damage. Cf. Minish Minister Minus Minute

sn.def: Inferior in bulk, degree, importance, etc.; less; smaller; of little account; as, minor divisions of a body.
Less by a semitone in interval or difference of pitch; as, a minor third.

entry.note: ☞ In hereditary monarchies, the minority of a sovereign ends at an earlier age than of a subject. The minority of a sovereign of Great Britain ends upon the completion of the eighteenth year of his age.

sn.def: A person of either sex who has not attained the age at which full civil rights are accorded; an infant; in England and the United States, one under twenty-one years of age.

The minor term, that is, the subject of the conclusion; also, the minor premise, that is, that premise which contains the minor term; in hypothetical syllogisms, the categorical premise. It is the second proposition of a regular syllogism, as in the following: Every act of injustice partakes of meanness; to take money from another by gaming is an act of injustice; therefore, the taking of money from another by gaming partakes of meanness.
A Minorite; a Franciscan friar.

entry.def: A custom or right, analogous to borough-English in England, formerly existing in various parts of Europe, and surviving in parts of Germany and Austria, by which certain entailed estates, as a homestead and adjacent land, descend to the youngest male heir.

entry.ety: L. minoratus; p. p. of minorare to diminish, fr. minor, a. See 1st Minor
entry.def: To diminish.
A diminution.
See Franciscan Nuns, under Franciscan a.
A Franciscan friar.

entries.entry:
Mi*nor"i*ty n.; pl.Minorities #. Cf. F. minorité. See Minor a. & n.
The state of being a minor, or under age.
State of being less or small. Obs
The smaller number; -- opposed to majority; as, the minority must be ruled by the majority.
Those members of a legislature that belong to the political party which is in the minority in that institution; as, the bill will pass even if the minority are strongly opposed.

entry.note: Certain minor league sports teams are often owned by those owning a major league club, and the minor league clubs are used to provide practise and opportunity for evaluation for candidates who wish to play in the major leagues.
entry.def: A league of professional sports teams less proficient than a major leagues. Players in the minor leagues generally are paid less than those in the major leagues, and their games attract less atention.
Of or pertaining to a minor league.

sn.def: Of mediocre talent or poor accomplishment; unimportant; -- of people; as, a minor-league physicist.

entry.def: The minor leagues, those leagues of professional sports teams less proficient than the majors, or major leagues.
A king and lawgiver of Crete, fabled to be the son of Jupiter and Europa. After death he was made a judge in the Lower Regions.

entry.ety: L. Minotaurus, Gr. Minw`tayros; Mi`nos, the husband of Pasiphaë + tay^ros a bull, the Minotaur being the offspring of Pasiphaë and a bull: cf. F. minotaure
entry.def: A fabled monster, half man and half bull, confined in the labyrinth constructed by Dædalus in Crete.
See Minnow.

cs.cd: the official house in which the canons of a cathedral live in common or in rotation.

entry.ety: AS. mynster, fr. L. monasterium. See Monastery
entry.def: A church of a monastery. The name is often retained and applied to the church after the monastery has ceased to exist (as Beverly Minster, Southwell Minster, etc.), and is also improperly used for any large church.

entry.ety: OE. minstrel menestral, OF. menestrel, fr. LL. ministerialis servant, workman (cf. ministrellus harpist), fr. L. ministerium service. See Ministry, and cf. Ministerial
entry.def: In the Middle Ages, one of an order of men who subsisted by the arts of poetry and music, and sang verses to the accompaniment of a harp or other instrument; in modern times, a poet; a bard; a singer and harper; a musician.

sn.def: The arts and occupation of minstrels; the singing and playing of a minstrel.
Musical instruments.
A collective body of minstrels, or musicians; also, a collective body of minstrels' songs.
sn.q: Theminstrelsyof heaven.

entry.note: ☞ Corn mint is Mentha arvensis. Horsemint is Mentha sylvestris, and in the United States Monarda punctata, which differs from the true mints in several respects. Mountain mint is any species of the related genus Pycnanthemum, common in North America. Peppermint is Mentha piperita. Spearmint is Mentha viridis. Water mint is Mentha aquatica.
entry.cs: Mint camphor. Chem See Menthol. Mint julep. See Julep. Mint sauce a sauce flavored with spearmint, for meats.
entry.ety: AS. minte, fr. L. mentha, Gr. mi`nqa mi`nqh
entry.def: The name of several aromatic labiate plants, mostly of the genus Mentha, yielding odoriferous essential oils by distillation. See Mentha.

entry.ety: AS. mynet money, coin, fr. L. moneta the mint, coined money, fr. Moneta, a surname of Juno, in whose at Rome money was coined; akin to monere to warn, admonish, AS. manian, and to E. mind. See Mind, and cf. Money Monition

sn.def: A place where money is coined by public authority.
Any place regarded as a source of unlimited supply; the supply itself.
sn.q: A mint of phrases in his brain.

sn.def: A large quantity of money; as, to make a mint in stock trading.

cs.cd: a coining press.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Minted; p. pr. & vb. n. Minting

sn.def: To make by stamping, as money; to coin; to make and stamp into money.
To invent; to forge; to fabricate; to fashion.
sn.q: Titles . . . of such natures as may be easily minted.

entry.def: Like new; in brand-new condition; unworn, as a coin recently made at a mint{1}; as, he had a '53 Cadillac in mint condition.

sn.def: Uncirculated; in the same condition as when it was freshly coined at the mint{1}.
The coin, or other production, made in a mint.
sn.q: Stamped in clay, a heavenly mintage.
