sn.def: The duty paid to the mint for coining. At one time people could bring precious metals, as gold or silver, to a mint and receive in return coins of the same value, minus the commision charged by the mint, which was the mintage.
The act or process of minting{1}; as, a coin of recent mintage .
The quantity of coins of a specific type made by the mint; as, coins of low mintage tend to be more valuable as collectors' items.

entry.def: One who mints.

entries.entry: Mint"man n.; pl.Mintmen. One skilled in coining, or in coins; a coiner.

entry.def: The master or superintendent of a mint. Also used figuratively.

entries.entry:
Mint sauce. A sauce of vinegar and sugar flavored with spearmint leaves.
Money. Slang, Eng

mint state. n. Numismatics A numerical grade indicating the degree of perfection of the condition of a coin which is classified as uncirculated, ranging from 70 for a coin in perfect condition to 60 for a coin which is uncirculated but may have a weak strike, or numerous small scratches from being handled in mint bags; usually used as the abbreviation MS; as, an MS-67 Morgan Dollar.

entry.ety: L. minuendus to be diminished, fr. minuere to lessen, diminish. See Minish
entry.def: In the process of subtraction{2}, the number from which another number (the subtrahend) is to be subtracted, to find the difference.

entry.ety: F., fr. menu small, L. minutus small. So called on account of the short steps of the dance. See 4th Minute

sn.def: A slow graceful dance consisting of a coupee, a high step, and a balance.
A tune or air to regulate the movements of the dance so called; a movement in suites, sonatas, symphonies, etc., having the dance form, and commonly in 3-4, sometimes 3-8, measure.
A small kind of printing type; minion.
A minim.

cs.cd: the sign [-] denoting minus, or less, prefixed to negative quantities, or quantities to be subtracted. See Negative sign, under Negative.

entry.ety: L. See Minor, and cf. Mis- pref. from the French
entry.def: Less; requiring to be subtracted; negative; as, a minus quantity.

entries.entry: mi"nus mī"nŭs n.; pl.minuses mī"nŭs*�z. A factor counted as a disadvantage; a loss or potential loss in a situation or plan; as, he added up all the pluses and minuses and decided not to do it; as, the lack of money is a big minus in an election campaign.

entry.def: of or relating to minuscule script, a small cursive script developed from uncial, and used in the 7th to 9th centuries.

entry.ety: L. minusculus rather small, fr. minus less: cf. F. minuscule

sn.def: Any very small, minute object.
A small Roman letter which is neither capital nor uncial; a manuscript written in such letters.

entry.def: Of or relating to a minuscule{2} or of a script written in minuscules{2}; of the size and style of minuscules{2}; written in minuscules{2}; minuscular.
entry.q: These minuscule letters are cursive forms of the earlier uncials.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or consisting of, minutes.

entry.note: ☞ Different writers take as the minute one twelfth, one eighteenth, one thirtieth, or one sixtieth part of the module.
entry.ety: LL. minuta a small portion, small coin, fr. L. minutus small: cf. F. minute. See 4th Minute

sn.def: The sixtieth part of an hour; sixty seconds. (Abbrev. m. or min.; as, 4 h. 30 m.
sn.q: Four minutes, that is to say, minutes of an hour.

sn.def: The sixtieth part of a degree; sixty seconds (Marked thus ('); as, 10° 20').
A nautical or a geographic mile.
A coin; a half farthing.
A very small part of anything, or anything very small; a jot; a tittle.
sn.q: Minutes and circumstances of his passion.

sn.def: A point of time; a moment.
sn.q: I go this minute to attend the king.

sn.def: The memorandum; a record; a note to preserve the memory of anything; as, to take minutes of a contract; to take minutes of a conversation or debate; to read the minutes of the last meeting.
A fixed part of a module. See Module.

cs.cd: a bell tolled at intervals of a minute, as to give notice of a death or a funeral.
a book in which written minutes are entered.
a glass measuring a minute or minutes by the running of sand.
a discharge of a cannon repeated every minute as a sign of distress or mourning.
the long hand of a watch or clock, which makes the circuit of the dial in an hour, and marks the minutes.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a minute or minutes; occurring at or marking successive minutes.

entry.ety: imp. & p. p. Minuted; p. pr. & vb. n. Minuting
entry.def: To set down a short sketch or note of; to jot down; to make a minute or a brief summary of.
entry.q: The Empress of Russia, with her own hand, minuted an edict for universal tolerance.

entry.usage: Minute Circumstantial Particular. A circumstantial account embraces all the leading events; a particular account includes each event and movement, though of but little importance; a minute account goes further still, and omits nothing as to person, time, place, adjuncts, etc.
entry.ety: L. minutus, p. p. of minuere to lessen. See Minish Minor, and cf. Menu Minuet

sn.def: Very small; little; tiny; fine; slight; slender; inconsiderable; as, minute details.
sn.q: Minutedrops.

sn.def: Attentive to small things; paying attention to details; critical; particular; precise; as, a minute observer; minute observation.
sn.syn: Little; diminutive; fine; critical; exact; circumstantial; particular; detailed.

sn.def: A figure which strikes the hour on the bell of some fanciful clocks; -- called also jack of the clock house.
A timeserver; an inconstant person.

entry.def: In a minute manner; with minuteness; exactly; nicely.

entry.ety: F., fr. mirer to look at carefully, to aim, se mirer to look at one's self in a glass, to reflect, to be reflected, LL. mirare to look at. See Mirror
entry.def: An optical effect, sometimes seen on the ocean, but more frequently in deserts, due to total reflection of light at the surface common to two strata of air differently heated. The reflected image is seen, commonly in an inverted position, while the real object may or may not be in sight. When the surface is horizontal, and below the eye, the appearance is that of a sheet of water in which the object is seen reflected; when the reflecting surface is above the eye, the image is seen projected against the sky. The fata Morgana and looming are species of mirage.
entry.q: By the mirage uplifted the land floats vague in the ether, Ships and the shadows of ships hang in the motionless air.

entry.def: See Nitrobenzene.

Miss to fail of). In words from the French, fr. OF. mes-, F. mé- mes-, fr. L. minus less (see Minus). entry.usage: Mischief Damage Harm. Damage is an injury which diminishes the value of a thing; harm is an injury which causes trouble or inconvenience; mischief is an injury which disturbs the order and consistency of things. We often suffer damage or harm from accident, but mischief always springs from perversity or folly.

entry.note: ☞ As a rule, in the old English law, offenses capitally punishable were felonies; all other indictable offenses were misdemeanors. In common usage, the word crime is employed to denote the offenses of a deeper and more atrocious dye, while small faults and omissions of less consequence are comprised under the gentler name of misdemeanors. Blackstone. The distinction, however, between felonies and misdemeanors is purely arbitrary, and is in most jurisdictions either abrogated or so far reduced as to be without practical value. Cf. Felony. Wharton.

sn.def: The psalm usually appointed for penitential acts, being the 50th psalm in the Latin version. It commences with the word miserere.
A musical composition adapted to the 50th psalm.
sn.q: Where only the wind signs miserere.

sn.def: A small projecting boss or bracket, on the under side of the hinged seat of a church stall (see Stall). It was intended, the seat being turned up, to give some support to a worshiper when standing. Called also misericordia.
Same as Ileus.
Compassion; pity; mercy.
Same as Misericordia, 2.

entry.ety: L., mercy, compassion; miser wretched + cor cordis, heart

sn.def: An amercement.
A thin-bladed dagger; so called, in the Middle Ages, because used to give the death wound or “mercy” stroke to a fallen adversary.
An indulgence as to food or dress granted to a member of a religious order.

entry.def: Like a miser; very covetous; avaricious; stingy; sordid; niggardly.
entry.syn: Avaricious; niggardly; sordid; parsimonious; avaricious; penurious; covetous; stingy; mean. See Avaricious.

entries.entry:
Mi"ser*y n.; pl.Miseries #. OE. miserie, L. miseria, fr. miser wretched: cf. F. misère, OF. also, miserie
Great unhappiness; extreme pain of body or mind; wretchedness; distress; woe. Destruction and misery are in their ways.
Cause of misery; calamity; misfortune. When we our betters see bearing our woes, We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
Covetousness; niggardliness; avarice. Obs Wretchedness; torture; agony; torment; anguish; distress; calamity; misfortune.

entry.def: Want of esteem; disrespect.
To estimate erroneously.
An erroneous explanation.
Wrong explication.
Wrong exposition.

Wrong expression.
Want of faith; distrust.

entry.vmorph: imp. Misfell; p. p. Misfallen; p. pr. & vb. n. Misfalling
entry.def: To befall, as ill luck; to happen to unluckily.
To fare ill.
To form wrongly.

entry.ety: OF. pref. mes- wrong (L. minus less) + faisance doing, fr. faire to do, L. facere. Cf. Malfeasance
entry.def: A trespass; a wrong arising from an overt act; the improper doing of an act which a person might lawfully do.
Ill feature.
Insensate.
To feign with an evil design.

sn.def: The act or the state of fitting badly; as, a misfit in making a coat; a ludicrous misfit.
Something that fits badly, as a garment.
sn.q: I saw an uneasy change in Mr. Micawber, which sat tightly on him, as if his new duties were a misfit.

sn.def: A person who does not fit in comfortably with the surrounding situation or society; one who cannot conform or adjust to the circumstances in which he lives.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misformed; p. pr. & vb. n. Misforming
entry.def: To make in an ill form.
Malformation.
Producing misfortune.
Bad fortune or luck; calamity; an evil accident; disaster; mishap; mischance.
entry.q: Consider why the change was wrought, You 'll find his misfortune, not his fault.
entry.syn: Calamity; mishap; mischance; misadventure; ill; harm; disaster. See Calamity.

entry.def: To happen unluckily or unfortunately; to miscarry; to fail.
Unfortunate.
To frame wrongly.
To get wrongfully.
See Misgye.

entry.vmorph: imp. Misgave; p. p. Misgiven; p. pr. & vb. n. Misgiving

sn.def: To give or grant amiss.

Specifically: To give doubt and apprehension to, instead of confidence and courage; to impart fear to; to make irresolute; -- usually said of the mind or heart, and followed by the objective personal pronoun.
sn.q: So doth my heart misgive me in these conflicts What may befall him, to his harm and ours.
Such whose consciences misgave them, how ill they had deserved.

sn.def: To suspect; to dread.

entry.def: To give out doubt and apprehension; to be fearful or irresolute.
entry.q: My mindmisgives.

entry.def: Evil premonition; doubt; distrust; a feeling of apprehension; -- used commonly in the plural.
entry.q: Suspicious andmisgivings.

entry.def: To go astray.
Unjustly gotten.
To govern badly; as, to misgovern a country.
Misgovernment; misconduct; misbehavior.
Ill governed, as a people; ill directed.

entry.def: Bad government; want of government.
Not gracious.
To misgraft.
To graft wrongly.
To found erroneously.
entry.q: Misgroundedconceit.

entry.def: Bad growth; an unnatural or abnormal growth.
To guess wrongly.
Wrong guidance.
To guide wrongly; to lead astray; as, to misguide the understanding.
Misguidance; error.
Misleading.
To misguide.
To handle ill or wrongly; to maltreat.
Evil accident; ill luck; misfortune; mischance.
entry.q: Secure from worldly chances and mishaps.

entry.def: To happen unluckily; -- used impersonally.
entry.q: If that memishap.

entry.def: To happen ill or unluckily.
Unhappy.
The scup.
To hear incorrectly.

entry.ety: Cf. G. mish-mash, fr. mischen to mix
entry.def: A hodgepodge or hotchpotch; a confused jumble.

entry.ety: NHeb. mishnāh, i. e., repetition, doubling, explanation (of the divine law), fr. Heb. shānāh to change, to repeat
entry.def: A collection or digest of Jewish traditions and explanations of Scripture, forming the text of the Talmud.
Of or pertaining to the Mishna.
Wrong imagination; delusion.
To use for a bad purpose; to abuse; to misuse; as, to misimprove time, talents, advantages, etc.
Ill use or employment; use for a bad purpose.
To cause to have a wrong inclination or tendency; to affect wrongly.
To infer incorrectly.
To give untrue information to; to inform wrongly.
To give untrue information; (with against) to calumniate.
A misinformer.
Untrue or incorrect information.
One who gives untrue or incorrect information.
To instruct amiss.
Wrong or improper instruction.

sn.def: Wrong information; misinformation.
Disagreement; misunderstanding.

entry.def: To aim amiss.
To interpret erroneously; to understand or to explain in a wrong sense.
Capable of being misinterpreted; liable to be misunderstood.
The act of interpreting erroneously; a mistaken interpretation.
One who interprets erroneously.
To join unfitly or improperly.
An incorrect union of parties or of causes of action in a procedure, criminal or civil.
To judge erroneously or unjustly; to err in judgment; to misconstrue.
A wrong or unjust judgment.
To keep wrongly.
Not to know.
A little bagpipe.
To kindle amiss; to inflame to a bad purpose; to excite wrongly.
To have a mistaken notion of or about.
Defective flow or vitiated condition of the milk.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mislaid; p. pr. & vb. n. Mislaying

sn.def: To lay in a wrong place; to ascribe to a wrong source.
sn.q: The fault is generally mislaid upon nature.

sn.def: To lay in a place not recollected; to misplace; to lose.
sn.q: The . . . charter, indeed, was unfortunately mislaid: and the prayer of their petition was to obtain one of like import in its stead.

entry.def: One who mislays.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misled; p. pr. & vb. n. Misling
entry.ety: Prop. mistle, fr. mist. Cf. Mistle Mizzle
entry.def: To rain in very fine drops, like a thick mist; to mizzle; to drizzle.
A fine rain; a thick mist; a mizzle; a drizzle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misled mĭs*lĕd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Misleading
entry.ety: AS. mislǣdan. See Mis-, and Lead to conduct
entry.def: To lead into a wrong way or path; to lead astray; to guide into error; to cause to mistake; to deceive.
entry.q: Trust not servants who mislead or misinform you.
To give due light To the mislead and lonely traveler.

entry.def: One who leads into error.
Leading astray; delusive.
To learn wrongly.
imp. & p. p. of Mislead.
See Maslin.
See Mistletoe.
To deceive or lead astray with a false light.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misliked mĭs*līkt"; p. pr. & vb. n. Misliking
entry.ety: AS. mislīcian to displease. See Like v.
entry.def: To dislike; to disapprove of; to have aversion to; as, to mislike a man.
entry.q: Who may like or mislike what he says.

entry.def: Dislike; disapprobation; aversion.
One who dislikes.
Dislike; aversion.
See Maslin.
To live amiss.
To lodge amiss.
Ill luck; misfortune.
Raining in very small drops; drizzling.
To make or form amiss; to spoil in making.

entry.def: To manage ill or improperly; as, to mismanage public affairs.
Wrong or bad management; as, he failed through mismagement .
One who manages ill.
To mark wrongly.
To match unsuitably.

entry.sn: Matched unsuitably; grouped into pairs or sets with incompatible characteristics.Narrower terms: ill-sorted, incompatible, mismated, unsuited; odd, unmatched, unmated, unpaired Also See: incompatible. Antonym: matched.

sn.def: Of very unequal ability; -- of contestants in a contest. The less able contestant is said to be overmatched or outclassed.

entry.def: To mate wrongly or unsuitably; to mismatch; as, to mismate gloves or shoes; a mismated couple.
To measure or estimate incorrectly.
Wrong measurement.
To give the wrong meter to, as to a line of verse.
To call by the wrong name; to give a wrong or inappropriate name to.

entry.ety: OF. pref. mes- amiss, wrong (L. minus less) + F. nommer to name, L. nominare, fr. nomen name. See Name
entry.def: The misnaming of a person in a legal instrument, as in a complaint or indictment; any misnaming of a person or thing; a wrong or inapplicable name or title.
entry.q: Many of the changes, by a great misnomer, called parliamentary “reforms”.
The word “synonym” is fact a misnomer.

entry.def: To misname.
To number wrongly.
To nurture or train wrongly; as, to misnurture children.
Mistaken obedience; disobedience.
To observe inaccurately; to mistake in observing.
One who misobserves; one who fails to observe properly.
A hater of marriage.
Hatred of marriage.
misogynous.
misogyny.

entry.ety: Gr. misogy`nhs misogy`naios; misei^n to hate + gynh` woman: cf. F. misogyne
entry.def: A woman hater. Contrast misandrist.
Hating women; having deep-seated distrust of women; -- used of men.
Hatred of women. Contrast misandry.

entry.ety: Gr. misologi`a; misei^n to hate + lo`gos discourse
entry.def: Hatred of argument or discussion; hatred of enlightenment.
Wrong opinion.
To order ill; to manage erroneously; to conduct badly.
Irregularity; disorder.
Irregular; disorderly.
Wrong ordination.

entry.ety: Gr. misei^n to hate + qeo`s god
entry.def: Hatred of God.
To paint ill, or wrongly.
Wrong passion or feeling.
To dissatisfy.

entry.mhw: Mis*pell" v. t. Mis*pend" v. t., etc.
entry.def: See Misspell Misspend, etc.
See Misspense.
Erroneous perception.
To persuade amiss.
A false persuasion; wrong notion or opinion.
Arsenical iron pyrites; arsenopyrite.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misplaced; p. pr. & vb. n. Misplacing

sn.def: To put in a wrong place; to set or place on an improper or unworthy object; as, he misplaced his confidence.
To place in a location that one does not recall; to mislay; to lose.

entry.def: The act of misplacing, or the state of being misplaced.
To err in pleading.
An error in pleading.
To point improperly; to punctuate wrongly.
Wrong policy; impolicy.
Wrong practice.
To praise amiss.
To print wrongly; to make a mistake in printing.
A mistake in printing; a deviation from the copy; as, a book full of misprints . Misprints are sometimes noted and corrected in a list of corrigenda distributed with a book.
See Misprize.

entry.ety: OF. mesprise mistake, F. méprise, fr. mespris, masc., mesprise, fem., p. p. of mesprendre to mistake; F. méprendre; pref. mes- amiss + prendre to take, L. prehendere
entry.def: To mistake.

entry.note: ☞ In its larger and older sense it was used to signify “every considerable misdemeanor which has not a certain name given to it in the law.” Russell. In a more modern sense it is applied exclusively to two offenses:1.Misprision of treason, which is omission to notify the authorities of an act of treason by a person cognizant thereof. Stephen.2.Misprision of felony, which is a concealment of a felony by a person cognizant thereof. Stephen.
entry.ety: LL. misprisio, or OF. mesprison, prop., a mistaking, but confused with OF. mespris contempt, F. mépris. See 2d Misprise Misprize Prison

sn.def: The act of misprising; misapprehension; misconception; mistake.
sn.q: The misprision of this passage has aided in fostering the delusive notion.

sn.def: Neglect; undervaluing; contempt.
A neglect, negligence, or contempt.

entry.ety: OF. mesprisier to deprise, F. mépriser; pref. amiss, wrong (L. minus less + LL. pretium price. See price Prize v.
entry.def: To slight or undervalue.
entry.q: O, for those vanished hours, so much misprized!
I do not blame them, madam, nor misprize.

entry.def: Wrong or irregular proceding.
To make a false profession; to make pretensions to skill which is not possessed.
To make a false profession of.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mispronounced; p. pr. & vb. n. Mispronouncing
entry.def: To pronounce incorrectly.
Wrong or improper pronunciation.
To give wrong or unesthetic proportions to; to join without due proportion; as, the legs were misrpoportioned to the body.
An improper or unesthetic proportion.
Viciously proud.
To punctuate wrongly or incorrectly.
Erroneous or inaccurate quotation.
To quote erroneously or incorrectly.
To raise or excite unreasonable.
entry.q: Misraisedfury.

entry.def: To rate erroneously.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misread; p. pr. & vb. n. Misreading
entry.def: To read amiss; to misunderstand in reading.
To receive wrongly.
An inaccurate recital.
To recite erroneously.
To reckon wrongly; to miscalculate.
An erroneous computation.
To have an erroneous remembrance of; to suppose erroneously that one recollects.
Erroneous or inaccurate recollection.
To reform wrongly or imperfectly.
Wrong understanding; misconstruction.
To regulate wrongly or imperfectly; to fail to regulate.
To rehearse or quote incorrectly.
To relate inaccurately.
Erroneous relation or narration.
False religion.
To mistake in remembering; not to remember correctly.
To render wrongly; to translate or recite wrongly.
To repeat wrongly; to give a wrong version of.
To report erroneously; to give an incorrect account of.
An erroneous report; a false or incorrect account given.
To represent incorrectly (almost always, unfavorably); to give a false or erroneous representation of, either maliciously, ignorantly, or carelessly.
To make an incorrect or untrue representation.

entry.note: ☞ In popular use, this word often conveys the idea of intentional untruth.
entry.def: Untrue representation; false or incorrect statement or account; -- usually unfavorable to the thing represented; as, a misrepresentation of a person's motives.
Tending to convey a wrong impression; misrepresenting.
One who misrepresents.
To have in wrong estimation; to repute or estimate erroneously.
To rule badly; to misgovern.

entry.cs: Abbot of MisruleorLord of Misrule . See under Abbot, and Lord.

sn.def: The act, or the result, of misruling.
Disorder; confusion; tumult from insubordination.
sn.q: Enormous riot and misrule surveyed.

entry.def: Unruly.

entries.entry:
Miss ☞ There is diversity of usage in the application of this title to two or more persons of the same name. We may write either the Miss Browns or the Misses Brown. mĭs n.; pl.Misses mĭs"sĕz. Contr. fr. mistress
A title of courtesy prefixed to the name of a girl or a woman who has not been married. See Mistress, 5.
A young unmarried woman or a girl; as, she is a miss of sixteen. Gay vanity, with smiles and kisses, Was busy 'mongst the maids and misses.
A kept mistress. See Mistress, 4. Obs
Card Playing In the game of three-card loo, an extra hand, dealt on the table, which may be substituted for the hand dealt to a player.

entry.cs: To miss stays. Naut See under Stay.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Missed mĭst; p. pr. & vb. n. Missing
entry.ety: AS. missan; akin to D. & G. missen, OHG. missan, Icel. missa, Sw. mista, Dan. miste. √100. See Mis-, pref

sn.def: To fail of hitting, reaching, getting, finding, seeing, hearing, etc.; as, to miss the mark one shoots at; to miss the train by being late; to miss opportunites of getting knowledge; to miss the point or meaning of something said.
sn.q: When a man misses his great end, happiness, he will acknowledge he judged not right.

sn.def: To omit; to fail to have or to do; to get without; to dispense with; -- now seldom applied to persons.
sn.q: She would never miss, one day, A walk so fine, a sight so gay.
We cannot miss him; he does make our fire, Fetch in our wood.

sn.def: To discover the absence or omission of; to feel the want of; to mourn the loss of; to want; as, to miss an absent loved one.
sn.q: Neither missed we anything . . . Nothing was missed of all that pertained unto him.
What by me thou hast lost, thou least shalt miss.

sn.def: To fail to hit; to fly wide; to deviate from the true direction.
sn.q: Men observe when things hit, and not when they miss.

sn.def: To fail to obtain, learn, or find; -- with of.
sn.q: Upon the least reflection, we can not miss of them.

sn.def: To go wrong; to err.
To be absent, deficient, or wanting.
sn.q: What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.

sn.def: The act of missing; failure to hit, reach, find, obtain, etc.
Loss; want; felt absence.
sn.q: There will be no great miss of those which are lost.

sn.def: Mistake; error; fault.
sn.q: He did without any great miss in the hardest points of grammar.

sn.def: Harm from mistake.

entries.entry:
‖Mis"sa n.; pl.Missæ #. LL. See 1st Mass
R. C. Ch The service or sacrifice of the Mass.

entry.ety: LL. missale, liber missalis, from missa mass: cf. F. missel. See 1st Mass
entry.def: The book containing the service of the Mass for the entire year; a Mass book.
Of or pertaining to the Mass, or to a missal or Mass book.

sn.def: To say wrongly.
To speak evil of; to slander.

entry.def: To speak ill.
To seek for wrongly.

sn.def: To make a false appearance.
To misbecome; to be misbecoming.

cs.cd: a large European thrush (Turdus viscivorus) which feeds on the berries of the mistletoe; -- called also mistletoe thrush and missel.

entry.def: Mistletoe.
The mistletoe.
See Mistletoe.
False resemblance or semblance.
To send amiss or incorrectly.
To serve unfaithfully.
To set or place wrongly.
To shape ill; to give an ill or unnatural from to; to deform.
entry.q: Figures monstrous andmisshaped.

entry.def: Having a bad or ugly form.
entry.q: The mountains aremisshapen.

entry.def: Sheathed by mistake; wrongly sheathed; sheathed in a wrong place.

entry.ety: LL. missa Mass + -ficarein comp.) to make. See fy-
entry.def: To perform Mass.

entry.ety: L. missils, fr. mittere missum, to cause to go, to send, to throw; cf. Lith. mesti to throw: cf. F. missile. Cf. Admit Dismiss Mass the religious service, Message Mission
entry.def: Capable of being thrown; adapted for hurling or to be projected from the hand, or from any instrument or engine{2}, so as to strike an object at a distance.
entry.q: We bend the bow, or wing the missile dart.

entry.note: Numerous types of rocket-propelled missile{2} are now used in modern warfare. Some types with names indicating their range or function are: antiaircraft missile; ballistic missile; cruise missile; antiballistic missile missile; air-to-air missile; air-to-ground missile; guided missile; intercontinental ballistic missile IBM); intermediate range ballistic missile IRBM); surface-to-air missile.

sn.def: A weapon thrown or projected or intended to be projected, as a lance, an arrow, or a bullet.
A rocket-propelled device designed to fly through the air and deliver a warhead of explosive materials to a target.

entry.def: Absent from the place where it was expected to be found; lost; lacking; wanting; not present when called or looked for.
entry.q: Neither was there aught missing unto them.
For a time caught up to God, as once Moses was in the mount, and missing long.

entry.def: With a sense of loss.

entry.cs: Mission school. A school connected with a mission and conducted by missionaries. A school for the religious instruction of children not having regular church privileges.
entry.ety: L. missio, fr. mittere missum, to send: cf. F. mission. See Missile

sn.def: The act of sending, or the state of being sent; a being sent or delegated by authority, with certain powers for transacting business; comission.
sn.q: Whose glorious deeds, but in these fields of late, Made emulous missions 'mongst the gods themselves.

sn.def: That with which a messenger or agent is charged; an errand; business or duty on which one is sent; a commission.
sn.q: How to begin, how to accomplish best His end of being on earth, and mission high.

sn.def: Persons sent; any number of persons appointed to perform any service; a delegation; an embassy; as, the Russian mission to the United Nations.
sn.q: In these ships there should be a mission of three of the fellows or brethren of Solomon's house.

sn.def: An assotiation or organization of missionaries; a station or residence of missionaries.
An organization for worship and work, dependent on one or more churches.
A course of extraordinary sermons and services at a particular place and time for the special purpose of quickening the faith and zeal participants, and of converting unbelievers.
Dismission; discharge from service.

entry.def: To send on a mission.
entry.mark: Mostly used in the form of the past participle

entries.entry:
Mis"sion*ary
Missionary apostolic a Roman Catholic missionary sent by commission from the pope.
n.; pl.Missionaries #. Cf. F. missionnaire. See Mission n
One who is sent on a mission; especially, one sent to propagate religion.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to missions; as, a missionary meeting; a missionary fund.
A missionary; an envoy; one who conducts a mission. See Mission n., 6.
entry.q: Like mightymissioneryou come.

entry.def: A mistress; a wife; -- so used by the illiterate.
Like a miss; prim; affected; sentimental.

sn.def: A geological period extending from from 310 million to 345 million years ago; it was associated with an increase of land areas, the presence of primitive ammonites, and emergence of winged insects; called also Missippian period and Lower Carboniferous period.
sn.syn: Missippian period, Lower Carboniferous, Lower Carboniferous period.

sn.def: A resident of Mississippi.

entry.def: To sit badly or imperfectly upon; to misbecome.

cs.cd: letters conveying the permission, comand, or advice of a superior authority, as a sovereign. They are addressed and sent to some certain person or persons, and are distinguished from letters patent, which are addressed to the public.

sn.def: Specially sent; intended or prepared to be sent; as, a letter missive .
Missile.
sn.q: Themissiveweapons fly.

entry.ety: F. lettre missive. See Mission n.

sn.def: That which is sent; a writing containing a message.
One who is sent; a messenger.

entry.def: To sound wrongly; to utter or pronounce incorrectly.
A resident of Missouri.
To err in speaking.
To utter wrongly.
Wrong speech.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misspelled, or Misspelt; p. pr. & vb. n. Misspelling
entry.def: To spell incorrectly.
A wrong spelling.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misspent; p. pr. & vb. n. Misspending
entry.def: To spend amiss or for wrong purposes; to squander; to waste; as, to misspend time or money.
One who misspends.
A spending improperly; a wasting.
imp. & p. p. of Misspend.
To state wrongly; as, to misstate a question in debate.
An incorrect statement.
Having missed stays; -- said of a ship.
A wrong step; an error of conduct.
To take a wrong step; to go astray.
Failure.
Wrong or evil suggestion.
Wrong summation.
To swear falsely.
See Misy.
An affectionate, or contemptuous, form of miss; a young girl; a miss.

cs.cd: a composite plant (Eupatorium cœlestinum), having heart-shaped leaves, and corymbs of lavender-blue flowers. It is found in the Western and Southern United States.

entry.ety: AS. mist; akin to D. & Sw. mist, Icel. mistr, G. mist dung, Goth. maíhstus, AS. mīgan to make water, Icel. mīga, Lith. migla mist, Russ. mgla, L. mingere meiere, to make water, Gr. � to make water, � mist, Skr. mih to make water, n., a mist m☞gha cloud. √102. Cf. Misle Mizzle Mixen

sn.def: Visible watery vapor suspended in the atmosphere, at or near the surface of the earth; fog.
Coarse, watery vapor, floating or falling in visible particles, approaching the form of rain; as, Scotch mist .
Hence, anything which dims or darkens, and obscures or intercepts vision.
sn.q: His passion cast a mist before his sense.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misted; p. pr. & vb. n. Misting
entry.def: To cloud; to cover with mist; to dim.
To rain in very fine drops; as, it mists .
Liable to be mistaken; capable of being misconceived.

entry.vmorph: imp. & obs. p. p. Mistook mĭs*t�k"; p. p. Mistaken mĭs*tāk"'n; p. pr. & vb. n. Mistaking
entry.ety: Pref. mis- + take: cf. Icel. mistaka

sn.def: To take or choose wrongly.
To take in a wrong sense; to misunderstand misapprehend, or misconceive; as, to mistake a remark; to mistake one's meaning.
sn.q: My father's purposes have been mistook.

sn.def: To substitute in thought or perception; as, to mistake one person for another.
sn.q: A man may mistake the love of virtue for the practice of it.

sn.def: To have a wrong idea of in respect of character, qualities, etc.; to misjudge.
sn.q: Mistake me not so much, To think my poverty is treacherous.

entry.def: To err in knowledge, perception, opinion, or judgment; to commit an unintentional error.
entry.q: Servants mistake, and sometimes occasion misunderstanding among friends.

cs.cd: surely; without fail; as, it will happen at the appointed time, and no mistake .

sn.def: An apprehending wrongly; a misconception; a misunderstanding; a fault in opinion or judgment; an unintentional error of conduct.
sn.q: Infallibility is an absolute security of the understanding from all possibility of mistake.

sn.def: Misconception, error, which when non-negligent may be ground for rescinding a contract, or for refusing to perform it.
Being in error; judging wrongly; having a wrong opinion or a misconception; as, a mistaken man; he is mistaken.
Erroneous; wrong; as, a mistaken notion.

entry.def: By mistake.
Erroneousness.
One who mistakes.
entry.q: Well meaning ignorance of some mistakers.

entry.def: An error; a mistake.
Erroneously.
Wrongly taught; as, a mistaught youth.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mistaught; p. pr. & vb. n. Misteaching
entry.def: To teach wrongly; to instruct erroneously.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mistold; p. pr. & vb. n. Mistelling
entry.def: To tell erroneously.
To temper ill; to disorder; as, to mistemper one's head.
entry.q: This inundation of mistempered humor.

entry.def: A title of courtesy prefixed to the name of a man or youth. It is usually written in the abbreviated form Mr.
entry.q: To call your name, inquire your where, Or what you think of Mister Some-one's book, Or Mister Other's marriage or decease.

entry.def: To address or mention by the title Mr.; as, he mistered me in a formal way.

entry.ety: OF. mistier trade, office, ministry, need, F. métier trade, fr. L. ministerium service, office, ministry. See Ministry Mystery trade

sn.def: A trade, art, or occupation.
sn.q: In youth he learned had a good mester.

sn.def: Manner; kind; sort.
sn.q: But telleth me what mester men ye be.

sn.def: Need; necessity.

entry.def: To be needful or of use.
entry.q: As for my name, it mistereth not to tell.

entry.def: To call by a wrong name; to miscall.
See Mystery, a trade.
Clouded with, or as with, mist.
To think wrongly.
entry.q: Adammisthoughtof her.

entry.def: To have erroneous thoughts or judgment of; to think ill of.
Erroneous thought; mistaken opinion; error.
To thrive poorly; to be not thrifty or prosperous.
To throw wrongly.
A kind of small sailing vessel used in the Mediterranean. It is rigged partly like a xebec, and partly like a felucca.
To happen or come to pass unfortunately; also, to suffer evil fortune.
A variety of the game of poker in which the joker is used, and called mistigris or mistigri.
Mistiness.
With mist; darkly; obscurely.

entry.ety: AS. mistīmain to turn out ill
entry.def: To time wrongly; not to adapt to the time.
The act or process of assigning something to a time when it could not have existed or occurred.
State of being misty.

entry.ety: L. mistio mixtio. See Mix, and cf. Mixtion
entry.def: Mixture.
To call by a wrong title.

entry.ety: Eng. mist. See Misle, and Mizzle
entry.def: To fall in very fine drops, as rain; to drizzle.

entry.note: ☞ The mistletoe of the United States is Phoradendron serotinumsyn. Phoradendron flavescens), having broader leaves than the European kind. In different regions various similar plants are called by this name. The mistletoe is used as a decoration at Christmas time, and it is a tradition that two persons of the oposite sex finding each other under a mistletoe sprig should kiss.
entry.ety: AS. misteltān; mistel mistletoe + tān twig. AS. mistel is akin of D., G., Dan. & Sw. mistel, OHG. mistil, Icel. mistilteinn; and AS. tān to D. teen, OHG. zein, Icel. teinn, Goth. tains. Cf. Missel
entry.def: A parasitic evergreen plant of Europe (Viscum album), bearing a glutinous fruit. When found upon the oak, where it is rare, it was an object of superstitious regard among the Druids. A bird lime is prepared from its fruit.
The American badger.
imp. & obs. p. p. of Mistake.
A wrong tradition.
entry.q: Monsters ofmistradition.

entry.def: To train amiss.
A violent and cold northwest wind experienced in the Mediterranean provinces of France, etc.
To translate erroneously.
Wrong translation.
To carry away or mislead wrongfully, as by passion.
Misstep; misbehavior.
entry.q: To punish mymistreadings.

entry.def: To treat amiss; to abuse.

entries.entry: mistreated adj. physically abused.Narrower terms: assaulted, molested, raped; battered, beaten; misunderstood abused, ill-treated, maltreated.

entry.def: Wrong treatment.

cs.cd: to be exempt from control by another person.

entry.ety: OE. maistress, OF. maistresse, F. maîtresse, LL. magistrissa, for L. magistra, fem. of magister. See Master Mister, and cf. Miss a young woman

sn.def: A woman having power, authority, or ownership; a woman who exercises authority, is chief, etc.; the female head of a family, a school, etc.
sn.q: The late queen's gentlewoman! a knight's daughter! To be her mistress' mistress!

sn.def: A woman well skilled in anything, or having the mastery over it.
sn.q: A letter desires all young wives to make themselves mistresses of Wingate's Arithmetic.

sn.def: A woman regarded with love and devotion; she who has command over one's heart; a beloved object; a sweetheart.

A woman filling the place, but without the rights, of a wife; a woman having an ongoing usually exclusive sexual relationship with a man, who may provide her with financial support in return; a concubine; a loose woman with whom one consorts habitually; as, both his wife and his mistress attended his funeral.
A title of courtesy formerly prefixed to the name of a woman, married or unmarried, but now superseded by the contracted forms, Mrs., for a married, and Miss, for an unmarried, woman.
sn.q: Now Mistress Gilpin (careful soul).

sn.def: A married woman; a wife.
sn.q: Several of the neighboring mistresses had assembled to witness the event of this memorable evening.

sn.def: The old name of the jack at bowls.

entry.def: To wait upon a mistress; to be courting.

sn.def: Female rule or dominion.
Ladyship, a style of address; -- with the personal pronoun.

entry.def: A false or erroneous trial; a trial which has no result; a trial which comes to no conclusion, such as a criminal trial which does not produce a unanimous verdict of the jurors.
To mistrust.
To think wrongly.
Want of confidence or trust; suspicion; distrust.

sn.def: To regard with jealousy or suspicion; to suspect; to doubt the integrity of; to distrust.
sn.q: I will never mistrust my wife again.

sn.def: To forebode as near, or likely to occur; to surmise.
sn.q: By a divine instinct, men's minds mistrust Ensuing dangers.

entry.def: One who mistrusts.
Having or causing mistrust, suspicions, or forebodings.
entry.q: Their light blown out in some mistrustful wood.

entry.def: With distrust or suspicion.
Having no mistrust or suspicion.
entry.q: The swain mistrustless of his smutted face.

entry.def: To tune wrongly.
A mingled compound in which different ingredients are contained in a liquid state; a mixture. See Mixture n., 4.
Sometimes, a liquid medicine containing very active substances, and which can only be administered by drops.
To turn amiss; to pervert.
To instruct amiss.

entry.ety: AS. mistig. See Mist. In some senses misty has been confused with mystic

sn.def: Accompanied with mist; characterized by the presence of mist; obscured by, or overspread with, mist; as, a misty morning; misty weather; misty mountains; a misty atmosphere.
Obscured as if by mist; dim; obscure; clouded; as, misty sight; to peer into the misty future.
sn.q: The more I muse therein [theology], The mistier it seemeth.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Misunderstood mĭs*ŭn`dẽr*st�d"; p. pr. & vb. n. Misunderstanding
entry.def: To misconceive; to mistake; to miscomprehend; to take in a wrong sense.
One who misunderstands.

sn.def: Mistake of the meaning; error; misconception.
Disagreement; difference of opinion; dissension; quarrel.
sn.q: Misunderstandingsamong friends.

entry.def: Measured; -- a direction to perform a passage in strict or measured time.
Bad treatment; abuse.

entry.ety: F. mésuser. See Mis-, prefix from French, and Use

sn.def: To treat or use improperly; to use to a bad purpose; to misapply; as, to misuse one's talents.
sn.q: The sweet poison of misused wine.

sn.def: To abuse; to treat ill.
sn.q: O, she misused me past the endurance of a block.

sn.def: Wrong use; misapplication; erroneous or improper use.
sn.q: Words little suspected for any such misuse.

sn.def: Violence, or its effects.

entry.def: Misuse.

sn.def: One who misuses.
sn.q: Wretchedmisusersof language.

sn.def: Unlawful use of a right; use in excess of, or varying from, one's right.

entry.def: To value wrongly or too little; to undervalue.
entry.q: But for I am so young, I dread my work Wot be misvalued both of old and young.

entry.def: To vouch falsely.
To wander in a wrong path; to stray; to go astray.
A wrong way.
To wear ill.
To wed improperly.
To ween amiss; to misjudge; to distrust; to be mistaken.
To go wrong; to go astray.
entry.q: The world ismiswent.

entry.def: To word wrongly; as, to misword a message, or a sentence.
A word wrongly spoken; a cross word.
Wrong or false worship; mistaken practices in religion.
entry.q: Such hideous jungle of misworships.

entry.def: To worship wrongly.
One who worships wrongly.
To write incorrectly.
Badly wrought.

entry.ety: Cf. L. misy a mineral, perh. copperas, Gr. �
entry.def: An impure yellow sulphate of iron; yellow copperas or copiapite.
To yoke improperly.
Mistakenly zealous.

entry.ety: AS. mīte mite (in sense 1); akin to LG. mite, D. mijt, G. miete, OHG. mīza; cf. Goth. maitan to cut

sn.def:
A minute arachnid, of the order Acarina, of which there are many species; as, the dust mite
cheese mite
sugar mite
harvest mite
three-toed spider mite , etc. See Acarina.

sn.ety: D. mijt; prob. the same word
sn.def: A small coin formerly circulated in England, rated at about a third of a farthing. The name is also applied to a small coin used in Palestine in the time of Christ.
sn.q: Two mites, which make a farthing.

sn.def: A small weight; one twentieth of a grain.
Anything very small; a minute object; a very little quantity or particle.
sn.q: For in effect they be not worth a myte.

entry.def: A genus of low slender herbs of North America and Northeast Asia having flowers with trifid or pinnatifid petals.

cs.cd: an apparatus for guiding a handsaw at the proper angle in making a miter joint; esp., a wooden or metal trough with vertical kerfs in its upright sides, for guides.
a kind of dovetail for a miter joint in which there is only one joint line visible, and that at the angle.
a gauge for determining the angle of a miter.

a joint formed by pieces matched and united upon a line bisecting the angle of junction, as by the beveled ends of two pieces of molding or brass rule, etc. The term is used especially when the pieces form a right angle, such as the edges of a window frame, and the edge of each piece at the point of junction is cut at a 45° angle to its long direction. See Miter, 2.
any one of numerous species of marine univalve shells of the genus Mitra.
a bevel with an immovable arm at an angle of 45°, for striking lines on stuff to be mitered; also, a square with an arm adjustable to any angle.
a pair of bevel gears, of equal diameter, adapted for working together, usually with their axes at right angles.

entry.ety: F. mitre, fr. L. mitra headband, turban, Gr. �

sn.def: A covering for the head, worn on solemn occasions by bishops and other church dignitaries. It has been made in many forms, the present form being a lofty cap with two points or peaks.
The surface forming the beveled end or edge of a piece where a miter joint is made; also, a joint formed or a junction effected by two beveled ends or edges; a miter joint.
A sort of base money or coin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mitered or Mitred; p. pr. & vb. n. Mitering or Mitring

sn.def: To place a miter upon; to adorn with a miter.
sn.q: Miteredlocks.

sn.def: To match together, as two pieces of molding or brass rule on a line bisecting the angle of junction; to fit together in a miter joint.
To bevel the ends or edges of, for the purpose of matching together at an angle.

entry.def: To meet and match together, as two pieces of molding, on a line bisecting the angle of junction.

cs.cd: a white-flowered perennial herb of the United States (Tiarella cardifolia).

entry.def: Any plant of the genus Mitella, -- slender, perennial herbs with a pod slightly resembling a bishop's miter; bishop's cap.
See Mythic.
The sun god of the ancient Persians; the god of light and truth.
Of or pertaining to Mithraism.
Mithraism.
The ancient Persian religion which worshiped Mithra; it was popular among Romans during first three centuries a. d.
An adherent of Mithraism.

An antidote against poison, or a composition in form of an electuary, supposed to serve either as a remedy or a preservative against poison; an alexipharmic; -- so called from King Mithridates , its reputed inventor.
entry.q: Love is] a drop of the true elixir; no mithridate so effectual against the infection of vice.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to King Mithridates, or to a mithridate.
Admitting of mitigation; that may be mitigated.

entry.ety: L. mitigans, p. pr. of mitigare. See Mitigate
entry.def: Tending to mitigate; mitigating; lenitive.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mitigated; p. pr. & vb. n. Mitigating
entry.ety: L. mitigatus, p. p. of mitigare to soften, mitigate; mitis mild, soft + the root of agere to do, drive

sn.def: To make less severe, intense, harsh, rigorous, painful, etc.; to soften; to meliorate; to alleviate; to diminish; to lessen; as, to mitigate heat or cold; to mitigate grief.
To make mild and accessible; to mollify; -- applied to persons.
sn.q: This opinion . . . mitigated kings into companions.
sn.syn: To alleviate; assuage; allay. See Alleviate.

entry.def: made less severe or intense.

entries.entry: mitigating adj. serving to reduce blame; -- of situations; as, mitigating factors; mitigating circumstances. Opposite of aggravating.Narrower terms: exculpatory extenuating.

entry.ety: OE. mitigacioun, F. mitigation, fr. L. mitigatio
entry.def: The act of mitigating, or the state of being mitigated; abatement or diminution of anything painful, harsh, severe, afflictive, or calamitous; as, the mitigation of pain, grief, rigor, severity, punishment, or penalty.
Tending to mitigate; alleviating.
One who, or that which, mitigates.
Tending to mitigate or alleviate; mitigative.
A little one; -- used as a term of endearment.

entries.entry: Mi"tis cast`ing. Perh. fr. L. mitis mild A process, invented by P. Ostberg, for producing malleable iron castings by melting wrought iron, to which from 0.05 to 0.1 per cent of aluminum is added to lower the melting point, usually in a petroleum furnace, keeping the molten metal at the bubbling point until it becomes quiet, and then pouring the molten metal into a mold lined with a special mixture consisting essentially of molasses and ground burnt fire clay; also, a casting made by this process; -- called also wrought-iron casting.
Mitis metal. The malleable iron produced by mitis casting; -- called also simply mitis.

entry.def: The denser part of the protoplasm of a cell.
See Karyokinesis.
Of or pertaining to mitosis; karyokinetic; as, mitotic cell division; -- opposed to amitotic.
Shot or bits of iron used sometimes in loading cannon.

sn.def: One who serves a mitrailleuse.
A mitralleuse.

entry.ety: F., fr. mitrailler to fire grapeshot, fr. mitraille old iron, grapeshot, dim. of OF. mite a mite
entry.def: A breech-loading machine gun consisting of a number of barrels fitted together, so arranged that the barrels can be fired simultaneously, or successively, and rapidly.
Pertaining to a miter; resembling a miter; as, the mitral valve between the left auricle and left ventricle of the heart.
See Miter.
Any of various rhizomatous perennial herbs of the genus Mitella having a capsule resembling a bishop's miter.
Having the form of a miter, or a peaked cap; as, a mitriform calyptra.

sn.def: A mitten; also, a covering for the wrist and hand and not for the fingers, usually worn by women.

A large glove, usually made of leather or similar material, with differing degrees of padding and usually some form of webbing in the large space between the thumb insert and the insert for the index finger; a baseball glove. It is used to assist in catching the baseball. The catcher's mitt has more padding and less webbing.
A hand; -- used mostly in slang expressions; as, keep your mitts off my box of chocolates!

cs.cd: to dismiss as a lover; to reject the suit of.
to treat roughly; to handle without gloves.

entry.ety: OE. mitaine meteyn, F. mitaine, perh. of Celtic origin; cf. Ir. miotog, Gael. miotag, Ir. & Gael. mutan a muff, a thick glove. Cf. Mitt

sn.def: A covering for the hand, worn to defend it from cold or injury. It differs from a glove in not having a separate sheath for each finger.
A cover for the wrist and forearm.

entry.def: Covered with a mitten or mittens.
entry.q: Mittenedhands.

entry.ety: L. mittens, p. pr. of mittere to send
entry.def: Sending forth; emitting.

entry.ety: L., we send, fr. mittere to send
entry.def: A precept or warrant granted by a justice for committing to prison a party charged with crime; a warrant of commitment to prison.
A writ for removing records from one court to another.

entries.entry: Mit"tler's green`. Chem A pigment of a green color, the chief constituent of which is oxide of chromium.

entry.def: The stormy petrel.
A South American curassow of the genus Mitua.
Having, or abounding with, mites.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mixed mĭkstless properly Mixt); p. pr. & vb. n. Mixing
entry.ety: AS. miscan; akin to OHG. misken, G. mischen, Russ. mieshate, W. mysgu, Gael. measg, L. miscere mixtum, Gr. mi`sgein migny`nai, Skr. miçra mixed. The English word has been influenced by L. miscere mixtumcf. Mixture), and even the AS. miscan may have been borrowed fr. L. miscere. Cf. Admix Mash to bruise, Meddle

sn.def: To cause a promiscuous interpenetration of the parts of, as of two or more substances with each other, or of one substance with others; to unite or blend into one mass or compound, as by stirring together; to mingle; to blend; as, to mix flour and salt; to mix wines.
sn.q: Fair persuasions mixed with sugared words.

sn.def: To unite with in company; to join; to associate.
sn.q: Ephraim, he hath mixed himself among the people.

sn.def: To form by mingling; to produce by the stirring together of ingredients; to compound of different parts.
sn.q: Hast thou no poison mixed?
I have chosen an argument mixed of religious and civil considerations.

sn.def: To combine (two or more activities) within a specified or implied time frame; as, to mix studying and partying while at college.
To become united into a compound; to be blended promiscuously together.
To associate; to mingle; as, Democrats and Republicans mixed freely at the party.
sn.q: He had mixed Again in fancied safety with his kind.

entry.def: Capable of being mixed.

cs.cd: a suit combining the properties of a real and a personal action.
a mixtilineal angle.
a textile fabric composed of two or more kinds of fiber, as a poplin.
a marriage between persons of different races or religions; specifically, one between a Roman Catholic and a Protestant.
a whole number and a fraction taken together.
a railway train containing both passenger and freight cars.
voices of both males and females united in the same performance.

entry.def: Formed by mixing; united; mingled; blended. See Mix v. t. & i.
In a mixed or mingled manner.

entry.ety: AS. mixen myxen, fr. meohx meox, dung, filth; akin to E. mist. See Mist
entry.def: A compost heap; a dunghill.

sn.def: One who, or that which, mixes.
A person who has social intercourse with others of many sorts; a person viewed as to his casual sociability; -- commonly used with some characterizing adjective; as, a good mixer; a bad mixer .
a social gathering, game, or dance organized to provide an opportunity for people to meet each other; as, on the first night of the conference they had a wine-and-cheese mixer .
a nonalcoholic beverage (such as fruit juice, club soda or ginger ale) added to an alcoholic beverage to produce a mixed drink.
any device used for mixing.
an electronic device for blending or manipulating sounds from different sources to produce a composite soundtrack, for an audio recording, video recording, or a movie.
The technician who operates a mixer{6.

entry.def: Pairing with several males; -- said of certain fishes of which several males accompany each female during spawning.

entries.entry:
Mix`o*lyd"i*an mode`. Gr. � a mixing + E. Lydian
Mus The seventh ecclesiastical mode, whose scale commences on G.

entry.ety: L. mixtus mixed (p. p. of miscere to mix) + E. lineal linear
entry.def: Containing, or consisting of, lines of different kinds, as straight, curved, and the like; as, a mixtilinear angle, that is, an angle contained by a straight line and a curve.

entry.ety: L. mixtio mistio: cf. F. mixtion. See Mistion Mix

sn.def: Mixture.
A kind of cement made of mastic, amber, etc., used as a mordant for gold leaf.

entry.def: With mixture; in a mixed manner; mixedly.

entry.ety: L. mixtura, fr. miscere mixtum, to mix: cf. F. mixture. See Mix

sn.def: The act of mixing, or the state of being mixed; as, made by a mixture of ingredients.
That which results from mixing different ingredients together; a compound; as, to drink a mixture of molasses and water; -- also, a medley.
sn.q: There is also a mixture of good and evil wisely distributed by God, to serve the ends of his providence.

sn.def: An ingredient entering into a mixed mass; an additional ingredient.
sn.q: Cicero doubts whether it were possible for a community to exist that had not a prevailing mixture of piety in its constitution.

sn.def: A kind of liquid medicine made up of many ingredients; esp., as opposed to solution, a liquid preparation in which the solid ingredients are not completely dissolved.

A mass of two or more ingredients, the particles of which are separable, independent, and uncompounded with each other, no matter how thoroughly and finely commingled; -- contrasted with a compound and solution; thus, gunpowder is a mechanical mixture of carbon, sulphur, and niter.

An organ stop, comprising from two to five ranges of pipes, used only in combination with the foundation and compound stops; -- called also furniture stop. It consists of high harmonics, or overtones, of the ground tone.
To confuse the identities of (two or more objects); to mistake (one object for another); as, at the family gathering he mixed up his two nieces, to their great amusement.
To mix together; -- usually implying a mistake, whether done intentionally or unintentionally; as, the mixed up this year's receipts with last year's, and it took hours to find the right ones.

entry.def: a mistake that results from taking one thing to be another.
mizzenmast.
A maze or labyrinth.

entry.ety: It. mezzana, fr. mezzano middle, fr. mezzo middle, half: cf. F. misaine foresail. See Mezzo
entry.def: Hindmost; nearest the stern; as, the mizzen shrouds, sails, etc.
The hindmost of the fore and aft sails of a three-masted vessel; also, the spanker.

entry.note: The definition varies slightly with the dictionary; in some dictionaries it is the last mast of a three-masted vessel; in others, it is the mast after the mainmast of a vessel of three or more masts. PJC.
entry.def: the third mast from the bow in a vessel having three or more masts; the after and shorter mast of a yawl, ketch, or dandy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mizzled; p. pr. & vb. n. Mizzling

sn.def: To rain in very fine drops; to drizzle.
To take one's self off; to go.
sn.q: As long as George the Fourth could reign, he reigned, And then he mizzled.

entry.def: Mist; fine rain.

entry.ety: Cf. F. moisi moldy, musty, p. p. of moisir to mold, fr. L. mucere to be moldy
entry.def: A bog or quagmire.
milliliter; -- the IS standard abbreviation.
millimeter; -- the IS standard abbreviation.
millimolar; -- the IS standard abbreviation.
The chemical symbol for manganese.

To increase the power of (a single-cylinder beam engine) by adding a small high-pressure cylinder with a piston acting on the beam between the center and the flywheel end, using high-pressure steam and working as a compound engine, -- a plan introduced by M'Naught, a Scottish engineer, in 1845.

entry.ety: Gr. mnhmoniko`s, fr. mnh`mwn mindful, remembering, mnh`mh memory, mna^sqai to think on, remember; akin to E. mind
entry.def: Assisting in memory; helping to remember; as, a mnemonic device.

entry.note: In basic organic chemistry class, one may learn the mnenomic “Oh my, such good apple pie” to help remember the names of the dicarboxylic acids in increasing order of length, namely: oxalic, malonic, succinic, glutaric, adipic, and pimelic acids. (From L. Fieser's Organic Chemistry text).

sn.def: Something used to assist the memory, as an easily remembered acronym or verse.
An abbreviated word that resembles the full word, used so as to be easily recognized; as, the CIDE uses ... tags as mnemnonics for an italicised word or field.

entry.def: One who instructs in the art of improving or using the memory.

entry.ety: Gr. ta~ mnhmonika`: cf. F. mnémonique
entry.def: The art of memory; a method for improving the memory; a system of precepts and rules intended to assist the memory; artificial memory.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. mnhmosy`nh remembrance, memory, and the goddess of memory. See Mnemonic
entry.def: The goddess of memory and the mother of the Muses.

sn.def: same as mnemonic.

entry.ety: Gr. � memory + � art: cf. F. mnémotechnie
entry.def: Mnemonics.
A natural family of erect mosses with club-shaped paraphyses andgonal cells of the upper leaf surface; sometimes treated as a subfamily of Bryaceae.
A genus of mosses similar to those of genus Bryum but larger.
More; -- usually, more in number.
entry.q: An hundred thousand mo.
Likely to find mo to commend than to imitate it.

entry.def: chemical symbol for the element molybdenum.
abbreviation for modus operandi, manner of operating; -- often used to refer to the method an habitual criminal uses to perpetrate his crime.

entries.entry: -mo. A suffix added to the names of certain numerals or to the numerals themselves, to indicate the number of leaves made by folding a sheet of paper; as, sixteenmo or 16mo; eighteenmo or 18mo . It is taken from the Latin forms similarly used; as, duodecimo sextodecimo, etc. A small circle, placed after the number and near its top, is often used for -mo; as, 16°, 18°, etc.

entry.def: Any one of several very large extinct species of wingless birds belonging to Dinornis, and other related genera, of the suborder Dinornithes, found in New Zealand. They are allied to the apteryx and the ostrich. They were probably exterminated by the natives before New Zealand was discovered by Europeans. Some species were much larger than the ostrich.
One of the posterity of Moab, the son of Lot. (Gen. xix. 37.) Also used adjectively.
A female Moabite.

entries.entry: Mo"ab*ite stone. Archæol A block of black basalt, found at Dibon in Moab by Rev. F. A. Klein, Aug. 19, 1868, which bears an inscription of thirty-four lines, dating from the 9th century b. c., and written in the Moabite alphabet, the oldest Phœnician type of the Semitic alphabet. It records the victories of Mesha, king of Moab, esp. those over Israel (2 Kings iii. 4, 5, 27).

entry.def: Moabite.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Moaned mōnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Moaning
entry.ety: AS. mǣnan to moan, also, to mean; but in the latter sense perh. a different word. Cf. Mean to intend

sn.def: To make a low prolonged sound of grief or pain, whether articulate or not; to groan softly and continuously.
sn.q: Unpitied and unheard, where misery moans.
Let there bechance him pitiful mischances, To make him moan.

sn.def: To emit a sound like moan; -- said of things inanimate; as, the wind moans .
To bewail audibly; to lament.
sn.q: Ye floods, ye woods, ye echoes, moan My dear Columbo, dead and gone.

sn.def: To afflict; to distress.
sn.q: Which infinitely moans me.

entry.ety: OE. mone. See Moan v. i.

sn.def: A low prolonged sound, articulate or not, indicative of pain or of grief; a low groan.
sn.q: Sullen moans, hollow groans.

sn.def: A low mournful or murmuring sound; -- of things.
sn.q: Rippling waters made a pleasant moan.

entry.def: Full of moaning; expressing sorrow.

entry.ety: OF. mote hill, dike, bank, F. motte clod, turf: cf. Sp. & Pg. mota bank or mound of earth, It. motta clod, LL. mota motta, a hill on which a fort is built, an eminence, a dike, Prov. G. mott bog earth heaped up; or perh. F. motte, and OF. mote, are from a LL. p. p. of L. movere to move (see Move). The name of moat, properly meaning, bank or mound, was transferred to the ditch adjoining: cf. F. dike and ditch
entry.def: A deep trench around the rampart of a castle or other fortified place, sometimes filled with water; a ditch.
To surround with a moat.
To void the excrement, as a bird; to mute.
A mobcap.
To wrap up in, or cover with, a cowl.

cs.cd: law administered by the mob; lynch law.
well dressed thieves and swindlers, regarded collectively.

entry.ety: L. mobile vulgus, the movable common people. See Mobile n.

sn.def: The lower classes of a community; the populace, or the lowest part of it.
sn.q: A cluster of mob were making themselves merry with their betters.

sn.def: A throng; a rabble; esp., an unlawful or riotous assembly; a disorderly crowd.
sn.q: The mob of gentlemen who wrote with ease.
Had every Athenian citizen been a Socrates, every Athenian assembly would still have been a mob.
Confused by brainless mobs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mobbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Mobbing
entry.def: To crowd about, as a mob, and attack or annoy; as, to mob a house or a person.
Like a mob; tumultuous; lawless; as, a mobbish act.

entry.ety: D. mop-muts; OD. mop a woman's coif + D. muts cap
entry.def: A plain cap or headdress for women or girls; especially, one tying under the chin by a very broad band, generally of the same material as the cap itself.

entry.ety: L. mobilis, for movibilis, fr. movere to move: cf. F. mobile. See Move

sn.def: Capable of being moved; not fixed in place or condition; movable.
sn.q: Fixed or elsemobile.

sn.def: Characterized by an extreme degree of fluidity; moving or flowing with great freedom; as, benzine and mercury are mobile liquids; -- opposed to viscous viscoidal, or oily.
Easily moved in feeling, purpose, or direction; excitable; changeable; fickle.
sn.q: The quick and mobile curiosity of her disposition.

sn.def: Changing in appearance and expression under the influence of the mind; as, mobile features.
Capable of being moved, aroused, or excited; capable of spontaneous movement.
Capable of moving readily, or moving frequenty from place to place; as, a mobile work force.
Having motor vehicles to permit movement from place to place; as, a mobile library; a mobile hospital.

entry.ety: L. mobile vulgus. See Mobile a., and cf. 3d Mob
entry.def: The mob; the populace.
entry.q: The unthinkingmobile.

entry.def: a form of sculpture having several sheets or rods of a stiff material attached to each other by thin wire or twine in a balanced and artfully arranged tree configuration, with the topmost member suspended in air from a support so that the parts may move independently when set in motion by a current of air.

sn.def: Mobilize.

entry.def: Mobilization.

sn.def: The quality or state of being mobile; as, the mobility of a liquid, of an army, of the populace, of features, of a muscle.
The mob; the lower classes.

entry.def: The act of mobilizing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mobilized; p. pr. & vb. n. Mobilizing

sn.def: To assemble and organize and make ready for use or action; as, to mobilize volunteers for the election campaign.
To put in a state of readiness for active service in war, as an army corps; as, to mobilize the National Guard.

entry.ety: From August F. Möbius , German mathematician
entry.def: A mathematical object, or a physical representation of it, which is a two-dimensional sheet with only one surface. It is constructed or visualized as a rectangle, one end of which is held fixed while the opposite end is twisted through a 180 degree angle and joined to the fixed end. It is a two-dimensional object that can only exist in a three-dimensional space.
To wrap the head of in a hood.
See Moebles.
A condition in which the lower classes of a nation control public affairs without respect to law, precedents, or vested rights.
entry.q: It is good name that Dr. Stevens has given to our present situation (for one can not call it a government), a mobocracy.

entry.def: One who favors a form of government in which the unintelligent populace rules without restraint.
Of, or relating to, a mobocracy.
Variant spelling of moccasin.

cs.cd: a species of lady's slipper (Cypripedium acaule) found in North America. The lower petal is two inches long, and forms a rose-colored moccasin-shaped pouch. It grows in rich woods under coniferous trees.

sn.def: A shoe made of deerskin, or other soft leather, the sole and upper part being one piece. It is the customary shoe worn by the American Indians.

A poisonous snake of the Southern United States. The water moccasin (Ancistrodon piscivorus syn. Agkistrodon piscivorus, also called cottonmouth and cottonmouth water moccasin) is usually found in or near water. Above, it is olive brown, barred with black; beneath, it is brownish yellow, mottled with darker. The upland moccasin is Ancistrodon atrofuscus. They resemble rattlesnakes, but are without rattles.

entry.def: Covered with, or wearing, a moccasin or moccasins.
entry.q: Moccasinedfeet.

cs.cd: moss agate.

sn.def: A seaport town of Yemen, on the Red Sea, also spelled Mukha.
A variety of coffee originally brought from Mocha.
An Abyssinian weight, equivalent to a Troy grain.
A flavoring made from an infusion of coffee or of a combination of coffee with chocolate or cocoa.
A color of a deep chocolate brown.

entry.def: A bale of raw silk.
Much.
Much.
A large leather flap which covers the saddletree.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mocked; p. pr. & vb. n. Mocking
entry.ety: F. moquer, of uncertain origin; cf. OD. mocken to mumble, G. mucken, OSw. mucka

sn.def: To imitate; to mimic; esp., to mimic in sport, contempt, or derision; to deride by mimicry.
sn.q: To see the life as lively mocked as ever Still sleep mocked death.
Mocking marriage with a dame of France.

sn.def: To treat with scorn or contempt; to deride.
sn.q: Elijah mocked them, and said, Cry aloud.
Let not ambition mock their useful toil.

sn.def: To disappoint the hopes of; to deceive; to tantalize; as, to mock expectation.
sn.q: Thou hast mocked me, and told me lies.
He will not . . . Mock us with his blest sight, then snatch him hence.
sn.syn: To deride; ridicule; taunt; jeer; tantalize; disappoint. See Deride.

entry.def: To make sport in contempt or in jest; to speak in a scornful or jeering manner.
entry.q: When thou mockest, shall no man make thee ashamed?
She had mocked at his proposal.

sn.def: An act of ridicule or derision; a scornful or contemptuous act or speech; a sneer; a jibe; a jeer.
sn.q: Fools make a mock at sin.

sn.def: Imitation; mimicry.

entry.cs: Mock bishop's weed Bot a genus of slender umbelliferous herbs (Discopleura) growing in wet places. Mock heroic burlesquing the heroic; as, a mock heroic poem. Mock lead. See Blende). Mock nightingale Zoöl the European blackcap. Mock orange Bot a genus of American and Asiatic shrubs (Philadelphus), with showy white flowers in panicled cymes. Philadelphus coronarius, from Asia, has fragrant flowers; the American kinds are nearly scentless. Mock sun. See Parhelion. Mock turtle soup a soup made of calf's head, veal, or other meat, and condiments, in imitation of green turtle soup. Mock velvet a fabric made in imitation of velvet. See Mockado.
entry.def: Imitating reality, but not real; false; counterfeit; assumed; sham.
entry.q: That superior greatness and mock majesty.

entry.def: Such as can be mocked.
A stuff made in imitation of velvet; -- probably the same as mock velvet.
entry.q: Our rich mockado doublet.

entry.def: See Mokadour.
Mockery.
The European sedge warbler (Acrocephalus phragmitis).

sn.def: One who, or that which, mocks; a scorner; a scoffer; a derider.
A deceiver; an impostor.
A mocking bird.
A smooth-barked North American hickory (Carya tomentosa) with 7 to 9 leaflets bearing a hard-shelled edible nut, which is far inferior to the true shagbark hickory nut.
sn.syn: mockernut hickory, black hickory, white-heart hickory, big-bud hickory, Carya tomentosa .

sn.def: The fruit of the mockernut{1}.

entries.entry:
Mock"er*y n.; pl.Mockeries #. F. moquerie
The act of mocking, deriding, and exposing to contempt, by mimicry, by insincere imitation, or by a false show of earnestness; a counterfeit appearance. It is, as the air, invulnerable, And our vain blows malicious mockery. Grace at meals is now generally so performed as to look more like a mockery upon devotion than any solemn application of the mind to God. And bear about the mockery of woe.
Insulting or contemptuous action or speech; contemptuous merriment; derision; ridicule. The laughingstock of fortune's mockeries.
Subject of laughter, derision, or sport. The cruel handling of the city whereof they made a mockery.

cs.cd: any species of the genus Harporhynchus, as the brown thrush (Harporhynchus rufus).
any American wren of the genus Thryothorus, esp. Thryothorus Ludovicianus.

entry.def: Imitating, esp. in derision, or so as to cause derision; mimicking; derisive.

A long-tailed gray-and-white songbird of North America (Mimus polyglottos), remarkable for its exact imitations of the notes of other birds. Its back is gray; the tail and wings are blackish, with a white patch on each wing; the outer tail feathers are partly white. Originally its range was confined mostly to the southern states, but by late 19th century it had migrated as far north as New York. The name is also applied to other members of thee same and related genera, found in Mexico, Central America, and the West Indies, such as the blue mockingbird of Mexico, Melanotis caerulescens.
By way of derision; in a contemptuous or mocking manner.
A butt of sport; an object of derision.
Mock; counterfeit; sham.
See Mickle.
A South American rodent (Cavia rupestris), allied to the Guinea pig, but larger; -- called also rock cavy.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a mode or mood; consisting in mode or form only; relating to form; having the form without the essence or reality.
Indicating, or pertaining to, some mode of conceiving existence, or of expressing thought, such as the modes of possibility or obligation.
Pertaining to or denoting mood.

entry.def: A modal auxiliary.

Any one of the auxiliary verbs of English, such as can may will shall must might could would, or should, which are used together with the infinitive form of another verb to express distinctions of mood{2}, such as uncertainty, possibility, command, emphasis, and obligation.
One who regards Father, Son, and Spirit as modes of being, and not as persons, thus denying personal distinction in the Trinity.

sn.def: The quality or state of being modal.
A modal relation or quality; a mode or point of view under which an object presents itself to the mind. According to Kant, the quality of propositions, as assertory, problematical, or apodeictic.

entry.def: A system of logic which studies how to combine propositions which include the concepts of necessity, possibility, and obligation.
In a modal manner.
entry.q: A compound proposition, the parts of which are united modally . . . by the particles “as” and “so.”

entry.note: ☞ In modern music, only the major and the minor mode, of whatever key, are recognized.
entry.ety: L. modus a measure, due or proper measure, bound, manner, form; akin to E. mete: cf. F. mode. See Mete, and cf. Commodious Mood in grammar, Modus

sn.def: Manner of doing or being; method; form; fashion; custom; way; style; as, the mode of speaking; the mode of dressing.
sn.q: The duty of itself being resolved on, the mode of doing it may easily be found.
A table richly spread in regal mode.

sn.def: Prevailing popular custom; fashion, especially in the phrase the mode.
sn.q: The easy, apathetic graces of a man of the mode.

sn.def: Variety; gradation; degree.

Any combination of qualities or relations, considered apart from the substance to which they belong, and treated as entities; more generally, condition, or state of being; manner or form of arrangement or manifestation; form, as opposed to matter.
sn.q: Modes I call such complex ideas, which, however compounded, contain not in them the supposition of subsisting by themselves, but are considered as dependencies on, or affections of, substances.

sn.def: The form in which the proposition connects the predicate and subject, whether by simple, contingent, or necessary assertion; the form of the syllogism, as determined by the quantity and quality of the constituent proposition; mood.
Same as Mood.
The scale as affected by the various positions in it of the minor intervals; as, the Dorian mode, the Ionic mode, etc., of ancient Greek music.
A kind of silk. See Alamode n.

the value of the variable in a frequency distribution or probability distribution, at which the probability or frequency has a maximum. The maximum may be local or global. Distributions with only one such maximum are called unimodal; with two maxima, bimodal, and with more than two, multimodal.

cs.cd: a model of a machine which can do on a small scale the work which the machine itself does, or is expected to do.

entry.ety: F. modèle, It. modello, fr. (assumed) L. modellus, fr. modulus a small measure, dim. of modus. See Mode, and cf. Module

sn.def: A miniature representation of a thing, with the several parts in due proportion; sometimes, a facsimile of the same size; as, a 1/100 scale model of the B-52 bomber.
sn.q: In charts, in maps, and eke in models made.
I had my father's signet in my purse, Which was the model of that Danish seal.
You have the models of several ancient temples, though the temples and the gods are perished.

sn.def: Something intended to serve, or that may serve, as a pattern of something to be made; a material representation or embodiment of an ideal; sometimes, a drawing; a plan; as, the clay model of a sculpture; the inventor's model of a machine.
sn.q: The application for a patent] must be accompanied by a full description of the invention, with drawings and a model where the case admits of it.
When we mean to build We first survey the plot, then draw the model.

sn.def: Anything which serves, or may serve, as an example for imitation; as, a government formed on the model of the American constitution; a model of eloquence, virtue, or behavior.
That by which a thing is to be measured; standard.
sn.q: He that despairs measures Providence by his own little, contracted model.

sn.def: Any copy, or resemblance, more or less exact.
sn.q: Thou seest thy wretched brother die, Who was the model of thy father's life.

sn.def: A person who poses as a pattern for an artist; as, the artist used his daughter as a model for an Indian maiden.
A person who is employed to wear clothing for the purpose of advertising or display, or who poses with a product for the same purpose; a mannequin{1}; as, a fashion model .
sn.q: A professional model.

sn.def: A particular version or design of an object that is made in multiple versions; as, the 1993 model of the Honda Accord; the latest model of the HP laserjet printer. For many manufactured products, the model name is encoded as part of the model number.

An abstract and often simplified conceptual representation of the workings of a system of objects in the real world, which often includes mathematical or logical objects and relations representing the objects and relations in the real-world system, and constructed for the purpose of explaining the workings of the system or predicting its behavior under hypothetical conditions; as, the administration's model of the United States economy predicts budget surpluses for the next fifteen years; different models of the universe assume different values for the cosmological constant; models of proton structure have grown progressively more complex in the past century.

entry.def: Suitable to be taken as a model or pattern; as, a model house; a model husband.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Modeled or Modelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Modeling or Modelling
entry.def: To plan or form after a pattern; to form in model; to form a model or pattern for; to shape; to mold; to fashion; as, to model a house or a government; to model an edifice according to the plan delineated.
To make a copy or a pattern; to design or imitate forms; as, to model in wax.
resembling sculpture; as, her finely modeled features.
One who models; hence, a worker in plastic art.

cs.cd: a small plane for planing rounded objects.
beeswax melted with a little Venice turpentine, or other resinous material, and tinted with coloring matter, usually red, -- used in modeling.

entry.def: The act or art of making a model from which a work of art is to be executed; the formation of a work of art from some plastic material. Also, in painting, drawing, etc., the expression or indication of solid form.
To model.

An electronic device that converts electronic signals into sound waves, and sound waves into electronic signals, used to transmit information between computers by the use of ordinary telephone lines; also called modulator-demodulator; as, the latest modems can transmit data at 56,000 baud over a clear telephone line. The speed of transmission of information by a modem is usually measured in units of baud, equivalent to bits per second.
A certain crimsonlike color.
Of or pertaining to Modena or its inhabitants.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Modena; the people of Modena.

sn.def: A mother.
The principal piece of an astrolabe, into which the others are fixed.

entry.def: To moderate.
Moderate; temperate.
Moderation.

entries.entry:
Mod"er*ate a. L. moderatus, p. p. of moderate moderati, to moderate, regulate, control, fr. modus measure. See Mode
Kept within due bounds; observing reasonable limits; not excessive, extreme, violent, or rigorous; limited; restrained; as: Limited in quantity; sparing; temperate; frugal; as, moderate in eating or drinking; a moderate table. Limited in degree of activity, energy, or excitement; reasonable; calm; slow; as, moderate language; moderate endeavors.
Not extreme in opinion, in partisanship, and the like; as, a moderate Calvinist; a moderate Republican. A number of moderate members managed . . . to obtain a majority in a thin house. Not violent or rigorous; temperate; mild; gentle; as, a moderate winter.
Moderateshowers. Walter. Limited as to degree of progress; as, to travel at moderate speed.
