entries.entry: Monitor nozzle. A nozzle capable of turning completely round in a horizontal plane and having a limited play in a vertical plane, used in hydraulic mining, fire-extinguishing apparatus, etc.

entry.def: The post or office of a monitor.
Giving admonition; instructing by way of caution; warning.
entry.q: Losses, miscarriages, and disappointments, are monitory and instructive.

entry.def: Admonition; warning; especially, a monition proceeding from an ecclesiastical court, but not addressed to any one person.
A female monitor.

cs.cd: a South American and West Indian bat (Molossus nasutus); -- so called because the males live in communities by themselves.
the friar bird.
a species of seal (Monachus albiventer) inhabiting the Black Sea, the Mediterranean Sea, and the adjacent parts of the Atlantic.
a kind of dock; -- also called patience Rumex Patientia).

entry.ety: AS. munuc munec munc, L. monachus, Gr. �, fr. mo`nos alone. Cf. Monachism

sn.def: A man who retires from the ordinary temporal concerns of the world, and devotes himself to religion; one of a religious community of men inhabiting a monastery, and bound by vows to a life of chastity, obedience, and poverty.
sn.q: Amonkout of his cloister.

Monks in some respects agree with regulars, as in the substantial vows of religion; but in other respects monks and regulars differ; for that regulars, vows excepted, are not tied up to so strict a rule of life as monks are.

sn.def: A blotch or spot of ink on a printed page, caused by the ink not being properly distributed. It is distinguished from a friar, or white spot caused by a deficiency of ink.
A piece of tinder made of agaric, used in firing the powder hose or train of a mine.

sd.def: A South American monkey (Pithecia monachus); also applied to other species, as Cebus xanthocephalus.
The European bullfinch.

entries.entry:
Monk"er*y n.; pl.Monkeries.
The life of monks; monastic life; monastic usage or customs; -- now usually applied by way of reproach. Miters, and wretched dead mediæval monkeries.
A collective body of monks. Obs Though he have a whole monkery to sing for him.

Mon"key ☞ The monkeys are often divided into three groups: (a Catarrhines, or Simidæ. These have an oblong head, with the oblique flat nostrils near together. Some have no tail, as the apes. All these are natives of the Old World. (b Platyrhines, or Cebidæ. These have a round head, with a broad nasal septum, so that the nostrils are wide apart and directed downward. The tail is often prehensile, and the thumb is short and not opposable. These are natives of the New World. (c Strepsorhines, or Lemuroidea. These have a pointed head with curved nostrils. They are natives of Southern Asia, Africa, and Madagascar.
Monkey boat. Naut A small boat used in docks. A half-decked boat used on the River Thames. Monkey block Naut a small single block strapped with a swivel. R. H. Dana, Jr. Monkey flower Bot a plant of the genus Mimulus; -- so called from the appearance of its gaping corolla. Gray. Monkey gaff Naut a light gaff attached to the topmast for the better display of signals at sea. Monkey jacket a short closely fitting jacket, worn by sailors. Monkey rail Naut a second and lighter rail raised about six inches above the quarter rail of a ship. Monkey shine monkey trick. Slang, U.S Monkey trick a mischievous prank. Saintsbury. Monkey wheel. See Gin block, under 5th Gin.
n.; pl.Monkeys #. Cf. OIt. monicchio, It. monnino, dim. of monna an ape, also dame, mistress, contr. fr. madonna. See Madonna
Zoöl
In the most general sense, any one of the Quadrumana, including apes, baboons, and lemurs.
Any species of Quadrumana, except the lemurs.
Any one of numerous species of Quadrumana (esp. such as have a long tail and prehensile feet) exclusive of apes and baboons.
A term of disapproval, ridicule, or contempt, as for a mischievous child. This is the monkey's own giving out; she is persuaded I will marry her.
The weight or hammer of a pile driver, that is, a very heavy mass of iron, which, being raised on high, falls on the head of the pile, and drives it into the earth; the falling weight of a drop hammer used in forging.
A small trading vessel of the sixteenth century.

cs.cd: to handle in a meddlesome manner.

entry.def: To act or treat as a monkey does; to ape; to act in a grotesque or meddlesome manner.
The fruit of the Adansonia digitata; also, the tree. See Adansonia.
See Nepenthes.
large ornamental tropical American tree (Albizia saman) with bipinnate leaves and globose clusters of flowers with crimson stamens and sweet-pulp seed pods eaten by cattle.
entry.syn: rain tree, saman, zaman, zamang, Albizia saman.

entry.def: The fruit of two South American trees (Lecythis Ollaria, and Lecythis Zabucajo), which have for their fruit large, pot-shaped, woody capsules containing delicious nuts, and opening almost explosively by a circular lid at the top. Vases and pots are made of this capsule.

entries.entry: Mon"key's puz"zle. Bot A lofty coniferous Chilian tree (Araucaria araucana, formerly Araucaria imbricata), the branches of which are so crowded and intertwisted “as to puzzle a monkey to climb.” It is also called monkey puzzle and monkey puzzle tree. The edible nuts are over an inch long, and are called piñon by the Chilians.

entry.def: A short, round iron bar or lever used in naval gunnery.
A wrench or spanner which has one fixed and one adjustable jaw.
The angel fish (Squatina).
The angler (Lophius), esp. the goosefishes Lophius Americanus in America and Lophius piscatorius in Europe, used for food.

A name of certain curious orchids which bear three kinds of flowers formerly referred to three genera, but now ascertained to be sexually different forms of the same genus (Catasetum tridentatum, etc.).

sn.def: The character or condition of a monk.
Monks, regarded collectively.

entry.def: Monkish.
Like a monk, or pertaining to monks; monastic; as, monkish manners; monkish dress; monkish solitude.
Like, or suitable to, a monk.
A plant of the genus Aconitum; aconite. See Aconite.

entries.entry: Monk's" seam`. Naut An extra middle seam made at the junction of two breadths of canvas, ordinarily joined by only two rows of stitches.

Mon"o- Mon- . Gr. � A prefix signifying one single alone; as, monocarp, monopoly; Chem indicating that a compound contains one atom one radical, or one group of that to the name of which it is united; as, monoxide, monosulphide, monatomic, etc.

entry.def: The black howler Mycetes villosus), a monkey of Central America.
Capable of being neutralized by a univalent base or basic radical; having but one acid hydrogen atom to be replaced; -- said of acids; as, acetic, nitric, and hydrochloric acids are monobasic .
Containing one carboxyl group; as, acetic acid is a monocarbonic acid. The more common term is monocarboxylic. Contrasted with dicarboxylic tricarboxylic, etc.
Having a single heart, as fishes and amphibians.

def2.def: An animal having a single heart.

entry.def: A monocarpic plant.
Consisting of a single carpel, as the fruit of the pea, cherry, and almond.

entry.note: ☞ Annual and biennual herbs are monocarpic, so also some plants of longer duration, as the century plant.
entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. � fruit: cf. F. monocarpe
entry.def: Bearing fruit but once, and dying after fructification, as beans, maize, mustard, etc.
Having a solitary head; -- said of unbranched composite plants.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �; mo`nos alone, single + ke`ras horn

sn.def: A one-horned creature; a unicorn; a sea monster with one horn.
sn.q: Mighty monoceroses with immeasured tails.

sn.def: The Unicorn, a constellation situated to the east Orion.

entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. �, �, cloak: cf. F. monochlamydé
entry.def: Having a single floral envelope, that is, a calyx without a corolla, or, possibly, in rare cases, a corolla without a calyx.

entry.ety: L. monochordon, Gr. �, fr. � with but one string; � only, single + � string: cf. F. monocorde. See Chord, and cf. Mainchord
entry.def: An instrument for experimenting upon the mathematical relations of musical sounds. It consists of a single string stretched between two bridges, one or both of which are movable, and which stand upon a graduated rule for the purpose of readily changing and measuring the length of the part of the string between them.

entry.cs: Monochromatic lamp Opt,a lamp whose flame yields rays of some one homogenous light. It is of great importance in optical experiments.
entry.def: Consisting of one color, or presenting rays of light of one color only.

entry.ety: Gr. � of one color; mo`nos single + � color: cf. F. monochrome
entry.def: A painting or drawing in a single color; a picture made with a single color.
Made, or done, with a single color; as, a monochromic picture. Called also, monochromatic and monochrome.
The art of painting or drawing in monochrome.
Existing at the same time; contemporaneous.
Having but one cilium.
An eyeglass for one eye.
Having one oblique inclination; -- applied to strata that dip in only one direction from the axis of elevation.
A monoclinal fold.
Having one oblique intersection; -- said of that system of crystallization in which the vertical axis is inclined to one, but at right angles to the other, lateral axis. See Crystallization.

entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. � couch, fr. � to lie down: cf. F. monocline
entry.def: Hermaphrodite, or having both stamens and pistils in every flower.
A group of vertebrates, including the birds and reptiles, or those that have only one occipital condyle; the Sauropsida.
Any monocotyledonous plant.
Monocotyledonous.

entry.note: ☞ The plural, monocotyledons, is used as the name of a large class of plants (the Monocotyledones, or Monocotyledonae), and is generally understood to be equivalent to the term endogens.
entry.def: A plant with only one cotyledon, or seed lobe; a member of the Monocotyledonae.

A class of plants comprising seed plants that produce an embryo with a single cotyledon and parallel-veined leaves: grasses; lilies; palms; and orchids. It is divided into four subclasses or superorders: Alismatidae; Arecidae; Commelinidae; and Liliidae.
entry.syn: class Monocotyledones Monocotyledonae, class Monocotyledonae Liliopsida, class Liliopsida.

entry.def: Having only one cotyledon, seed lobe, or seminal leaf.
Government by a single person; undivided rule.
One who governs alone.
Of, pertaining to, or showing, monocrotism; as, a monocrotic pulse; a pulse of the monocrotic type.
That condition of the pulse in which the pulse curve or sphygmogram shows but a single crest, the dicrotic elevation entirely disappearing.

entry.ety: L. monoculus; Gr. mo`nos single + L. oculus eye: cf. F. monoculaire

sn.def: Having only one eye; with one eye only; as, monocular vision.
Adapted to be used with only one eye at a time; as, a monocular microscope.

entry.def: A small crustacean with one median eye.
Monocular.
Of or pertaining to a division (Monocystidea) of the protozoan order Gregarinida, in which the body consists of one sac.

entry.ety: Gr. monoda`ktylos; mo`nos single + da`ktylos finger: cf. F. monodactyle
entry.def: Having but one finger or claw.
One of the Monodelphia.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + delfy`s the womb
entry.def: The group that includes all ordinary or placental mammals; the Placentalia. See Mammalia.
Of or pertaining to the Monodelphia.

sn.def: Belonging to a monody.

sd.def: For one voice; monophonic.
Homophonic; -- applied to music in which the melody is confined to one part, instead of being shared by all the parts as in the style called polyphonic.

entry.def: Dimetric.
A writer of a monody.
A drama acted, or intended to be acted, by a single person.
Pertaining to a monodrama.

entries.entry:
Mon"o*dy n.; pl.Monodies #. L. monodia, Gr. �, fr. � singing alone; mo`nos single + � song: cf. F. monodie. See Ode
A species of poem of a mournful character, in which a single mourner expresses lamentation; a song for one voice.

entry.def: Possessing but one capacity or power.
entry.q: Monodynamicmen.

entry.note: A philosophical form of the grand unified theory?
entry.def: The theory that the various forms of activity in nature are manifestations of the same force.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + � house
entry.def: A Linnæan class of plants, whose stamens and pistils are in distinct flowers in the same plant.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the Monœcia; monœcious.
A monœcious animal, as certain mollusks.

entry.def: Having the sexes united in one individual, as when male and female flowers grow upon the same individual plant; hermaphrodite; -- opposed to diœcious.
The state or condition of being monœcious.
One of the Monogamia.
A Linnæan order of plants, having solitary flowers with united anthers, as in the genus Lobelia.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or involving, monogamy.
Of or pertaining to the Monogamia; having a simple flower with united anthers.

entry.def: One who practices or upholds monogamy.

entry.ety: L. monogamus having but one wife, Gr. �; mo`nos single + � marriage

sn.def: Upholding, or practicing, monogamy.
Same as Monogamian.
Mating with but one of the opposite sex; -- said of birds and mammals.

entry.def: The state of being monogamous; having one wife at a time.

entry.ety: L. monogamia, Gr. �: cf. F. monogamie

sn.def: Single marriage; marriage with but one person, husband or wife, at the same time; -- opposed to polygamy. Also, one marriage only during life; -- opposed to deuterogamy.
State of being paired with a single mate.

entry.def: Having but a single stomach.

sn.def: Oneness of origin; esp. Biol, development of all beings in the universe from a single cell; -- opposed to polygenesis. Called also monism.
That form of reproduction which requires but one parent, as in reproduction by fission or in the formation of buds, etc., which drop off and form new individuals; asexual reproduction.
The direct development of an embryo, without metamorphosis, into an organism similar to the parent organism; -- opposed to metagenesis.
One in genesis; resulting from one process of formation; -- used of a mountain range.
Relating to, or involving, monogenesis; as, the monogenetic school of physiologists, who admit but one cell as the source of all beings.
Of or pertaining to monogenesis.
Producing only one kind of germs, or young; developing only in one way.

entry.def: The theory or doctrine that the human races have a common origin, or constitute a single species.
One who maintains that the human races are all of one species; -- opposed to polygenist.
Monogenic.
Of or pertaining to monogenesis; as, monogenous, or asexual, reproduction.

sn.def: Monogenesis.
The doctrine that the members of the human race have all a common origin.

entry.def: Having but one brood in a season.

entry.note: ☞ The monogram above, combining the letters of the name Karolvs, was used by Charlemagne.
entry.ety: L. monogramma; Gr. mo`nos single + gra`mma letter, fr. gra`fein to write: cf. F. monogramme. See Graphic

sn.def: A character or cipher composed of two or more letters interwoven or combined so as to represent a name, or a part of it (usually the initials). Monograms are often used on seals, ornamental pins, rings, buttons, and by painters, engravers, etc., to distinguish their works.
A picture in lines; a sketch.
An arbitrary sign for a word.

entry.def: To inscribe or ornament with a monogram.
See Monogrammic.
Monogrammic.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a monogram.
Monogrammic.
A written account or description of a single thing, or class of things; a special treatise on a particular subject of limited range.
A writer of a monograph.
Of or pertaining to a monograph, or to a monography; as, a monographic writing; a monographic picture.
One who writes a monograph.
Monographic.

sn.def: Representation by lines without color; an outline drawing.
A monograph.

entry.def: One of the Monogynia.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + � woman, female
entry.def: A Linnæan order of plants, including those which have only one style or stigma.
Pertaining to the Monogynia; monogynous.
Of or pertaining to Monogynia; having only one style or stigma.

sn.def: Marriage with the one woman only.
The state or condition of being monogynous.

entry.def: Lasting but one day.
Monœcious.
Worship of a single deity.
Using or knowing only one language; as, monolingual speakers; a monolingual dictionary. Opposite of multilingual.

entry.ety: F. monolithe, L. monolithus consisting of a single stone, Gr. �; mo`nos single + li`qos stone
entry.def: A single stone, especially one of large size, shaped into a pillar, statue, or monument.
Monolithic.
Of or pertaining to a monolith; consisting of a single stone.
One who soliloquizes; esp., one who monopolizes conversation in company.

entry.ety: F. monologue, Gr. � speaking alone; mo`nos alone, single, sole + lo`gos speech, discourse, le`gein to speak. See Legend

sn.def: A speech uttered by a person alone; soliloquy; also, talk or discourse in company, in the strain of a soliloquy; as, an account in monologue .
A dramatic composition for a single performer.

entry.def: The habit of soliloquizing, or of monopolizing conversation.
entry.q: It was not by an insolent usurpation that Coleridge persisted in monology through his whole life.

entry.ety: L. monomachia, Gr. �, fr. � fighting in single combat; mo`nos single, alone + � to fight
entry.def: A duel; single combat.
entry.q: The duello ormonomachia.

entry.def: One who fights in single combat; a duelist.
A monomaniac.
Derangement of the mind in regard of a single subject only; also, such a concentration of interest upon one particular subject or train of ideas to show mental derangement.
entry.syn: Insanity; madness; alienation; aberration; derangement; mania. See Insanity.

entry.def: A person affected by monomania.
Affected with monomania, or partial derangement of intellect; caused by, or resulting from, monomania; as, a monomaniacal delusion.

entry.ety: F., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + -nome as in binome. See Binomial
entry.def: A monomial.

The basic conceptual building unit of a polymer; a molecule of low molecular weight which may combine with other molecules to form a molecule in a chain or branched form having high molecular weight; as, amino acids are the monomer units which are combined to form proteins; vinylic plastics are formed from monomers having a vinyl group.
Not linked to other molecules of the same kind; having the property of a monomer. Opposed to polymeric.

sn.def: Composed of solitary parts, as a flower with one sepal, one petal, one stamen, and one pistil.
Having but one joint; -- said of the foot of certain insects.

entry.def: Consisting of one metal; of or pertaining to monometallism.
The legalized use of one metal only, as gold, or silver, in the standard currency of a country, or as a standard of money values. See Bimetallism.
One who believes in monometallism as opposed to bimetallism, etc.

entry.ety: Gr. � of one meter; mo`nos single + � measure
entry.def: A rhythmic series, consisting of a single meter.
Same as Isometric.
A single algebraic expression; that is, an expression unconnected with any other by the sign of addition, substraction, equality, or inequality.
Consisting of but a single term or expression.

Having but a single form; retaining the same form throughout the various stages of development; of the same or of an essentially similar type of structure; -- opposed to dimorphic trimorphic, and polymorphic.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos alone + � the navel
entry.def: A form of double monster, in which two individuals are united by a common umbilicus.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + �, �, muscle
entry.def: An order of lamellibranchs having but one muscle for closing the shell, as the oyster.
Of or pertaining to the Monomya.
Monomyal.
Having but one and the same nature or essence.
Suffering or sensibility in a single organ or function.
Having but one person, or form of existence.

entry.note: ☞ The most recent authors restrict this form to flowers having a solitary petal, as in species of Amorpha, and use gamopetalous for a corolla of several petals combined into one piece. See Illust. of Gamopetalous.
entry.def: Having only one petal, or the corolla in one piece, or composed of petals cohering so as to form a tube or bowl; gamopetalous.
Having one and the same appearance; having a mutual resemblance.

sn.def: Single-voiced; having but one part; as, a monophonic composition; -- opposed to polyphonic.

Of or relating to a system for recording and reproducing sound, which has only one sound channel; also called monaural or mono. It contrasts with stereophonicor stereo), quadraphonic, or surround-sound, which have two or more channels, and can thus reproduce the effect of the sound coming from more than one direction.

entry.ety: Gr. � with one sound; mo`nos alone + � sound, voice

sn.def: A single uncompounded vowel sound.
A combination of two written vowels pronounced as one; a digraph.

entry.def: Consisting of, or pertaining to, a monophthong.

entry.ety: Gr. � of one tribe, fr. mo`nos single + � clan
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a single family or stock, or to development from a single common parent form; -- opposed to polyphyletic; as, monophyletic origin.

entry.ety: Gr. mono`fyllos; mo`nos alone + fy`llon leaf: cf. F. monophylle
entry.def: One-leaved; composed of a single leaf; as, a monophyllous involucre or calyx.

entry.ety: Gr. mo`nos single (mo`nos alone + � to produce) + 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth
entry.def: Having but one set of teeth; -- opposed to diphyodont.

entry.ety: Gr. �; mo`nos single + � nature: cf. F. monophysite
entry.def: One of a sect, in the ancient church, who maintained that the human and divine in Jesus Christ constituted but one composite nature. Also used adjectively.
Of or pertaining to Monophysites, or their doctrines.
A monoplastic element.
That has one form, or retains its primary form, as, a monoplastic element.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + � a stroke
entry.def: Paralysis affecting a single limb.
A suborder of Dipnoi, including the Ceratodus.

sn.def: One of a fabulous tribe or race of Ethiopians having but one leg and foot.
A monopodium.

entry.def: Having a monopodium or a single and continuous axis, as a birchen twig or a cornstalk.

entries.entry:
‖Mon`o*po"di*um n.; pl. L. Monopodia #, E. -ums #. L. See Monopody
Bot A single and continuous vegetable axis; -- opposed to sympodium.

entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. poy`s podo`s, foot: cf. �, �, one-footed
entry.def: A measure of but a single foot.
A monopolist.
One who monopolizes; one who has a monopoly; one who favors monopoly.
Of or pertaining to a monopolist.
A monopolist.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Monopolized; p. pr. & vb. n. Monopolizing
entry.def: To acquire a monopoly of; to have or get the exclusive privilege or means of dealing in, or the exclusive possession of; to engross the whole of; as, to monopolize the coffee trade; to monopolize land.
One who monopolizes.

entries.entry:
Mo*nop"o*ly n.; pl.Monopolies #. L. monopolium, Gr. �, �; mo`nos alone + � to sell
The exclusive power, or privilege of selling a commodity; the exclusive power, right, or privilege of dealing in some article, or of trading in some market; sole command of the traffic in anything, however obtained; as, the proprietor of a patented article is given a monopoly of its sale for a limited time; chartered trading companies have sometimes had a monopoly of trade with remote regions; a combination of traders may get a monopoly of a particular product.
Raleigh held a monopoly of cards, Essex a monopoly of sweet wines.
Exclusive possession; as, a monopoly of land. If I had a monopoly out, they would have part on 't.
The commodity or other material thing to which the monopoly relates; as, tobacco is a monopoly in France. Colloq

entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. poly`s many + lo`gos speech
entry.def: An exhibition in which an actor sustains many characters.
The doctrine that there is but one immortal soul or intellect with which all men are endowed.

entry.ety: Gr. mono`pteros with a row of pillars only; mo`nos alone, only + ptero`n feather, wing, also, a row of pillars: cf. F. monoptère
entry.def: Round and without a cella; consisting of a single ring of columns supporting a roof; -- said esp. of a temple.

entries.entry:
‖Mo*nop"ter*on n.; pl.Monoptera #. NL. See Monopteral
Arch A circular temple consisting of a roof supported on columns, without a cella.

entry.ety: L. monoptotum, Gr. mono`ptwtos; mo`nos single + � apt to fall, fallen, fr. � to fall; cf. � case

sn.def: A noun having only one case.
A noun having only one ending for the oblique cases.

entry.def: Having but a single stone or kernel.
Belonging to, or affecting, a single organ, or set of organs.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + �, �, nose
entry.def: The Marsipobranchiata.
A composition in verse, in which all the lines end with the same rhyme.

entries.entry:
Mon`o*sac"cha*ride n. Also -rid . Mono- + saccharide
Chem A simple sugar; any of a number of sugars (including the trioses, tetroses, pentoses, hexoses, etc.), not decomposable into simpler sugars by hydrolysis. Specif., as used by some, a hexose. The monosaccharides are all open-chain compounds containing hydroxyl groups and either an aldehyde group or a ketone group.

entry.note: ☞ The most recent writers restrict this term to flowers having a solarity sepal, and use gamosepalous for a calyx formed by several sepals combined into one piece. Cf. Monopetalous.
entry.def: Having only one sepal, or the calyx in one piece or composed of the sepals united into one piece; gamosepalous.

The monosodium salt of the natural amino acid L-glutamine (C5H8NNaO4), used as a food additive to enhance flavor; abbreviated MSG. It is usually marketed as the monhydrate (C5H8NNaO4.H2O). It is commmonly used in Chinese-American restaurants, and has been identified as a main cause of Chinese restaurant syndrome.
A monospermous plant.

entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. spe`rma seed: cf. F. monosperme
entry.def: Having only one seed.
Consisting of one sphere only.

entry.ety: Gr. �, from � consisting of one verse; mo`nos single + sti`chos line, verse
entry.def: A composition consisting of one verse only.
Arranged in a single row on one side of an axis, as the flowers in grasses of the tribe Chloridæ.
A metrical composition consisting of a single strophe.

entry.ety: Gr. monostrofiko`s; mo`nos single + strofh` strophe
entry.def: Having one strophe only; not varied in measure; written in unvaried measure.
A sulphide containing one atom of sulphur, and analogous to a monoxide; -- contrasted with a polysulphide; as, galena is a monosulphide .
See Monosulphide.
Being a monosyllable, or composed of monosyllables; as, a monosyllabic word; a monosyllabic language.
The state of consisting of monosyllables, or having a monosyllabic form; frequent occurrence of monosyllables.

entry.ety: L. monosyllabus of one syllable, Gr. �: cf. F. monosyllabe. See Mono- Syllable
entry.def: A word of one syllable.
Formed into, or consisting of, monosyllables.
Same as Monoclinic.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + � four
entry.def: A single narrative framed from the statements of the four evangelists; a gospel harmony.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + qa`lamos a chamber
entry.def: A division of Foraminifera including those that have only one chamber.
A foraminifer having but one chamber.

entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. qa`lamos chamber: cf. F. monothalame
entry.def: One-chambered.
Formed from one pistil; -- said of fruits.
Having a single loculament.

entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. � god: cf. F. monothéisme
entry.def: The doctrine or belief that there is but one God.
One who believes that there is but one God.
Of or pertaining to monotheism.
The doctrine of the Monothelites.

entry.ety: Gr. �; mo`nos alone, only + �, �, to will, be willing: cf. F. monothélite
entry.def: One of an ancient sect who held that Christ had but one will as he had but one nature. Cf. Monophysite.
Of or pertaining to the Monothelites, or their doctrine.

sn.def: Bearing fruit but once; monocarpic.
Uniparous; laying a single egg.

entry.ety: Mono- + Gr. � cutting, fr. � to cut
entry.def: Having a distinct cleavage in a single direction only.

sn.def: A single unvaried tone or sound.
The utterance of successive syllables, words, or sentences, on one unvaried key or line of pitch.
Of, pertaining to, or uttered in, a monotone; monotonous.
sn.q: Monotonicaldeclamation.

sn.def: Always increasing or always decreasing, as the value of the independent variable increases; -- of a function.

entry.def: One who talks in the same strain or on the same subject until weariness is produced.

entry.ety: Gr. �; mo`nos alone, single + � tone. See Tone
entry.def: Uttered in one unvarying tone; continued with dull uniformity; characterized by monotony; without change or variety; wearisome.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. monotonie. See Monotonius

sn.def: A frequent recurrence of the same tone or sound, producing a dull uniformity; absence of variety, as in speaking or singing.
Any irksome sameness, or want of variety.
sn.q: At sea, everything that breaks the monotony of the surrounding expanse attracts attention.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + � hole
entry.def: A subclass of Mammalia, having a cloaca in which the ducts of the urinary, genital, and alimentary systems terminate, as in birds. The female lays eggs like a bird. See Duck mole, under Duck, and Echidna.
Of or pertaining to the Monotremata.
One of the Monotremata.
A kind of intercolumniation in an entablature, in which only one triglyph and two metopes are introduced.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. mo`nos single + � turn, from � to turn
entry.def: A genus of parasitic or saprophytic plants including the Indian pipe and pine sap. The name alludes to the dropping end of the stem.
A natural family of plants, used in some classifications for saprophytic herbs; it is sometimes included in the family Pyrolaceae, and contains the genera Monotropa and Sarcodes.
Having but one type; containing but one representative; as, a monotypic genus, which contains but one species.

sn.def: The only representative of its group, as a single species constituting a genus.
A print (but one impression can be taken) made by painting on metal and then transferring the painting to paper by pressure; also, the process of making such prints.
A kind of keyboard-operated typesetting and casting machine that makes and sets separate characters.

entry.ety: Mono- + L. valens, p. pr. See Valence
entry.def: Having a valence of one; univalent. See Univalent.
derived from a single egg or ovum; -- of twins; as, identical twins are monovular . Contrasted with fraternal.
An oxide containing one atom of oxygen in each molecule; as, barium monoxide .

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. �, fr. � made from one piece of wood; mo`nos alone + � wood
entry.def: A canoe or boat made from one piece of timber.
Made of one piece of wood.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. mo`nos single + zo^,on an animal
entry.def: A division of Radiolaria; -- called also Monocyttaria.

entries.entry: Mon*roe" doc"trine. See under Doctrine.

‖Mon`sei`gneur" n.; pl.Messeigneurs #. F., fr. mon my + seigneur lord, L. senior older. See Senior, and cf. Monsieur
My lord; -- a title in France of a person of high birth or rank; as, Monseigneur the Prince, or Monseigneur the Archibishop. It was given, specifically, to the dauphin, before the Revolution of 1789. (Abbrev. Mgr.
Mon"sel's salt`. Med A basic sulphate of iron; -- so named from Monsel, a Frenchman.

Mon"sel's so*lu"tion. See Monsel's salt
Med An aqueous solution of Monsel's salt, having valuable styptic properties.

‖Mon*sieur" n.; pl.Messieurs #. F., fr. mon my + Sieur, abbrev. of seigneur lord. See Monseigneur
The common title of civility in France in speaking to, or of, a man; Mr. or Sir.
The oldest brother of the king of France.
A Frenchman. Contemptuous

‖Mon`si*gno"re n.; pl.Monsignors #. It., my lord. Cf. Monseigneur
My lord; -- an ecclesiastical dignity bestowed by the pope, entitling the bearer to social and domestic rank at the papal court. (Abbrev. Mgr.

entry.ety: Malay mūsim, fr. Ar. mausim a time, season: cf. F. monson mousson, Sr. monzon, Pg. monção, It. monsone
entry.def: A wind blowing part of the year from one direction, alternating with a wind from the opposite direction; -- a term applied particularly to periodical winds of the Indian Ocean, which blow from the southwest from the latter part of May to the middle of September, and from the northeast from about the middle of October to the middle of December.

sn.def: A heavy rainfall in India associated with the southwest monsoon{1}.
The season in which the monsoon{2} occurs.

entry.ety: OE. monstre, F. monstre, fr. L. monstrum, orig., a divine omen, indicating misfortune; akin of monstrare to show, point out, indicate, and monere to warn. See Monition, and cf. Demonstrate Muster

sn.def: Something of unnatural size, shape, or quality; a prodigy; an enormity; a marvel.
sn.q: A monster or marvel.

sn.def: Specifically , an animal or plant departing greatly from the usual type, as by having too many limbs.
Any thing or person of unnatural or excessive ugliness, deformity, wickedness, or cruelty.
Monstrous in size.
Enormous or very powerful.

entry.def: To make monstrous.

sn.def: any plant of the genus Monstera; they are often grown as houseplants.
A tropical cylindrical pineconelike fruit with pineapple-banana flavor.

entry.ety: LL. monstrantia, fr. L. monstrare to show: cf. OF. monstrance. See Monster
entry.def: A transparent pyx, in which the consecrated host is exposed to view.
The act of demonstrating; proof.
entry.q: A certain monstration.

entries.entry:
Mon*stros"i*ty n.; pl.Monstrosities #. Cf. F. monstruosité. See Monstrous
The state of being monstrous, or out of the common order of nature; that which is monstrous; a monster. A monstrosity never changes the name or affects the immutability of a species.

entry.ety: OE. monstruous, F. monstrueux, fr. L. monstruosus, fr. monstrum. See Monster

sn.def: Marvelous; strange.
Having the qualities of a monster; deviating greatly from the natural form or character; abnormal; as, a monstrous birth.
sn.q: He, therefore, that refuses to do good to them whom he is bound to love . . . is unnatural and monstrous in his affections.

sn.def: Extraordinary in a way to excite wonder, dislike, apprehension, etc.; -- said of size, appearance, color, sound, etc.; as, a monstrous height; a monstrous ox; a monstrous story.
Extraordinary on account of ugliness, viciousness, or wickedness; hateful; horrible; dreadful.
sn.q: So bad a death argues a monstrous life.

sn.def: Abounding in monsters.
sn.q: Where thou, perhaps, under the whelming tide Visitest the bottom of the monstrous world.

entry.def: Exceedingly; very; very much.
entry.q: Amonstrousthick oil on the top.
And will be monstrous witty on the poor.

entry.def: In a monstrous manner; unnaturally; extraordinarily; as, monstrously wicked.
entry.q: Who with his wife ismonstrouslyin love.

entry.def: The state or quality of being monstrous, unusual, extraordinary.
Monstrosity.
Monstrous.
Mountain.
A mountain.

entry.ety: L. montanus, fr. mons montis, mountain. See Mount n.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to mountains; consisting of mountains.

A follower of Mintanus, a Phrygian enthusiast of the second century, who claimed that the Holy Spirit, the Paraclete, dwelt in him, and employed him as an instrument for purifying and guiding men in the Christian life.

entry.ety: F.,prop., mounting, fr. monter to mount, fr. L. mons montis, mountain. See Mount

sn.def: An upward thrust or blow.
An upright piece in any framework; a mullion or muntin; a stile.

entries.entry: ‖Mont" de pi`é`té". F., fr. It. monte di pietà mount of piety One of certain public pawnbroking establishments which originated in Italy in the 15th century, the object of which was to lend money at a low rate of interest to poor people in need; -- called also mount of piety. The institution has been adopted in other countries, as in Spain and France. See Lombard-house.

cs.cd: a gambling game using playing cards, in which a dealer shows a bettor three cards face up and specifies one to be identified, and after the cards are turned face down and moved around quickly, the bettor must identify which of the three cards is the specified card. It is sometimes engaged in by dealers on the streets of a city, with bets made by passers-by.

entry.ety: Sp., lit., mountain, hence, the stock of cards remaining after laying out a certain number, fr. L. mons montis, mountain
entry.def: A favorite gambling game among Spaniards, played with dice or cards.
In Spanish America, a wood; forest; timber land; esp., in parts of South America, a comparatively wooden region.

entry.ety: F. monter to raise + acide acid
entry.def: An acid elevator, as a tube through which acid is forced to some height in a sulphuric acid manufactory.
See Monteth.
A kind of cotton handkerchief having a uniform colored ground with a regular pattern of white spots produced by discharging the color; -- so called from the Glasgow manufactures.

entry.ety: F., fr. monter to bring up + jus juice
entry.def: An apparatus for raising a liquid by pressure of air or steam in a reservoir containing the liquid.

entry.ety: L. ad montem to the hillock. See Mount n.
entry.def: A custom, formerly practiced by the scholars at Eton school, England, of going every third year, on Whittuesday, to a hillock near the Bath road, and exacting money from all passers-by, to support at the university the senior scholar of the school.

entry.ety: Sp. montera a hunting cap, fr. montero a huntsman, monte a mountain, forest, L. mons montis, mountain. See Mount n.
entry.def: An ancient kind of cap worn by horsemen or huntsmen.

entries.entry: Mon`tes*so"ri Meth"od. Pedagogy A system of training and instruction, primarily for use with normal children aged from three to six years, devised by Dr. Maria Montessori while teaching in the “Houses of Childhood” (schools in the poorest tenement districts of Rome, Italy), and first fully described by her in 1909. The fundamental aim is to create self-motivation for education, and the leading features are freedom for physical activity (no stationary desks and chairs), informal and individual instruction, the very early development of reading and writing skills, and an extended sensory and motor training (with special emphasis on vision, touch, perception of movement, and their interconnections), mediated by a patented, standardized system of “didactic apparatus,” which is declared to be “auto-regulative.” Most of the chief features of the method are borrowed from current methods used in many institutions for training feeble-minded children, and dating back especially to the work of the French-American physician Edouard O. Seguin1812-80).

entry.def: A vessel in which glasses are washed; -- so called from the name of the inventor.
entry.q: New things produce new words, and thus Monteth Has by one vessel saved his name from death.

entry.def: A balloon which ascends by the buoyancy of air heated by a fire; a fire balloon; -- so called from two brothers, Stephen and Joseph Montgolfier , of France, who first constructed and sent up a fire balloon.

entry.note: ☞ In the common law, a month is a lunar month, or twenty-eight days, unless otherwise expressed. Blackstone. In the United States the rule of the common law is generally changed, and a month is declared to mean a calendar month. Cooley's Blackstone.
entry.cs: A month mind. A strong or abnormal desire. Obs Shak. A celebration made in remembrance of a deceased person a month after death. Strype. Calendar months the months as adjusted in the common or Gregorian calendar; April, June, September, and November, containing 30 days, and the rest 31, except February, which, in common years, has 28, and in leap years 29. Lunar month the period of one revolution of the moon, particularly a synodical revolution; but several kinds are distinguished, as the synodical month, or period from one new moon to the next, in mean length 29 d. 12 h. 44 m. 2.87 s.; the nodical month, or time of revolution from one node to the same again, in length 27 d. 5 h. 5 m. 36 s.; the sidereal, or time of revolution from a star to the same again, equal to 27 d. 7 h. 43 m. 11.5 s.; the anomalistic, or time of revolution from perigee to perigee again, in length 27 d. 13 h. 18 m. 37.4 s.; and the tropical, or time of passing from any point of the ecliptic to the same again, equal to 27 d. 7 h. 43 m. 4.7 s. Solar month the time in which the sun passes through one sign of the zodiac, in mean length 30 d. 10 h. 29 m. 4.1 s.
entry.ety: OE. month moneth, AS. mōnð mōnað; akin to mōna moon, and to D. maand month, G. monat, OHG. mānōd, Icel. mānuðr mānaðr, Goth. mēnōþs. √272. See Moon
entry.def: One of the twelve portions into which the year is divided; the twelfth part of a year, corresponding nearly to the length of a synodic revolution of the moon, -- whence the name. In popular use, a period of four weeks is often called a month.
That which is a month old, or which lives for a month.

cs.cd: a nurse who serves for a month or some short time, esp. one which attends women after childbirth.

sn.def: Continued a month, or a performed in a month; as, the monthly revolution of the moon.
Done, happening, payable, published, etc., once a month, or every month; as, a monthly visit; monthly charges; a monthly installment; a monthly magazine.

entries.entry: Month"ly n.; pl.Monthlies. A publication which appears regularly once a month.

sn.def: Once a month; in every month; as, the moon changes monthly .
As if under the influence of the moon; in the manner of a lunatic.

entry.ety: L. monticulus, dim. of mons montis, mountain: cf. F. monticule. See Mount n.
entry.def: A little mount; a hillock; a small elevation or prominence.
Furnished with monticles or little elevations.
See Monticle.
Monticulate.
Resembling a mountain in form.

entry.ety: L. montigena; mons montis, mountain + the root of gignere to beget
entry.def: Produced on a mountain.

entry.ety: F., fr. monter to mount. See Montant
entry.def: A stone used in mounting a horse; a horse block.
A heap of ore; a mass undergoing the process of amalgamation.

entry.ety: F., show, show case, organ case

sn.def: A stop, usually the open diapason, having its pipes “shown” as part of the organ case, or otherwise specially mounted.
A hole in the wall of a pottery kiln, by which the state of the pieces within can be judged.

entry.def: See Matross.

entry.ety: F., fr. monter to mount. See Montoir
entry.def: That on which anything is mounted; a setting; hence, a saddle horse.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. monumentum, fr. monere to remind, admonish. See Monition, and cf. Moniment

sn.def: Something which stands, or remains, to keep in remembrance what is past; a memorial.
sn.q: Of ancient British art A pleasing monument.
Our bruised arms hung up for monuments.

sn.def: A building, pillar, stone, or the like, erected to preserve the remembrance of a person, event, action, etc.; as, the Washington monument; the Bunker Hill monument . Also, a tomb, with memorial inscriptions.
sn.q: On your family's old monument Hang mournful epitaphs, and do all rites That appertain unto a burial.

sn.def: A stone or other permanent object, serving to indicate a limit or to mark a boundary.
A saying, deed, or example, worthy of record.
sn.q: Acts and Monuments of these latter and perilous days.

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or suitable for, a monument; as, a monumental inscription.
Serving as a monument; memorial; preserving memory.
sn.q: Of pine, ormonumentaloak.
A work outlasting monumental brass.

sn.def: Of lasting significance; as, a monumental work of literature; a monumental accomplishment.
Exceptionally large in quantity, quality, or degree; as, a monumental amount of work to be done
By way of memorial.
By means of monuments.

entry.def: Any one of a series of complex nitrogenous substances regarded as derived from one molecule of urea; as, alloxan is a monureid .
See Mo.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mooed; p. pr. & vb. n. Mooing
entry.def: To make the noise of a cow; to low; -- a child's word.
The lowing of a cow.

sn.def: to ask for and get free; to borrow without intending to repay; to sponge; -- usually with objects of small value; as, he mooched a few cigarettes from me.
To beg for.

entry.def: a cow{1}; -- a child's word. See 1st cow1}, n.

entry.ety: The same word as mode, perh. influenced by mood temper. See Mode

sn.def: Manner; style; mode; logical form; musical style; manner of action or being. See Mode which is the preferable form).

Manner of conceiving and expressing action or being, as positive, possible, conditional, hypothetical, obligatory, imperitive, etc., without regard to other accidents, such as time, person, number, etc.; as, the indicative mood; the imperitive mood; the infinitive mood; the subjunctive mood. Same as Mode.

entry.ety: OE. mood mod, AS. mōdmind, feeling, heart, courage; akin to OS. & OFries. mōd, D. moed, OHG. muot, G. muth mut, courage, Dan. & Sw. mod, Icel. mōðr wrath, Goth. mōds
entry.def: Temper of mind; temporary state of the mind in regard to passion or feeling; humor; as, a melancholy mood; a suppliant mood.
entry.q: Till at the last aslaked was his mood.
Fortune is merry, And in this mood will give us anything.
The desperate recklessness of her mood.

entry.def: Mother.
In a moody manner.
The quality or state of being moody; specifically, liability to strange or violent moods.
The governor of a province in Egypt, etc.
Moody.
Moodily.

sn.def: Subject to varying moods, especially to states of mind which are unamiable or depressed.
Hence: Out of humor; peevish; angry; fretful; also, abstracted and pensive; sad; gloomy; melancholy.
sn.q: Every peevish,moodymalcontent.
Arouse thee from thy moody dream!

entry.def: See Mollah.
Same as Mulley.
money.

entry.cs: Moon blindness. Far A kind of ophthalmia liable to recur at intervals of three or four weeks. Med Hemeralopia. Moon dial a dial used to indicate time by moonlight. Moon face a round face like a full moon. Moon madness lunacy. Poetic Moon month a lunar month. Moon trefoil Bot a shrubby species of medic (Medicago arborea). See Medic. Moon year a lunar year, consisting of lunar months, being sometimes twelve and sometimes thirteen. blue moon see blue moon in the vocabulary.
entry.ety: OE. mone, AS. mōna; akin to D. maan, OS. & OHG. māno, G. mond, Icel. māni, Dan. maane, Sw. måne, Goth. mēna, Lith. menů, L. mensis month, Gr. mh`nh moon, mh`n month, Skr. mās moon, month; prob. from a root meaning to measure (cf. Skr. mā to measure), from its serving to measure the time. √271. Cf. Mete to measure, Menses Monday Month

sn.def: The celestial orb which revolves round the earth; the satellite of the earth; a secondary planet, whose light, borrowed from the sun, is reflected to the earth, and serves to dispel the darkness of night. The diameter of the moon is 2,160 miles, its mean distance from the earth is 240,000 miles, and its mass is one eightieth that of the earth. See Lunar month, under Month.
sn.q: The crescent moon, the diadem of night.

sn.def: A secondary planet, or satellite, revolving about any member of the solar system; as, the moons of Jupiter or Saturn.
The time occupied by the moon in making one revolution in her orbit; a month.
A crescentlike outwork. See Half-moon.
The deliberately exposed naked buttocks.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mooned; p. pr. & vb. n. Mooning

sn.def: To expose to the rays of the moon.
sn.q: If they have it to be exceeding white indeed, they seethe it yet once more, after it hath been thus sunned and mooned.

sn.def: To expose one's naked buttocks to (a person); -- a vulgar sign of contempt or disrespect, sometimes done as a prank.

entry.def: To act if moonstruck; to wander or gaze about in an abstracted manner.
entry.q: Elsley was mooning down the river by himself.

entry.def: A ray of light from the moon.
Dim-sighted; purblind.
A temporary blindness, or impairment of sight, said to be caused by sleeping in the moonlight; -- sometimes called nyctalopia.

sn.def: A monster; a false conception; a mass of fleshy matter, generated in the uterus.
A dolt; a stupid fellow.

entry.def: Culminating, or coming to the meredian, at or about the same time with the moon; -- said of a star or stars, esp. of certain stars selected beforehand, and named in an ephemeris (as the Nautical Almanac), as suitable to be observed in connection with the moon at culmination, for determining terrestrial longitude.
Of or resembling the moon; symbolized by the moon.
entry.q: Sharpening inmooned MoonedAshtaroth.

entry.def: One who abstractedly wanders or gazes about, as if moonstruck.
Conduct of one who moons.
A little moon.

sn.def: A eye affected by the moon; also, a disease in the eye of a horse.

sd.def: Any species of American fresh-water fishes of the genus Hyodon, esp. Hyodon tergisus of the Great Lakes and adjacent waters.
The cisco.

entry.def: Having eyes affected by the moon; moonblind; dim-eyed; purblind.
Having a round, full face.
An American marine fish (Vomer setipennis); -- called also bluntnosed shiner horsefish, and sunfish.
A broad, thin, silvery marine fish (Selene vomer); -- called also lookdown, and silver moonfish.
The mola. See Sunfish, 1.
The oxeye daisy; -- called also moon daisy.
A kind of morning glory (Ipomœa Bona-nox) with large white flowers opening at night.
Same as Mung.
The bright reflection of the moon's light on an expanse of water.
The European goldcrest.

entry.ety: from Sun Myun Moon , Korean evangelist and founder
entry.def: A member of the Unification Church, founded by Sun Myun Moon .
Like the moon; variable.
entry.q: Being but a moonish youth.

entry.def: Being without a moon or moonlight.
The light of the moon.

def2.def: Occurring during or by moonlight; characterized by moonlight.

entry.def: to work at a second job in addition to one's main occupation; -- often done at night.

entries.entry: Moon"light`er m�n"līt`ẽr n. One who follows an occupation or pastime by moonlight; as: A moonshiner. In Ireland, one of a band that engaged in agrarian outrages by night. A serenader by moonlight. Local, U. S One who works at a second job in addition to his main occupation.

entry.def: A simpleton; a lunatic.
Illumined by the moon.
entry.q: Themoonlitsea.
Moonlitdells.

entry.def: Same as Moonsail.
The rising of the moon above the horizon; also, the time of its rising.
resembling the moon in shape.
A sail sometimes carried in light winds, above a skysail.
A climbing plant of the genus Menispermum; -- so called from the crescentlike form of the seeds.
The descent of the moon below the horizon; also, the time when the moon sets.

entry.ety: Hind. munishī, fr. Ar. munishī a writer, author, secretary, tutor
entry.def: A Mohammedan professor or teacher of language.

sn.def: The light of the moon.
Hence, show without substance or reality.
A month.
A preparation of eggs for food.
Liquor smuggled or illicitly distilled, especially liquor distilled illegally in rural parts of the southern U. S.
sn.mark: Dial. Eng., & Colloq. or Slang, U. S

entry.def: Moonlight.

sn.def: Empty; trivial; idle.
Designating, or pertaining to, illicit liquor; as, moonshine whisky.
sn.mark: Dial. Eng., & Colloq. or Slang, U. S

entry.def: A person engaged in illicit distilling; -- so called because the work is largely done at night.
Illicit distilling.
Moonlight.
entry.q: I went to see them in a moonshiny night.

entry.def: The action or event of sending a spacecraft to the moon; -- used of manned or unmanned missions.
splashed or covered patchily with moonlight; as, the moon-splashed world.
A nearly pellucid variety of feldspar, showing pearly or opaline reflections from within. It is used as a gem. The best specimens come from Ceylon.
See Moonstruck.

sn.def: Mentally affected or deranged by the supposed influence of the moon; lunatic.
Produced by the supposed influence of the moon.
sn.q: Moonstruckmadness.

sn.def: Made sick by the supposed influence of the moon, as a human being; made unsuitable for food, as fishes, by such supposed influence.
a kind of dance step in which the dancer seems to be sliding backward on the spot; as, Michael Jackson perfected the moonwalk in the 1980s.
an exploratory walk by an astronaut on the surface of Earth's moon.

entry.def: The herb lunary or honesty. See Honesty.
Any fern of the genus Botrychium, esp. Botrychium Lunaria; -- so named from the crescent-shaped segments of its frond.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the moon.
sn.q: Soft and pale as the moony beam.

sn.def: Furnished with a moon; bearing a crescent.
sn.q: But soon the miscreant moony host Before the victor cross shall fly.

sn.def: Silly; weakly sentimental.

entry.def: A follower of the Rev. Sun Myun Moon ; a member of the Unification Church; -- often considered disparaging.

entry.ety: F. More Maure, L. Maurus a Moor, a Mauritanian, an inhabitant of Mauritania, Gr. May^ros; cf. may^ros black, dark. Cf. Morris a dance, Morocco

sn.def: One of a mixed race inhabiting Morocco, Algeria, Tunis, and Tripoli, chiefly along the coast and in towns.
Any individual of the swarthy races of Africa or Asia which have adopted the Mohammedan religion.
sn.q: In Spanish history the termsMoors, Saracens, and Arabs are synonymous.

entry.cs: Moor buzzard Zoöl the marsh harrier. Prov. Eng Moor coal Geol a friable variety of lignite. Moor cock Zoöl the male of the moor fowl or red grouse of Europe. Moor coot. Zoöl See Gallinule. Moor game. Zoöl Same as Moor fowl. Moor grass Bot a tufted perennial grass (Sesleria cærulea), found in mountain pastures of Europe. Moor hawk Zoöl the marsh harrier. Moor hen. Zoöl The female of the moor fowl. A gallinule, esp. the European species. See Gallinule. An Australian rail (Tribonyx ventralis). Moor monkey Zoöl the black macaque of Borneo (Macacus maurus). Moor titling Zoöl the European stonechat (Pratinocola rubicola).
entry.ety: OE. mor, AS. mōr moor, morass; akin to D. moer moor, G. moor, and prob. to Goth. marei sea, E. mere. See Mere a lake

sn.def: An extensive waste covered with patches of heath, and having a poor, light soil, but sometimes marshy, and abounding in peat; a heath.
sn.q: In her girlish age she kept sheep on the moor.

sn.def: A game preserve consisting of moorland.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Moored m�rd; p. pr. & vb. n. Mooring
entry.ety: Prob. fr. D. marren to tie, fasten, or moor a ship. See Mar

sn.def: To fix or secure, as a vessel, in a particular place by casting anchor, or by fastening with cables or chains; as, the vessel was moored in the stream; they moored the boat to the wharf.
Fig.: To secure, or fix firmly.

entry.def: To cast anchor; to become fast.
entry.q: On oozy ground his galleys moor.

entry.def: A place for mooring.
A fresh-water alga (Cladophora Ægagropila) which forms a globular mass.
See Moorpan.
A female Moor; a Moorish woman.

sn.def: A reddish-brown grouse (Lagopus Scoticus) of upland moors of Great Britain; the European ptarmigan, or red grouse, also called the moorgame.
sn.syn: red grouse, moorbird, moorgame, Lagopus scoticus.

sn.def: The European heath grouse. See under Heath.

entry.def: The moorfowl.

sn.def: A black gallinule (Gallinula chloropus) that inhabits ponds and lakes.
The female of the moor fowl; the moor hen.

cs.cd: a heavy block of cast iron sometimes used as an anchor for mooring vessels.

sn.def: The act of confining a ship to a particular place, by means of anchors or fastenings.
That which serves to confine a ship to a place, as anchors, cables, bridles, etc.
The place or condition of a ship thus confined.
sn.q: And the tossed bark in moorings swings.

entry.def: Having the characteristics of a moor or heath.
entry.q: Moorishfens.

cs.cd: the style developed by the Moors in the later Middle Ages, esp. in Spain, in which the arch had the form of a horseshoe, and the ornamentation admitted no representation of animal life. It has many points of resemblance to the Arabian and Persian styles, but should be distinguished from them. See Illust. under Moresque.

entry.ety: See 1st Moor, and cf. Morris Moresque
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Morocco or the Moors; in the style of the Moors.
Land consisting of a moor or moors.
A clayey layer or pan underlying some moors, etc.
A species of English granite, used as a building stone.

A species of cassowary (Casuarius Bennetti) found in New Britain, and noted for its agility in running and leaping. It is smaller and has stouter legs than the common cassowary. Its crest is bilobed; the neck and breast are black; the back, rufous mixed with black; and the naked skin of the neck, blue.
Of or pertaining to moors; marshy; fenny; boggy; moorish.
entry.q: As when thick mists arise from moory vales.

entry.def: A kind of blue cloth made in India.

entry.cs: Moose bird Zoöl the Canada jayor whisky jack. See Whisky jack. Moose deer. Same as Moose. Moose yard Zoöl a locality where moose, in winter, herd together in a forest to feed and for mutual protection.
entry.ety: A native name; Knisteneaux mouswah; Algonquin monse. Mackenzie

sn.def: A large cervine mammal (Alces alces syn. Alces machlis, syn Alces Americanus), native of the Northern United States and Canada. The adult male is about as large as a horse, and has very large, palmate antlers. It closely resembles the European elk, and by many zoölogists is considered the same species. See Elk.
A member of the Progressive Party; a Bull Moose.
A member of the fraternal organization named Loyal Order of Moose.

entry.def: The striped maple (Acer Pennsylvanicum).
Leatherwood.
See 1st Mot.
A ring for gauging wooden pins.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mooted; p. pr. & vb. n. Mooting
entry.ety: OE. moten motien, AS. mōtan to meet or assemble for conversation, to discuss, dispute, fr. mōt gemōt, a meeting, an assembly; akin to Icel. mōt, MHG. muoz. Cf. Meet to come together

sn.def: To argue for and against; to debate; to discuss; to propose for discussion.
sn.q: A problem which hardly has been mentioned, much less mooted, in this country.

sn.def: Specifically: To discuss by way of exercise; to argue for practice; to propound and discuss in a mock court.
sn.q: First a case is appointed to be mooted by certain young men, containing some doubtful controversy.

sn.def: To render inconsequential, as having no effect on the practical outcome; to render academic; as, the ruling that the law was invalid mooted the question of whether he actually violated it.

entry.def: To argue or plead in a supposed case.
entry.q: There is a difference between mooting and pleading; between fencing and fighting.

cs.cd: a case or question to be mooted; a disputable case; an unsettled question.
a mock court, such as is held by students of law for practicing the conduct of law cases.
a point or question to be debated; a doubtful question.
to render moot{2}; to moot{3}.

entry.ety: AS. mōt gemōt, a meeting; -- usually in comp.]

sn.def: A meeting for discussion and deliberation; esp., a meeting of the people of a village or district, in Anglo-Saxon times, for the discussion and settlement of matters of common interest; -- usually in composition; as, folk-moot .
A discussion or debate; especially, a discussion of fictitious causes by way of practice.
sn.q: The pleading used in courts and chancery called moots.

sn.def: Subject, or open, to argument or discussion; undecided; debatable; mooted.
Of purely theoretical or academic interest; having no practical consequence; as, the team won in spite of the bad call, and whether the ruling was correct is a moot question.

entry.def: Capable of being mooted.
A disputer of a mooted case.
A hall for public meetings; a hall of judgment.
entry.q: Themoot-hallof Herod.

entry.def: A hill of meeting or council; an elevated place in the open air where public assemblies or courts were held by the Saxons; -- called, in Scotland, mute-hill.

entries.entry: Moot"man n.; pl.Mootmen. O. Eng. Law One who argued moot cases in the inns of court.

entry.def: A made-up face; a grimace.
entry.q: Whatmopsand mowes it makes!

entry.def: To make a wry mouth.

entry.cs: Mop head. The end of a mop, to which the thrums or rags are fastened. A clamp for holding the thrums or rags of a mop. U.S
entry.ety: CF. W. mop mopa, Ir. moipal, Gael. moibeal moibean; or OF. mappe a napkin (see Map Napkin)

sn.def: An implement for washing floors, or the like, made of a piece of cloth, or a collection of thrums, or coarse yarn, fastened to a handle.
A fair where servants are hired.
The young of any animal; also, a young girl; a moppet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mopped; p. pr. & vb. n. Mopping
entry.def: To rub or wipe with a mop, or as with a mop; as, to mop a floor; to mop one's face with a handkerchief.
A narrow board nailed against the wall of a room next to the floor; skirting board; baseboard. See Baseboard.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Moped; p. pr. & vb. n. Moping
entry.ety: Cf. D. moppen to pout, Prov. G. muffen to sulk
entry.def: To be dull and spiritless; to spend time doing little; as, to mope around the house.
entry.q: Mopingmelancholy.
A sickly part of one true sense Could not so mope.

entry.def: To make spiritless and stupid.
A dull, spiritless person.
Shortsighted; purblind.
Mopish.
having a bushy top without a leader; -- of trees; as, mop-headed cabbage palms.
Dull; spiritless; dejected.
One of a class of Mohammedans in Malabar.

sn.def: A rag baby; a puppet made of cloth; hence, also, in fondness, a little girl, or a woman.
A long-haired pet dog.
A moppet.
A slatternly, untidy woman.

entry.def: Shortsighted; mope-eyed.
The long handle of a mop.
A mope; a drone.
A kind of carpet having a short velvety pile.
A game of guessing the number of fingers extended in a quick movement of the hand, -- much played by Italians of the lower classes.
A leguminous tree of Guiana and Trinidad (Dimorphandra excelsa); also, its timber, used in shipbuilding and making furniture.
Delay; esp., culpable delay; postponement.

entry.note: ☞ If the moraine is at the extremity of the glacier it is a terminal moraine; if at the side, a lateral moraine; if parallel to the side on the central portion of the glacier, a medial moraine. See Illust. of Glacier. In the last case it is formed by the union of the lateral moraines of the branches of the glacier. A ground moraine is one beneath the mass of ice.
entry.ety: F. Cf. Prov. G. mur stones broken off, It. mora a heap of stones, hillock, G. mürbe soft, broken up, OHG. muruwi, AS. mearu tender, Gr. � to cause to wither, Skr. mlā to relax
entry.def: An accumulation of earth and stones carried forward and deposited by a glacier.
Of or pertaining to a moranie.

cs.cd: a being who is capable of acting with reference to right and wrong.

a very high degree or probability, although not demonstrable as a certainty; a probability of so high a degree that it can be confidently acted upon in the affairs of life; as, there is a moral certainty of his guilt.
insanity, so called, of the moral system; badness alleged to be irresponsible.
the science of duty; the science which treats of the nature and condition of man as a moral being, of the duties which result from his moral relations, and the reasons on which they are founded.
an allegorical play; a morality.

the power of moral judgment and feeling; the capacity to perceive what is right or wrong in moral conduct, and to approve or disapprove, independently of education or the knowledge of any positive rule or law.
theology applied to morals; practical theology; casuistry.

entry.ety: F., fr. It. moralis, fr. mos moris, manner, custom, habit, way of life, conduct

sn.def: Relating to duty or obligation; pertaining to those intentions and actions of which right and wrong, virtue and vice, are predicated, or to the rules by which such intentions and actions ought to be directed; relating to the practice, manners, or conduct of men as social beings in relation to each other, as respects right and wrong, so far as they are properly subject to rules.
sn.q: Keep at the least within the compass of moral actions, which have in them vice or virtue.
Mankind is broken loose from moral bands.
She had wandered without rule or guidance in a moral wilderness.

sn.def: Conformed to accepted rules of right; acting in conformity with such rules; virtuous; just; as, a moral man. Used sometimes in distinction from religious; as, a moral rather than a religious life.
sn.q: The wiser and more moral part of mankind.

sn.def: Capable of right and wrong action or of being governed by a sense of right; subject to the law of duty.
sn.q: A moral agent is a being capable of those actions that have a moral quality, and which can properly be denominated good or evil in a moral sense.

sn.def: Acting upon or through one's moral nature or sense of right, or suited to act in such a manner; as, a moral arguments; moral considerations. Sometimes opposed to material and physical; as, moral pressure or support.
Supported by reason or probability; practically sufficient; -- opposed to legal or demonstrable; as, a moral evidence; a moral certainty.
Serving to teach or convey a moral; as, a moral lesson; moral tales.
The doctrine or practice of the duties of life; manner of living as regards right and wrong; conduct; behavior; -- usually in the plural.
sn.q: Corrupt in their morals as vice could make them.

sn.def: The inner meaning or significance of a fable, a narrative, an occurrence, an experience, etc.; the practical lesson which anything is designed or fitted to teach; the doctrine meant to be inculcated by a fiction; a maxim.
sn.q: Thus may we gather honey from the weed, And make a moral of the devil himself.
To point a moral, or adorn a tale.
We protest against the principle that the world of pure comedy is one into which no moral enters.

sn.def: A morality play. See Morality, 5.

entry.def: To moralize.

The moral condition, or the condition in other respects, so far as it is affected by, or dependent upon, moral considerations, such as zeal, spirit, hope, and confidence; mental state, as of a body of men, an army, and the like.
A moralizer.
A maxim or saying embodying a moral truth.
moralize.

sn.def: One who moralizes; one who teaches or animadverts upon the duties of life; a writer of essays intended to correct vice and inculcate moral duties.

One who practices moral duties; a person who lives in conformity with moral rules; one of correct deportment and dealings with his fellow-creatures; -- sometimes used in contradistinction to one whose life is controlled by religious motives.
sn.q: The love (in the moralist of virtue, but in the Christian) of God himself.

sn.def: narrowly and conventionally moral; -- of people.
disposed to moralize{2}; -- of people.

entries.entry:
Mo*ral"i*ty n.; pl.Moralities #. L. moralitas: cf. F. moralité
The relation of conformity or nonconformity to the moral standard or rule; quality of an intention, a character, an action, a principle, or a sentiment, when tried by the standard of right. The morality of an action is founded in the freedom of that principle, by virtue of which it is in the agent's power, having all things ready and requisite to the performance of an action, either to perform or not perform it.
The quality of an action which renders it good; the conformity of an act to the accepted standard of right. Of moralitee he was the flower. I am bold to think that morality is capable of demonstration.
The doctrines or rules of moral duties, or the duties of men in their social character; ethics. The end of morality is to procure the affections to obey reason, and not to invade it. The system of morality to be gathered out of . . . ancient sages falls very short of that delivered in the gospel.
The practice of the moral duties; rectitude of life; conformity to the standard of right; virtue; as, we often admire the politeness of men whose morality we question.
A kind of allegorical play, so termed because it consisted of discourses in praise of morality between actors representing such characters as Charity, Faith, Death, Vice, etc. Such plays were occasionally exhibited as late as the reign of Henry VIII.
Intent; meaning; moral. Obs Taketh the morality thereof, good men.

sn.def: The act of moralizing; moral reflections or discourse.
Explanation in a moral sense.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Moralized mŏr"�l*īzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Moralizing mŏr"�l*ī*zĭng

sn.def: To apply to a moral purpose; to explain in a moral sense; to draw a moral from.
sn.q: This fable is moralized in a common proverb.
Did he not moralize this spectacle?

sn.def: To furnish with moral lessons, teachings, or examples; to lend a moral to.
sn.q: While chastening thoughts of sweetest use, bestowed By Wisdom, moralize his pensive road.

sn.def: To render moral; to correct the morals of.
sn.q: It had a large share in moralizing the poor white people of the country.

sn.def: To give a moral quality to; to affect the moral quality of, either for better or worse.
sn.q: Good and bad stars moralize not our actions.

sn.def: To make moral reflections; to regard acts and events as involving a moral.
to lecture to a person in a manner asserting moral principles.

entry.def: One who moralizes.

sn.def: In a moral or ethical sense; according to the rules of morality.
sn.q: By good, good morally so called, “bonum honestum” ought chiefly to be understood.

sn.def: According to moral rules; virtuously.
sn.q: To livemorally.

sn.def: In moral qualities; in disposition and character; as, one who physically and morally endures hardships.
In a manner calculated to serve as the basis of action; according to the usual course of things and human judgment; according to reason and probability.
sn.q: It is morally impossible for an hypocrite to keep himself long upon his guard.

entry.def: motivation based on ideas of right and wrong.

entry.cs: Morass ore. Min See Bog ore, under Bog.
entry.ety: OE. marras mareisperh. through D. moeras), fr. F. marais, prob. from L. mare sea, in LL., any body of water; but perh. influenced by some German word. See Mere a lake, and cf. Marsh
entry.def: A tract of soft, wet ground; a marsh; a fen.
Marshy; fenny.
A salt of moric acid.
A delaying tarrying; delay.

sn.def: A period during which an obligor has a legal right to delay meeting an obligation, esp. such a period granted, as to a bank, by a moratory law.
a suspension of an activity.
an officially authorized period of delay or waiting; as, a moratorium on putting a law into effect.

entry.ety: L. moratorius delaying, fr. morari to delay
entry.def: Of or pertaining to delay; esp., designating a law passed, as in a time of financial panic, to postpone or delay for a period the time at which notes, bills of exchange, and other obligations, shall mature or become due.
Of or pertaining to Moravia, or to the United Brethren. See Moravian n.

One of a religious sect called the United Brethrenan offshoot of the Hussites in Bohemia), which formed a separate church of Moravia, a northern district of Austria, about the middle of the 15th century. After being nearly extirpated by persecution, the society, under the name of The Renewed Church of the United Brethren, was reëstablished in 1722-35 on the estates of Count Zinzendorf in Saxony. Called also Herrnhuter.
The religious system of the Moravians.
A muræna.

entry.usage: Morbid Diseased. Morbid is sometimes used interchangeably with diseased, but is commonly applied, in a somewhat technical sense, to cases of a prolonged nature; as, a morbid condition of the nervous system; a morbid sensibility, etc.
entry.ety: L. morbidus, fr. morbus disease; prob. akin to mori to die: cf. F. morbide, It. morbido. See Mortal

sn.def: Not sound and healthful; induced by a diseased or abnormal condition; diseased; sickly; as, a morbid condition; a morbid constitution; a morbid state of the juices of a plant.
sn.q: Her sick andmorbidheart.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to disease or diseased parts; as, morbid anatomy.

Indicating an unhealthy mental attitude or disposition; especially, abnormally gloomy, to an extent not justified by the situation; preoccupied with death, disease, or fear of death; as, a morbid interest in details of a disaster.
Gruesome; as, a morbid topic.
Delicacy or softness in the representation of flesh.
A term used as a direction in execution, signifying, with extreme delicacy.
The quality or state of being morbid.
Morbid quality; disease; sickness.
Amount of disease; rate of sickness.

entry.def: In a morbid manner.
The quality or state of being morbid; morbidity.

entry.ety: L. morbus disease + -ficarein comp.) to make: cf. F. morbifique. See -fy
entry.def: Causing disease; generating a sickly state; as, a morbific matter.

entry.ety: LL. morbilli measles, dim. of L. morbus disease: cf. F. morbilleux
entry.def: Pertaining to the measles; partaking of the nature of measels, or resembling the eruptions of that disease; measly.
Proceeding from disease; morbid; unhealthy.
entry.q: Morbose tumors and excrescences of plants.

entry.def: A diseased state; unhealthiness.
A bit; a morsel.

entry.ety: L. mordax -acis, fr. mordere morsum, to bite. See Morsel
entry.def: Biting; given to biting; hence, figuratively, sarcastic; severe; scathing.

entry.ety: L. mordacitas: cf. F. mordacité. See Mordacious
entry.def: The quality of being mordacious; biting severity, or sarcastic quality.

entry.ety: F., p. pr. of mordere to bite; L. mordere. See Morsel

sn.def: Biting; caustic; sarcastic; keen; severe.
Serving to fix colors.
Any corroding substance used in etching.
Any substance, as alum or copperas, which, having a twofold attraction for organic fibers and coloring matter, serves as a bond of union, and thus gives fixity to, or bites in, the dyes.
Any sticky matter by which the gold leaf is made to adhere.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mordanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Mordanting
entry.def: To subject to the action of, or imbue with, a mordant; as, to mordant goods for dyeing.
In the manner of a mordant.
An embellishment resembling a trill.
A biting quality; corrosiveness.

entry.ety: L. mordicans, p. pr. of mordicare to bite, fr. mordere: cf. F. mordicant
entry.def: Biting; acrid; as, the mordicant quality of a body.
The act of biting or corroding; corrosion.
Biting; corrosive.

entry.ety: AS. mōr. See Moor a waste
entry.def: A hill.

entry.ety: AS. more moru; akin to G. möhre carrot, OHG. moraha morha
entry.def: A root.

entry.note: ☞ More, in this sense, was formerly used in connection with some other qualifying word,a the this their, etc., -- which now requires the substitution of greater further, or the like, for more.
entry.ety: OE. more mare, and (orig. neut. and advmo ma, AS. māra, and (as neut. and advmā; akin to D. meer, OS. mēr, G. mehr, OHG. mēro mēr, Icel. meiri meirr, Dan. meere meer, Sw. mera mer, Goth. maiza, a., mais, adv., and perh. to L. major greater, compar. of magnus great, and magis, adv., more. √103. Cf. Most uch Major

sn.def: Greater; superior; increased;

sd.def: Greater in quality, amount, degree, quality, and the like; with the singular.
sd.q: If we procure not to ourselves more woe.
Whilst sisters nine, which dwell on Parnasse height, Do make them music for their more delight.
The more part knew not wherefore they were come together.
Wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.

sd.def: Greater in number; exceeding in numbers; -- with the plural.
sd.q: The people of the children of Israel are more and mightier than we.

sn.def: Additional; other; as, he wept because there were no more worlds to conquer.
sn.q: With open arms received one poet more.

entry.cs: Any more. Anything or something additional or further; as, I do not need any more . Adverbially: Further; beyond a certain time; as, do not think any more about it. No more not anything more; nothing in addition. The more and less the high and low. Obs Shak. “All cried, both less and more.” Chaucer.

sn.def: A greater quantity, amount, or number; that which exceeds or surpasses in any way what it is compared with.
sn.q: And the children of Israel did so, and gathered, some more, some less.

sn.def: That which is in addition; something other and further; an additional or greater amount.
sn.q: They that would have more and more can never have enough.
O! That pang where more than madness lies.

entry.note: ☞ Double comparatives were common among writers of the Elizabeth period, and for some time later; as, more brighter; more dearer.The duke of Milan And his more braver daughter. Shak.
entry.cs: More and more with continual increase. “Amon trespassed more and more.” 2 Chron. xxxiii. 23. The more to a greater degree; by an added quantity; for a reason already specified. The more -- the more by how much more -- by so much more. “The more he praised it in himself, the more he seems to suspect that in very deed it was not in him.” Milton. To be no more to have ceased to be; as, Cassius is no more; Troy is no more . Those oracles which set the world in flames, Nor ceased to burn till kingdoms were no more. Byron.

sn.def: In a greater quantity; in or to a greater extent or degree.

sd.def: With a verb or participle.
sd.q: Admiring more The riches of Heaven's pavement.

sd.def: With an adjective or adverb (instead of the suffix -er) to form the comparative degree; as, more durable; more active; more sweetly.
sd.q: Happy here, and more happy hereafter.

sn.def: In addition; further; besides; again.
sn.q: Yet once more, O ye laurels, and once more, Ye myrtles brown, with ivy never sere, I come to pluck your berries harsh and crude.

entry.def: To make more; to increase.
A thick woolen fabric, watered or with embossed figures; -- used in upholstery, for curtains, etc.
An edible fungus (Morchella esculenta), the upper part of which is covered with a reticulated and pitted hymenium. It is used as food, and for flavoring sauces.

cs.cd: the deadly nightshade.
the black nightshade. See Nightshade.

sn.def: Nightshade; -- so called from its blackish purple berries.
A kind of cherry. See Morello.

entry.def: Moorland.

entry.ety: F., orig. fem. of moreau black, OF. morel, fr. LL. morellus. Cf. Morello Murrey
entry.def: Nightshade. See 2d Morel.

entry.ety: Cf. It. morello blackish, OF. morel. Cf. Morelle
entry.def: A kind of nearly black cherry with dark red flesh and juice, -- used chiefly for preserving.
Dying; a gradual decrescendo at the end of a strain or cadence.
Greatness.

entry.usage: Of the two words, moreover is the stronger and is properly used in solemn discourse, or when what is added is important to be considered. See Besides.
entry.def: Beyond what has been said; further; besides; in addition; furthermore; also; likewise.
entry.q: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks.

entry.def: The Australian crested goatsucker (Ægotheles Novæ-Hollandiæ). Also applied to other allied birds, as Podargus Cuveiri.

entries.entry: ‖Mo"res mō"rēz n. pl.; sing.Mos mōs . L Customs; habits; esp., moral customs conformity to which is more or less obligatory; customary law. singular is rarely used

entry.def: Moresque.

entry.ety: F., fr. It. moresco, or Sp. morisco. See Morris
entry.def: Of or pertaining to, or in the manner or style of, the Moors; Moorish.

def2.def: The Moresque style of architecture or decoration. See Moorish architecture, under Moorish.

entry.def: One of a celebrated breed of small compact American saddle and trotting horses; -- so called from the name of the stud (Justin Morgan) from which the breed originated in Vermont.
John Pierpont Morgan, a noted American financier and philanthropist; 1837-1913.
