entry.q: You can't go mountaineering in a flat country.

entry.def: Climbing mountains as a sport.
A mountaineer.
A small mountain.

sn.def: Full of, or containing, mountains; as, the mountainous country of the Swiss.
Inhabiting mountains.
Large as, or resembling, a mountain; huge; of great bulk; as, a mountainous heap.

entry.def: The state or quality of being mountainous.
Amount; sum; quantity; extent.

entries.entry: Moun"tain spec"ter. An optical phenomenon sometimes seen on the summit of mountains (as on the Brocken) when the observer is between the sun and a mass of cloud. The figures of the observer and surrounding objects are seen projected on the cloud, greatly enlarged and often encircled by rainbow colors.
Moun"tain State. Montana; -- a nickname.

entry.ety: F. montant, p. pr. of monter. See Mount, and cf. Montant
entry.def: Raised; high.

entry.ety: It. montimbanco montambanco; montare to mount + in in, upon + banco bench. See Mount, and 4th Bank

sn.def: One who mounts a bench or stage in the market or other public place, boasts of his skill in curing diseases, and vends medicines which he pretends are infallible remedies; a quack doctor.
sn.q: Such is the weakness and easy credulity of men, that a mountebank . . . is preferred before an able physician.

sn.def: Any boastful or false pretender; a charlatan; a quack.
sn.q: Nothing so impossible in nature but mountebanks will undertake.

entry.def: To cheat by boasting and false pretenses; to gull.
To play the mountebank.
The practices of a mountebank; quackery; boastful and vain pretenses.
Like a mountebank or his quackery.
The practices of a mountebank; mountebankery.

sn.def: Seated or serving on horseback or similarly; as, mounted police; mounted infantry.
Placed on a suitable support, or fixed in a setting; as, a mounted gun; a mounted map; a mounted gem.

entry.def: Mountance.

sn.def: One who mounts.
An animal mounted; a monture.
The act of one that mounts.
That by which anything is prepared for use, or set off to advantage; equipment; embellishment; setting; as, the mounting of a sword or diamond.
same as Carriage.

entry.def: In an ascending manner.
A small or low mountain.

entry.ety: F. montée, fr. monter. See Mount v.
entry.def: The rise of a hawk after prey.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mourned mōrnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Mourning
entry.ety: AS. murnan; akin to OS. mornian, OHG. mornen, Goth. maúrnan

sn.def: To express or to feel grief or sorrow; to grieve; to be sorrowful; to lament; to be in a state of grief or sadness.
sn.q: Abraham came to mourn for Sarah, and to weep for her.

sn.def: To wear the customary garb of a mourner.
sn.q: We mourn in black; why mourn we not in blood?
Grieve for an hour, perhaps, then mourn a year.

sn.def: To grieve for; to lament; to deplore; to bemoan; to bewail.
sn.q: As if he mourned his rival's ill success.
And looking over the hills, I mourn The darling who shall not return.

sn.def: To utter in a mournful manner or voice.
sn.q: The lovelorn nightingale Nightly to thee her sad song mourneth well.

entry.def: The armed or feruled end of a staff; in a sheephook, the end of the staff to which the hook is attached.

sn.def: One who mourns or is grieved at any misfortune, as the death of a friend.
sn.q: His mourners were two hosts, his friends and foes.

sn.def: One who attends a funeral as a hired mourner.
sn.q: Mourners were provided to attend the funeral.

entry.def: Full of sorrow; expressing, or intended to express, sorrow; mourning; grieving; sad; also, causing sorrow; saddening; grievous; as, a mournful person; mournful looks, tones, loss.
entry.syn: Sorrowful; lugubrious; sad; doleful; heavy; afflictive; grievous; calamitous.

entry.cs: Deep mourning. See under Deep.

sn.def: The act of sorrowing or expressing grief; lamentation; sorrow.
Garb, drapery, or emblems indicative of grief, esp. clothing or a badge of somber black.
sn.q: The houses to their tops with black were spread, And ev'n the pavements were with mourning hid.

cs.cd: a garden flower (Scabiosa atropurpurea) with dark purple or crimson flowers in flattened heads.
a wild dove (Zenaidura macroura) found throughout the United States; -- so named from its plaintive note. Called also Carolina dove. See Illust. under Dove.
an American ground warbler (Geothlypis Philadelphia). The male has the head, neck, and chest, deep ash-gray, mixed with black on the throat and chest; other lower parts are pure yellow.

sn.def: Grieving; sorrowing; lamenting.
Employed to express sorrow or grief; worn or used as appropriate to the condition of one bereaved or sorrowing; as, mourning garments; a mourning ring; a mourning pin, and the like.

entry.def: In a mourning manner.
See Murnival.

entries.entry:
Mouse
Field mouse Flying mouse , etc. See under Field Flying, etc. Mouse bird Zoöl a coly. Mouse deer Zoöl a chevrotain, as the kanchil. Mouse galago Zoöl a very small West American galago (Galago murinus). In color and size it resembles a mouse. It has a bushy tail like that of a squirrel. Mouse hawk. Zoöl A hawk that devours mice. The hawk owl; -- called also mouse owl. Mouse lemur Zoöl any one of several species of very small lemurs of the genus Chirogaleus, found in Madagascar. Mouse piece Cookery the piece of beef cut from the part next below the round or from the lower part of the latter; -- called also mouse buttock.
mous n.; pl.Mice mīs. OE. mous mus, AS. mūs, pl. mȳs; akin to D. muis, G. maus, OHG. & Icel. mūs, Dan. muus, Sw. mus, Russ. muishe, L. mus, Gr. my^s, Skr. mūsh mouse, mush to steal. √277. Cf. Muscle Musk
Zoöl Any one of numerous species of small rodents belonging to the genus Mus and various related genera of the family Muridæ. The common house mouse (Mus musculus) is found in nearly all countries. The American white-footed mouse, or deer mouse Peromyscus leucopus, formerly Hesperomys leucopus) sometimes lives in houses. See Dormouse Meadow mouse, under Meadow, and Harvest mouse, under Harvest.
Naut
A knob made on a rope with spun yarn or parceling to prevent a running eye from slipping.
Same as 2d Mousing, 2.
A familiar term of endearment.
A dark-colored swelling caused by a blow. Slang
A match used in firing guns or blasting.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Moused; p. pr. & vb. n. Mousing

sn.def: To watch for and catch mice.
To watch for or pursue anything in a sly manner; to pry about, on the lookout for something.
To tear, as a cat devours a mouse.
sn.q: Deathmousingthe flesh of men.

sn.def: To furnish with a mouse; to secure by means of a mousing. See Mouse n., 2.

cs.cd: a name of two common species of chickweed (Cerastium vulgarium, and Cerastium viscosum).
a low cruciferous herb (Sisymbrium Thaliana). All these are low herbs with soft, oval, or obovate leaves, whence the name.

entry.def: The forget-me-not (Myosotis palustris) and other species of the same genus.
A European species of hawkweed (Hieracium Pilosella).
See Frogfish.
A hole made by a mouse, for passage or abode, as in a wall; hence, a very small hole like that gnawed by a mouse.
A little mouse.
One of a group of children appearing on the television program The Mickey Mouse Club in the 1950's.

sn.def: A cat that catches mice; as, a good mouser is better than a dozen mousetraps.
One who pries about on the lookout for something.

entry.def: A genus of ranunculaceous plants (Myosurus), in which the prolonged receptacle is covered with imbricating achenes, and so resembles the tail of a mouse.

Any device that catches, and usually kills, mice. They are of various designs, the most common being a stiff loop of wire mounted on a small wooden platform base and attached to a strong spring, which holds the loop firmly against the base. To activate the trap, the loop is pulled through a 180° arc against the tension of the spring and held against the base by a delicate metal catch, which can keep the loop from moving, though in a state of high tension. The metal catch is moved when a mouse tries to take a piece of bait attached to it, releasing the loop which forcefully moves though an arc, usually killing the mouse. A larger version of the same device is used as a rat trap.
Diminutive for Mouse.
Impertinently inquisitive; prying; meddlesome.
entry.q: Mousingsaints.

cs.cd: a hook with an attachment which prevents its unhooking.

sn.def: The act of hunting mice.
A turn or lashing of spun yarn or small stuff, or a metallic clasp or fastening, uniting the point and shank of a hook to prevent its unhooking or straighening out.
A ratchet movement in a loom.

entry.def: To sport with roughly; to rumple.

sn.def: A musketeer, esp. one of the French royal musketeers of the 17th and 18th centuries, conspicuous both for their daring and their fine dress.
A mosquetaire cuff or glove, or other article of dress fancied to resemble those worn by the French mosquetaires.

entries.entry: Mousquetaire cuff. A deep flaring cuff.
Mousquetaire glove. A woman's glove with a long, loosely fitting wrist.

sn.def: A frozen dessert of a frothy texture, made of sweetened and flavored whipped cream, sometimes with the addition of egg yolks and gelatin. Mousse differs from ice cream in being beaten before -- not during -- the freezing process.
Any of a variety of foods whipped to a light texture; as, a salmon mousse .
A foam containing special chemicals, used for styling hair.

entry.cs: ‖Mousseline de laine. F., muslin of wool Muslin delaine. See under Muslin. Mousseline glass a kind of thin blown glassware, such as wineglasses, etc.
entry.def: Muslin.

entries.entry: ‖Mousse`line de soie". F A soft thin silk fabric with a weave like that of muslin.

entry.def: Mustache.
A large bushy moustache.
Infested with mice; smelling of mice.
The Chinese tree peony (Pæonia Mountan), a shrub with large flowers of various colors.

entries.entry:
Mouth
Down at the mouthorDown in the mouth
chapfallen; of dejected countenance; depressed; discouraged. Obs. or Colloq Mouth friend one who professes friendship insincerely. Shak. Mouth glass a small mirror for inspecting the mouth or teeth. Mouth honor honor given in words, but not felt. Shak. Mouth organ. Mus Pan's pipes. See Pandean. An harmonicon. Mouth pipe an organ pipe with a lip or plate to cut the escaping air and make a sound. To stop the mouth to silence or be silent; to put to shame; to confound. To put one's foot in one's mouth to say something which causes one embarrassment. To run off at the mouth to speak excessively. To talk out of both sides of one's mouth to say things which are contradictory.
mouth n.; pl.Mouths mou�z. OE. mouth muþ, AS. mūð; akin to D. mond, OS. mūð, G. mund, Icel. muðr munnr, Sw. mun, Dan. mund, Goth. munþs, and possibly L. mentum chin; or cf. D. muil mouth, muzzle, G. maul, OHG. mūla, Icel. mūli, and Skr. mukha mouth
The opening through which an animal receives food; the aperture between the jaws or between the lips; also, the cavity, containing the tongue and teeth, between the lips and the pharynx; the buccal cavity.
Hence: An opening affording entrance or exit; orifice; aperture; as: The opening of a vessel by which it is filled or emptied, charged or discharged; as, the mouth of a jar or pitcher; the mouth of the lacteal vessels, etc.
The opening or entrance of any cavity, as a cave, pit, well, or den.
The opening of a piece of ordnance, through which it is discharged.
The opening through which the waters of a river or any stream are discharged.
The entrance into a harbor.
Saddlery The crosspiece of a bridle bit, which enters the mouth of an animal.
A principal speaker; one who utters the common opinion; a mouthpiece. Every coffeehouse has some particular statesman belonging to it, who is the mouth of the street where he lives.
Cry; voice. Obs
Speech; language; testimony. That in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word may be established.
A wry face; a grimace; a mow. Counterfeit sad looks, Make mouths upon me when I turn my back.
The mouth of them that speak lies shall be stopped. Whose mouths must be stopped.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mouthed mou�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Mouthing

sn.def: To take into the mouth; to seize or grind with the mouth or teeth; to chew; to devour.
To utter with a voice affectedly big or swelling; to speak in a strained or unnaturally sonorous manner; as, mouthing platitudes.
sn.q: Mouthingbig phrases.
Mouthing out his hollow oes and aes.

sn.def: To form or cleanse with the mouth; to lick, as a bear her cub.
To make mouths at.
To speak with a full, round, or loud, affected voice; to vociferate; to rant.
sn.q: I'll bellow out for Rome, and for my country, And mouth at Cæsar, till I shake the senate.

sn.def: To put mouth to mouth; to kiss.
To make grimaces, esp. in ridicule or contempt.
sn.q: Well I know, when I am gone, How she mouths behind my back.

sn.def: Furnished with a mouth.
Having a mouth of a particular kind; using the mouth, speech, or voice in a particular way; -- used only in composition; as, wide-mouthed; hard-mouthed; foul-mouthed; mealy-mouthed.

entry.def: One who mouths; an affected speaker.
Having the basal joints of the legs converted into jaws.

entries.entry:
Mouth"ful n.; pl.Mouthfuls.
As much as is usually put into the mouth at one time.
Hence, a small quantity.
A statement that has a profound truth in it; as, you said a mouthful!
informal

entry.def: Destitute of a mouth.
Spoken without sincerity; not heartfelt.
entry.q: Mouth-madevows.

entry.note: This is a term that was used sometimes in old movies. When a tough bad guy was arrested he might say “I ain't sayin' nothin' without my mouthpiece!”

sn.def: The part of a musical or other instrument to which the mouth is applied in using it; as, the mouthpiece of a bugle, or of a tobacco pipe.
An appendage to an inlet or outlet opening of a pipe or vessel, to direct or facilitate the inflow or outflow of a fluid.
One who delivers the opinion of others or of another; a spokesman; as, the mouthpiece of his party.
sn.q: Egmont was imprudent enough to make himself the mouthpiece of their remonstrance.

sn.def: A person's lawyer.

entry.def: a medicated solution used for gargling and rinsing the mouth.
meat from a mature sheep.
Movableness.

cs.cd: a letter that is pronounced, as opposed to one that is quiescent.
a holy day that changes date, depending on the lunar cycle. An example of such a day is Easter.

sn.def: Capable of being moved, lifted, carried, drawn, turned, or conveyed, or in any way made to change place or posture; susceptible of motion; not fixed or stationary; as, a movable steam engine.
Changing from one time to another; as, movable feasts, i. e., church festivals, the date of which varies from year to year.

entries.entry:
Mov"a*ble ☞ The word is not convertible with personal property, since rents and similar incidents of the soil which are personal property by our law are immovables by the Roman law. n.; pl.Movables.
An article of wares or goods; a commodity; a piece of property not fixed, or not a part of real estate; generally, in the plural, goods; wares; furniture.
moveable
Furnished with the most rich and princely movables.
Rom. Law Property not attached to the soil.

entry.def: The quality or state of being movable; mobility; susceptibility of motion.
In a movable manner or condition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Moved m�vd; p. pr. & vb. n. Moving
entry.ety: OE. moven, OF. moveir, F. mouvoir, L. movere; cf. Gr. 'amei`bein to change, exchange, go in or out, quit, Skr. mīv, p. p. mūta, to move, push. Cf. Emotion Mew to molt, Mob Mutable Mutiny

sn.def: To cause to change place or posture in any manner; to set in motion; to carry, convey, draw, or push from one place to another; to impel; to stir; as, the wind moves a vessel; the horse moves a carriage.
To transfer (a piece or man) from one space or position to another on a playing board, according to the rules of the game; as, to move a king.
To excite to action by the presentation of motives; to rouse by representation, persuasion, or appeal; to influence.
sn.q: Minds desirous of revenge were not moved with gold.
No female arts his mind could move.

sn.def: To arouse the feelings or passions of; especially, to excite to tenderness or compassion; to touch pathetically; to excite, as an emotion.
sn.q: When he saw the multitudes, he was moved with compassion on them.
The use of images] in orations and poetry is to move pity or terror.

sn.def: To propose; to recommend; specifically, to propose formally for consideration and determination, in a deliberative assembly; to submit, as a resolution to be adopted; as, to move to adjourn.
sn.q: Let me but move one question to your daughter.
They are to be blamed alike who move and who decline war upon particular respects.

sn.def: To apply to, as for aid.
sn.syn: To stir; agitate; trouble; affect; persuade; influence; actuate; impel; rouse; prompt; instigate; incite; induce; incline; propose; offer.

sn.def: To change place or posture; to stir; to go, in any manner, from one place or position to another; as, a ship moves rapidly.
sn.q: The foundations also of the hills moved and were shaken, because he was wroth.
On the green bank I sat and listened long, . . . Nor till her lay was ended could I move.

sn.def: To act; to take action; to stir; to begin to act; as, to move in a matter.
To change residence; to remove, as from one house, town, or state, to another.
To change the place of a piece in accordance with the rules of the game.

entry.cs: To make a move. To take some action toward a goal, usually one involving interaction with other people. To move a piece, as in a game. To be on the move to bustle or stir about. Colloq

sn.def: The act of moving; a movement.

The act of moving one of the pieces, from one position to another, in the progress of the game; also, the opportunity or obligation to so move a piece; one's turn; as, you can only borrow from the bank in Monopoly when it's your move .
An act for the attainment of an object; a step in the execution of a plan or purpose.

entry.def: movable.
affected emotionally. Opposite of unmoved.
Motionless; fixed.
entry.q: Movelessas a tower.

entry.cs: Febrile movement Med an elevation of the body temperature; a fever. Movement cure. Med See Kinesiatrics. Movement of the bowels an evacuation or stool; a passage or discharge.
entry.usage: Movement Motion. Motion expresses a general idea of not being at rest; movement is oftener used to express a definite, regulated motion, esp. a progress.
entry.ety: F. mouvement. See Move, and cf. Moment

sn.def: The act of moving in space; change of place or posture; motion; as, the movement of an army in marching or maneuvering; the movement of a wheel or a machine.
Manner or style of moving; as, a slow, or quick, or sudden, movement .

Transference, by any means, from one situation to another; a change of situation; progress toward a goal; advancement; as, after months of fruitless discussion there was finally some movement toward an agreement.
Motion of the mind or feelings; emotion.

sd.def: The rhythmical progression, pace, and tempo of a piece.
sd.q: Any change of time is a change ofmovement.

sd.def: One of the several strains or pieces, each complete in itself, with its own time and rhythm, which make up a larger work; as, the several movements of a suite or a symphony.

sn.def: A system of mechanism for transmitting motion of a definite character, or for transforming motion; as, the wheelwork of a watch; as, a seventeen jewel movement .
A more or less organized effort by many people to achieve some goal, especially a social or artistic goal; as, the women's liberation movement; the progressive movement in architecture.

entry.ety: L. movens, p. pr. of movere. See Move
entry.def: Moving.
That which moves anything.

sn.def: A person or thing that moves, stirs, or changes place.
A person or thing that imparts motion, or causes change of place; a motor.
One who, or that which, excites, instigates, or causes movement, change, etc.; as, movers of sedition.
sn.q: These most poisonous compounds, Which are the movers of a languishing death.

sn.def: A proposer; one who offers a proposition, or recommends anything for consideration or adoption; as, the mover of a resolution in a legislative body.
A motion picture.
sn.syn: film, picture, moving picture, motion picture, picture show, flick.

sn.def: A motion picture show; the event of showing a motion picture. In the pl., the event of showing a motion picture at a movie theater; as, to go to the movies; to spend an evening at the movies .
The motion picture industry or medium, generally.

cs.cd: a force that accelerates, retards, or deflects the motion of a body.
a leguminous plant (Desmodium gyrans); -- so called because its leaflets have a distinct automatic motion.

sn.def: Changing place or posture; causing motion or action; as, a moving car, or power.
Exciting movement of the mind or feelings; adapted to move the sympathies, passions, or affections; touching; pathetic; as, a moving appeal.
sn.q: I sang an old moving story.

cs.cd: a day when one moves; esp., a day when a large number of tenants change their dwelling place.

entry.def: The act of changing place or posture; esp., the act of changing one's dwelling place or place of business.
In a moving manner.
The power of moving.

entries.entry: Moving picture. same as motion picture.

entry.ety: F. moue pouting, a wry face; cf. OD. mouwe the protruded lip
entry.def: A wry face.
entry.q: Makemowsat him.

entry.def: To make mouths.
entry.q: Nodding, becking, and mowing.

entry.def: Same as Mew, a gull.
May; can.
entry.q: Thoumownow escapen.
Our walles mowe not make hem resistence.

entry.vmorph: imp. Mowed mōd; p. p. Mowed or Mown mōn; p. pr. & vb. n. Mowing
entry.ety: OE. mowen mawen, AS. māwan; akin to D. maaijen, G. mähen, OHG. mājan, Dan. meie, L. metere to reap, mow, Gr. 'ama^n. Cf. Math Mead a meadow, Meadow

sn.def: To cut down, as grass, with a scythe or machine.
To cut the grass from; as, to mow a meadow.
To cut down; to cause to fall in rows or masses, as in mowing grass; -- with down; as, a discharge of grapeshot mows down whole ranks of men.

entry.def: To cut grass, etc., with a scythe, or with a machine; to cut grass for hay.

sn.def: A heap or mass of hay or of sheaves of grain stowed in a barn.
The place in a barn where hay or grain in the sheaf is stowed.

entry.def: To lay, as hay or sheaves of grain, in a heap or mass in a barn; to pile and stow away.
To heat and ferment in the mow, as hay when housed too green.
See 4th Mow.
See 1st & 2d Mow.
One who, or that which, mows; a mowing machine; as, a lawn mower .

cs.cd: an agricultural machine armed with knives or blades for cutting standing grass, etc. It may be drawn by a horse or horses, or propelled by a powered engine.

sn.def: The act of one who, or the operation of that which, mows.
Land from which grass is cut; meadow land.

entry.def: Cut down by mowing, as grass; deprived of grass by mowing; as, a mown field.
A mower.

entry.ety: A corruption of Japan. mogusapronounced mongsa), an escharotic made from the plant yomigi: cf. F. moxa

sn.def: A soft woolly mass prepared from the young leaves of Artemisia Chinensis, and used as a cautery by burning it on the skin; hence, any substance used in a like manner, as cotton impregnated with niter, amadou.
A plant from which this substance is obtained, esp. Artemisia Chinensis, and Artemisia moxa.

entry.ety: fr. Moxie, a trade name for a beverage

sn.def: energy; pep.
courage, determination.
Know-how, expertise.

entry.def: Mud poured out from volcanoes during eruptions; -- so called in South America.
See Moil, and Moile.

entries.entry: Moz"a*rab Moz`a*rab"ic . Same as Muzarab Muzarabic.

entry.ety: It. mozzetta: cf. F. mosette. Cf. Amice a hood or cape
entry.def: A cape, with a small hood; -- worn by the pope and other dignitaries of the Roman Catholic Church.

entries.entry: Mr.. . The customary abbreviation of Mister in writing and printing. See Master, 4.
Mrs.. The customary abbreviation of Mistress or Missess when used as a title of courtesy, in writing and printing; as, Mrs. Clinton is commonly called by her full name, Hillary Rodham Clinton .

entry.def: Amall shrubby African tree (Brachystegia speciformis) having compound leaves and racemes of small fragrant green flowers.
See mutual savings bank.
See monosodium glutamate.
Mountain Standard Time, the time of the 105th meridian, used in the mountain states of the U.S.
A metric ton, a unit of weight equivalent to 1000 kilograms.
The 12th letter of the Greek alphabet (μ, Μ).
Same as muezzin.
Same as muezzin.
The acid amide of mucic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance.
A salt of mucic acid.
See Muse, and Muset.
A yellowish white, amorphous, nitrogenous substance found in wheat, rye, etc., and resembling gluten; -- formerly called also mucin.

entry.amorph: Compar. & superl. wanting, but supplied by More mōr, and Most mōst, from another root
entry.ety: OE. moche muche miche, prob. the same as mochel muchel michel mikel, fr. AS. micel mycel; cf. Gr. me`gas, fem. mega`lh, great, and Icel. mjök, adv., much. √103. See Mickle

sn.def: Great in quantity; long in duration; as, much rain has fallen; much time.
sn.q: Thou shalt carry much seed out into the field, and shalt gather but little in.

sn.def: Many in number.
sn.q: Edom came out against him with much people.

sn.def: High in rank or position.

entry.note: ☞ Muchin this sense can be regarded as an adjective qualifying a word unexpressed, and may, therefore, be modified by as so too very.

cs.cd: to treat as something of especial value or worth.

sn.def: A great quantity; a great deal; also, an indefinite quantity; as, you have as much as I.
sn.q: He that gathered much had nothing over.

sn.def: A thing uncommon, wonderful, or noticeable; something considerable.
sn.q: And [he] thought not much to clothe his enemies.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. mjök. See Much a.
entry.def: To a great degree or extent; greatly; abundantly; far; nearly.
entry.q: Muchsuffering heroes.
Thou art much mightier than we.
Excellent speech becometh not a fool, much less do lying lips a prince.
Henceforth I fly not death, nor would prolong Life much.
All left the world much as they found it.

entry.def: Much.

entry.cs: Much of a muchness much the same. Colloq “Men's men; gentle or simple, they're much of a muchness.” G. Eliot.
entry.def: Greatness; extent.
entry.q: The quantity and muchness of time which it filcheth.

entry.def: Nearly; almost; much.
entry.q: Muchwhatafter the same manner.

entry.ety: L. mucus mucus: cf. F. mucique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, gums and micilaginous substances; specif., denoting an acid obtained by the oxidation of gums, dulcite, etc., as a white crystalline substance isomeric with saccharic acid.

entry.ety: L. mucidus, fr. L. mucus mucus. See Mucus, and cf. Moist
entry.def: Musty; moldy; slimy; mucous.

entry.ety: Mucus + L. -ficarein comp.) to make. See -fy

sn.def: Inducing or stimulating the secretion of mucus; blennogenous.
Secreting mucus.

entry.def: Resembling mucus; having the character or appearance of mucus.
A substance which is formed in mucous epithelial cells, and gives rise to mucin.
Connected with the formation of mucin; resembling mucin.
entry.q: The mucigenous basis is manufactured at the expense of the ordinary protoplasm of the cell.

entry.ety: F., from L. mucilago a musty juice, fr. mucus mucus, slime. See Mucus

sn.def: A gummy or gelatinous substance produced in certain plants by the action of water on the cell wall, as in the seeds of quinces, of flax, etc.
An aqueous solution of gum, or of substances allied to it; a glue; a liquid adhesive; as, medicinal mucilage; mucilage for fastening envelopes.
Partaking of the nature of, or resembling, mucilage; moist, soft, and viscid; slimy; ropy; as, a mucilaginous liquid.
Of, pertaining to, or secreting, mucilage; as, the mucilaginous glands.
Soluble in water, but not in alcohol; yielding mucilage; as, mucilaginous gums or plants.
See Mucedin.

Any of a class of high molecular weight glycoproteins which are contained in mucus, and give to the latter secretion its peculiar ropy character. They are found in all the secretions from mucous glands, and also between the fibers of connective tissue, as in tendons. They form viscous solutions and serve to provide lubrication for movement within body cavities, and some protection of surfaces. See Illust. of Demilune.

entry.def: Same as Mucigen.
Secreting, or producing, mucus or mucin.

entry.ety: L. mucus slime, mucus + vorare to devour
entry.def: An insect which feeds on mucus, or the sap of plants, as certain Diptera, of the tribe Mucivora.

entry.cs: To run a muck. See Amuck.
entry.def: Abbreviation of Amuck.

cs.cd: bar iron which has been through the rolls only once.
crude puddled iron ready for the squeezer or rollers.
see muck pile in the vocabulary.

entry.ety: Icel. myki; akin to D. mög. Cf. Midden

sn.def: Dung in a moist state; manure.
Vegetable mold mixed with earth, as found in low, damp places and swamps.
Anything filthy or vile.
Money; -- in contempt.
sn.q: The fatal muck we quarreled for.

sn.def: The unwanted material, especially rock or soil, that must be excavated in order to reach the valuable ore; also, the unwanted material after being excavated or crushed by blasting, or after being removed to a waste pile. In the latter sense, also called a muck pile.

entry.def: Like muck; mucky; also, used in collecting or distributing muck; as, a muck fork.
To manure with muck.
To excavate and remove muck{5}. Often used with out as, to muck out a round.
entry.q: . . . Inco is still much more advanced than other mining companies. He says that the LKAB mine in Sweden is the closest rival. He predicts that, by 2008, Inco can reach a new productivity plateau, doubling the current mining productivity from 3,350 tonnes to 6,350 tonnes per person per year. Another aim is to triple the mine cycle rate (the time to drill, blast and muck a round) from one cycle to three complete cycles per 24 hours.

entry.def: A handkerchief.
A term of reproach for a low or vulgar labor person.
An excavating machine designed to remove particulate material from within a confined area, as in a tunnel or mine.
To scrape together, as money, by mean labor or shifts.
A miser; a niggard.
The quality of being mucky.
Much.
A dunghill.

sn.def: The broken material at the face of a tunnel being bored, after being crushed by blasting.
Muck{5} that has been placed in a spoil area.

entries.entry: Muck" rake`. A rake for scraping up muck or dung. See Muckrake v. i., below. obs

entry.note: On April 14, 1906, President Roosevelt delivered a speech on “The Man with the Muck Rake,” in which he deprecated sweeping and unjust charges of corruption against public men and corporations. The phrase was taken up by the press, and the verb to muckrake, in the above sense, and the noun muckraker, to designate one so engaged, were speedily coined and obtained wide currency. The original allusion was to a character in Bunyan's “Pilgrim's Progress” so intent on raking up muck that he could not see a celestial crown held above him.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. -raked; p. pr. & vb. n. -raking
entry.def: To seek for, expose, or charge, especially habitually, corruption, real or alleged, on the part of public men and corporations.
A person who habitually muckrakes.
Somewhat mucky; soft, sticky, and dirty; muxy.

sn.def: A larva or grub that lives in muck or manure; -- applied to the larvæ of the tumbledung and allied beetles.
One who scrapes together money by mean labor and devices; a miser.
sn.q: Misers aremuckworms.

sn.def: Filthy with muck; miry; as, a mucky road.
sn.q: Muckyfilth.

sn.def: Vile, in a moral sense; sordid.
sn.q: Mucky money and false felicity.

entry.def: An enlargement or protrusion of the mucous membrane of the lachrymal passages, or dropsy of the lachrymal sac, dependent upon catarrhal inflammation of the latter.

cs.cd: a form of degeneration in which the tissues are transformed into a semisolid substance resembling mucus.

entry.def: Resembling mucus.
One of a class of mucinlike substances yielding on decomposition a reducing carbohydrate together with some form of proteinaceous matter.
A salt of muconic acid.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (C6H6O4 2-4-hexadienedoic acid), obtained indirectly from mucic acid, and somewhat resembling itaconic acid. Various other means of synthesis have been reported.
Having the character or appearance of both mucus and pus.

entry.ety: L., fr. mucere to be moldy or musty
entry.def: A genus of minute fungi. The plants consist of slender threads with terminal globular sporangia; mold.
An order of mostly saprophytic fungi.
The mucus-secreting membrane lining all body cavities or passages that communicate with the exterior; called also mucous membrane.
The quality or state of being mucous or slimy; mucousness.

entry.cs: Mucous membrane. Anat See under Membrane. Mucous patches Med elevated patches found in the mucous membranes of the mouth and anus, usually due to syphilis. Mucous tissue Anat a form of connective tissue in an early stage of development, found in the umbilical cord and in the embryo, and also in certain tumors called myxomata.

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, mucus; slimy, ropy, or stringy, and lubricous; as, a mucous substance.
Secreting a slimy or mucigenous substance; as, the mucous membrane.

entry.def: The quality or state of being mucous; sliminess.
A minute abrupt point, as of a leaf; any small, sharp point or process, terminating a larger part or organ.

entry.ety: L. mucronatus, fr. mucro a sharp point: cf. F. mucroné
entry.def: Ending abruptly in a sharp point; abruptly tipped with a short and sharp point; as, a mucronate leaf.
Having, or tipped with, a small point or points.
Slimy; moist, and moderately viscous.

entry.ety: L. mucus muccus; cf. mucere to be moldy or musty, Gr. my`xa mucus, and Skr. muc to release. Cf. Match for striking fire, Moist Mucilage

sn.def: A viscid fluid secreted by mucous membranes, which it serves to moisten and protect. It covers the lining membranes of all the cavities which open externally, such as those of the mouth, nose, lungs, intestinal canal, urinary passages, etc.
Any other animal fluid of a viscid quality, as the synovial fluid, which lubricates the cavities of the joints; -- improperly so used.
A gelatinous or slimy substance found in certain algæ and other plants.

entry.def: Mucin.

entry.cs:
Mud bass Zoöl a fresh-water fish (Acantharchum pomotis or Acantharchus pomotis) of the Eastern United States. It produces a deep grunting note. Mud bath an immersion of the body, or some part of it, in mud charged with medicinal agents, as a remedy for disease. Mud boat a large flatboat used in dredging. Mud cat. See mud cat in the vocabulary. Mud crab Zoöl any one of several American marine crabs of the genus Panopeus. Mud dab Zoöl the winter flounder. See Flounder, and Dab. Mud dauber Zoöl a mud wasp; the mud-dauber. Mud devil Zoöl the fellbender. Mud drum Steam Boilers a drum beneath a boiler, into which sediment and mud in the water can settle for removal. Mud eel Zoöl a long, slender, aquatic amphibian (Siren lacertina), found in the Southern United States. It has persistent external gills and only the anterior pair of legs. See Siren. Mud frog Zoöl a European frog (Pelobates fuscus). Mud hen. Zoöl The American coot (Fulica Americana . The clapper rail. Mud lark a person who cleans sewers, or delves in mud. Slang Mud minnow Zoöl any small American fresh-water fish of the genus Umbra, as Umbra limi. The genus is allied to the pickerels. Mud plug a plug for stopping the mudhole of a boiler. Mud puppy Zoöl the menobranchus. Mud scow a heavy scow, used in dredging; a mud boat. U.S
Mud turtle Mud tortoise
Zoöl any one of numerous species of fresh-water tortoises of the United States. Mud wasp Zoöl any one of numerous species of hymenopterous insects belonging to Pepæus, and allied genera, which construct groups of mud cells, attached, side by side, to stones or to the woodwork of buildings, etc. The female places an egg in each cell, together with spiders or other insects, paralyzed by a sting, to serve as food for the larva. Called also mud dauber.
entry.ety: Akin to LG. mudde, D. modder, G. moder mold, OSw. modd mud, Sw. modder mother, Dan. mudder mud. Cf. Mother a scum on liquors
entry.def: Earth and water mixed so as to be soft and adhesive.

sn.def: To bury in mud.
To make muddy or turbid.

entry.def: Either one of two asclepiadaceous shrubs (Calotropis gigantea, and Calotropis procera), which furnish a strong and valuable fiber. The acrid milky juice is used medicinally.
A brown, amorphous, bitter substance having a strong emetic action, extracted from the root of the mudar.
A large catfish (Pylodictus olivaris, formerly Leptops olivaris) of the central U. S. having a flattened head and projecting jaw.
entry.syn: flathead catfish, goujon, shovelnose catfish, spoonbill catfish, Pylodictus olivaris.

entry.def: A wasp of the family Sphegidae Sphecidae) which builds a nest of mud and stores insects and spiders in it; a digger-wasp.
A crab of the genus Panopœusalso written Panopeus).
In a muddy manner; turbidly; without mixture; cloudily; obscurely; confusedly.

sn.def: a racehorse that exhibits a better than usual performance when the racetrack is wet or muddy.
An athlete who performs better than his/her average under muddy conditions.
The condition or quality of being muddy; turbidness; foulness caused by mud, dirt, or sediment; as, the muddiness of a stream.
Obscurity or confusion, as in treatment of a subject; intellectual dullness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Muddled; p. pr. & vb. n. Muddling

sn.def: To make turbid, or muddy, as water.
sn.q: He did ill to muddle the water.

sn.def: To cloud or stupefy; to render stupid with liquor; to intoxicate partially.
sn.q: Epicurus seems to have had brains so muddled and confounded, that he scarce ever kept in the right way.
Often drunk, always muddled.

sn.def: To waste or misuse, as one does who is stupid or intoxicated.
sn.q: They muddle it [money] away without method or object, and without having anything to show for it.

sn.def: To mix confusedly; to confuse; to make a mess of; as, to muddle matters; also, to perplex; to mystify.
To dabble in mud.
To think and act in a confused, aimless way.

entry.def: A state of being turbid or confused; hence, intellectual cloudiness or dullness.
entry.q: We both grub on in a muddle.

entry.def: A stupid person; a blunderer.
One who, or that which, muddles.

sn.def: Abounding in mud; besmeared or dashed with mud; as, a muddy road or path; muddy boots.
Turbid with mud; as, muddy water.
Consisting of mud or earth; gross; impure.
sn.q: This muddy vesture of decay.

sn.def: Confused, as if turbid with mud; cloudy in mind; dull; stupid; also, immethodical; incoherent; vague.
sn.q: Cold hearts and muddy understandings.
Dost think I am so muddy, so unsettled.

sn.def: Not clear or bright.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Muddied; p. pr. & vb. n. Muddying

sn.def: To soil with mud; to dirty; to render turbid.

entry.sn: Fig: To cloud; to make dull or heavy; to confuse.

entry.def: Dull; stupid.
Dull-spirited.
The European loach.
The bowfin (Amia calva).
The South American lipedosiren, and the allied African species (Protopterus annectens). See Lipedosiren.
The mud minnow, a fish of the genus Umbra or family Umbridae.
entry.cd: any fish which lives in muddy waters, such as the mummichog, a killifish.

sn.def: A hole, or hollow place, containing mud, as in a road.
A hole near the bottom, through which the sediment is withdrawn.

entry.def: Same as Moodir.

sn.def: The lowest sill of a structure, usually embedded in the soil; the lowest timber of a house; also, that sill or timber of a bridge which is laid at the bottom of the water. See Sill.
Fig.: A person of the lowest stratum of society; -- a term of opprobrium or contempt.

entry.def: A woodcock.
The European bee-eater. See Bee-eater.
A small herbaceous plant growing on muddy shores (Limosella aquatica).
To mew; to molt.
A mixture of untoasted dry cereals, nuts, and fruits, eaten mostly as a breakfast cereal; -- of Swiss origin.
A Mohammedan crier of the hour of prayer; the Moslem official of a mosque who summons the faithful to prayer from a minaret five times a day.

entry.ety: Cf. LG. muff, D. mof, G., Dan., & Sw. muff, F. moufle mitten, LL. muffula, MHG. mouwe sleeve, D. mouw, and E. muffle, v

sn.def: A soft cover of cylindrical form, usually of fur, worn by women to shield the hands from cold.
A short hollow cylinder surrounding an object, as a pipe.
A blown cylinder of glass which is afterward flattened out to make a sheet.

sn.ety: Perhaps a different word; cf. Prov. E. maffle to slammer
sn.def: A stupid fellow; a poor-spirited person.
sn.q: Amuffof a curate.

sn.def: A failure to hold a ball when once in the hands.
The whitethroat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Muffed; p. pr. & vb. n. Muffing
entry.def: To handle awkwardly; to fumble; to fail to hold, as a ball, in catching it.
A small muff worn over the wrist.
A light, spongy, cylindrical cake, used for breakfast and tea.
A dish for keeping muffins hot.
Stupid; awkward.
The bare end of the nose between the nostrils; -- used esp. of ruminants.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Muffled; p. pr. & vb. n. Muffling
entry.ety: Cf. F. moufle a mitten, LL. muffula, OD. moffel a muff. See Muff

sn.def: To wrap up in something that conceals or protects; to wrap, as the face and neck, in thick and disguising folds; hence, to conceal or cover the face of; to envelop; to inclose; -- often with up.
sn.q: The face lies muffled up within the garment.
He muffled with a cloud his mournful eyes.
Muffled up in darkness and superstition.

sn.def: To prevent seeing, or hearing, or speaking, by wraps bound about the head; to blindfold; to deafen.
To wrap or fit with something that dulls or deadens the sound of; as, to muffle the strings of a drum, or that part of an oar which rests in the rowlock; to muffle the exhaust of a motor vehicle.

entry.ety: Cf. F. maffle mumble, D. moffelen
entry.def: To speak indistinctly, or without clear articulation.

entry.ety: F. moufle, prop., a mitten, from the resemblance in shape. See Muffle v. t. Muff

sn.def: Anything with which another thing, as an oar or drum, is muffled; also, a boxing glove; a muff.

An earthenware compartment or oven, often shaped like a half cylinder, used in furnaces to protect objects heated from the direct action of the fire, as in scorification of ores, cupellation of ore buttons, etc.
A small oven for baking and fixing the colors of painted or printed pottery, without exposing the pottery to the flames of the furnace or kiln.
A pulley block containing several sheaves.
same as muted; as, muffled drums; the muffled noises of the street.
Wrapped up especially for protection or secrecy; as, children muffled almost to the eyebrows.
Anything used in muffling; esp., a scarf for protecting the head and neck in cold weather; a tippet.
sn.q: Fortune is painted blind, with a muffler above her eyes.

sn.def: A cushion for terminating or softening a note made by a stringed instrument with a keyboard.
A kind of mitten or boxing glove, esp. when stuffed.
One who muffles.

Any of various devices to deaden the noise of escaping gases or vapors, as a tube filled with obstructions, through which the exhaust gases of an internal-combustion engine, as on an automobile, are passed (called also silencer).

entry.def: See Mouflon.

entries.entry:
Muf"ti n.; pl.Muftis #. Ar. mufti
An official expounder of Mohammedan law.
One of the chief legal advisers to the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire.

entry.def: Ordinary civilian dress when worn by persons who serve in a uniformed service, such as the military or police. It originally was used in reference to British naval or military officers, and originated with the British service in India.

entry.ety: Cf. Ir. mugam a mug, mucog a cup

sn.def: A kind of ceramic or metal drinking cup, with a handle, -- usually cylindrical and without a lip.
The face or mouth; as, I don't want to see your ugly mug again; -- often used contemptuously.

entry.note: To rob a person or a business indoors is not usually referred to as to mug, but to stick up or hold up.
entry.def: To take property from (a person) in a public place by threatening or committing violence on the person who is robbed; to rob, especially to rob by use of a weapon such as a knife or gun.
the quantity that can be held in a mug.

entry.ety: Cf. G. mucker a sulky person, muckish sullen, peevish, mucken to mutter, grumble
entry.def: Sullen; displeased.

entries.entry: Mug"ger n. Also Mug"gar Mug"gur . Hind. magar, fr. Skr. makara sea monster The common crocodile (Crocodilus palustris) of India, the East Indies, etc. It becomes twelve feet or more long.

entry.def: A thief who takes property by threatening (or performing) violence on the person who is robbed; a person who commits a mugging; one who mugs. See mug v. t.
The small entrails of a calf or a hog.
The condition or quality of being muggy.

entry.ety: p. pr. & vb. n. from mug v.
entry.def: A robbery; a taking of property by threatening (or performing) violence on the person who is robbed. See mug v.

sn.def: A game of dominoes in which the object is to make the sum of the two ends of the line some multiple of five.
A game at cards which depends upon building in suits or matching exposed cards, the object being to get rid of one's cards.

entry.def: In certain games, to score against, or take an advantage over (an opponent), as for an error, announcing the act by saying “muggins.”
See Muggy.
One of an extinct sect, named after Ludovic Muggleton , an English journeyman tailor, who (about 1657) claimed to be inspired.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. mugga mist, mugginess. Cf. 4th Mold

sn.def: Moist; damp; moldy; as, muggy straw.
Warm, damp, and windless; uncomfortably hot and humid; sultry; as, muggy air, weather.

entry.def: An alehouse; a pothouse.
A bellowing.

entry.ety: L. mugiens, p. pr. of mugire to bellow
entry.def: Lowing; bellowing.
A genus of fishes including the gray mullets. See Mullet.
A natural family of fish including the gray mullets.
A suborder of fishes distinguished by abdominal pelvic fins, including the families Mugilidae; Atherinidae; and Sphyraenidae.
Like or pertaining to the genus Mugil, or family Mugilidæ.
A slender European weed (Galium Cruciata); -- called also crossweed.
A somewhat aromatic composite weed (Artemisia vulgaris), at one time used medicinally; -- called also motherwort.

sn.def: A bolter from the Republican party in the national election of 1884; an Independent.
A person who is undecided about an issue, especially a political one; a person who takes a neutral stance on an issue; a fence-sitter.

entry.def: The acts and views of the mugwumps.
Mohammedan.
Mohammedanism.
the first month of the Islamic calendar.
A southern African weasel.
A Russian peasant (especially prior to 1917).
A moor.

entry.ety: Sp. Amer., fr. Sp. mulo mula, a mule
entry.def: A drove of mules.

entries.entry:
Mu*lat"to n.; pl.Mulattoes #. Sp. & Pg. mulato, masc., mulata, fem., of a mixed breed, fr. mulo mule, L. mulus. See Mule
The offspring of a negress by a white man, or of a white woman by a negro, -- usually of a brownish yellow complexion.

entry.def: A female mulatto.

entries.entry:
Mul"ber*ry
Mulberry mass. Biol See Morula. Paper mulberry a tree (Broussonetia papyrifera), related to the true mulberry, used in Polynesia for making tapa cloth by macerating and pounding the inner bark, and in China and Japan for the manufacture of paper. It is seen as a shade tree in America.
n.; pl.Mulberries #. OE. moolbery murberie, AS. murberie, where the first part is fr. L. morum mulberry; cf. Gr. �, �. Cf. Murrey Sycamore
Bot The berry or fruit of any tree of the genus Morus; also, the tree itself. See Morus.
A dark pure color, like the hue of a black mulberry.

entry.def: Having a face of a mulberry color, or blotched as if with mulberry stains.

entry.ety: Cf. mull dirt, also Prov. G. mulsch molsch, rotten, soft, mellow, as fruit
entry.def: Half-rotten straw, or any similar light, porous, organic substance strewn on the ground, as over the roots of plants, to protect from heat, drought, etc., and to hinder weed growth and preserve moisture.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mulched; p. pr. & vb. n. Mulching
entry.def: To cover or dress with mulch.

sn.def: A fine or penalty, esp. a pecuniary punishment or penalty.
A blemish or defect.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mulcted; p. pr. & vb. n. Mulcting

sn.def: To punish for an offense or misdemeanor by imposing a fine or forfeiture, esp. a pecuniary fine; to fine.
Hence, to deprive of; to withhold by way of punishment or discipline.

entry.def: Imposing a pecuniary penalty; consisting of, or paid as, a fine.
entry.q: Fines, or some known mulctuary punishments.

entry.note: ☞ Mules are much used as draught animals. They are hardy, and proverbial for stubbornness.

cs.cd: a long-eared armadillo Tatusia hybrida, native of Buenos Ayres; -- called also mulita. See Illust. under Armadillo.
a large deer (Cervus macrotis syn. Cariacus macrotis) of the Western United States. The name refers to its long ears.
an idle pulley for guiding a belt which transmits motion between shafts that are not parallel.
cotton yarn in cops, as spun on a mule; -- in distinction from yarn spun on a throstle frame.

entry.ety: F., a she-mule, L. mula, fem. of mulus; cf. Gr. my`klos mychlo`s. Cf. AS. mūl, fr. L. mulus. Cf. Mulatto

sn.def: A hybrid animal; specifically, one generated between an ass and a mare. Sometimes the term is applied to the offspring of a horse and a she-ass, but that hybrid is more properly termed a hinny. See Hinny.
A plant or vegetable produced by impregnating the pistil of one species with the pollen or fecundating dust of another; -- called also hybrid.
A very stubborn person.
A machine, used in factories, for spinning cotton, wool, etc., into yarn or thread and winding it into cops; -- called also jenny and mule-jenny.
A slipper that has no fitting around the heel.

entry.def: See Mule, 4.

entries.entry: Mule killer. Any of several arthropods erroneously supposed to kill live stock, in the southern United States, by stinging or by being swallowed; as: A whip scorpion. Florida A walking-stick insect. Texas A mantis. A wheel bug.

entry.ety: F. muletier, fr. mulet a mule, dim. fr. L. mulus
entry.def: One who drives mules.
A fern of the genus Hemionitis.

cs.cd: a car axle without collars at the outer ends of the journals.

entry.def: A stiff, long saw, guided at the ends but not stretched in a gate.
See Mulley.

entry.ety: L. muliebritas, fr. muliebris belonging to a woman, fr. mulier a woman

sn.def: The state of being a woman or of possessing full womanly powers; womanhood; -- correlate of virility.
Effeminancy; softness.
A woman.

sd.def: Lawful issue born in wedlock, in distinction from an elder brother born of the same parents before their marriage; a lawful son.
A woman; a wife; a mother.

entry.def: In the manner or condition of a mulier; in wedlock; legitimately.
Fond of woman.
A fondness for women.
Condition of being a mulier; position of one born in lawful wedlock.
Like a mule; sullen; stubborn.

entry.ety: Perh. contr. fr. mossul. See Muslin
entry.def: A thin, soft kind of muslin.

entry.ety: Icel. mūli a snout, muzzle, projecting crag; or cf. Ir. & Gael. meall a heap of earth, a mound, a hill or eminence, W. moel. Cf. Mouth

sn.def: A promontory; as, the Mull of Cantyre.
A snuffbox made of the small end of a horn.

entry.ety: Prob. akin to mold. √108. See Mold
entry.def: Dirt; rubbish.
To powder; to pulverize.
To work (over) mentally; to cogitate; to ruminate; -- usually with over; as, to mull over a thought or a problem.
An inferior kind of madder prepared from the smaller roots or the peelings and refuse of the larger.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mulled mŭld; p. pr. & vb. n. Mulling
entry.ety: From mulled, for mold, taken as a p. p.; OE. mold-ale funeral ale or banquet. See Mold soil

sn.def: To heat, sweeten, and enrich with spices; as, to mull wine.
sn.q: New cider, mulled with ginger warm.

sn.def: To dispirit or deaden; to dull or blunt.

entry.def: Same as Mollah.
An East Indian curry soup.
See Mollah.
A die, cut in intaglio, for stamping an ornament in relief, as upon metal.

entry.cs: Moth mullein. See under Moth. Mullein foxglove an American herb (Seymeria macrophylla) with coarse leaves and yellow tubular flowers with a spreading border. Petty mullein the cowslip. Dr. Prior.
entry.def: Any plant of the genus Verbascum. They are tall herbs having coarse leaves, and large flowers in dense spikes. The common species, with densely woolly leaves, is Verbascum Thapsus.
See Mullein.

sn.def: One who, or that which, mulls.
A vessel in which wine, etc., is mulled over a fire.

entry.ety: OE. mullen to pulverize, bruise; cf. Icel. mylja; prob. akin to E. mold soil. See Mold soil, and cf. Mull dirt
entry.def: A stone or thick lump of glass, or kind of pestle, flat at the bottom, used for grinding pigments or drugs, etc., upon a slab of similar material.

cs.cd: a pair of embryonic ducts which give rise to the genital passages in the female, but disappear in the male.
the sustentacular or connective-tissue fibers which form the framework of the retina.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Johannes Müller .

entry.cs: French mullet. See Ladyfish.
entry.ety: OE. molet mulet, F. mulet, fr. L. mullus

sn.def: Any one of numerous fishes of the genus Mugil; -- called also gray mullets. They are found on the coasts of both continents, and are highly esteemed as food. Among the most valuable species are Mugil capito of Europe, and Mugil cephalus which occurs both on the European and American coasts.

Any species of the genus Mullus, or family Mullidæ; called also red mullet, and surmullet, esp. the plain surmullet (Mullus barbatus), and the striped surmullet (Mullus surmulletus) of Southern Europe. The former is the mullet of the Romans. It is noted for the brilliancy of its colors. See Surmullet.

entry.def: A star, usually five pointed and pierced; -- when used as a difference it indicates the third son.

entry.ety: Cf. F. molet a sort of pinchers
entry.def: Small pinchers for curling the hair.

entry.ety: CF. Gael. maolag a hornless cow, maol bald, hornless, blunt

sn.def: A mulley or polled animal.
A cow.
sn.mark: Prov. Eng.; U.S., a child's word
sn.q: Leave milking and dry up old mulley, thy cow.

entry.def: Destitute of horns, although belonging to a species of animals most of which have horns; hornless; polled; as, mulley cattle; a mulleyor moolley) cow.

sn.def: A stew made typically of meat, vegetables, and any conveniently available ingredients; also, an Irish version of burgoo.

In informal and friendly games of golf, a permission to take another stroke without counting the previous stroke against the score, when a stroke was poorly played; a free stroke; as, to take a mulligan .

entry.def: See Mullagatawny.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. E. mull to squeeze, pull about, mulling numb or dull

sn.def: A griping of the intestines; colic.
sn.q: Whose dog lies sick of the mulligrubs?

sn.def: Hence, sullenness; the sulks.

entry.def: See Duck mole, under Duck.

entry.ety: A corruption of munnion, F. moignon stump of an amputated limb, stump, OF. moing mutilated; cf. Armor. moñ mouñ mank monk, and also L. mancus maimed
entry.def: A slender bar or pier which forms the division between the lights of windows, screens, etc.
An upright member of a framing. See Stile.
To furnish with mullions; to divide by mullions.

entry.ety: From Mull dirt: cf. Scot. mulloch mulock, crumb. √108
entry.def: Rubbish; refuse; dirt.
entry.q: All this mullokwas] in a sieve ythrowe.

entry.ety: NL. Mullus, generic name (fr. L. mullus surmullet) + -oid
entry.def: Like or pertaining to the genus Mullus, which includes the surmullet, or red mullet.
To think about; to consider; to ruminate about; as, mull it over and decide in the morning.
A fine, soft muslin; mull.

entry.ety: L. mulsumsc. vinum), fr. mulsus mixed with honey, honey-sweet, p. p. of mulcere to sweeten, soften
entry.def: Wine boiled and mingled with honey.

entries.entry: Mult-. See Multi-.

entry.ety: L. multangulus; multus much, many + angulus angle: cf. F. multangulaire
entry.def: Having many angles.
Many-minded; many-sided.
entry.q: The multanimous nature of the poet.

entry.def: Having many articulations or joints.
Multiplicity.

entries.entry: Mul"ti- Mult- . L. multus much A prefix signifying much or many; several; more than one; as, multiaxial, multocular.

entry.def: Having more than one axis; developing in more than a single line or plain; -- opposed to monoaxial.
Having many, or several, capsules.
Many-keeled.

entry.ety: L. multicavus; multus much, many + cavum cavus, a cavity, hole, fr. cavus hollow
entry.def: Having many cavities.
Consisting of, or having, many cells or more than one cell.

cs.cd: growth, or development, from several centers. According as the insubordination to a single center is more or less pronounced, the resultant organism will be more or less irregular in form and may even become discontinuous.

entry.def: Having many, or several, centers; as, a multicentral cell.
Having many heads or many stems from one crown or root.
Having many, or several, colors.
Having numerous ribs, or costæ, as the leaf of a plant, or as certain shells and corals.
Multicuspidate; -- said of teeth.
Having many cusps or points.
Having many teeth, or toothlike processes.
Having many fingers, or fingerlike processes.
Having many faces.

entry.ety: L. multifarius; multus much, many. Cf. Bifarious

sn.def: Having multiplicity; having great diversity or variety; of various kinds; diversified; made up of many differing parts; manifold.
sn.q: There is a multifarious artifice in the structure of the meanest animal.

sn.def: Having parts, as leaves, arranged in many vertical rows.

entry.def: With great multiplicity and diversity; with variety of modes and relations.

sn.def: Multiplied diversity.
The fault of improperly uniting in one bill distinct and independent matters, and thereby confounding them.

entry.ety: L. multifer; multus much, many + ferre to bear
entry.def: Bearing or producing much or many.

entry.ety: L. multifidus; multus much, many + findere to split: cf. F. multifide
entry.def: Having many segments; cleft into several parts by linear sinuses; as, a multifid leaf or corolla.

entry.ety: L. multiflorus; multus much, many + flos floris, flower: cf. F. multiflore
entry.def: Having many flowers.
Having many flues; as, a multiflue boiler. See Boiler.
An ornamental foliation consisting of more than five divisions or foils.
Having more than five divisions or foils.
Many times doubled; manifold; numerous.

entry.ety: L. multiformis; multus much, many + forma shape: cf. F. multiforme
entry.def: Having many forms, shapes, or appearances.
entry.q: A plastic and multiform unit.

entry.def: The quality of being multiform; diversity of forms; variety of appearances in the same thing.
Multiform.

entry.ety: L. multigenerus; multus + genus generis, kind
entry.def: Having many kinds.
Having, or consisting of, many grains.

A combined rotary type-setting and printing machine for office use. The type is transferred semi-automatically by means of keys from a type-supply drum to a printing drum. The printing may be done by means of an inked ribbon to print “typewritten” letters, or directly from inked type or a stereotype plate, as in a printing press.
Having many pairs of leaflets.

sn.def: Consisting of many parts.
Same as Multijugate.

entry.def: Having many sides; many-sided.
Having many lines.
Consisting of, or having, many lobes.
Having many or several cells or compartments; as, a multilocular shell or capsule.
Quality of being multiloquent; use of many words; talkativeness.

entry.ety: L. multiloquus; multus much, many + loqui to speak
entry.def: Speaking much; very talkative; loquacious.
Excess of words or talk.
Having many knots or nodes.
Same as Multinodate.

entry.ety: Multi- + -nomial, as in binomial. See Binomial
entry.def: Same as Polynomial.

entry.ety: L. multinominis; multus many + nomen nominis name
entry.def: Having many names or terms.
Polynomial.
Containing many nuclei; as, multinuclear cells.
Multinuclear.

entry.ety: Multi- + L. parere to produce: cf. F. multipare
entry.def: Producing many, or more than one, at a birth.

entry.ety: L. multipartitus multus much, many partitus divided, p. p.: cf. F. multipartite. See Partite
entry.def: Divided into many parts; having several parts.

entry.ety: L. multipes multipeda; multus much, many + pes pedis, foot: cf. F. multipède
entry.def: An insect having many feet, as a myriapod.
Having many feet.
Having many phases;
pertaining to, or designating, a generator producing, or any system conveying or utilizing, two or more waves of pressure, or electromotive force, not in phase with each other; polyphase.
Having several or many planes or plane surfaces; as, a multiplane kite.
An aëroplane with three or more superposed main planes.

entry.cs: Law of multiple proportion Chem the generalization that when the same elements unite in more than one proportion, forming two or more different compounds, the higher proportions of the elements in such compounds are simple multiples of the lowest proportion, or the proportions are connected by some simple common factor; thus, iron and oxygen unite in the proportions FeO Fe2O3 Fe3O4, in which compounds, considering the oxygen, 3 and 4 are simple multiplies of 1. Called also the Law of Dalton or Dalton's Law, from its discoverer. Multiple algebra a branch of advanced mathematics that treats of operations upon units compounded of two or more unlike units. Multiple conjugation Biol a coalescence of many cells (as where an indefinite number of amœboid cells flow together into a single mass) from which conjugation proper and even fertilization may have been evolved. Multiple fruits. Bot See Collective fruit, under Collective. Multiple star Astron several stars in close proximity, which appear to form a single system.
entry.ety: Cf. F. multiple, and E. quadruple, and multiply
entry.def: Containing more than once, or more than one; consisting of more than one; manifold; repeated many times; having several, or many, parts.

entry.note: ☞ A common multiple of two or more numbers contains each of them a number of times exactly; thus, 24 is a common multiple of 3 and 4. The least common multiple is the smallest number that will do this; thus, 12 is the least common multiple of 3 and 4 (abbreviated LCM).
entry.def: A quantity containing another quantity an integral number of times without a remainder.
Manifold; multiple.
Capable of being multiplied.
Capable of being multiplied; multipliable.

entry.ety: L. multiplicandus to be multiplied: cf. F. multiplicande
entry.def: The number which is to be multiplied by another number called the multiplier. See Note under Multiplication.

cs.cd: a flower that is double, or has an unusual number of petals in consequence of the abnormal multiplication of the parts of the floral whorls.

entry.ety: L. multiplicatus, p. p. of multiplicare. See Multiply
entry.def: Consisting of many, or of more than one; multiple; multifold.

entry.note: ☞ The word multiplication is sometimes used in mathematics, particularly in multiple algebra, to denote any distributive operation expressed by one symbol upon any quantity or any thing expressed by another symbol. Corresponding extensions of meaning are given to the words multiply multiplier multiplicand, and product. Thus, since φ(x + y) = φx + φysee under Distributive), where φ(x + y), φx, and φy indicate the results of any distributive operation represented by the symbol φ upon x + yx, and y, severally, then because of many very useful analogies φ(x + y) is called the product of φ and x + y, and the operation indicated by φ is called multiplication. Cf. Facient n., 2.

cs.cd: a table giving the product of a set of numbers multiplied in some regular way; commonly, a table giving the products of the first ten or twelve numbers multiplied successively by 1, 2, 3, etc., up to 10 or 12. Called also a times table, used by students in elementary school prior to memorization of the table.

entry.ety: L. multiplicatio: cf. F. multiplication. See Multiply

sn.def: The act or process of multiplying, or of increasing in number; the state of being multiplied; as, the multiplication of the human species by natural generation.
sn.q: The increase and multiplication of the world.

sn.def: The process of repeating, or adding to itself, any given number or quantity a certain number of times; commonly, the process of ascertaining by a briefer computation the result of such repeated additions; also, the rule by which the operation is performed; -- the reverse of division.
An increase above the normal number of parts, especially of petals; augmentation.
The art of increasing gold or silver by magic, -- attributed formerly to the alchemists.

entry.def: Tending to multiply; having the power to multiply, or incease numbers.
So as to multiply.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. multiplicateur. Cf. Multiplier
entry.def: The number by which another number is multiplied; a multiplier.
Manifold.
The quality of being multiple, manifold, or various; a state of being many; a multitude; as, a multiplicity of thoughts or objects.
entry.q: Amultiplicityof goods.

sn.def: One who, or that which, multiplies or increases number.
The number by which another number (the multiplicand) is multiplied. See the Note under Multiplication.

An instrument for multiplying or increasing by repetition or accumulation the intensity of a force or action, as heat or electricity. It is particularly used to render such a force or action appreciable or measurable when feeble. See Thermomultiplier.

entry.cs: Multiplying gear Mach gear for increasing speed. Multiplying lens. Opt See under Lens.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Multiplied; p. pr. & vb. n. Multiplying
entry.ety: F. multiplier, L. multiplicare, fr. multiplex manifold. See Multitude Complex

sn.def: To increase in number; to make more numerous; to add quantity to.
sn.q: Impunity will multiply motives to disobedience.

sn.def: To add (any given number or quantity) to itself a certain number of times; to find the product of by multiplication; thus 7 multiplied by 8 produces the number 56; to multiply two numbers. See the Note under Multiplication.
To increase (the amount of gold or silver) by the arts of alchemy.
To become greater in number; to become numerous.
sn.q: When men began to multiply on the face of the earth, and daughters were born unto them.

sn.def: To increase in extent and influence; to spread.
sn.q: The word of God grew and multiplied.

sn.def: To increase amount of gold or silver by the arts of alchemy.
Having many poles; in Anat., designating specif. a nerve cell which has several dendrites.
Having, or pertaining to, many poles, as a field magnet or armature of a dynamo, or a dynamo having such a field magnet or (sometimes) armature.

entry.ety: L. multipotens; multus much + potens powerful. See Potent
entry.def: Having manifold power, or power to do many things.
entry.q: Jovemultipotent.

entry.def: The state or power of being multipresent.
entry.q: The multipresence of Christ's body.

entry.def: Being, or having the power to be, present in two or more places at once.
Having many rays.
Divided into many branches.
Having many branches.

entry.ety: L. multiscius; multus much + scius knowing, fr. scire to know
entry.def: Having much or varied knowledge.

entry.ety: Multi- + L. sectus, p. p. of secare to cut
entry.def: Divided into many similar segments; -- said of an insect or myriapod.
Divided into many chambers by partitions, as the pith of the pokeweed.
Arranged in many rows, or series, as the scales of a pine cone, or the leaves of the houseleek.
Having many pods or seed vessels.

entry.ety: L. multisonus; multus much, many + sonus sound
entry.def: Having many sounds, or sounding much.
Having numerous spiral coils round a center or nucleus; -- said of the opercula of certain shells.
Having many streaks.
Having many furrows.
A word of many syllables; a polysyllable.
Having many titles.
Having many tubes; as, a multitubular boiler.

cs.cd: the populace; the mass of men.

entry.ety: F. multitude, L. multitudo multitudinis, fr. multus much, many; of unknown origin

sn.def: A great number of persons collected together; a numerous collection of persons; a crowd; an assembly.
sn.q: But when he saw the multitudes, he was moved with compassion on them.

sn.def: A great number of persons or things, regarded collectively; as, the book will be read by a multitude of people; the multitude of stars; a multitude of cares.
sn.q: It is a fault in a multitude of preachers, that they utterly neglect method in their harangues.
A multitude of flowers As countless as the stars on high.

sn.def: The state of being many; numerousness.
sn.q: They came as grasshoppers for multitude.
sn.syn: Throng; crowd; assembly; assemblage; commonalty; swarm; populace; vulgar. See Throng.

entry.def: Multitudinous.

sn.def: Consisting of a multitude; manifold in number or condition; as, multitudinous waves.
sn.q: Themultitudinousseas.
A renewed jingling of multitudinous chains.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a multitude.
sn.q: Themultitudinoustongue.

entry.ety: L. multivagus; multus much + vagus wandering; cf. vagans, p. pr. of vagari. See Vagary
entry.def: Wandering much.
Quality, state, or degree, of a multivalent element, atom, or radical.

entry.ety: Multi- + L. valens, p. pr. See Valence

sd.def: Having a valence greater than one, as silicon.
Having more than one degree of valence, as sulphur.

sn.def: Having multiple antigen-binding sites; -- of antibody molecules.
Containing several types of antibody, to protect against more than one disease; polyvalent; -- of vaccines.

entry.def: Any mollusk which has a shell composed of more than two pieces.

entry.ety: Multi- + valve valvular: cf. F. multivalve

sn.def: Having many valves.
Many-valved; having more than two valves; -- said of certain shells, as the chitons.

entry.ety: Multi- + L. versans, p. pr. See Versant
entry.def: Turning into many shapes; assuming many forms; protean.

entry.ety: L. multivius; multus many + via way
entry.def: Having many ways or roads; by many ways.
Signifying many different things; of manifold meaning; equivocal.
entry.q: An ambiguousmultivocalword.

entry.def: Having many eyes, or more than two.

cs.cd: a preparation made from Cocculus Indicus, etc., used to impart an intoxicating quality to beer.

entry.def: An extract of quassia licorice, fraudulently used by brewers in order to economize malt and hops.
Having many hoofs.

entry.ety: OF. multure moulture, F. mouture, fr. L. molitura a grinding, molere to grind. See Mill the machine

sn.def: The toll for grinding grain.
A grist or grinding; the grain ground.

cs.cd: keep this a secret; don't tell anybody.

entry.def: Silent; not speaking; as, to keep mum .
entry.q: The citizens are mum, and speak not a word.

entry.def: Be silent! Hush!
entry.q: Mum, then, and no more.

entry.def: Silence.

entry.ety: G. mummere, fr. Christian Mumme, who first brewed it in 1492
entry.def: A sort of strong beer, originally made in Brunswick, Germany.
entry.q: The clamorous crowd is hushed with mugs of mum.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mumbled; p. pr. & vb. n. Mumbling
entry.ety: OE. momelen; cf. D. mompelen mommelen, G. mummelen, Sw. mumla, Dan. mumle. Cf. Mum a. Mumm Mump v.

sn.def: To speak with the lips partly closed, so as to render the sounds inarticulate and imperfect; to utter words in a grumbling indistinct manner, indicating discontent or displeasure; to mutter.
sn.q: Peace, you mumbling fool.
A wrinkled hag, with age grown double, Picking dry sticks, and mumbling to herself.

sn.def: To chew something gently with closed lips.
To utter with a low, inarticulate voice.
To chew or bite gently, as one without teeth.
sn.q: Gums unarmed, to mumble meat in vain.

sn.def: To suppress, or utter imperfectly.

entry.def: A game played with a pocketknife, the object of which is to throw the knife in any of a vairety of ways (such as over the back), or from various positions, and have it stick in the ground or another surface. Also called mumble-the-peg and mumble peg.
A talebearer.
One who mumbles.
Low; indistinct; inarticulate.

entry.ety: Perh. fr. the native name of an African god

sn.def: Among the Mandingos of the western Sudan, a bugbear by means of which the women are terrified and disciplined by societies of the men, one of whom assumes a masquerade for the purpose; hence, loosely, any Negro idol, fetish, or bugaboo.
sn.q: The miserable Mumbo Jumbo they paraded.

sn.def: An object of superstitious homage and fear.
Incomprehensible or senseless language, usually intended to avoid answering plainly, confuse a listener, or obscure an issue.
Language so arcane or obscure as to be unintelligible to the listener.
A game of hazard played with cards in silence.
A silent, stupid person.

entry.def: Silent and idle.
entry.q: Boys can't sit mum-chance always.

entry.def: an elementary particle with a negative charge and a half-life of 2 microseconds; the muon. It is a lepton, not a true meson, and decays to an electron and neutrino and antineutrino.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mummed; p. pr. & vb. n. Mumming
entry.ety: D. mimmen to mask, mom a mask; akin to G. mumme disguise; prob. of imitative origin, and akin to E. mum mumble, in allusion to the indistinctness of speech occasioned by talking from behind a mask. Cf. Mumble Mummery
entry.def: To sport or make diversion in a mask or disguise; to mask.
entry.q: With mumming and with masking all around.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. mommeur. See Mumm, and cf. Momier
entry.def: One who mumms, or makes diversion in disguise; a masker; a buffon.
entry.q: Jugglers and dancers, antics, mummers.

entries.entry:
Mum"mer*y n.; pl.Mummeries #. F. momerie, of Dutch or German origin. See Mumm
Masking; frolic in disguise; buffoonery. The mummery of foreign strollers.
Farcical show; hypocritical disguise and parade or ceremonies.

entry.def: Any one of several species of small American cyprinodont fishes of the genus Fundulus, and of allied genera; the killifishes; -- called also minnow.
The act of making a mummy.
Converted into a mummy or a mummylike substance; having the appearance of a mummy; withered.
Having some resemblance to a mummy; -- in zoölogy, said of the pupæ of certain insects.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mummified; p. pr. & vb. n. Mummifying
entry.def: To embalm and dry as a mummy; to make into, or like, a mummy.
To turn into a mummy-like corpse; to dry up with unusually little decomposition; -- said of dead animals; as, A mummified body was found in the attic.

entries.entry:
Mum"my
Mummy brown a brown color, nearly intermediate in tint between burnt umber and raw umber. A pigment of this color is prepared from bitumen, etc., obtained from Egyptian tombs. Mummy wheat Bot wheat found in the ancient mummy cases of Egypt. No botanist now believes that genuine mummy wheat has been made to germinate in modern times. To beat to a mummy to beat to a senseless mass; to beat soundly.
mŭm"m� n.; pl.Mummies mŭm"mĭz. F. momie; cf. Sp. & Pg. momia, It. mummia; all fr. Per. mūmiyā, fr. mūm wax
A dead body embalmed and dried after the manner of the ancient Egyptians; also, a body preserved, by any means, in a dry state, from the process of putrefaction.
Dried flesh of a mummy. Obs
A gummy liquor that exudes from embalmed flesh when heated; -- formerly supposed to have magical and medicinal properties. Obs
A brown color obtained from bitumen. See Mummy brownbelow).
Gardening A sort of wax used in grafting, etc.
One whose affections and energies are withered.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mummied; p. pr. & vb. n. Mummying
entry.def: To embalm; to mummify.
See Mummichog.

entry.ety: Akin to mumble; cf. D. mompen to cheat; perh. orig., to whine like a beggar, D. mompelen to mumble. See Mumble Mum, and cf. Mumps

sn.def: To move the lips with the mouth closed; to mumble, as in sulkiness.
sn.q: He mumps, and lovers, and hangs the lip.

sn.def: To talk imperfectly, brokenly, or feebly; to chatter unintelligibly.
To cheat; to deceive; to play the beggar.
sn.q: And then when mumping with a sore leg, . . . canting and whining.

sn.def: To be sullen or sulky.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Mumped; p. pr. & vb. n. Mumping

sn.def: To utter imperfectly, brokenly, or feebly.
sn.q: Old men who mump their passion.

sn.def: To work over with the mouth; to mumble; as, to mump food.
To deprive of (something) by cheating; to impose upon.

entry.def: A beggar; a begging impostor.
entry.q: Deceived by the tales of a Lincoln's Inn mumper.

entry.def: Sullen, sulky.

entry.ety: Prov. E. mump to be sulky. Cf. Mump Mumble, and Mum

sn.def: Sullenness; silent displeasure; the sulks.

sn.ety: Prob. so called from the patient's appearance
sn.def: A specific infectious febrile disorder characterized by a nonsuppurative inflammation of the parotid glands, and sometimes causing inflammation of the testes or ovaries; also called epidemic parotitis or infectious parotitis. It is caused by infection with a paramyxovirus.

entry.def: The mouth.
entry.q: One a penny, two a penny, hot cross buns, Butter them and sugar them and put them in your muns.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Munched; p. pr. & vb. n. Munching
entry.ety: Prob. akin to mumble: cf. also F. manger to eat (cf. Mange), and mâcher to cher (cf. Masticate). See Mumble
entry.def: To chew with a grinding, crunching sound, as a beast chews provender; to chew deliberately or in large mouthfuls.
entry.q: I could munch your good dry oats.

entry.ety: So called in allusion to Baron Munchausen's extravagant tales of travel
entry.def: An extravagant fiction embodying an account of some marvelous exploit or adventure.
One who munches.
See Mun.

entry.ety: L. mundanus, fr. mundus the world, an implement, toilet adornments, or dress; cf. mundus, a., clean, neat, Skr. maṇḍ to adorn, dress, maṇḍa adornment. Cf. Monde Mound in heraldry

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the world; worldly, as contrasted with heavenly; earthly; terrestrial; as, the mundane sphere; mundane concerns.
sn.q: The defilement of mundane passions.

sn.def: Commonplace; ordinary; banal.

entry.def: Worldliness.

entry.ety: L. mundatio, fr. mundare to make clean
entry.def: The act of cleansing.
Cleansing; having power to cleanse.
Iron pyrites, or arsenical pyrites; -- so called by the Cornish miners.

entry.ety: L. mundificans, p. pr. of mundificare to make clean, fr. mundus clean + -ficarein comp.) to make. See -fy
entry.def: Serving to cleanse and heal.
The act or operation of cleansing.
Cleansing.

entry.ety: Cf. F. mondifier, L. mundificare. See Mundificant
entry.def: To cleanse.
A turban ornamented with an imitation of gold or silver embroidery.

entry.ety: L. mundus the world + vagans wandering, p. pr. of vagari. See Vagary
entry.def: Wandering over the world.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. mondongo paunch, tripe, black pudding
entry.def: A stinking tobacco.

entry.ety: L. munerarius, from munus a gift
entry.def: Having the nature of a gift.

entry.ety: L. muneratus, p. p. of munerare to give, bestow, fr. munus a gift
entry.def: To remunerate.
Remuneration.

Green gram, a kind of legume (pulse) (Vigna radiata syn. Phaseolus aureus, syn. Phaseolus Mungo), grown for food in British India; called also gram mung bean Chinese mung bean, and green-seeded mung bean.
